Anyone thinking about coming to this company within their first 10 years of career experience should think of one thing and one thing only.  "Who am I REALLY going to work for, once I get Anonymous to pay for my FINRA registration?"  If you don't have a 1-2 year exit strategy, enjoy becoming one of Anonymous's many 40-50 year old junior/senior associates who will never even make it to middle management.

Summary: "The worst job you will ever have."
Pro: Great place to work if you like to work while the rest of the world is off.  Working nights untill 11 or 12, weekends and hollidays, (christmas, thanksgiving and new years are the norm).
Con: This is by far the worst employeer in the finacial services industry.  There is little chance of career advancement.. The company culture is one that breeds off of hostility and intimidation.  Being creative and thinking outside of the box is frowned upon.  Most job opportunities consist of lateral moves with little if any increase in pay.

Summary: "Ned Johnson is no longer in control of this company."
Pro: If you want to be a low paid phone drone, Anonymous is the place for you. If you love being treated like dirt and feel that management should rightfully walk all over their employees, Anonymous is the place for you. If you have no ambition other than to make a paycheck and go home frustrated every day, Anonymous is DEFINITELY the place for you. On the other hand, if you are an IT Professional who places value on their contribution to a company and would like to feel that your efforts will be rewarded, Anonymous is a place you should stay far, far away from.
Con: Ned Johnson no longer has anything to do with the day-to-day operations of the company and consequently the goal of the current management is to take the company in the complete opposite direction to that which it was once directed. IT is now considered a low priority and the emphasis on using technology to stay at the forefront of the financial industry is a thing of the past. No new equipment, move as many jobs overseas as possible, reduce the technical staff to a shadow of what it once was, bring in the head choppers, and generally shift the emphasis to the sales force is Roger Lawson's method of running the company (into the ground).

Pro: The best reason to go to work for Anonymous, is frankly that they will hire anyone, from any background, and fully pay for the employee's FINRA licensing.  The testing program is top-notch.  And the campus is very nice, although you will never see it because you will be shackled to your cubicle.  If you are lucky, you may be near a window.
Con: Management at all levels really gets in its own way when it comes to getting anything accomplished.  The sole purpose of your team manager is not so much to encourage, motivate, or lead, as it is to make sure every second of your day is accounted for.  This micromanagement is the main task of your supervisors, who can be very creative at coming up with reasons to charge you with errors, which in turn keeps the bonus and raise levels down.  So basically, when you are given errors for actually helping customers, it comes to a point when the employees just don't care anymore.  Everyone only wants to meet quotas to keep their job.  And this comes at the expense of the clients.  fortunately, I was able to move on to bigger and better things, and have the microscope removed from my rear end.

Pro: There aren't any.  It a career death trap
Con: Status reports, time sheets and meeting about nothing.

Summary: "On the brink of success or failure?"
Pro: There are great people here.  You need to stay away from the bad people and do not let them get you down.  It begins to feel like family and co workers really protect each other in there own group.
Con: Pay can be stingy at times and dumb VPs are left to run aprts of the company when they should be booted. My biggest pet peeve is how other groups abuse the crap out of each other.  Within your own group things are fine, but it is your group against the rest of the company.  There is no team work across the company.  Many of our issues here could be solved by some good old teamwork and dicussion.  The Anonymous Fifedoms are still very evident and those barriers need to be broken down.

Pro: It's all about flexibility and compensation.  Being able to work from home and adjust my schedule is key for me.
Con: Right now, it's unstable.  With lay offs looming and the market being what it is..... it's a scary place to be.

Summary: "Great company to gain experience and build a career."
Pro: Benefits are good and there are pockets of really enlightened management.  Honesty and integrity are highly valued ( you will never get in trouble for doing the right thing). There is still limited opportunity to be entrepreneurial and make a name for yourself, as that is the key to advancement.
Con: Increasing bureaucracy is an issue.

Summary: "Anonymous Investments needs on it's old time values."
Pro: Anonymous Investments has a good reputation and cache. Additionally, Anonymous generally uses recent technology and is not way behind the curve in this regard.
Con: Company is downsizing and it is unclear what their future direction may be. In particular, the beaucracy and level of management precludes individual initiative.

Pro: Overall the benefits and compensation at Anonymous are excellent, and they are the main reason I joined the organization. The 401k matching is unbelievable, and the health insurance is outstanding (although the employee contribution is rising significantly in 2009). There is also a real sense of comradery within departments and my coworkers are some of the smartest and professional people that I have ever worked with. I think Anonymous does a great job at trying to have a good work/life balance, giving employees flexible work options and offering plenty of time off. I think there is also plenty of opportunity to succeed and grow at Anonymous, but you must perceiver throughout times of great change and recognize the potential.
Con: As with any large institution, you tend to get lost with the amount of people and how huge the organizational chart is. I also feel, that at least in my company (FTG, FISC, Infrastructure, whatever it is called this month) there is a disconnect between Management (directors and above) and non management. In my last company I felt like the organization was more of a family, and here I feel like I can not approach management because I am below them, very close door policy. Obviously 2008 was a challenging year, and the financial services industry as a whole has been a challenge, its sometimes hard to see past the turmoil when your job itself is unknown. Finally I think theres a lot of employees who are “lifers”, people who glide by just doing the minimum and not adding real progressive value.

Summary: "Anonymous could become a good place to work again.  How much time will it take?"
Pro:
If you are motivated you can gain alot of valuable experience and know how.  But you have to be motivated on your own.  Anonymous as an organization, despite its claims, will not assist you nor look out for your career.  If you are cognizant enough to see certain situations as opportunities, you can at least gain the experience.



In the past sr. management has funded the important business initiatives.  Still not clear on how this will shake out.   



The technology investment has always been strong.  The implementation has been less that optimal at times.



Until the recent RIF, you could usually count on having the best and brightest people to work with.



In the last few years, high performers seem to be rewarded significantly higher than average performers from a compensation perspective.  For many year has not been the case.
Con:
Across the entire organization, there are alot people who are in the wrong positions.  This applies to IT, general management , Senior management , etc.  Overall,  management ability is poor.  Despite the bevy of management training required, it would seem that some people are just not cut out to be management.  This poor management performance also prevents line management from removing poor performers.  When its clear that a person is mismatch for the position he/she holds, the line manager does not have the skill/ability to make the change.  This goes on for years on end.



In the IT world, the various organizations have conflicting agendas and business plans.  Very poor coordination if any across the various IT and business organizations.  This causes high costs, high risk and significant inefficiencies.



It used to be that the average Anonymous associate was very passionate about his/her job.  Not so sure now.  Its clear that the new management is shoring up cost containment and streamlining and maybe cleaning out the under performers.  That's just good business, if that is in fact what's happening.  I'm afraid that days of working with truly dedicated and passionate people are over.

Summary: "It's a great company going through some painful changes."
Pro: The company is highly profitable; compensation is on the generous side; there is a lot of diversity among the people; there are many opportunities and challenges for growth; the benefits are generous; there are opportunities to be an entrepreneur.
Con: Current and prospective employees should be careful in the short term as the transition is causing a lot of turmoil. You can get purged no matter how good you are. Some of the generous benefits are being trimmed back, such as the pension plan.

Summary: "Don't do it.  Don't even think about it."
Pro: A good opportunity to get professional licenses, job experience, a good benefits package, and salary opposed to commission.
Con: The job sucks the soul out of people.  You will get paid next to nothing because Anonymous is the Walmart of the financial services industry (i.e. low cost provider).  The company is top heavy and bottom heavy..  Middle management are complete puppets with cozy jobs but no input.  The company has a sweatshop mentality and does not see its employees at added value.  They breed mediocrity in all aspects of job performance.

Summary: "Great opportunities if you are a self starter"
Pro: Good management of the Employer services part of the company meant it was a great place to work in IT. Many opportunities to shine but it required hard work and you need to be a self starter. If you want to gain skills in running projects, managing up or down and overall leadership, FESCo was a wonderful environment.
Con: Other Anonymous business units are not as well managed, if you do not work in a group with good leadership you may have a different experience altogether. Security is tight, you will go through extensive background checks and must adhere to the companies many policies. As with any large company, there is a reasonable amount of red tape and paperwork to get anything done. Internal IT services in this company are particularly inefficient.

Pro: Anonymous provide great oppertunities to those willing to put in the effort.  Hard and smart work is rewarded with promotions... like most thing in life should be it is what you put in to it.  Health benefit are great.  The company also encourages employees to complete thier educaiton or to persue advanced educaiton.  Work / Life balance is important.  Managers understand this balance and work to accomodate request.
Con: Benefits are great but the starting representative and manager pay is average.  Company wide career planning is some what lacking.  Many career conversations with your manager are limited to your current company.

Pro:
No age discrimination at all.  I was hired at age 62 as a beginning employee.  The training was intense and excellent,.  One of the requirements for staying is that you HAVE to pass the Series 7 licensing exam.  For a person who is interested in istock and fund investing, this is a great place to learn.  The company has a rigid insistence on integrity, which is a good thing.  I worked with persons who had been at Merrill, and other companies; they universally said that the expectation of integrity made communications with customers much easier for all parties.



Anonymous offers various Health Insurance and savings programs; insurance is very good.  Also, the 401K Program, Pension, etc are excellent.



Anonymous Phone Representatives are available 24/7,  In an on-the-phones team. at about six monts intervals, you have the opportunity to bid to move to a different shift.
Con:
The company requires a college degree for evey employee who will have contact with the public, but the starting slalary seems low for that type of position.  There are opportunities to earn bonuses, but you are competing with all other employees in your job type for the share of a fixed "pot" of money.  Since I was the age of some of my supervisor's parents, and I had also been a senior military officer, two of them appeared to fell awkward about advising me about job performance, and took a harsh tone to cover up their embarassment.  This was only two persons in eight years with the company;  most persons in Team Leader/Management positions are excellent.



The shift work requirements can become very wearing, especially late shifts.

Summary: "Is Anonymous a good place to work?"
Pro: benefits, work balance and opportunity to advance
Con: salary caps- employees that work with clients work hard and can only make so much

Pro: benefits, training, a company with good values
Con: As many large organizations are, Anonymous is often so bureaucratic that sometimes you feel like you're banging your head against the wall to get policies changed for employees.

Summary: "Fidleity is a great place to work"
Pro: Fideltiy is an organizatiion that demonstrates integrity in their policies and actions.  Individuals at times lose the vision at times, but the organition is self correcting over time. The products and services are excelelent and the vlue to the clients is as good or better than most competitors.  Anonymous has strong and solid senior management, fair treatment of employees, a excellent business plan in their retail services. Cannot comment on other parts of the organization.
Con: Politics, lack of recognition for excellent work.  Processes are in place to do so, but they are hollow at times.

Pro: Privately held, lots of smart people, good benefits
Con:
"Lions led by Donkeys" - I'm stealing this phrase from Rodger Lawson, who mentioned it during one of his briefings. 



During this time of unprecedented change, it seems the place has become even more political and bureaucratic. Personally, I think Rodger Lawson is a much needed shot-in-the-arm for the company and has done much to infuse new leadership at the top. However, the next few levels down are in turmoil and disarray. Political infighting, turf wars, back-stabbing...it couldn't be further from the goals and objectives that Rodger laid out when he arrived at Anonymous. I think he would be stunned if he knew the truth about how some of his senior leaders were making decisions during the recent waves of layoffs, how good (but "non political") talent was being purged from the company, how things were being done more for "optics" than actual results. There are still many S and E level VPs in the company that need to find some religion...or seek other pastures.

Summary: "Be prepared to answer 50-70 calls a day in a structured environment. 95% of day spent talking to random callers."
Pro: Good benefits.  Good place to learn industry and get licenses or have them pay for your degree.
Con: Very structured. Never time for career development or time off phones.  Constantly answer phones 40-50 hours a week, 30 min break 30 min lunch.

Summary: "You can't complain if you're not willing to leave."
Pro: opportunities to acquire multiple skill sets are available to those interested.
Con: growth seems limited because of the number of employees. the bonuses are pretty silly. being a phone monkey is the only option.

Pro: They pay well. People are very polite, and the management structure is very clear.
Con: It is an extremely political corporate culture and you have to fit in to get ahead. There is one style of behavior that is considered appropriate and you are expected to act that way. You have to be very careful about expressing your opinions--getting along is valued very highly. You have to learn how to fit in with the corporate culture.

Summary: "Fast-paced professional and ethical place to work"
Pro: The benefits ( 401k, profit sharing, vacation, health/dental) are top tier .  The access to technology to complete your daily job functions is tremendous.  There are a tremendous amount of resources (if you know who/where to look)  to help accomplish your job function.  The majority of colleagues/people very responsive to questions and inquiries.
Con: You must be self-motivated and have the ability to succeed with minimal training and guidance.  You really need to ask the right questions/get a consensu answer from multiple sources to obtain the correct answers.  Obtaining resources is very beurocratic and painful to get.  Too many forms/blind e-mail inboxes to submit to get things completed with great difficulty in getting updates on requests.

Summary: "Great place to work, but you will get burnt out easily"
Pro: Anonymous really has the name brand recognition in the industry. People generally respect Anonymous as a whole. They also have a very good benefits package, and between a 7% 401k match and profit sharing, they take good year of your retirement account. Also, with Anonymous being a privately held company, they have a little bit more flexibility to do what is right for the employees.
Con: I have come to find that it is a very micro-managed company, where management really is not in tune with what is happening in the real world. With regards to work/life balance, there are too many times where you need to take your work home to get to know the materials better or study for a presentation, and there is definitely not enough time off. There is also too many worries about "perception is reality", and you always have to watch who takes notice or looks over your shoulder.

Summary: "Nice benefits, good place to start, but opportunities may be limited"
Pro: They offer a good benefits package, including a 401k match of 7% and annual profit sharing which is normally 10%.  The health and dental are also good.  High deductible health plan with annual company contribution may be good for those without a family who are in good general health.  Good place to get started in the industry and get your license.  Also good foundation for your personal investing and retirement planning.  Some schedule flexibility, 4 weeks vacation after 5 years, and good place to meet people, for friends and romance.  Know a number of people who met their future spouse here.
Con: As it is a very large company, it can be easy to get lost in the shiffle and pigeonholed into limited opportunities.  You can also feel like you are just a number at times.  Individual talent and superior work performance is not always properly recognized and rewarded, it seems too often that cronyism and politics are more important for advancement.  Too many levels of middle management, often staffed by people less talented and motivated than those the are "managing"- a key point, as there seems to be too much managing and not enough leading.  In recent years, occasional layoffs are also a concern.

Summary: "Building relationships goes a long way here. . .not hard work."
Pro: -Very good compensation and benefits package.
Con: -Poor leadership and a lot of management staff are more fit for individual contributor positions.

Summary: "Pay for Performance is not all it is cracked up to be"
Pro: Has opportunity for those willing to work extremely hard, Benefits are great, and the company is stronger than most financial services firms out there.  They are a private firm so there are no "Shareholders" to pander to.
Con: 40 hour work week is not an option need to work 55+ hours per week and not get paid for it, Bonus restructured so TOP employees get all comp others get minimum.  Employees who have worked there a long time get small changes in comp while new hires comp is more premium.  you need to leave the company and come back in a higher postion to get any significant changes in compensation or title

Pro:
--Some of the best compensation and benefit packages you will find anywhere in the corporate world. 

--Management is considerate towards the personal needs of employees and work/life balance really exists here. 

--Great brand name in the industry and the company has a good reputation as an ethical and upright corporate citizen (despite some high-profile cases suggesting the opposite).

--Company seems well positioned to capture the assets of the baby-boomer retiree market.
Con:
Oh, so many of them. I can speak only of my group, but looking at all the comments made here, apparently it is the same elsewhere.



Many (if not most) senior employees (VP level and above) didn't get there because they were smart, were productive or were visionaries or were good subject matter experts. Neither are they great leaders and neither are they perceptive of how to make things work. They seem to have made it purely because they knew how to 'game' the system. And the system tolerates this because there is no system to objectively identify top-performers. The bi-annual performance appraisal is a farce. 



And something very striking about the place is that we don't have any benchmarks of how long a certain job or project should take and we willingly spend $1000 on a project that would get done with better quality and shorter timeframe for $200 elsewhere. We are an island of mediocrity and I wonder how we will survive (forget thriving) in a brutal marketplace. What kind of a fool's paradise are we living in here?

Summary: "Feels like a dead-end into Fund Accounting and that you will never be able to leave."
Pro: They give you good exposure to the market while providing the tools necessary to perform your job.  There are all sorts of jobs within this company that cover a broad range.
Con: Depending on the job, a lot is expected from you with not a lot of recognition when a job well done is performed.  The pay is generally in the lower part of their industry.

Summary: "Stable company with many opportunities for growth."
Pro: Anonymous recognizes individual contribution - hard work pays generally pays off with increased bonuses and profit sharing.  It is a large company so you can be pidgeon holed if you don't work hard to expand your sphere of influence.  Over the years, Anonymous has tried hard to treat employees fairly.
Con: It is easy to just come and go and meet the minimum requirements of your job.  You'll have stability but will be quickly marginalized as a serious playmaker.

Pro: Benefits, great co-workers, VTO and location
Con: Goals for employees are unrealilistic and management will even tell you so.  Company goes from one extreme to another, unable to find a realistic medium on any goals or changes.

Summary: "Good for a call center, but don't be fooled.....you will be on the phones for years before any real advancement occurs."
Pro: Great starting ground to break into the business.
Con: Promise of career advancement is limited to call center jobs, regardless of how hard you work.

Summary: "Very good place to start a job, tremendous place to establish a career."
Pro: Very easily to be promoted within the company, as long as you excel at your previous role.  Challenging enough to keep you interested until you master that role, at that time there is opportunity to move along.  Benefits are unmatched compared to anywhere!  7% match on 401(k), 10% profit sharing into 401(k) each December, quarterly bonuses, health packages, fitness reimbursement, almost fully paid advance degrees (i.e. MBA).
Con: It can be monotonous at times.  Initially, you start out on the phones as a Customer Service rep.  As long as you aren't a screw up in that role, it's easy to move along to others with more responsibility.  It is very much an inbound call center, however, training there is very good.  Still good education when it comes to market knowledge and very, very good licensing training (7, 63, 66... possibly CFP pending on how far you move along).  I have no experience in branch roles.

Summary: "if you like to stay in one job for a long time go with Anonymous"
Pro: profit shareing bonus is awsome 10% of salary after the first full year of working there.  Also they match dollar for dollar up to 7% every pay check.  Great for getting securities licences.  Also the education match is helpful for people going to school they will pay up to $10,000.  However, my manager said this started right away when I was hired he lied I had to wait 6 months before they would pay me back.
Con: no upward movement... once your in a role you feel stuck in a box you cannot get out of

Summary: "Good place to work for a few years, then get a better job elsewhere."
Pro: Good place to start out, get some experience; and move on.
Con: I've seen people promoted to positions they did not deserve, while the person who puts in 100% gets passed over time and time again.  I have been through three major "re-orgs," and had my title changed, pay changed, managers changed (three times in one year once), and have seen good people leave due to the overwhelming feeling of discouragement when they are passed up for a promotion yet again given to an incompetent person who "knows" someone.  It is difficult to work like that everyday, and I can understand why people leave.  It is also highly compartmentalized, which means that once you have worked there for a few years or more; it becomes difficult to be marketable to another company.

Summary: "Working at Anonymous is like being among the walking dead!!"
Pro: Privately held company, high-level of ethics, decent pay
Con: They take advantage of high-performers, They would rather listen and be driven by consultants with MBAs rather than their own people, They are right now de-leveling the organization and enforcing a uniform corp structure without regard to what actually makes sense, They are easily lured to thinking that process improvement strategies are going to have a huge impact on the business (such as Six Sigma and Transformation)

Summary: "Anonymous is a good place to work if you want to work in the financial sector."
Pro: The best reasons to work for Anonymous are the benefits, the compensation versus other financial institutions, and the ability to work from home when it is necessary.  I wa blown away by the compensation I got this year and how it shows that they actually pay for performance.
Con: There is a lot of red tape around getting things done, especially at the software development level.  Sometimes they also squash creativity but it gets better over time.  The one thing to know about this is that it is all about the group that you get into and who you work for.

Summary: "Anonymous has good compensation and benefits, but can be very bureacratic."
Pro:
There are a lot of different areas of the company which allows for a lot of opportunity.  You can spend many years there and actually experience a number of different careers.  Unfortunately, it takes a lot of personal career management and "political" savy to get the opportunities.  



Anonymous is very innovative in their use of technology.  They have an amazing technology research center where they are constantly are looking to improve their systems.
Con: Very old school culture.  If you haven't been with the company for at least 10 years it feels like no one listens to you.  There is also a very strong aversion to change, you hear things like "this is the way Anonymous does it" and "Ned (the Chairman) likes it to be this way".  Unfortunately, I think people are afraid to question the way things are done.  Also, it is a large (50k employees) private company that is mostly family owned, so trying to drive change is almost impossible.

Summary: "People are treated with respect, most employees have a positive attitude and great place to start a career."
Pro: The culture is one of respect for co-workers at all levels.  People really do care about your life outside of work.  I have met some wonderful people there that I will always stay in contact with.  Too many themes and flavors of the week to promote productivity and increase morale.  But they do really cute things like ice cream socials, all types of charity promotions, flue shot day, etc...  In the last few years, they seemed to have nailed down certain slogans that teams incorporated into their daily work.  I started my career there out of school, and learned how important image and perception is correlated to what opportunities your manager or senior person will give to you.  Great place to start a career.  I worked in Operations, so the raises sucked, but my hours were pretty much 8:30 to 5.  Most people are out by 5 in the Ops group.  All the internal systems that are meant for the employees to navigate through technology requests, benefits and pay are fantastic.  Most of the time, you are given the right tools to succeed in your job.  Metrics reporting sucked.    But if you come in with a positive attitude then you will get one back most of the time.
Con: I would say the salaries are not competitive and merit increases are insignificant, but at the same time, there was never a year when an increase did not happen, or when a bonus was cancelled.

Pro: Good benefits package.  Company was in good shape financially until recently.  Friendly people.  Involved in lots of charitable orginazations.  They have a nice Xmas party and do lots of things for families such as the Big Apple circus and the books fair.  If you need to travel for the company, cuh as going to India, they are generous on expenses for the trip.  Relocation packaages for people going to NC or Texas were good.  Working from home is something that seems to be available to most people.  Bi annual meetings with Sr management attempt to give you info about whats going on but they are usually a waste of time.
Con: Little to no room for a promotion.  Tiny raises for the masses.  No recoginition for doing a good job, unless your a major kiss a..  Poltics and lots of it.

Pro: Very good name recognition.  The company has a strong history of performance.  A local Boston-area company that has gone national.  The profit sharing plan is excellent (10% of base salary), which is on top of the 7% 401(k) company match.  Salaries are competitive to the rest of the job market.  Overall, a very good company to work for and one I'm proud to be employed by.
Con: In downcycles of the market there are often many rounds of layoffs, so job security can be tenuous.  Certain depertments can be highly stressful, and the work culture is one where those who stick to a regular 8 hour day are frowned upon.

Summary: "Great place to start, but staying there may be a mistake for your career"
Pro: Great place to start a career in the financial industry.  Great training and they pay for licensing
Con: Anonymous claims to be a "meritocracy" but that is simply not the case

Summary: "A good company for financial services newbies"
Pro: If you are interested in gaining experience at a large company in Financial Services for your resume, this is the place to start.  Anonymous's reputation in the industry even today is solid. The breadth of offerings from Anonymous offers newcomers a range of options for a new job.  The Benefits package at Anonymous is fine, not more or less than any other company, but it is all-inclusive.
Con: This is not the place for you if you have ever worked ANYWHERE else where employee treatment was a core value.  The company talks a good line but that's as far as it goes.  There is no work/life balance, people are not valued, and management hasn't got a clue how the make the environment better.

Pro: Some of the smartest people I have ever worked with, many truly care about the customer and doing right by them.  The company allows for tremendous growth and mobility, and, over the years, one can build a very rich skillset by working in different areas.  Anonymous also has seemingly infinite resources, and invests in research and new ideas.  Innovation is rewarded and encouraged.
Con: Anonymous is a relationship company, and decisions are often made based on who is "in good graces" with the current leadership.  Often, stakeholders on a project or activity can number in the dozens, and strong opinions are encouraged.  Conflict and competition are also encouraged

Summary: "Getting Better, still will work you to the bone."
Pro: Benefits are the number one reason people work at Anonymous.  The 401k match is 7%, then another 10% in profit sharing in January each year. Its pretty amazing, but understandable since the money goes straight into Anonymous funds.  The people are generally good at there jobs and work very hard for the company.
Con: Anonymous will work you to the bone, especially in technology where Senior Management continually picks arbitrary dates for when projects need to be delivered.  This causes cramped analysis time and due to the archaic architecture, issues always come up at the last minute.

Pro: The experience! You're surrounded by the best of the best-which makes you work that much harder. There can be great opportunity for advancement as long as you can keep your head down when need be, not step on too many toes and don't screw up.
Con: Ultra competitive, ALL THE TIME! Also not always the friendliest co-workers. It is often very political. If you rub someone the wrong way it can really set you back. It's also hard to get a lot of visibility for a job well done due to the shear size and the politics of the day to day.

Pro: Honestly there were none...it was a horrible experience
Con: It is a private company that is based in Boston.  So if you are not based in Boston and you never were, then be prepared to struggle in this network.

Pro: the benefits are good however the dental could be better.
Con: Private company, the dental coudl be better. They did away with the pension and the profit sharing is also changing

Summary: "Anonymous is good or bad to work for depending on which group you're in"
Pro: If you enjoy crunching numbers it is a good place to work.
Con: If you have ideas about how to improve processes and get work done more efficiently people who've been there a long time don't want to hear it.

Summary: "If you work here, leave as soon you can.  If offered a job, respectfully decline it."
Pro: There are no more good reasons to work here, they are all gone.  Over 15 years in IT at this company and they have layed off the brightest and most valuable employees.  The 'real' workers are gone, teams cut to the bone and expected to still get the work done.  Anonymous is cutting IT  and are preparing to outsource the whole thing over the next 5 years.  Get a job at a company who is going to provide the outsourcing.  You are expected to do your job with a blindfold on and both hands tied behind your back.  Benefits are going to be cut, demotions are days away, salaries will be cut and no pay raises expected this year.
Con: Too many to list in the space provided.  Run away and don't look back.

Pro: The people who work there are friendly and have an interest in the markets and business in general. They have a wide array of shifts to choose from. Managers manage effectively, thats not to say they are good leaders, simply they encourage working hard as well as smart, they provide feedback in a timely manner. Their benefits package is very top notch. The profit-sharing enables them to have a great benefits package from computer purchases to gym memberships and quarterly bonuses. Their lack of accountability to shareholders makes their business model more effective and gives them the incentive to work hard for the benefit of the customers
Con: being paid hourly and not being paid for lunch, therefore one must give up 9 hours a day to work an 8hour day. If you're not working in corporate, you're answering phones. Also their new hire training teaches the fundamentals of their systems, they dont teach anything stock related, the closest thing you'll get to learning how markets work is through the series 7 exam and talking with colleagues, but even they are somewhat clueless. Lastly, Anonymous, being a conservative company severely limits employee investing, for instance, any position thats considered bearish is not allowed.

Summary: "Johnson leading in the background, but others in front taking the reins."
Pro: Despite the tough economy, Anonymous is in a relatively strong position compared to some of the competition.  In addition, working for a private company has its advantages and the company can be a little longer term in its focus for making investments.  My colleagues are all very intelligent and at least in my group, I think management's heart is in the right place.  If you are willing to aggressively seek out new opportunities, they are there for those who embrace change.  Benefis are definitely above average compared to my last company and despite the down year, bonuses and profit sharing were still paid out.
Con: One downside is that Anonymous is extremely large and there are many, many layers of management.  In addition, while a lot of great things come out of change, there can be so much of it that initiatives can sometimes not complete before things change again.  Lately, perhaps partly due to the downturn, there have not been many promotional opportunities for associates, though there are opportunities on firmwide initiatives.  That being said, due to the sheer #'s of people, you need to sometimes toot your own horn to get your performance noticed.  Finally, more emphasis seems to be on bonuses as base pay increases are paltry - very little separates average performers from the strongest performers.  Timing for performance goal setting often does not match up with when reviews are actually being done - this needs to be brought together better.

Summary: "Anonymous Investments, a decent place to work."
Pro: The benefits are great at Anonymous.  You also can meet some good contacts as well.
Con: Takes forever to move up in this company.  Management are dads and mothers who are content in staying in their positions for many years which prevents movement within the firm.

Pro: I feel that Anonymous Investments has many good attributes .  I feel that employees receive fair treatment by managers, good salary and benefits, and have plenty of opportunities for advancement.  They also encourage you to develop your skills as a planner and provide lots of support.
Con: Very conservative corporate culture, sometimes it's difficult to navigate the different parts of the company.  Sometimes it takes a while to get things done.

Summary: "a decent employer if you can manage to hold on to your job"
Pro: Excellent Pay, Great Benefits, they pay for your series 6 & 63 license if necessary to your job function.
Con:
They will can you if it means the company will save a buck.

Your computer system is always crashing. How can you be expected to service your customers, when your ONLY means of servicing them DOESN'T WORK!!!!.

Pro: There are a variety of opportunities and moving between business units is encouraged, so you get to build on your skill set.  Historically Anonymous has been at the forefront of inovation and has been a market leader.  The company has strong business ethics.
Con: The business has moved into a "mature" phase.  It's more concerned with protecting business than expanding business.  It used to feel more exciting to work there than it has the past few years.

Pro: Great pay, good benefits, above average working conditions
Con: Company is undergoing a transformation and re-org .... lots of uncertainty and personal agendae at work.

Pro: Incredible benefits!  The match, profit sharing, bonus, health insurance, etc.  It's a Great place to work.
Con: They can't decide on where the growth sites are.  They start one and finish too quick without giving it a chance to work.

Summary: "Hopefully Ned can turn the company back around- iceberg dead ahead."
Pro: Anonymous has a great brand, a great product, it is always looking to change and improve, is very modern in its outlook. Because the founding family still owns the company, management is very committed to keeping true to the company's original core values. Offices are modern and HR is progressive, offering the cutting edge in benefits and employee development. Up until the past couple of years, it was a great place to work- hands down with lots of opportunity for advancement, personal development etc.
Con: In the past several years, the company got too big, It became a huge bureaucracy and "old boy's network".  Those people (mostly men) who were "buddies" with their business unit's  Sr. VPs advanced quickly. The rest of us were worked very hard with small raises. Employees all spent a lot of their time trying to negotiate a huge bureaucracy. This had not been my experience of Anonymous in the past. The good news is, management realized this. They wisely picked up from employee surveys that employees were feeling frustrated. In recent years they shook up upper management and have been working to get rid of the dead wood. I hope for their sake they can return to Anonymous as it used to be. I used to love working there, but in recent years was so frustrated. My co-workers all experienced the same thing.

Summary: "Good and bad areas to work; weak economy has adversely affected opportunities and satisfaction."
Pro: The benefit package has historically been very good, although financial pressures are causing cutbacks in that area. When times are good, there can be good opportunities for development and advancement - especially if you work in a business or site that is growing or you are willing to move around. There are a lot of dedicated and intelligent employees at all levels of the company in my experience there were generally opportunities to spread your involvement and contribution beyond your job description. It was a good first job, but if you get stuck in one place for very long consider bailing.
Con: Like any large company, there are good places to work and bad ones; strong managers and weak ones; good teams and dysfunctional ones. If you are in the wrong place or under a poor manager, life can be ugly. In IT, morale has been pretty low over the past few years for a number of reasons and I wouldn't recommend that part of the business to a friend right now. IT got hit pretty hard in the last couple rounds of layoffs and frankly many were happier to be let go than to be among those left behind. In many areas the pressure and hours can be brutal.

Summary: "Anonymous is a GREAT building block and FOUNDATION"
Pro: If you are starting out in the financial industry you can get your series 7, 63, and 66 within a year to a year and a half at Anonymous. You are constantly in training. I would stay at fidelity for at least the first 5 years moving from department to department learning as much as you possible can. Then if they do not compensate you the way you want...MOVE ON.
Con: The competition. I work in a phone site where there are over 1,000 people, and everyone wants the same higher paying jobs. The last job interview I had within the department was against 100 other people fighting for a handful of jobs

Summary: "A great place to start, but it can take a while to make a decent salary."
Pro: Great place to learn about the financial markets and great benefits.  Tons of customers to work with, don't have to worry about building your own book of clients.
Con: Not a lot of variety in most of the roles at Anonymous.  Need to try hard to make the phone jobs exciting.  Too many campaigns and changing goals in the sales roles.  Tiered approach to bonuses, someone is always at the bottom, no matter what.  Not necessarily paid for what you do (but that's the rules of a salary plus bonus structure).

Pro: Large firm, privatley held provides much lattitude for the business to try new things
Con: Many layers, highly matrixed  & complicated to gain approvals for large scale programs

Summary: "Good Company - needs to show more organizational maturity"
Pro: Anonymous is good company for early and mid career opportunities.Excellent use of technolgy for building their business and getting your job done. The benefits are excellent, but you will need to work hard and sometimes work/life balance get be difficult to maintain.
Con: Can be very political and you need to spend a considerable amount of time promoting your accomplishments up the organization. Need to stay close to your boss and whoever he/she reports to to receive deserved recognition. If you want to move up you will need to an inordinate amount of time managing up. There can be a sense of entitlement amongst the longer term employees, but that is changing.  Anonymous makes money despite itself and spends money foolishly at times.

Pro: Management and staff seem to actually care about the quality of the work. They do move people up, but it can take some time. There are big changes going on now, but in spite of that people are keeping their heads up and being treated with the respect that they deserve. The benefits are better than most, and from what I can tell, the people who didn't make it through the layoffs were treated much better than those at other corporations.
Con: Shaky, scary economy.  But, hang in there, the financial markets have to turn around and then things will be better for everyone.

Summary: "You Can Be a Star Today, Gone Tomorrow"
Pro: Total compensation and benefits package. Good place to get some experience. Work for a few years, then think about moving on.
Con: Too much politics, red tape, and committee-based decision making. Little opportunity for lateral training and transition. More internal promotion and assignments based upon who you know rather than what you know.

Summary: "solid platform, potential to lose innovation and talent"
Pro: incredible scale and power in the industry
Con: very internally focused and political - tends to reward status quo relationships vs market differentiation

Pro: Good health benefits. 7% 401k match. Profit sharing of usually 10% of your salary at end of year. You have to stay 5 years to be vested. Good people to work with. Anonymous has a great training program the 1st 3 months you are there to get you licensed and ready for the phones.
Con: Chained to the phone like a workhorse. Not much opportunity for upward movement in company. You are micromanaged big time and have to follow a strict schedule. The constant beeping in your ear from phone calls will drive you crazy after a while.

Pro: Great reputation.  You can quickly learn the business, and gain experience because of the high volumes.
Con:
Change, change, change.  Anonymous has historically been a place where people expect change.  Lately, they have taken it to a level that is unusual even here.

I have been with firm for 10+ years.  I can't remember a time with more internal discontent..

Summary: "Anonymous's an excellent ship but it navigation systems may be flawed"
Pro:
- Willing to take risks on emerging technologies

- Excellent benefits and pay, 401k and profit sharing are industry leaders

- Excellent work life balance, vacation time and personal time is encouraged

- Respected industry leader, with major market share in most sectors

- Large company with ample opportunties for movement
Con:
- Company has lost its direction, doesn't seem to be able to be the market leader

- Focus on technological innovation has become second to financial accounting

- Organization impedes risk tasking and innovation

- Difficult to navigate the complexities of the new organization structure

- Operational processes often impede productivity and progress

Summary: "Great company with limited growth in current environment."
Pro: Excellent benefits and large job diversification across the firm.
Con: With the market being slow right now there are limited promotional opportunities.  Any personal trading activity must be cleared before the transaction depending on which department you work in.

Pro: Overall, very solid company with great benefits, opportunities for promotion.  Anonymous has multiple locations so there is potential to move around.  You can get in contact with the top easier than you'd think for a large corporation.  The old saying was you never get rich while at Anonymous, but because you worked there you will be rich.  I think this is true because of the incentive programs between annual bonus opportunities which can be a substantial amount of your income, phantom share program that pay out every two years and their profit sharing that was their year in and out.
Con: I thought that Anonymous got a little too big and struggled to find out how to structure itself to succeed.  It seemed like we would go through 3-4 organizational alignments each year.  It's not that it's bad, but they never seem to be able to stay the course with their decisions.  It really depended upon who was leading the charge.  Current senior management is more about the bottom line as oppose to prior leadership.  Prior leadership still looked at growth opportunities and current leadership wants to maintain and not necessary grow the business unless it is an EXACT fit or match.

Pro: Gain experience in the financial industry. Good pay and great benefits.
Con: At Anonymous Investments there are too many politics. I thought I was in the novel "Catch 22" but instead of the book being set in WW2, it's set in Corporate America. Some of the most asinine decisions I've ever seen, including those in movies and on TV, were made at the manager level. Too many layers and layers of middle management who don't really have a function other than to attend meetings and self-promote. Some of the managers even make the associates complete manager reviews for them.

Summary: "Magical place to a place of misery"
Pro:
Money

Benefits

Colleagues are the best
Con:
What you hear is...white collar sweatshop...accurate!

Suffering from ethics problems at top (cutting most old timers who helped build the place)

Works on the basis of sponsorship

Pro: They take care of the employees. Great training. Laid back environment at branches. There is a lot of training. I traveled to california and texas to get the right training i needed for my job. It was far better than just having someone teach me in the branch.
Con:
They are quick to let employees go. There are a lot of people willing to work for less so they have a revolving door of employees. 



The branches push contests quite frequently. You may be urged to sell something in order to meet some sort of goal, even though it might not be right for the customer.

Summary: "Anonymous used to be great but is now just good and hopefully stops there."
Pro: Anonymous supports work-life balance and has excellent benefits.  The work is challenging and mostly interesting.  Anonymous has a high degree of integrity and is a place you can generally be proud to be associated.
Con: Anonymous is a large, lumbering organization that is going through significant change.  This can make for a challenging work environment.  Processes to get day to day work completed are often cumbersome and inefficient.  Decision making is often decentralized and requires buy-in from many different organizations.  Strategic decisions seem to take excessively long and sometimes waffle back and forth.  This makes execution of the strategy much harder than it needs to be and sometimes nearly impossible to meet required time frames.

Summary: "Work in the branch not the call center"
Pro: The benefits are good. Opportunity for advancement is Depends on the department you work for.
Con: Call center environment is not a Team oriented place. Management changes happen every week. Communication from management needs lot of work.

Summary: "Anonymous investments, a great place to start out in the financial industry."
Pro: Heath benefits and other benifits
Con: no commissions, we should get better recognition.

Pro: Good entry level financial experience. They like to promote from within. Decent pay for the work that you have to do.
Con: Call center is extremely micromanaged. The managers can make a difference. In the end they just want you to do your job but they have so many people who do the bare minimum that it makes it necessary to micromanage, which ruins the job for those of us who take pride in what we do.

Summary: "People made the company great - why let them go?"
Pro: Benefits - was also once a powerhouse with great momentum.
Con: Highly matrxed - difficult to take tasks to completion.

Summary: "The Good and Not so Good  when considering working for Anonymous Investments"
Pro: Name Brand Recognition - Everyone knows Anonymous. Private Company. They Have great 401k platform and strong mutual Funds that are recognized for their management. The benefits are great and it is a family oriented company. The company is quick to adapt to a changing market environment and are committed to providing the BEST customer service to clients.
Con: Changes, specifically to compensation and goals, are not communicated effectivly and in a timely manner. There are too many funds on the advisor side and while there are some good funds there is a lot of overlap and some of them are not managed well which can make sales very challenging. The daily job of an investment consultant is not correlated to compensation or to performance measurements. The stress level is high in my opinion especially when compared to the compensation. Competition with the direct side of Anonymous can also present a unique challenge compared to other firms.

Summary: "Great place to work if confusion at the top doesn't bother you."
Pro: Large company with may different opportunities.  Anonymous has its hand in so many areas of business that you could do pretty much anything.
Con: There is no clear actionable vision from senior management.  Many outsiders have come into very senior level positions and haven't lasted too long.  There have also been some very high profile departures from the firm.  This has caused a general sense of uncertainty about the vision and direction the company is heading towards in the future.

Summary: "Good, better  than most perhaps - but could be the best."
Pro:
Excellent facilities and infrastructure (may not last long due to recession).

Highly encourages innovation and employee development even though scope is minimal due to restricted financial domain.

Competitive pay structures (may not last long due to recession).

Management ensures proper communication to all employees in major decisions.
Con:
Certain sections' job responsibilities are highly stress-prone - management sometimes take decisions based on budget planning rather than people development.

Most of upper level leadership is not technology aware, which makes them poor project planners, which in turn affects people development.

HR is too busy managing technical workforce coming in and going out, hence cannot do much to solve the management issues.

Summary: "Once #1 mutual fund industry leader now slowly decenting to the middle of the pack"
Pro: The money and benefits are excellent.  Salary, Bonus, Profit Sharing, Shares, Life Insurance, company match in 401(k), etc.
Con: Performance is not always valued.  Mediocre resources can flourish and even excel if they are liked by senior management.  Pay for Performance is not managed well.  New Senior Leadership is cutting staff based on money not performance.

Summary: "Anonymous Investments is a good place to work for someone who expects as much out of the company as they put in."
Pro: Anonymous offers extensive growth opportunities to those individuals who display talent and a drive to succeed.  In most cases the managers are very understanding of family and personal time needs, coupled with an expectation that everyone is a professional and will make their hours up as necessary. Anonymous also offers excellent benefits packages.
Con: Depending on your position, there can be an expectation of working well beyond 40 hr work weeks, though that is not a consistent occurence.  Occasionally Executive Management may have plans in the works that are driving changes organizationally, but which not all employees are privvy to at the time, and which can then make some of the organizational changes seem inappropriate (at that time).

Pro: Privately held allows for long-term investment.  Great pay for people willing to put in the effort, however, that might all be changing.  Great benefit, even with recent reductions.
Con: Priorities and management is always changing.  Too many senior people working to protect their careers versus taking chances to grow the business.  Most recent changes handled poorly, way too many people kept in constant fear of loosing their job...tough to focus on the work to be done.

Pro: They have great health and 401k benefits as well as vacation.  There are a lot of great people and they really promote a team atmosphere.  A lot of continuing education and reimbursement opportunities for education.
Con: You are chained to the phone.  You have a ton of measures you have to hit and very little independence.  They micromanage you to death and beat the Anonymous way into you.  The growth opportunities seem to be confined to the phone site.

Pro: It was a great place to learn and grow.  Senior Management are very professional and look to promote younger ambitious people.
Con: The downside is that the company is very large and it is hard to get promoted

Summary: "Anonymous is a Great Place to Launch a Career"
Pro: Anonymous (CSS ) is a great place to launch your career. There is alot of support and systems that are in place to ensure you are successful. Anonymous is a great place for wholesome people who want to work and a friendly, family-oriented environement. Its not the place for a gunslinger who wants some action. Wrong culture.
Con: The use of call flows is like being a robot. You can't really help the customers on the call's because of the liability Anonymous feels comes back on them, in my opinion. However, I don't think Anonymous really encourages there employee's in CSS to be better at helping customers with Investment Education calls.

Summary: "Anonymous is a great place to start a career in the financial industry and can be a great place to make a career."
Pro: Great management, employees and customers. Plenty of opportunity to learn the industry. Career opportunities in management and sales. Benefits are excellent. Privately held company which makes for a great environment.
Con: Compensation is at the low end for the financial industry in service, sales and management. There is no exposure to outside sales, no cold calling. This is a con because it makes moving to another company a bit of a shock.

Summary: "Can be a great company (depending on what business unit you work for)."
Pro:
It's a company with one of the best reputations in the industry, and it's especially good working for a privately held in the current market environment.  The constant internal message from senior management is that rule #1 is "what's right for the client"....no matter what your role is.  



I'm constantly impressed at the depth of knowledge at FMR (can't speak for other business units, but reference my "Cons").  I've worked at other firms and constantly feel that I work with some of the best and smartest people in the industry.  



Working for FMR (as opposed to other business units within Anonymous) is a real plus too.
Con:
It seems that compensation tends to be less competitive (at least in the non-supervisory roles).  I think Anonymous recognizes that their name cache on your resume is "value enough" in their eyes for future opportunities outside of the the company.



Because Anonymous has so many seperately managed business units under the "Anonymous Investments" umbrella, the cultures can vary widely.  I've interacted with some employees in other business units (outside of FMR) who seem to have a very relaxed work environment ("think I'll leave at 3 today...it's Friday, and it's so nice outside!") or generally seem to be less impressive on a talent level-- some business units' Directors or even VPs are less qualified/knowledgable than many of the non-managers in FMR.



That being said, there does seem to be either a little bit of arrogance from, or a little bit of jealousy toward, FMR in interactions between business units.

Pro: cutting edge technologies to work with, lot of room to learn and grow if you are a starter.  People are professional and talented, great team work among the groups to get the work done.
Con: This is not a place where they let people sit all day long doing nothing. 8+ hours a day is normal and often work over time.

Pro: Great co-workers and life long friends met there.  Nice facilities.  Broad array of low cost products providing a good value.  Good web site that is easy to use in general.
Con: Company recently completed mass layoffs that clearly targeted the older, longer-tenured, more experienced employees.  Anonymous has made the decision that clients will be satisfied getting their retirement planning and investment advice from younger, cheaper, recent college grads rather than from loyal and experienced professionals.  Morale is at rock bottom across the country.  Benefits have been slashed.  All benefits that were once the pride of the industry have been drastically cut or eliminated - no more pension, no more company match to 401K, drastically higher health insurance costs.  With most recent layoffs, there can be no comfort in your job security.  Dozens of 20+ year employees were lay off simply because their pay was higher.  Many who were liad off were top performers with exceptional management reviews or were sales achievers.  Decisions of who would be laid off was made far above any local, regional or area manager level.  Management had not control of who and who would not be let go.  Products are low cost but they are becoming more and more low performance.  Anonymous was once the best in the field of equity mutual fund managment.  This is no longer the case.  Most of their funds are medocre at best.  With over 300 funds, they will have a few towards the top of some lists but most are below average.  The financial media has covered this extensively.

Pro: As a representative, the job is low stress. People at the Albuquerque site are great! It has a friendly atmosphere.
Con: I was really surprised to see the cost of benefits. They pay is below the market average. If they would lower the cost of benefits, I would be working there again in a heartbeat!

Summary: "Great company, good opportunities when the economy permits"
Pro: This is a great company to work for. Smart, caring people (for the most part), great benefits, lots of extras, beautiful facilities and great managers (for the most part). This, at least my department, is pretty laid back and it runs very smoothly. Low stress job.
Con: It is still a cubical farm. There is a lot of corporate non-sense that you have to put up with. There are still some unqualified, and not-so-great managers who sneak in to their positions from other companies. Hard to move up right now of course w/ the hiring freeze and the economy in general. We just went through a reorg so it was very unfun to work here for the last few months, but things are getting back on track now that the panic has subsided a bit.

Pro: Typically take a long term approach to business. Not worried about hitting quarterly numbers like public firms.
Con: Tend to focus on strategy and business plans and not on execution and getting things done.

Pro: Privately owned, provides flexibility. Great benefits but getting weaker. Good individual technology, blackberry, laptop, etc. Lots of smart, hardworking people there. Well known name, brand recognition. Morally responsible people for the most part with minimal backstabbing.
Con: Ownership has let too many outsiders come in and has not protected internal employees. Many top leaders have been allowed to leave. This is completely opposite their prior approach. People have to work very hard to succeed with little reward or recognition. 55-60 hour weeks are not uncommon and are expected. Management does not prioritize and simply jump from one focus to the next with no continuity. They do not allow an idea or effort to develop and show results. Refuse to ask the hard question and demand results. They are drowning under the weight of their own size and becoming more bureacratic by the day.

Summary: "Watch out -trouble ahead this company could go into a tailspin"
Pro:
Money and benefits

Name recogintion 

benefits such as health care and shares

strong legacy business model
Con:
uncertainty of management

impersonal

dysfunctional leaders 

bad culture

failure to stay ahead of compentition

unprofitable business ventures are hurting prospects

Summary: "Despite the recent events, all in all a good place to be"
Pro: With respect to the changes being made due to the economic downturn, through 2008 the benefits package was outstanding in my opinion.  Health care was well covered. Salary, bonus and profit sharing was a nice combo.  Additionally,  the work/family balance was very nice and there was a high level of flexibility.  I also liked the number of community volunteer activities that you could choose from.
Con: It had become a bloated company with too many senior level people (a number without staff to manage). Additionally, I believe the review process could use overhauling (mixed signals on ratings/ranking) coming from HR and the department management.

Pro:
Majority of managers respects work-life balance. 

Great training opportunities.

Encouragement to explore career opportunities.
Con:
Understaffed.

Lack of direction & focus w/ recent org changes.

Merit / bonus review process promotes mediocrity.

Summary: "Good and bad things but that is everywhere..."
Pro: Great benefits and the ability to move and grow within the company are the best reasons to work for Anonymous.
Con: Too much red tape and constant micro-managing can be suffocating.

Pro: Comprehensive benefits which include 401k matching, profit sharing, year end bonus, health care, etc.
Con: Full of processes.  It's hard to get things done with so much gatekeepers who need to approve anything that you do.

Pro: Excellent benefits (medical, 401k, vacation, education).  Overall good corporate culture.
Con: Office politics.  Unfocused idea of where the company is going.  Upper mgmnt to quick to use layoffs to change bottom line.

Pro: Extremely well recognised in the City and a lot of sway with companies and brokers; great opportunities to learn. A lot of freedom to run your own diary and pursue ways that you think will add value to the research process.
Con: Most of the fund managers and other analysts have their own agenda and so it can be quite fragmented in terms of communication, and accordingly recognition, unless you really make an effort.

Pro:
If you're in sales, there's a very clear path to follow.



You can have your eyes on a promotion starting on day one.



The pay is about on par with the rest of the industry but the 401k match and profit sharing at Anonymous are pretty hard to beat.
Con:
Beware of office politics.



The system they have in place for measuring productivity is hugely flawed.



Branch Managers enjoy a great deal of power.

BM's don't really do much besides interview candidates.

Summary: "New leaders across firm changing the culture"
Pro: I loved the people I worked with at Anonymous - smart, creative, hardworking, fun.  Most people care about the customer and work hard to provide great service.  Operations and Technology groups had many talented individuals and middle managers, but lacked a cohesive strategy and strong SVP management.  I had excellent training opportunities and career progression.  Anonymous was a great company for the 15 years I worked there.
Con: With the overhaul at the executive levels from 2007 onwards, and the revolving door of external hires at the highest levels, the frequency of organizational and strategic changes became intense.  Major layoffs took place in 2008 and early 2009, due in part (but not entirely) to the market turmoil.  The whole financial services field has been downsizing, so think carefully before you apply for a job at Anonymous if the stock market is still very rocky.  Be prepared to manage your career and build a good network.  Have a "Plan B" ready in case you get laid off.

Summary: "Good place to work when they want it to be"
Pro: Anonymous is one of the only equity research jobs where an undergrad can immediately become a lead analyst on 20+ companies with good access to top management of the companies they are researching.  There is also a strong history of talent that you will be surrounded by.  Pay is fair to good for the job.
Con: Management is not honest with employees about current situation of the company and compensation outlook; there has been significant turnover in Anonymous C-suite, and it is unclear what direction the company is heading; limited real time feedback on how well you are doing your job.

Pro: Good benefits and paid time off. There are opportunities to advance but in order to do so you basically have to be a perfect employee in the the eyes of management. Not worth the time trying to be a customer service rep when managers are constantly looking over your shoulder.
Con: Terrible work environment in their call center. Treated like a machine and little tolerance for mistakes.

Pro: Benefits, communication with internal employees about important events. Challenge of the job.
Con: Tough industry during down economy. Sometimes a thankless job.

Pro:
- Anonymous's downtown location can not be beat.  

- It's a great stepping stone for college graduates who want to work in the financial industry as there are (were) many job opportunities within the company.
Con: Sometimes you have to wonder how some colleagues in senior level positions ever got to where they are in the company.

Pro: THey pay is nice, hours aren't to bad..
Con: It's a rat race. You always have impossible goals, and are reminded daily when you are not where you should be.

Pro: The 7% 401k match is great, as long as it lasts. Anonymous is cutting everthing else, so I don't anticipate this to last.
Con: If you are not one of the director's or VP's favorites, don't expect a good raise or bonus. It helps to rent a vacation house near the VP's vacation residence.

Summary: "Perpetual reorganizations & layoffs caused them to shed their best talent & left behind mgmt. that disdains employees."
Pro: 401(k) match - There's not much else.  The thing I hear most from my coworkers is that this used to be a great place to work, and now it's just a job... just a paycheck.  I keep hearing people say that they can't wait for the economy to recover so they can find a job elsewhere.
Con: Low morale, little room for advancement, poor work/life balance, little regard for employees.  Poor lower and middle management that's insecure and willing to burn out their direct reports in order to keep their own jobs.

Pro: Up until recently the pay, bonus and shares program were very good.
Con: Very paranoid atmosphere and constant reorganizations make for too much time spent on sucking up and positioning for the next reorg.  Most of the bosses I worked for were not very dynamic or interesting people you can learn from.   More interested in using their employees to shield their shortcomings.

Pro:
Looks good on a resume,

Get time off when you need it,

Decent pay raises.
Con:
Promotions based on who you know. 

Lack of any real ability to express innovative thought. 

Cookie cutter expectations no reward for anything more than cookie cutter results.

Summary: "A shame what has happened to this once great company."
Pro: I have none to offer.  5 years ago I would have said a good place to work.  10 years ago a great place to work.
Con: Senior management is totally out of touch with the fact that morale is at an all time low and they are the reason.  We are a ship adrift at sea with no direction.  When Ned was fully in charge it was a much better place to work.

Pro: Well known brand and respected reputation in the industry (Financial Services). My personal manager and other low- to mid-range managers of highest caliber and integrity.
Con:
What the heck happened since Roger Lawson came on board two years ago???!?!??!? Deteriorating from the inside.. and fast. Hack job management and direction setting at highest level(s) of management. Right hand doesn't know what the left is doing.... whack 20% of best people based on "secret sauce magic formula" in recent layoffs -- meanwhile setting new strategic direction in the areas which they just cut the top performers.

Ridiculous.

Firm has a stranglehold on employees financial life - and by extension the rest of employee's family also. Red tape upon red tape to make trades in personal ROTH or investment accounts - and onerous disclosure requirements (4 times a year) to meet a standard intended for Fund managers - not Sysadmins.

Morale in the tank. Lowest I've ever seen it in 11+ years. Excellent environment if you want to ensure you retain the poor talent and ensure the best talent leaves the company.

For example: Keep putting out ungodly levels of production.. and oh, by the way - no merit raises regardless of your rating or value to the firm -- and year end bonus (a significant incentive to reach stated goals) is a big question mark. Therefore highest performers treated exactly the same as poorest performers.

Attitude of "Where else are you going to go? There are no jobs right now." ... Ha! Just watch.

Pro: The people I have worked with for the past 10 years have been great and have made it easy to come to work.  In the beginning there were many perks and management really made you feel good about working at Anonymous.  The campus is beautiful.
Con: The culture is very political.  Your manager may have been hired becuase of a realtionship he/she had with a director or VP not becuase they were great at their job.  Anonymous is not a place for great managers or leaders of people.  Since the introduction of Six Sigma Anonymous has become an assembly line, you have your job to do and I have my job to do and I will not help you becuase I may be held responsibel if something goes wrong.

Summary: "A little big and bureaucratic but you get to work with some of the best people in the industry."
Pro: Strong brand name, career development, you can work anywhere else after being at Anonymous Investments.  Growing the business even now.
Con: Much politics, senior management seem very remote due to number of management layers, left hand doesn't always know what the right hand is doing.

Summary: "For the moment, advancement comes fastest for "teams" of one.  Blue chip employees need to be patient."
Pro: One of the best places to gain basic training.  This is a company struggling to find an identity for the 21st century... which gives it tremendous potential (for either success or decline).  Individual experience is dependent primarily on the quality of your immediate manager and their immediate superiors, as would be expected in any large (35,000+ employee) multinational firm trying to redefine itself.
Con: The unique history of this (non-public) enterprise provided a most credible corporate foundation to build loyalty between the Johnson family and their employees.  However, executive arrivals in the last two years were voluminous... accompanied by even more voluminous reports of executive departures... some of the brightest  long-term Anonymous executives plotted their own exits to Putnam Investments and Morgan Stanley.  Other long term Anonymous executives quietly and abruptly found themselves outside the evershrinking "circle of trust" atop the Anonymous pyramid, creating the largest leadership vacuum since the JFK tragedy in Dallas.   The Anonymous workforce planners look outside the company to hire leaders, so it's unlikely that anyone with mid-level or senior-level leadership abilities and aspirations will reach their full potential through long-term employment and loyalty to the company.

Summary: "Anonymous needs to show me the money!"
Pro: 401k match of 7%, profit sharing, medical/dental/vision benefits, even know we offered Roth 401k to our clients for the past year or more just last week we now get to participate...why so long?...voluntary time off unpaid but useful when you need time off for appointments/vacation. I've liked my managers! People are cool for the most part!
Con: with the phones are schedules are dictated by a console...so a 15 min break can't be more or less. Unpaid lunch without the option of not taking a lunch. Not enough money!

Pro:
Excellent work culture, work-life balance is well maintained.

Strong Ethics-genuine effort to keep ethics foremost important

Transperent deals-employee is informed about many of the deals happening inside
Con: Some of the policies are not helping employees but middleman.For example, when you are relocated to foreign country, they wont give the accomodation expenses to Employee,but get an apartment for a huge money.

Pro:
Salary is better compared to services company.

Work pressure  may be less compared to service companies.
Con:
Top heavy. Too many managers and directors. 

Managers, particularly lady managers are incompetent.

They don't do layoff, they give N rating and ask you to leave.

If you are a hard core techie, better don't join. Most of the work will be legacy code maintenance.

Summary: "A great place to work IF you pick the right business unit"
Pro: A place with strong work ethics and values.  I know that the work that I do matters for our customers.  I have learned much during the eleven years I have been working there.
Con: Work life balance might be impacted.  Really take care to ask anybody you know in Anonymous before taking a position the reputation of the business unit that you are considering.

Summary: "Many who have worked here for a long time"
Pro: do not appreciate how luckty they are to owrk here and how high the quality of work life is.  People are top notch.
Con: Not a place to be looking for promotions right now but where is?  Consensus environment and many silo's make forward progress slow.

Pro: Even though it is not the same company as it was 10 year ago it is still a good place to work if you have a drive and can work in fast paced and volatile environment
Con: A lot of turmoil and politics, management has good talks, but don't really follow up on their words and policies.

Pro:
Good Salary, but management is poor with people skills.

Anonymous is an old dinosaur with aged executives that should have been out to pasture when they hit 55.

This is a young person's game....
Con:
Poor work/life balance.

Management treated me like a piece of disposable waste from day one!

I think given the size and complexities of this organization, it would take a total restructuring to accomplish and as I said previously, old management can't cut it.

Pro:
Privately Held company

Management supports variety in career paths
