Con: Very hierarchical.  Skip level communication is not necessarily embraced.   Sometimes the tail wags the dog instead of the other way around.  Seems to be a cultural thing.

Pro: Pay for the liscencing and training, a good way to get a quick introduction into the financial services world...they pay and train you while you get real life experience...good benefit package
Con: your tied to your cubicle on the phone..not much freedom during the work hours, everything is scheduled...micromanaged

Summary: "They are very nice to deal with, but they overwork people.  Every single minute has to be accounted for."
Pro: They pay well and if you are smart, punctual, worker bee type and do not like to take time off this is the place to make money.
Con: Sometimes you have a hard time catching your breath.

Pro: As good a place as any to work in retail financial sales
Con: You don't own clients, captive environment, very political, don't think just sell

Summary: "Company only looking at immediate bottom line ... no long-term view."
Pro: Working with talented individuals.  Salaries and benefits are above average.
Con: Poor communication between groups due to organizational silos.  Upper management focus is on short-term success, not long-term growth. When times get bad it's every man for himself!

Pro: large technology investment so they were moving in every direction at once, recognizable brand so it looks good on your resume
Con: too many politiics and hard to get recognition for hard work, limited opportunity for advancement and the office conditions were cubicle hell

Pro:
People are wonderful to work with...and for....for the most part.

Advancement is possible when YOU WORK for it

Educational opportunities abound!  

Will hire without a college degree

Great benefits!
Con:
Lack a viable payscale where experience counts

Unclear direction where training doesn't = current projects or products Right hand and left hand need to get thier act together

Too much politics!  YIKES  good ole boy/girl club!

Summary: "My thoughts on working at Anonymous for 5 years"
Pro: Bennefits the 401k match and profit sharing are great.  Good place to get some experience in the financial services industry when you are first getting started.  They also pay for your training and licensing.
Con: Pay is not great seems like they should pay better for a professional position.  Yearly raises are small and moving between positions is about 5% bump if anything.

Pro: Food pay and benefits when I was hired.  Good location.
Con: They are cutting back the benefits.  No raise this year, cutting profit sharing, no bonus, changed the way they rank the employees for reviews.

Summary: "Long hours and little recongnition.  Management expects the world of employees but some how managers are able to slack!"
Pro: Tenure with the company and overall hard working people.
Con: No raise this year.  If you are exceeding expectations you are now considered proficient.  Too many hours and no recognition.  Contractors seem to have a better deal with no accountability compared to full time employees.

Summary: "Anonymous has changed, but not for the better."
Pro: Benefits were very good. In the early years there were people to share knowledge and people cared about one another. Back then it was possible to move ahead based on your work ethic and accomplishments.
Con: In recent years the company has created an atmosphere that seems to breed hostility and a need to put others down in order to keep a manager happy. No knowledge sharing because the general feeling is, if I don't tell anyone else, they cannot take my job away. Does not work, your job is probably going overseas anyway. Overseas not held to the standards stateside employees are. So it's not perfect, no problem. Not a way I ever thought Anonymous would behave.

Pro: The company is proud to follow bleeding-edge technologies for its products. There's good learning learning in new technologies. The company is also proud to share and educate about its systems architecture design as part of employee training.
Con: The company is very particular about expenditure in recent years and is ready to move employees to other locations to cut costs.

Pro: Salary is lower than industry standard, but made up for by benefit packages and little perks (fitness reimbursement, computer assistance, etc.) Great place to learn the ropes of the industry, sales techniques, etc.  Stable company, constantly changing internally to evolve with economy or client investment demand.
Con: I am in customer service so I've been getting burned out by the demanding customer expectations and Anonymous's policy that the "customer is always right".  I notice the sales roles have experienced greater pressure to fulfill goals due to the economy.  We have been short staffed for a long time, and they are slow to fill the roles (either internally or externally, and competition is FIERCE) puting added pressure and stress on the remaining employees.

Summary: "Past performance is not indicative of future returns-"
Pro: Finest facilities.  Great benefits and time off.  Flexible working hours for sales positions.  Terrific resources for information and training. done
Con: Lower level managers tend to be dropouts from the telephone rep positions.  They typically assume the "we" vs. "them" attitude toward reps.   The problem is that they stop listening to anything from below and develop a cutthroat attitude about their own careers.   Blackballing promotions of reps is common.   A manager has the last word on whether they want their rep to be promoted, regardless of who would like to hire them.    You will see managers advance many times before you move on yourself.

Pro: Good people, Good environment, reasonable work life balance. Comparative level of success with offshore teams.  Performance review process was reasonably clear as work had been done to improve on better linking this with the bonus to differentiate between staff.
Con: Pay could be improved, transport links to office were not good, if you missed the private coach slot due to a late train then you had to pay Â£20 for a taxi to the office.

Summary: "Good place to start but don't stay long."
Pro:
They pay for your licensing.

It's a good place to get your foot in the financial door.

Not a bad salary for a kid fresh out of college.
Con:
Little, if any, upward mobility.

Lots of interoffice politics.

Little time for office training or job shadowing of other positions in the company.

Pro: Pay is decent for young college grads; also good benefits.  401k - they potentially match up to 17% after some tenure,  Most of the people you work with are decent people.  Almost everyone realizes it's not the most exciting or fulfilling job; it's like everyone's in the same boat.  We can always connect with each other based upon bad calls we've had or some worthless reprimand from management.
Con:
Since the first day I've been there, it's felt like we're in elementary school or some nice form of a concentration camp.  You are almost told verbatim what to say.  The call model is a decent model, but management needs to understand that not every call is worth the whole effort.  Not client needs our guidance services, not everyone is an active trader.  



Also, there is a large amount of knowledge that is needed.  Not that it is necessarily a bad thing, but the environment is horrible.  There are several different computer programs we use for various things.  One for trading, one for problem resolution, one for money movement.  A small mistake or overlook is looked heavily down upon.  If, God forbid, you make a "trade error," you are reprimanded even if it had little to no impact on the company (I've also had trade errors that made the company money).  



Even if the mistake was question that 99 out of 100 people don't know about how our internal systems work, there is supposedly always an answer in OLR.  It stands for OnLine Reference.  It's basically the Anonymous bible for trading and service.  Problem is that OLR must have been written by either a mad robot or Ned Johnson himself.  It's not written well at all and even sometimes contain mistakes that we still "should have known."  



We are given several metrics that we must meet that grade us on various call aspects; these include: average call time, scheduling efficiency (how closely you fit into a minute by minute schedule daily), and % of time either in available to talk to on a call.  



As reps we are expected to "put the customer first" at all times.  They should really rephrase that to "put the customer first only on that phone call."  After the call ends, so does any contact that we have with that person.  Why is this a problem?  About 25% of the calls you take are problems that may take awhile to fix.  There is no researching or following up on problems after the call.  Managers criticize calling back customers.  



Also, about 92% of managers are really horrible people.

Summary: "Once a good company to work for but now it is just a sweat shop"
Pro: There are a number of different jobs, so you can move around and gain a lot of knowledge about different practices, procedures, environments, etc.
Con: At one time Anonymous was a premier company to work for but over the past 5 or 6 years it has gone in the toilet.  There is no longer any loyality to anyone, no matter how much knowledge they have, how beneficial they have been to the company, and their peers.  It is all about the bottom line and if you were paid too much, look out you may just get axed.

Summary: "No longer a good place to work"
Pro: Benefits are very good. Lots to learn. Can be a good place to establish a career.
Con: Anonymous was a great place to work in the 90s but that's all changed. There has been a great deal of pressure on the employees since at least 2003 to perform. Review ratings are absurd. You can literally perform with absolute excellence all year and still be rated average...after all the managers are all under pressure to meet the numbers and submit ratings within the allotted quotas. So...it the whole department had a banner year don't think the whole department is rewarded...this would never happen and it's grossly unfair. You're expected to suck it up and move on...until the next layoff then you're gone. Who needs that!!!

Summary: "Anonymous has very little regard for its employees"
Pro:
The experience is good, and my fellow colleagues are among the brightest in the field.  

However, management in London is very aggressive about getting as much as possible from employees, while paying as little as possible.  For example, in 2007 they gave such bad annual salary increases, that they had to reverse their decision because they suddenly realised they would have huge numbers leaving the investment team because everybody was so disgruntled...we were all called in individually 2 weeks after the 1st annual salary review mtg and told 'good news, we've decided to increase your remuneration'.  Literally, every year the company decides how little they can get away with paying..they push their employees to complete disillusionment.  I have never worked in such a negative environment...most people I talk to are waiting for the market to pick up so that we can jump ship.
Con: A very aggressive managment style that has no regard for their employees.....msg is clearly given that we can be easily replaced because of what they regard as the 'strength of the brand'.   Annual reviews are conducted by mgmt in the manner of how little they can get away with paying, rather than rewarding performance.  They string you along that next time it will be better, but most people realise after being through the process 3-4 times, that this is a continued practice, promoted by the owners who demand an 18% or so margin from the business.  We've even had it explained to us that our bonuses are down because this margin of profit to the Johnson Family must be preserved!!  I find it hard to believe that the company can continue this mgmt strategy towards employees, as morale is so low.  Once they've destroyed the goodwill among employees....as I've seen happen over and over again, when people realise that the promise of reward for hard work and exceptional performance is only a carrot they dangle with no intention of delivering....it is almost impossible to rebuild.

Pro: Good place to work--ethical and good values.  Great training and support for new associates.
Con: Sometimes to much politics.  Senior management is a little too worried about senior management most of the time.

Pro:
- Pay for Performance

- Excellent career development (if you choose to take it)
Con:
- Shifts in senior leadership leads to swings in strategic direction. 

- Down is the new up every 6 - 8 months.

Summary: "Good pay for the job you do."
Pro: Flexible schedule, great benefits (profit sharing, 401k match, HSA), good people to work with.
Con: high pressure to sell managed products, no recognition for helping clients if you use anything other than managed products

Summary: ""Would not suggest  working at Anonymous long term""
Pro: The company has very good benefits (aka golden handcuffs). The company is also good at training its employees to understand the basics of the investment industry.
Con: The management is poorly run, and is only concerned with it's bottom line. This is ironic because we work for a private company, yet profits are held to as high a standard as it would a public company with shareholders. The company expects it's clients to be treated well, however they choose not to treat their employees well.

Pro: Great opportunities and great to with whom to work
Con: Large organization that doesn't move as quickly as it can to seize opportunities

Summary: "Great pay, confused management, terrible HR/Employee relations"
Pro: Salary, bonus and Benefits are great - almost too great because people tend to stay there too long because of the money.
Con: The semi-annual performance reviews are a bad joke.  Management has no idea what you're doing and they base the 'feedback' on nothing more than their gut feeling of what they think you do.

Pro: Within 2 years, opportunities to help train new hires, work in multi-practice customer support, and advance to provide interim team support have left great aspirations to continue to strive for success.  They do not reward showing off or doing what's expected, so to get ahead, you need to network and do something for your manager like being a load-lifter in some way to show your worth, in addition to doing your job well.
Con: There are so many people, it can be hard to stand out.  Not all opportunities will apply to you or your business unit and sometimes information regarding availability might not be available with much notice.

Pro: The profit sharing and health benefits are amazing.  There are not many companies that can even come close to matching the benefits.
Con: The actual pay is lower that the average. However, the benefits make up the difference. I would highly recommend Anonymous Investments to anyone.

Summary: "If you enjoy "office politics" and backstabbing, this is the place for you."
Pro: Benefits and 401k are excellent for Permanent employee's.
Con: Too many office politics but if you kiss enough butt and enjoy backstabbing others you will be fine.

Summary: "Very challenging job having to deal with often unhappy customers."
Pro: You get good benefits and a fair number of vacation days.
Con: Management is difficult to deal with and it is hard to get promoted.  You often compete against others who are "buddy buddy" with the interviewer which means they get picked over you for better jobs.

Pro: Benefits are great. 401k, profit sharing, vacation days. Good place to learn investments. Have opportunity to move between departments and get to know different sides of business.
Con: Work place environment is not great. Too many layers of management. Big pressure to sell higher margin products. Margins are more important then people.

Pro:
- Private company so they can focus on the long term

- Genuine focus on integrity and customer service

- Heavy emphasis on  IT
Con:
- There has been creeping bureaucracy within IT

- Not a very social place to work (e.g., spouse aren't invited to the Xmas party)

Pro: The sky is the limit if you are a motivated, talented individual looking to grow within the organization.  Opportunities continue to be created and presented to talented individuals without office politics.
Con: Find many "warm bodies" showing-up every day just looking to receive the outstanding benefits package presented to all employees.

Pro:
-Portrays a good image of how it cares for employees. 

-The profit sharing and match for the 401k is outstanding and the work environment is decent. 

-Stable job environment, do not like laying off employees.

Fair amount of time off for vacation and maternity or paternity leave.

-Clients are sometimes good and sometimes bad to work with.
Con:
-All jobs are very much dumbed down, verymuch top-down management.

-Gradually increasing benefits cost to employees, next year, health care costs will rise substantially.

-Very limited upward growth for higher paying rep based jobs.  (> 75k)

-Very, very political and favorite rep driven. Managers are notorious for promoting best friends

-Easy to manipulate the "system" and get credit for stuff reps don't actually do.

-Feels like people are treated as "human capital" and not assets to the firm.

-Higher education does very little for you. A college degree is all you need and lots of people don't even have that. 

-Very little innovation and slow moving. The 1000 lb Gorilla.

-Very much a CYA environment

Pro: Good place to get licenses and necessary training.
Con: Being attached to a phone can be a grind. There also seemed to be a disconnect with promotions because the criteria was not consistent from quarter to quarter.

Pro: Smart people, access to great technology and professional development opportunities.  I feel I am challenged every day to do my best.
Con: Can be a challenging place in terms of work and life balance.  A very complex organization which is not easy to navigate due to its complexity.

Summary: "If you are looking to build a carrier and develop sales skills LOOK ELSWHERE"
Pro: Great 401K and profitsharing benefits, decent vacation paid time off, great for starting and entering brokerage and investments world, great training , awesome tools and platform, a lot of hand  holding towards begging in one word, if you are just starting this is a place to be.
Con:
Company is privatelly own ,which means top managment is forced upon , as natural way of passing on wealth.One of the top executives has no knowledge of various market segments which impacts potential growth of certain areas in the market, example fixed income. This company has so many products and many are Great , affordable and trully sell themselves but managment is lacking fundamental  marketing and sales skills. Lower end managers have came to their positons because they stayed many years with a company , and trully if they were that good they wouldn't stay in those places long.A lot of managers don't understand what company and business growth trully means and are very micro oriented on to a specific task and unable to view and understand a big picture. 

For someone very ambitious and creative there is no place within this company it's too big and there are many barriers when it comes to sharing ideas.Once you get to higher level sales there is no proper training , it's lacking because managment is lacking those skills.

Pro: Top notch talent, solid benefits (albeit chipped away in recent years), culture pre - Lawson.
Con: Politics and egos have overtaken the culture.  The culture used to be superior, employees fully and happily engaged, then off-shoring and new blood became all the rage.  What we have now is a solid "C" effort, with politics and egos challenging our future.

Pro:
Very generous benefits - tuition reimbursement, computer & fitness reimbursement, $1:$1 company match on 401k up to 7%, free access to professional books with Safari Online, etc.

Comfortable working facilities.

Some really great managers (amongst those not so great).

Many career paths if you take the iniative to learn new areas of the business and are willing to relocate.
Con:
Unstable job security.

Frequent turnover of senior leaders which results in constant changes in direction.

Company is in a cost cutting mode and looking for opportunities to ship job overseas, even to places that do not have the experience to perform well (save a dime now to spend a dollar later to fix things up!)

New hires seem to be coming in at salary rates lower than what they used to offer - another cost cutting strategy.

Pro: Generous compensation, lots of training & educational programs for interns.  Challenging work.  Friendly people for the most part. Great 401k plans and retirement benefits.
Con: Opportunities for upward mobility in the company are limited.  Management can take a narrow focus, often has a hard time seeing the big picture

Pro:
Good place to work. 

Lots of  scope for  promotion. Friendy PPL.   Nice location, big campus.  No taxs in New Hampshore.
Con: Nothing big at this time. However  just regular  concerns.  Working  hours  long. No compensation for putting extra hours as such.

Pro: Its a good place to get some experience either while going to college or when you just get out.
Con: Once you have been there 24 months its time to go somewhere else to get better pay

Pro: It really helps that I love what I do, but Anonymous is the best place I've ever worked.  Sure, I wish I was paid more, could advance faster, etc. (who wouldn't??), but on a day-to-day basis, I couldn't ask for more.  Anonymous has a wonderful company culture.  I work in an environment full of professionals, very competent at what they do, and everyone is extremely supportive.  Positive feedback is offered much more frequently than any other job I've had.  Management is incredible at communicating to employees what is expected of them, helping them when they're struggling, and letting them know how the company is doing.  The benefits are pretty good, and the flexibility available to help employees with their work-life balance is nothing short of amazing.
Con: I can only think of one consistent negative--I've had a few managers who pretty much ignored me or gave me bogus answers when I needed help, but even so it still happens much less of the time than any other job I've held.

Summary: "Very controlling place to work, political, not fun"
Pro: I worked at FITSCO (which is no longer in SLC) servicing 403b accounts.  The only bright spot about the company is that you get to learn a lot about mutual funds and about investment products.
Con: Management is incompetent.  Management says Anonymous is a "meritocracy" which is not true.  Very political in order to get ahead.  Managers don't have your best interests at heart.  You will do the same thing over and over again until you want to throw-up (no job rotation).

Summary: "Very demanding environment.  Opportunities are there, but you must take initiative"
Pro: A lot of opportunities, if you take initiative to pursue them.  Very good benefits
Con: You can quickly become pigeon-holed into a very narrow functions and limit your career advancement.  Too much politics not always acknowledge.

Summary: "Good place to WORK For Middle management"
Pro:
Pros:

> Good compensation

> Work Life Balance

> Promotions as applicable
Con:
Cons:

Senior management from US control the decision

Less project and long approval process

Summary: "Very good company to work with. Greal teams. Just a lot of layoffs due to poor economical conditions."
Pro:
Friendly environment.

Flexible work schedule.

Lot to  learn
Con: Lot of layoffs. no job security.

Pro:
Retirement benefits are realtivley good compared to other companies.

Long term incentives exist to those with high potential.

The talent level of employees is exceptional
Con:
Becomes more difficult to work here each year.  All incentives for staying at the company are paired back with the downsizing of beenfits each year.  



Also, in the past 5 years the company has been developing and implementing a site strategy that has caused numerous people to be moved all over the country.  Taking the package also does not mean safety in your job as numerous people have been let go only a year into moving.

Summary: "It seems like a good job to start a career"
Pro: great benefits, good team, no long hours, great vacation
Con: the job itself might be boring and monotonous. Because you have to talk to people all the time it wears you out. Also, there is no freedom in your actions, you just do what you are told

Pro: Fantastic benefits over the years, although these are being cut back.  Great people, although the level of tension has increased in the last few years.
Con: See the "pros" section, too.  Once you reach a certain level (somewhere around the high Director / low VP level), there are fewer opportunities to advance and you're more likely to be cut.

Pro: I had a great professional experience as an intern with Anonymous Investments.  Although the firm is very big, I found my managers to be quite accessible and friendly.
Con: I really don't have anything that is negative to say about Anonymous.  They provided me with one of my first internship opportunities on Wall Street.  I was very grateful.

Summary: "Good company to work for if that is your domain."
Pro: Good work culture, lots of room to learn new things. Various areas which are new and can be explored within the company.
Con: Lot of systems interacting with each other, sometimes gets overwhelming. Lots of processes, kill the real importance of work and time consuming.

Summary: "Anonymous is a good company to work for."
Pro: Opportunities to work for different types of businesses and different roles while staying in the same company - dedicated to using the latest technologies - lots of training and support in career development available - great benefits
Con: The biggest downsides are that you can't earn more than 4 weeks vacation time and it can be highly demanding and stressful

Summary: "Management and HR just do what the private shareholders tell them to do"
Pro: My fellow financial analysts are among the smartest in the industry.  A good place to have on your CV for a couple of years because of the formerly good reputation of this company.
Con:
This privately held company is only focused on delivering profit to the Johnson family and other shareholders.  Our management here in the UK is here simply to act on instruction, and HR are a joke.  Having worked for other Tier 1 public competitors it is amazing to see the poor quality of HR employees (big titles, low pay and below-average qualifications for such a large investment house)

 - who just implement instructions, with no focus on a happy and contented workforce.  I am getting more and more discouraged at the treatment of us as employees.  The morale is so bad that it is a key talking point- most fellow analysts that I speak are just waiting for an upturn in market conditions, to make a speedy exit to a better-paying, and more employee-friendly environment.

Pro:
Good 401K/Profit Share

Educational Reimbursement

Friendly atmosphere

Good location for traffic/parking

Company is very clear in communicating job responsibilities within each role

Great place for young person to start/get licensed
Con:
Job Performance and experience have little or nothing to do with advancement. Most promotions go to younger less experienced reps and those that have "branded themselves"  properly. IMO the "Brand" they seek is someone that never questions anything and is perceived to have a clean slate that they can mold to do things as they say "The Anonymous Way' . My new employer values my experience and sees it as an asset rather than a liability.



Most opportunities are lateral and involve little or no pay increase 



They are so concerned with everyone staying within their predefined roles that customers get passed to 3,4, even 5 people just to get a 401K rolled over. Along the way each rep is charged with getting some sort of lead.

Summary: "Annuitys are a small fun group at Anonymous."
Pro: Great people, lots of talent.  Excellent benefits, strong company.
Con: Difficult to move into Management with such a small department to choose from.  Pay is minimum.  Job can get repetitive at times.  At time you can feel micromanaged.

Summary: "Felt like a bit of a hypocrite"
Pro: Good salary and benefits. Good image. Good, wide product line. Very good computer systems.
Con: Changed the compensation plan continuously over 5 years. They promote an image of being independent and unbiased but push various product lines and have goals that must be met, even when those money management products are very poor performers.

Pro: Incredible job security, profit sharing and matching at 7%, full dental medical and vision. You will receive great off and on the job training on important financial issues,  you will not find any other financial services company that takes you out of production in order to train you. Get 90% of your education costs paid for with CFP, MBA classes. Overall great benefits, great training.
Con: The vast majority of employees will work in a call center so you will work in a cube and have no independence. You will be preached to about meaningless statistics and will take dozens of phone calls everyday. Management is unclear about the direction of the internal career paths because the directors will not pass it down, definitely an issue. Pay is mediocre in comparison to other firms, but you job security is huge in our industry and you can be a bump on a log for the next 40 years if you want.

Summary: "A solid company overall, but experiencing significant changes."
Pro: Anonymous Investments is a very stable company with decent job security, a solid reputation, smart people, and a solid brand name.  Decent opportunities for career changes (a large number of locations and divisions).
Con: Anonymous is a very siloughed company and is going through significant changes.  The companies leadership has transitioned numerous times in the past few years, signaling that their strategic direction can be lacking.

Pro: The benefits are good.  They are a leader in 401k services.  They should have good benefits.  I know people in other departments that love Anonymous, but I would never recommend a job in the call center.
Con: Micro managed to the max.  They control every minute of your day.  They measure you in every way.  The same thing over and over every day.

Summary: "This is a great company to work for and has consistently strived to live up to the trust of investors, and clients."
Pro: Great collegial culture, opportunities exist to learn,, Management support, performance-driven culture, meritocracy - based, privately owned company and company believes in a culture of continuous impovement.
Con: You need to be able to network to uncover career opportunities. If you produce results then it is a great company but if you are not a consistent producer- start packing your bags.

Pro: great benefits package, stingy on vacation, compensation should change to be more competitive
Con: too many layers of management, poor communications to employees on changes withing the company. Reps and Salespeople are just human capital unless you are in the top 5%.

Summary: "Your Experience at Anonymous Varies Depending on Your Manager; CONSTANT reorganization"
Pro: Benefits, including tuition reimbursement, 401K match, and annual bonuses are excellent; for the most part, it is a stable place to work, earn a good salary and interact with nice, smart people.
Con:
If you decide to work at Anonymous, make sure you like change -- there lots of it here (or Kaisan as the chairman calls it) especially within leadership.  Often times a new manager is brought in with a new "strategic vision" and you basically discard all the work you've done over the past 9 months and start over...this can happen again and again and can be frustrating...



I worked in several different business units during my 9 years with the company, and because the company is simply so huge, I found that if you have a good manager, you'll have a pleasant experience and receive appropriate performance and financial reviews and feedback, etc. BUT if your manager is one of many who are not good at being managers or for whatever reason don't "click" with you, it can become a miserable experience. HR tends to side with management, and it's extremely difficult to remove an incompetent or toxic boss from Anonymous.  Normally, you can weed these individuals out during your interview, but as I mentioned previously, Anonymous re-orgs so frequently, 90% of individuals hired end up working for different managers and doing different work than they signed on to do.  



You need to be prepared to roll with the punches and have a very flexible nature if you choose to work at Anonymous.



As far as promotional opportunity, there's no set rule such as after 2 years, you get promoted - i've seen individuals be promoted after 6 months or never promoted after many, many years.  Because your individual manager basically exclusively drives the promotion process, making sure he/she likes you is key.  When it comes to advancement, doing good work is often secondary to building a good relationship with your direct manager.

Pro: Pay, benefits, people, industry, facilities
Con: Matrixed organized...being flattened, paternalistic, does not value outside credentials

Pro:
- Very competitive pay and benefits

- Generally smart, experienced people who care about what they do

- Company known for honesty and integrity

- Variety of opportunities within the company
Con:
- Highly skilled and experienced people doing entry-level jobs (MBAs just working on endless Powerpoint slides)

- Constant organizational change without any apparent benefit

- People are subjected to illogical geographical moves that don't make business sense

- Too often, teams spend 100s of hours collecting data and building a case and the business decision is made based on a "hunch" from someone in senior management

Summary: "Overall good experience, maybe I have a bad manager"
Pro: Pay is good, hours are good, benefits are good.  Generally have a lot of flexibility with how I manage my day.
Con: Manager tends to play favorites and seems to be a ceiling once you have reached a particular level that prevents further advancement.

Summary: "Average pay. career path varies depend on manager"
Pro:
- good name to put in your resume

- smart people 

- reasonable working hour

- management is supportive on internal transfer or relocation
Con:
- base salary looks ok, but t bonus is minimal. total package is below the market

- promotion is hard

- senior management keeps changing

Pro: Great benefits.  Medical coverage and 401k are second to none.  Also very generous time off allocation.
Con: Overall, unsatisfied with the job.  It is what it is, which is a CALL CENTER.  Very little job satisfaction.  If you enjoy a call center job and being tied to a phone for 10 hrs a day, then you wouldn't mind it.

Summary: "Large privately held corporation with talented hard working people."
Pro:
- Lots of growth opportunities for those that work hard

- Very competitive benefit package

- Great corporate culture

- High integrity and charitable community partner

- Employees are empowered to make decisions independently 

- Smart talented employees
Con:
- Internal re-organizations are unpredictable and never ending

- Project teams are geographically dispersed across different time zones and countries and it is highly likely that you will never have the opportunity to ever meet face-to-face with some of your co-workers.

-  Rely too heavily on conference calls to negotiate concensus

Pro: it gave a great opportunity to improve Analytical and communicative skills, especially for someone who just started a professional career.
Con: It required a lot of effort to catch up with the hours and it was too crowded to be able to show yourself to managers to go up.

Pro:
Occasional perks were nice, but did not make up for lousy work conditions.

Decent benefits package.

Good support for successfully obtaining licenses.

Offered voluntary time off (see cons).
Con:
Sometimes stuck with bad hours.

Difficult to get promoted.

Voluntary time off.

Management was very deceitful with promises of promotions.

Unrealistic metric goals.

Pro: Great people, lots of opportunities.
Con: Upper management is always changing.  No consistency.  Much more political than it used to be.

Summary: "Anonymous Technology Group (subsid. of Anonymous Investments) seems to run smoothly, but is falling apart at the seams."
Pro:
- Decent Pay & Benefits, it's that's your main priority

- The company is moving away from working in silos; that's a plus for those whose skills lie in developing projects.

- The strength is in the contract people who are serious about their work and are very professional. If you have a choice to work with the contracted groups of people, you're more likely to have a good experience and can minimize interactions with the main tech support people and their management.
Con:
-  Probably the worst aspect of working at FTG is the "high school environment" and complete lack of professionalism. When you begin working there, the environment smacks of high school popularity groups. Yuck! And it only becomes worse with time. As much as one tries to remain professional it is difficult to avoid being pulled or pushed, one way or another.  I watched the group of support staff ostracize a former team member and leader because that person was promoted to a position that was ancillary to the support tasks. As I said, it is like a group of mean girls in high school and the guys just kind of follow along. What a sad environment.



-There are 'team leaders" within the support group, and those who are serious about getting their work done and doing an excellent job, easily standout from the rest.  Worst seems to be the bizarre nature of relationships between Senior Management and some of the employees who have been around for along time. These "older" support workers as it turns out, started at FTG at the same time as their now manger.  However, once the other person was promoted, and now holds a position of superior management over the first worker, the relationship between the two naturally has an uncomfortable strain even if it is not clearly evident to all. What was most obvious to those of us outside of this type of bizarre relationship is that the people still hanging around among the worker bees could easily see the passive aggressive behavior. In addition when a fresh new employee full of ideas is assigned to work with one of these people, the older worker bees exploit the new employees mercilessly. Since the newcomers are likely on the outside of the group of people, they don't stand a chance and if anything doesn't go as planned, the newcomers end up getting reprimanded by Senior Mgmt. in place of the worker bees. This ultimately creates a watch out for #1 environment in addition to the vicious "get rid of #2" nature of the workers. If you work there, always watch your back - trust no one - be friendly, but make no friends - and document everything you do to CYA.



- Poor leadership in management - mgmt. often does not realize (chooses not to realize?)  who is actually shouldering the work and who is slacking off. The nature of the "you're in" vs. "you're out" environment only serves to undermine anyone speaking up.



- Higher ups laid off the better managers in late 2008; all that left is those who don't draw healthy boundaries nor can they manage their own people because they have way too much on their plates.



- FTG component of Anonymous is shifting more and more of its human resources & capital over to India. The people we support are becoming increasingly frustrated with this as the quality of service decreases. Senior Management is aware of this but puts on a happy face to avoid being laid off as their own counterparts were.

Pro:
Profit Sharing

401k Match

overall pay and benefits
Con:
Inflexible hours

Constant unnecessary stress due to unstructured branch duties

There is little distinction between employee job functions in local branches.  Financial Consultants handle nearly all aspects of financial planning, account service, answering service related phone calls all day and even handling walk in traffic at front counter.   Planning any given day is next to impossible due to conflicting job functions

Summary: "Good work life balance, work and growth are not good"
Pro:
The best work-personal life balance (I hardly worked more than 9 hours a day during 3 years).

Good compensation compared to service providers, less variable & more fixed pay.

People are very professional and diplomatic. Very less politics. Management is approachable.

Good facilities like free transport, food etc.
Con:
Quality of work is not good, all the time you'll be doing the maintenance and enhancement work. Slow in adopting new technologies. Not the company to look for, if you want to stay technical.

Top heavy, there are almost equal number of managers & directors compared to developers (hope i'm not exaggerating it too much :) ). No growth prospects.

Everything is driven from US, management is a very good obeyer of their US counterparts. Though they talk about taking lot of good initiatives I hardly saw them being useful.

In fact the management is good & capable (by their qualification & experience) but fail to get good amount of work from US. Though FMR India is a captive centre for more than 6 years now, there are more critical projects with Infy & Patni than FMR India.

Very less onsite opportunities, especially for techies.

Summary: "Good benefits, poor pay, constant management change, little respect for employees"
Pro: Used to be a good company to work for, still a good brand on Resume, colleagues at the Analyst & Fund Manager level were smart.
Con: Poor pay.  Management constantly changes the strategic direction - every 6 months the investment team is presented with a new plan.  Get the impression they are constantly in fear of losing their job as performance is pretty bad, so get out of jail card is a new 'plan'.  Building fiefdoms is a key activity of middle-management, especially on the DOR team.  HR just seems to follow management around to see what they are required to do next - no strategic direction at all, 'yes-man' mentality.  Anonymous pays so badly that it really is not a long-term career option - benefits to your Resume after 1 year are more or less the same as after 5 years and even 10 - so makes sense to leave after 3-4 years.  However, the most disappointing thing about this company, is that there is no concern for employees, you are just a cog in the wheel.

Summary: "PAS is a great place to work. Great people, great atmosphere, great compensation. I would definitely recommend it."
Pro: The high pay, good hours, and manageable workload.
Con: The opportunity for upward movement is limited and many people end up staying in the same position for many many years. Location of the site is located far from any major metropolitan area.

Pro: Good opportunities, Great people, Collegiate, Focused on core business,
Con: Needs to focus more on internal career development

Pro: Small organization in India; High level of Client support and a lot of work on development projects. Good exposure to domain knowledge.
Con: No onsite opportunities. Senior management very poor. Far away from city centre. Very bad canteen. A lot of cost-cutting initiatives in place.

Pro:
Good People

Desire to do the right thing for customers

Strong Reputation and Track Record of Success
Con:
Limited Direction

Constant Change that is promoted as the Best Move Possible, when in reality, the projected outcomes have not been well thought out

Office Politics (Don't be fooled)

Summary: "Great training, professional environment.  Be prepared to learn and retain a lot of information."
Pro: Even if you do not have a background in the financial industry, you can excel at Anonymous.  The company provides great training and support.  Co-workers are helpful, this is a company of fantastic people.  No two days are ever the same.  If you enjoy an ever changing environment and are willing to continually improve your own skill set, this is the company for you.
Con:
Due to the economy, there seems to be limited upward mobility at this time.  

Balancing the metrics goals is not impossible, but can be a challenge.

Pro:
Name Recognition

Benefits

less cut-throat than other fin firms

Boston is less hectic than NYC

Diverse educational backgrounds
Con:
Benefits are Scaled Back

It's a Fund Co First and the only unit that matters

managers say one thing and do another

Summary: "It depends on the manager and the office"
Pro: Anonymous is a great place to work hard and gain a lot of industry experience.  For the most part, the work environment is open and friendly, and universal respect for the Anonymous brand carris over into the job.
Con: The same job at Anonymous could be completely different; much of that experience is based on the manager you work for.  Working for a great manager means being in a job you can be proud of and opportunity growth for people who work for it.  On the other hand, working for an average or poor manager can mean very long hours, being micro-managed, little appreciation for your efforts, and limited opportunities for advancement.

Summary: "Great place to work - especially if you stay a long time."
Pro: The management is terrific - my direct boss provides feedback, makes it fun to come to work, and the salary and benefits are great.  Medical plan is awesome (every doctor I've known is in it!) and when you rise higher in the company you get shares.
Con: They keep moving people around to different buildings - I've been here for 5 years and have moved 4 times!  I really wish we were in one location.  Some people don't like senior management and talk about it - A LOT!!!

Pro: People were fantastic!  I never worried about the stability of the firm, or the leadership of the company... except during the Lawson years.   Difficulty moving out of the phone site.
Con: Lack of opportunity as a manager to really progress.  Log jam at the next level.  Didn't want to do the "manager merrry-go-round."

Pro: The reasons to work at Anonymous are that you get a great benefit package, a pretty place to work, and can meet some good friends.
Con: The downside of Anonymous is that during the downturn of the economy, they quickly let a large number of people go without any particular reason. They opted to cut their resources before cutting some of the extra spending that they do. Think about that indicator of the loyalty that they show people who have dedicated their lives to the company.

Summary: "Great place to start not to finsh"
Pro: there is a great culture at fidelity. i was able to get along with all the other employees. i was very pleased with the managers i had which makes a big deal
Con: the worst part is that  you are tracked to the second every day and everyday is the same there is never any change and their never will be

Summary: "Good company but these are tough times"
Pro:
A company with a very strong customer focus

Nearly unlimited resources 

'Mostly interested in doing the right thing

Lots of good, smart people working there

Good compensation
Con:
Trouble at the top - where are they going

Change is constant and you have to be comfortable with that

Directional changes can be abrupt

Better at reacting than being planfull and proactive

Summary: "Anonymous is great for the benefits.  Get in, learn, and then go elsewhere."
Pro: The Benefits are great!  From that standpoint it is a great place to work.  It is a great place to learn and then take your experience elsewhere.
Con: I don't think management know what they want to put their focus to grow the business.  They are stuck in the past and trying to run to the future in a hurry.

Pro: Working there was wonderful, the people were great i learned a lot and had lots of resources to grow and learn from
Con: It was very difficult to be promoted and even more difficult to get the pay you deserverd. everything, as with most large companies revolved around politics.

Pro: Great company to work for, always on the edge of change in the financial services industry, opportunity for advancement within a certain channel
Con: Many people are stuck in their ways, hard to move to different divisions within the company, base pay not great but opportunity for bonus

Pro: they are a strong company and have good products and investments for your clients and you can move up in the firm
Con: they dont care for their employees and no good mentor or advice from managers / dont pay good fees on assets

Summary: "Deceitful Management; Reckless Decision Making; Terribly Inefficient"
Pro: Pays is fair and when bonus and profit sharing is funded - compensation is fair.
Con: This company is horribly inefficient. Senior management changes frequently and with those changes is always a reorganization and change of strategy. Anonymous chose RTP in NC as the home for their $100  million dollar new facility and planned to add 2000 + jobs. They started off strong - bought the land, moved hundreds of folks down from Boston and then pulled the plug and decided they would rather operate in TX and other parts of MA. With hundreds of families making a committment to relocate for the company, leaving family, selling their homes in a bad housing market and taking losses on the moves and home sales - most that relocated were laid off before their 1st year finished in the 'new' location. Folks that relocated without a relocation package paid thousands of dollars to get to NC for the company - and the company decided to change strategy and then laid these same 'committed' employees off. Many folks made personal sacrafices for Anonymous - and the company just hung their employees out to dry. Very deceitful company - provides little information to the employees - and what is communicated is mostly not accurate/honest. The culture is highly politicized and very back-stabbing as the company has so many layoffs everyone is always trying to make the other guy look bad in hopes of saving their own position.

Summary: "Decent place to work if you can deal with the political aspect"
Pro:
Work/life balance depending on group

Benefits
Con:
Politics

Lack of accountability

Definitely need to know people to get your job done

Summary: "I served there as a Contractor for hire for a six month project that turned into 3 years!"
Pro: They provide a great atmosphere for you to work, and they allow your personal life to be personal!
Con: You will work alot and take your work home with you.  Ok if you're a workaholic

Summary: "good company to work for but can drive a great, devoted employee to quit."
Pro: Good benefits, understanding management, encourage personal business developement.
Con: management lack of communication, too much layering, political when it comes to promotions and hires, salary not competitive with industry, company always wants blood from a stone, they rather pay an external higher more $$ that their own who are more capable to do the job, can never get a straight answer about anything.

Pro: If you are fresh out of college, spend a year here at most then move on quickly.  As the company declines further even this recommendation is only valid until 2011.  However, you can learn a lot here.  The Profit Sharing is a good benefit and tuition reimbursement is good, but all in all the rest of the bennies are pretty comparable to everyone else.  Long term at Anonymous is career suicide.
Con: Management has nothing but contempt for employees.  This is across the board.  Management practices are abusive.  I have personally heard a VP refer to his department as a "factory" and his staff as "work horses", and he has been promoted 3 times since then.  Hard work is expected and pay for performance is not a reality at Anonymous.  You work crazy hours to succeed and don'd get paid for it, recognized, and when the bonus cycle comes they wont pay out.  Dont fall for the bonus mumbo jumbo, Anonymous has not paid out its bonuses in the past 2 years.  Youll be lucky if you get 1/6 of the amount they promise you at your interview.  Get your money in your base on your way in the door.  No exit interviews as a corporate policy: they know they are everything I have said and they dont want to hear about it or learn from it.  In my department 4 people have resigned in the past 4 months, some without jobs to go to, others for better opportunities.

Pro:
You never have to take your work home with you.

Benefits are great.

Lots of 20 somethings, fun people to be around.

Pretty easy job - which can be a con, too.

Great company in general.
Con:
The day to day responsibilities can be mundane.

You can get stuck with an incompetent manager, however, most are fine.

Few career paths to choose from.

Pro: Privately held - Able to invest in long term w/o quarterly earnings pressure
Con: Constant reorganizations - As if exec management thinks company's problems can be solved by constantly rotating senior team

Summary: "Your experience is totally dependent on your manager/dept."
Pro: When you're working in the ideal group, there are ample opportunities for growth/advancement, amazing people and job satisfaction.
Con: When you're working in the wrong group, you may have to deal with terrible management, horrible office politics and HR nightmares.

Pro: Decent place to work. Make sure you are use to office politics. If you play the game well, it will pay off. Otherwise, you won't get anywhere.
Con: Politics. The best and the brightest doesn't always succeed here. You must form the proper alliances and you will be rewarded.

Summary: "Excellent company filled with talented, intelligent people"
Pro:
- Great benefits

- Excellent company culture with intelligent, collaborative, supportive coworkers

- Management with a clear interest in the career development of associates
Con:
- Unnecessary corporate politics at higher levels

- A few out-dated, inefficient processes and systems remain in effect and present hurdles to accomplishing work

Summary: "Empty assurances and no long term commitment."
Pro: The Anonymous brand still carries some positive aura
Con:
Anonymous can't maintain any leadership stability at the executive (or line) level.

The supposed benefits of working for a privately-held firm are hard to find.  Revenue and Profit-Margin are seemingly the only focus for the newest Johnson generation.

Innovation, long the hallmark of Anonymous, is replaced by growing stagnation and outsourcing.

Summary: "I used to think I died and went to heaven!"
Pro: Terrific opportunities to learn and there are a wealth of talented individuals.  The work/life balance has been great; no issues with workig from home and getting time off when needed.
Con: All evaluations are considered "subjective" and not measurable so management can't be held accountable.  You have no idea where you stand compared to your peers.   There are no guidelines for bonus programs.  The middle management is the worse as they all try to protect their turf and do nothing to develop or support their teams.  Any feedback on performance is based on hearsay and anomomous feedback.

Pro:
- Easy going, casual dress

- Laid back work atmosphere 

- Cyclic installation schedules (free at times, busy at others - this can be seen as a pro or con)

- Excellent on-site facilities

- Intern program is excellent, group-intern speaker sessions give you a lot of insight about the company
Con:
- Stagnation in the technology department after the tech boom in the 90's

- Lots of middle managers leads to lots of reporting (and reporting about reporting) 

- Lots of activity up top leads to many organizational changes

Pro: salary was pretty good, env was good, very good and intelligent peers. good exposure to current industry standards as far as technical stuff is concerned.
Con: no respect. no career potential at all within the company. poor communication. most decisions seem to be made in haste.

Pro: Intelligent people, access to all the resources I need to do my job, fast paced work environment, pay for performance
Con: difficult to move up in the company quickly, very large company with lots of expected bureaucracy, high turnover in executive management

Summary: "Good company but expects much of its employees"
Pro: The work is challenging and for the most part the people are supportive and helpful.     Anonymous pays an average salary but the bonuses make the difference and are above and beyond what most other companies give their employees.
Con:
If you're looking for a casual and laid back environment, Anonymous is not it.  It's very professional and reserved, which is not necessarily a negative but I found that it seemed to prohibit teamwork.  To survive, it's very much about developing a network and seeking those who have some history there to get answers.



The pay is not bad,but you will definitely earn it.  Anonymous expects a lot from its employees.

Pro: Best reasons would be the work/life balance and respect for family needs.
Con: Advancement and career tracks don't exist. The politics are ridiculous and management is constantly changing.

Pro: Its a convenient option as an investment company alternative to going into Boston.
Con: You're just a number, a replacable widget in the machine of the company.

Summary: "A decent place to work if you are patient and don't expect to progress quickly...or at all"
Pro: Benefits are decent; Management supports work-life balance; Tuition reimbursement program; Intelligent people; Upscale place to work, Modern building with amenities
Con: Bonus has never been what I was promised at the beginning, it is controlled by upper management who do not know and work with the lower level employees. They are more concerned with controlling their budgets, rather than rewarding and developing talented people. Difficult to get interesting and challenging projects, management is guarding their turf and does not delegate. Which is understandable, considering the constant threat of layoffs. If you are eager to advance, have varying assignments, get exposure to high visibility projects and rise quickly on the career ladder, this is NOT the place for you...unless you have really good connections and/or a senior exec family member. If you are, however, content with 9 to 5, easy, mindless work, go for it.

Summary: "With a strong focus on Benefit Communications"
Pro: Privately owned. Ethical company. Invests in technology to afford employees with the tools they need to effectively do their job.
Con: The environment and organizational structure is always changing. Management development program (if there is one) is not very apparent.

Pro: There is no space to move up.Its a nice company if you want to spend your last few years of your career relaxing and making money for not doing work and playing TT. It is left to you to take up initiative and work or give up and stay relaxed. The company provides a good environment to explore different domains and training is emphasized.
Con:
Old management. The directors barely know you or recognize you



Pay is not great



major work happens in US ..majorly support work happens in india

Pro:
- Great work culture

- ideal Work-life balance

- Very good benefits

- plenty of opportunity for growth

- mutual respect
Con:
- majorly local presence concentrated largely in Mass., New Hampshire and Rhode Island

- A very vertical organizational structure

Pro: Love my coworkers and clients.  I can't really compare it to other firms because this is my first job in this industry.
Con: Confused and self-confounding management, unfortunately.

Summary: "Below pay, good benefits, no opportunity for advancement"
Pro: Profit sharing every year, excellent 401k match, good bonus structure
Con: no opportunity for advancement, base pay is way below market, must be a management favorite to get anywhere, top management can't make decisions.

Summary: "Struggling to provide leadership and losing its luster over the past 5-10 years...still strong due to Ned's foundation."
Pro:
- Benefits

- Work-Life Balance

- Talented Employees
Con:
- Organizational complexity

- Constant organizational changes that don't make sense and create confusion

- Senior leadership lacking past 5-10 years due to turnover, lack of opportunities

Pro:
Wonderful people - talented and smart

Challenging work - pushes your boundries and invites creative problem solving

Ever changing environment - never the same day twice
Con:
Spin the org chart - change is constant

Time to market is often the driver, over quality

Too many people have to wear too many hats - expect to do more than what you're hired to do.

Pro: Great and energetic group of people.  Paid study time for exams.  Licensing fees all paid.  Starting salary was descent with raises after passing exams.  Quarterly bonuses of a few hundred bucks on up.
Con: All phone jobs suck.  Most callers are great and friendly, its just the cranky ones who didn't fill out forms correctly that make the day stressful.

Summary: "Not a bad place to start a career in finance. Get out when you get your licenses."
Pro: Free licenses and great benefits.
Con: Massive micromanagement. Management plays favorites with employees so due bonuses are skewed. Very low pay. Overworked. Very demanding work for the level of pay.

Pro: You can gain experience in a starting finance career. It offers on the job training, and the company's training is also good and extensive.
Con: The biggest downside is that opportunities for advancement aren't that bountiful....but as with any other company, you need to network and make connections.

Summary: "Fantastic  company back  in the 1980's; now struggling to regain its footing."
Pro:
Smart, talented people.

Great environment for learning more about investing and personal financial management.

Excellent benefits.

Huge firm with worldwide presense and many different operating companies offering, in theory, many different types of opportunities.
Con:
As you advance in your career there, your opportunity to move to a new position is difficult; as with

any "triangular" organizational structure, there are fewer and fewer jobs the higher up you go on the corporate ladder.

Summary: "Decent place for college kids, new grads & retirees"
Pro: Great place to earn some cash and pump up your resume. Not much upward mobility at all from the service rep position... dont drink the kool aid.
Con: way too scripted. you will often have to choose between whats right and whats scripted. You will be liable for the mistakes that the call flow tells you to make or you will be penalized for not following the call flow

Pro:
opportunity to work on many different things (lots of functions/many projects - interesting) 

lots of training avaialble 

great benefits 

great people
Con: For the past two years or more constant org changes, no consistent direction

Pro: Very few Pros: Paychek, Benefits, Location, recognizable name in your resume
Con:
Very limited development opportunities

Unfair treatment by management

Very little professional respect

If you can look somewhere else...

Summary: "I miss what it used to be."
Pro: It's a solid company, for the most part, and I say that knowing that my job will soon be coming to an end. My business unit is going away, but they have been upfront with us about that decision and I appreciate that. I'd have no intention of leaving if it wasn't for the fact the my job is going away.
Con: It has been Dilbert-ized a lot in recent years. I have loved working for this company, but it has gone down hill a lot since Roger Lawson came in. I'm glad he's leaving, but I think it's a bit too late.

Pro: Very few left. If you're an FTE "regular employee" they still have a great benefit package: excellent health plan, 401k with match, profit-sharing.
Con:
You're not going to get an FTE position, never mind keep one if you have it. They've pushed out almost all the competent managers, and have stuck individual contributors as "perma-temps" with horrible/no benefits. The "perma-temp" medical plans stop paying at $5000 even though advertised as $50,000, so don't plan on getting sick or injured.  FTE to "perma-temp" ratio is the worst I've seen in 15 years there.



Reorgs coming fast and furious. 4 Managers in 1 year. Raleigh was to be the new Tech HQ and now there are no managers left there, just bodyshop L1 Visa holders, perma-temps of their captive Veritude "temp" agency, and a few FTEs. Hundreds laid off again just this past week across the company, following last year's 10% 4000 person cut, and several "stealth layoffs" between then and now. Most of the very experienced people, especially if they are over 40, have been dumped. 



There is absolutely no sense to who they're dumping, if they were sincerely still trying to run and grow the company. They're just cleaning up the balance sheet to make the company's financials look good, in my opinion. 



The old-school Wall Streeters who came in to take over from the long-term Boston exec mgmt have now themselves started bailing out of the firm. There's nothing left of last year's 5-year plan except the souvenir mouse pads showing the cartoon of the transformation plan. On which we had to take mandatory training!

Pro:
Get to work with a lot of high-end technology with firewalls and network devices.

Very detail oriented approach to certifying solutions are fit for the environment before production deployment.   Promotes operational stabilty.

A lot of resources available like their FCAT technology library where you can get books and also the Safari online books anytime.  

I've had great managers and horrible managers during my time at Anonymous.  It really depends on who you work for sometimes.
Con:
Excessive process sometimes hinders getting work done but at the same time keeps things in check so that engineers are not over burdened all at once with too much work at a time.

A lot of politics in management.  It's more about which managers you are 'buddies'  with over merit.  

Very easy to get stuck in a group and focus on a select few technologies and be very good at it, but moving to other groups is not quite as easy.

Summary: "Great Place for Those Willing to Be Molded in the Anonymous Image"
Pro: Decent benefits and nice facilities.
Con:
Very autocratic management style.  Senior management would send their grandmothers packing if they thought it would fatten their bonuses.

Little room for diversity.   If you wish to stay as long as possible, opt for a lobotomy ASAP.

Pro:
This used to be a wonderful place to work. Now, even through staff may be all highly competent, you will be ranked on a bell curve. Expect layoffs every year. It is highly competitvie internally and lots of favoritism.



Check rank on the Country's Companies For Working Parents list -- it will not make the top 50% is my estimation.



Due to employees not moving on frrm Anonymous no one was getting promoted. To resolve this issue and to ensure all the competent highly paid workers were shown the door to make way for new and inexperienced people to come on board, Anonymous was able to save lots of $. This does happen with many compnaies, and finanical services was hit hard in the past few years. However, this started before that economic crisis.



They work you hard which is fine. Just don't expect to be fairly rated, and don't count on the bonus coming through. 



Great place several years ago, but now it is cut throat and highly political.

Other firms seem to be paying a lot more than Anonymous.
Con: Be prepared for change all of the time and "ride the wave." Ther eare many layoffs, reorgs, and other stressful changes.

Summary: "Plenty of opportunity, but hampered by poor leadership at senior levels."
Pro: bright and dedicated people, international opportunities, good work environment, salary and benefits commensurate with industry, lots of interesting work to do
Con: senior management not impressive, lack of leadership shown, direction of company not clear, mistakes repeated numerous times, despite international opportunities, appalling lack of cultural understanding

Pro: Great benefits, good pay, fair vacation policy
Con: Management is incompetent.  Most branch managers I encountered were complete morons and only cared about themselves, not the team.

Pro: They pay for you to become series 7 licensed. While overtime is encouraged, you can make a lot more than your starting wage if you want to.
Con: The hours are terrible for many employees starting in the call center. Their lines are open 24/7 so someone has to be available on the other end.

Pro:
Decent hourly rate for someone with no experience in the industry - as a contractor

Clients were great 

Very systematic methods which work well 

Bright people
Con:
High turnover 

Very political 

Contract to perm may never happen

High stress

Pro:
- Good hours (usually no weekends or staying much past 7)

- Friendly employees

- Decent pay

- Very good job security
Con:
- Too much bureaucracy (this will be found at any big company but seems to be especially prevalent here)

-

Summary: "Politics-based working environment with no regard to rewarding merit and overloads you with work."
Pro: Only the benefits are marginally better with 7% match, and 10% profit sharing(at the company's discretion though since they can cut it any time).
Con: Merits are mediocre at best, and there's a lot of incompetent managers there.

Pro: Overall company culture of customer experience, great employees
Con: How some decisions are made, alot of behind- the- scene politics that you cannot not or should question unless you want to affect your advancement opportunities

Summary: "There's growth and money but depends on what dept you're in.."
Pro: Great health benefits, better than any other company out there.  401k match $1 for $1 up to 7%, even now allowing Roth contributions.  Great vacation time & flexibility between home/work life.
Con: Extremely hard to move up and go anywhere in a call center.  Limited mobility in NC, you'll have to relocate to find the career paths.  Anonymous retail side is the best place to be if you're looking for money.

Pro: Great benefits, Life & Health Insurance as well as tuition reimbursement program. Competitive starting pay. Great training to get your licenses.
Con: It has been said before, micro-management. Whoever your manager is will determine your like or dislike of Anonymous. Unfortunately managers move around fairly quickly, so odd are you will get a bad one more often than you can stay with a good one. If you can transfer to the good manager's new area.

Pro: Great benefits - fantastic retirement package, company match, health, dental, various commuter and fitness reimbursement type offers. Great brand name, so looks good on resume
Con: Otherwise.... mostly cons. The culture is one in which (fair disclaimer: in my division. FMR is obviously a huge company, things may very well work differently elsewhere), in which employees are expected to essentially forgo personal life. The company has a rep as a bit of a meat-grinder for a reason...

Summary: "The financial services version of Ford Model T assembly line."
Pro: Base Pay / plus OT / plus variable comp
Con: Lack of career path.  Huge volume in terms of sales goals and lack of personal relationship with customers.

Pro: Anonymous in all of their crap offer really good benefits. Health insurance is very good it will cost you $20 bucks to have a kid. The dental is about average. The retirement is awesome they match up to 7% and give 10% profit sharing.
Con: You are stuck on a leash at the phone dealing with people who have some money but no idea how to invest it. They call in and get mad at the reps because they made poor decisions. The repetition is maddening and management doesnt care. The phone reps were getting bonuses of $600 per quarter and they were cutting costs so they took $200 per rep and left the upper managements bonuses at six figures. The fact is that upper management doesnt care about phone reps because they are expendible. Also they have no respect for education.

Pro: The work environment was based in learning as an intern. However, many of the tasks were monotonous and very boring.
Con: The pay is not quite as high as other competiting firms. The work can be boring and is sometime not intellectually challenging.

Pro: The large company offers several levels of responsibility, this gives you an opportunity for advancement.  The salaries are alright but the benefits are great.
Con: Layoffs have been going on for the past few years.  Moral is very low and many areas are overworked because of the past reductions.

Pro: If you are lazy and dim, you might be overpaid by a large amount long enough to accumulate real wealth. The name carries weight on your resume. Because of the very high turnover, you might get promoted into a vacancy, but will not have to worry about the pressure of higher pay.
Con: Whatever pay they promise will be total fiction. Layoffs happen monthly(for the last 2 years!). Most everyone is trying to get you fired, especially at bonus time. Bonuses, raises, and long term comp are often cut even when the company has record profits. Senior managers live in fear of the Family and will throw you under the bus if it helps them. We have a saying: the bullet that will kill you has already been fired, it is just a matter of when it will catch up to you. And I say this as someone who has been successful here and still am. Politics exist everywhere, but this place is a viper pit. Many, many successful execs have been hired and fired in under a year simply because the old guard decided to poison the well on them. Unless you started here twenty years ago or are part of The Family, you are dead. No manager will ever extend his personal political capital to save you.

Pro: Great benefits (7% 401k match, fantastic health insurance, education, fitness, and technology reimbursement, etc). They'll train you and walk you through getting the licenses you'll need, of which they cover the costs. They schedule weekly coaching sessions with your team manager to try and remain involved in your individual success. Easy metrics to follow, in general.
Con: While I mentioned the coaching sessions as a good thing, this is only true if you have a great manager. For most of the managers I worked with at Anonymous, it seemed they tried to fill the coaching time with criticisms, rather than using positive reinforcement and education. Phone center environment in general is rough on most.  For the last 2 years or so, they haven't been hiring within the company much for different departments.

Pro: Anonymous is a strong company with a streak of independence allowed by private ownership. Good product recognition. Solid and very conservative with respect to financial responsibility. Many opportunities for career growth, change and diversity if you are able to adopt the culture. Good availability of resources including career education. Better than average compensation and benefits.
Con: Your success at Anonymous will depend largely on the ability of your manager to steer you within the maze and to protect you from the political environment. Don't stay in any one area/unit/department for too long as you will become "type cast."  This is not a paternalistic environment; do not expect to be taken care of. This employer typifies the characterization of the "disposable employee." They have a reputation for re-organizing every six months. This is, if not literally, virtually true. You must be very flexible and not cling to the past. Upper management is currently (May 2010) in a state of upheaval that has been ongoing for perhaps 5 years. Continuity and vision is lacking.

Pro: If you can keep at job at Anonymous, that woud be a "pro"
Con: Anonymous use to be the BEST place to work and the most respected company in the industry.  To have Anonymous on your resume gave you the advantage over the competition.  However, that all changed in 2007.  The company culture, benefits structure and management style changed suddenly and negatively impacted clients and employees.  The company has considerable market share and has been wobbling ever since, trying to determine a direction to steer, go public, sell businesses piece by piece, not succession plan, etc.  I blame Roger Lawson for the down turn, but perhaps that was his purpose.  In 2010, the company still  has no clear direction and their current employees are not high the mgmt's priority.  The constant state of layoffs and restructure proves a detriment to moral and productivity.  Where is Ned?

Pro: The benefits are fantastic. The opportunities to advance your skills are only limited by your initiative. Sales are based on what's best for the client, not commission. Management has been in your position and truely care about their employees.
Con: Most opportunities are phone related. Management and back office work are highly strived for and aggressively persued when available.

Summary: "Good place to learn how to do fundamental research."
Pro:
Benefits (401k match and profit sharing adds up to 17% of base and bonus)

Free bottled water, sodas, juice, milk for people in the invesstment company (FMR Co)

Huge travel budget for investment professionals

Access to a lot of research tools 

Access to senior management of outside companies ... on any given day, we have 30-50 company meetnig inhouse.
Con:
Definitely lower base pay than other companies

Bonus potential is a scam ... e.g. I am in the 30% pool, by the end of the year, my bonus will be my salary x 30% (my pool) x ~80% (base on my group's performance) x ~75% (base on my own performance).  So, technically, my bonus is only 50-60% of my potential.  In the old days, there is only 1 haircut (only my performance).

Pro: Pay is decent, benefits are great
Con: In the call center, you can get stuck on a shift that you don't want.  Granted, because of the economy there isn't a lot of hiring, but there doesn't seem to be any opportunity for us to advance or even any concern by management to develop us for future roles.

Pro:
Great work life balance

Very good open door policy

Good HR policies

Management is very transparent is communicating important decisions

Salary package better than most of its peers
Con:
Top heavy comapny. Number of managers is more than double of what is actually required.

Stagnant career growth. Very good chance that even after 4 years you would at the same level.

Not much of cutting edge work. Mostly maintanence projects.

No onsite oppurtunities!!!

Although it is Anonymous's captive software house, Anonymous US seems to have more confidence in vendors like Infosys and Patni. Lot of projetcs still go to them.

Very unlikely that you can shift your project unless you have 'contacts'.

Summary: "Good Place to work for Married people"
Pro:
1.Good personal-professional life balance.

2. Good working enviornment and work culture

3. takes cares of their employees very well

4. approchable senior Management
