Con:
1.Not a good place to start your career with.

2. salaries are low these days as compared to market standards.

3. there's no much pressure, so less chances to learn.

Pro: almost unlimited resources, smart people willing to help you learn, stability, control over your time, freedom, creative thinking highly encouraged, plenty of responsibility
Con: training doesn't help you do the job, you just have to mess up a lot to learn what to do, you're wrong a lot

Pro: Good work/life balance, average salary with great benefits (especially after 5 years to fully vest).
Con: Not many opportunities to move horizontally across the company.

Summary: "Benefits are good, many management changes in the last few years."
Pro: Solid profit sharing and benefits, many opportunities in phone sites.  You can make a career out of it if you don't mind limited growth
Con: Very reactive to market change, can't seem to get comp right for branch sales, poor communication from the top management

Summary: "Decent place to work, employees treated well"
Pro: Decent place to work, employees treated well and there are good opportunities within Salt Lake although these are some what stacked towards direct contact with clients.  During busy times there is a lot of flexibility with overtime.
Con: The company can be slow moving sometimes, positive changes and feedback seem to be planned but take a long time to get acted on.  Career advancement past client focused or operations jobs will probably require you to relocate.

Pro: Pay, Work life balance, facilities.
Con: Promotions, growth, career options, partiality, unfair

Pro: Benefits and salary are good.
Con: Leadership is very poor, managers gossip about their employees.  I had great reviews all through my tenure, and then all of a suden I got a terrible review and was then laid off.  Many others I spoke to had the same experience.  A sudden bad review and then kicked out the door.  Its just a very lame way to treat employees who have put so much effort into the company.  Its one thing to be honest but that is horrible mistreatment, really brings down morale.  There are no training programs, you are basically thrown into your role.  You are expected to work at least 50 hours a week.    once it was  great place with positive feedback and growth potential, now everyone backstabs and is bitter and rude.

Pro: Good benefits and thats about it.
Con: I dread every single day I have to go into work. All you do is take phone calls all day long you are literally tied to the phone like a leash. You are expected to ACHEIVE on every phone call like you are a robot with a script to read. This job is horrible. if you are thinking about working here run away!!!! I wish i was told what is was really like before I interviewed. Anonymous may be ok to work at if you are working off the phones, but on the phones is a living hell.

Summary: "Company does not have a clear direction"
Pro: Benefits at Anonymous are great, but are more structured towards the long term.  Most of the management are long-termers, so while there is some political in-fighting, it's mostly limited and directed towards the "newcomers" in management.  Good and bad, depending which side of the coin you fall on.  Not a bank, but still nice to be privately owned in this environment.
Con: Corporate infighting, and some of the downsides of working at a large firm.  Adequate compensation just isn't there at the associate level.

Pro: The technology can be interesting.  There is always something happening with the business to keep you interested with the marketplace.
Con:
One thing is consistant and that is change.

Politics run extreamely thick and drive management to manage up and out vs. down.

There is a push to reduce the overall cost of the workforce so work is being offshored.

Summary: "Great name, but only used to be a great place to work. Now it's "what have you done for me lately.""
Pro:
Brand Recognition (Anonymous is almost like Coke in the investment world)

Great products (though managed product too cookie cutter for high net worth customers)

Pay is pretty good for premium discount brokerage compared with similar brokerage firms

Great Colleagues on the sales force, including regional specialists and consultants
Con:
Used to be great in that you were paid according to effort (small bps for products), there was no arguing your performance and you had greater control. Higher salaries seemed great at first, but ultimately muddied the waters on your value. 

Introduction of higher salaries vs. basis point commission for production made the retail channel thick with bureaucracy for the sales force, muddled value interpretation (having to prove you are worthy of your salary), and ultimately allows for back stabbing by direct management, who generally go unchecked while often adding little to nothing by way of support, help, and development.

Focus on numbers solely over development (Sell tons of PAS and FILI or else)

Management now uses fear of losing one's job as motivating tool, rather than true development while masking it with a smile and telling you it is not the case. Managers and sales force seem at odds; kind of like the shipmaster with a whip and the rowers of the boat (it doesn't feel as though you have anyone trying to help you develop, rather just trying to whip your performance for their own bottom line)

Morale has deteriorated dramatically-ask anyone on the sales force

Your career is in the hands of your manager who solely interprets your worth, especially now that sales force is primarily salary.

It started out as a job I woke up and was happy to go to, but ended up a job I dreaded because the focus became random numbers (some that made little sense or seemed arbitrary like the customer satisfaction numbers and contacts) Important, but nonsensical, unclear, and clearly more important to your manager's bottom line. (Customer satisfaction is important to the sales force, the numbers are important to management) Even though no one can make heads or tails of them, sales force gets beaten up over them.

Managers seem to go unchecked, and while they may face pressure from their managers, can easily shift the accountability to the employees sales performance rather than their own lack of support and development. 

I was actually told by a Regional Manager my past performance is irrelevant, it's a "what have you done for me lately environment."

Summary: "Great company overall, but bad recent management hiring decisions."
Pro: Great people, great culture, and overall great company.  Good opportunities to bounce around to different parts of the organization.
Con: The family owned company has recently taken in senior leaders from public companies, they shook things up, and now they are all gone with their golden parachutes.

Pro: The biggest plus that comes with working at Anonymous is the people. The atmosphere is one that is conducive to personal and professional growth. Other than the people, the benefits and compensation are great.
Con: One major downside was the systems we used. Some of them were fairly old and had horrible user interfaces, which got frustrating.

Summary: "Did a summer internship there.  Dilbert became less a joke and more of a documentary after."
Pro: Paid very well, silly but nice perks with things like a gym with personal trainers and pretty nice cafeteria.  Nicely maintained grounds.
Con: Everything else, nepotism was king.  Meritocracy died a lonely death a long time ago.  Large meetings were sessions of the "blame game" with discussions about how things should be "moving forward".  X Y scatter plots are not to be used in presentations, even if they are the only sane way to display the information.  We love pie, and pie charts.

Summary: "Anonymous Great Benefits; Must threaten for promotions"
Pro: Anonymous has great overall benefits regarding retirement, brokerage, and health care. Anonymous has many positions/locations to move throughout your development.
Con: I have noticed a lack of communication between the senior leaders and everyday associates. Also due to the many layers in the company it is challenging to pass through the buruacratic read tape to get your job accomplished.

Pro: Decent pay and benefits, looks good on a resume.
Con: Management! They belittled us in front of everyone when a mistake was made. Made it clear work came first, no family life expected or tolerated.

Pro: Within my group, there was an amazing sense of camaraderie and support. I felt like I was part of a high-performing team who liked to see results, but have fun at the same time. Even though I was an intern, my opinions were always respected and I never felt like a lesser member of the group.
Con: Inconsistency between groups, as the company is quite large (~40,000 employees.) It sometimes felt like employees in a different group were experiencing an entirely different work environment, almost as if they were in a different company.

Pro: Great Training, Friendly people, Plenty of jobs available, Helpful staff, gain meaningful experience, access to upper management, and great benefits
Con: depending on what business unit you are in, the hours can be a little inconvenient, can be difficult to change jobs

Pro:
- Incredible benefits package, excluding paid vacation time

- On-site management teams have always been understanding of personal situations or need for time off on short notice

- Great opportunity to learn the industry

- Very customer friendly environment and great brand recognition
Con:
- Too beaurocratic - front line employees are asked to provide feedback to upper management on ways to improve but little is acknowledged, much less acted on

- Upon hiring they promote career opportunity, and even managers state career developement is something they want to help out with, but unless you want to do sales and/ or be tied to a phone doing different levels of customer service, very little career growth exists unless you have the right connections

- Compensation seems to be appropriate for entry level jobs but does not keep pace as you do move through the company

- Severe disconnect between upper managment and front line employees

- Contracting expectations - they promote world class customer service as being the number one priority in this particular role, but great interactions are rarely rewarded, and sales are what most non-base pay compensation is tied to

Pro: Great name and reputation. A very professional atmosphere with great training! Teamwork is of great value here even though we are all individual contributor. If anyone has a problem or quesition, everyone is willing to help!
Con: It seems that moving up in the company from this specific position is very hard. Some people have been here a long time and have actually made it to the top but it takes patience.

Pro: Great pay, 401K match is excellent, health benefits are excellent.
Con: they work you very hard and it never stops. be prepared to work nights, weekends, holiday weekends especially.  Be prepared to be called and paged while on vacation.  Be prepared to be laid off at any time.

Summary: "Great company to work with great values. But the compansation mangagement is very bad. I didn't see any financial growth"
Pro: Anonymous values, Integrity, Team work, Respect for individual.  Flexible working hours.
Con: compansation mangagement is very bad. I didn't see any personal financial growth instead of outstading performance, The hike they give is to just match Indian inflation rate.

Pro: Great benefits (which include health, 401k, vacation)
Con: Terrible promotions (don't recognize efforts where due).  Stopped investing in their employees as well as technology and support.

Pro: benefits are good and they do train to pass the series 7 and 63 and get paid for it
Con: They do not support their employees in any way

Pro: Very good benefits, strong 401K matching and profit sharing plans.  You get a pretty good amount of vaction after the first few years.  Anonymous seems like a pretty ethical place to work at with good people from good backgrounds.
Con: Very poor salary, bonuses, and raises.  There isn't a lot of opportunity to move within the company.  Everything is driven by leads and acquiring new business whether you are in a sales function or not.  If you don't want to go into sales you won't ever be given the chance to even interview for the job within the company you would excel at.  Management does a poor job of using the talent they have within the company to fill the positions where it is needed.

Pro:
excellent facilities

people-centric (sometimes overdone!)

open communication

decent pay package

overall great
Con:
not much of a paymaster anymore.

good for freshers, but experienced people find it hard to stay because of better package elsewhere.

Pro: Great training and very good prep for sec licenses. Truly is a merit based company and if you perform well you can get promoted very quickly. Some of the best facilities that I have even worked in and have some many job opportunities at the Westlake center.
Con: Overall the pay is probably somewhat less then others companies but the 410k matching and other benefits make up for that and most likely create an equal compensation package.

Pro: Anonymous is a good place to work
Con: Too many changes recently have made employees uncomfortable

Pro:
profit sharing /401k match

some areas still have good leaders and great managers

some areas still have competent/ trustworthy co-workers

Good pay
Con:
Some parts of company are managed poorly-focus is on only those costs/benefits that are measurable 



Many changes in leadership has caused some groups to lose their grounding

Summary: "Easy to get in, hard to move up"
Pro:
Anonymous does a lot of solid training, considerably more than a lot of competitors in the field. 



Benefits are very good. Pay is a little less at Anonymous but when you consider benefits in the compensation package it is competitive.



Workplace environment is reasonably professional and not stuffy.



For the most part front-line managers are willing to work with associates to find a favorable resolution to personal issues.



Managers don't throw you under the bus to customers just to make the customer feel better about a problem.



There are some great employees and managers who care about the customer and care about the employees.
Con:
Middle and upper management appears to have no idea where they are trying to steer the company, so the company swings from taking an idea to the extreme to a complete 180. Today they may be focusing on customer satisfaction and personalizing the interaction and in a few months decide to strip down customer interactions to scripted nonsense.



There are very few outlets for good ideas to arrive at implementation. Although there are feedback channels that may from time to time result in small changes, the bigger process issues or customer/client issues are completely controlled from the top by people who don't understand (and at times take pride in not knowing) what they manage so they don't know how to recognize or fix problems. So something may be a problem for years before somebody decides to do something about it, and even then the "solution" may aggravate the problem.



Anonymous is very political. Anonymous is obsessed today with it's brand image to the public, but one thing that is always constant at Anonymous is the constant obsession about your "brand". Gossip is taken as gospel and can ruin your brand in a second. What people have to say about you will override your performance in virtually all cases. Many managers would rather sink one of their employee's opportunity for advancement to be able to keep that person's performance in their numbers. A lot of backstabbing and stealing credit occurs.



There's not a lot of advancement opportunity. When the economy was great in 2007 it wasn't that hard. If you were great in your job, you could move on to a slightly better position, and when you did well there, you could move to another slightly improved position, until you were where you wanted to be. Once the economy crashed in 2008 that all stopped. I get it. That happened everywhere. However, it also stopped all discussions of professional development and no effort was made to give opportunities to develop skills for the current role or another. As a result, future promotion will be very difficult because internal candidates won't be as competitive against external candidates.



Recruiting/HR and their processes are absurd. It can take months after applying for a position before you get an interview. You can apply for a role, not hear anything for several months, and then get an email that you have an interview the next day. So you end up with no opportunity to prepare and made no efforts to prepare because you never heard anything back. Feedback from interviews rarely exists or is very generic. Hiring managers are lazy and don't follow through. 



For every great manager there are ten clueless unhelpful managers. It's obvious that middle and upper management have no idea how to manage their people because there's very little accountability or responsibility on the part of front-line managers. Directors believe yelling at people is the only way to manage, so they will yell at their managers when the numbers are bad, and that's pretty much the extent of direction or vision executed at the management level. I have heard several managers complain that they don't feel it's right that their performance is judged based on the performance of the people they manage. Well, that's what managers are there to do. If they aren't managing towards success, then they aren't doing a great job. I understand there are low performers, etc. but when I see managers playing ping pong for hours in the break room, there's not a lot of accountability in the system.



There's a lot of infighting between different business units. Everybody points fingers but nobody takes ownership over problems and fixes them. Customers and employees get stuck in the middle with no way to get out.



Anonymous no longer places a premium on its talent. Since 2008 the company has eliminated whole business groups with no effort to keep around people with tenure with tremendous transferrable skills. It does very little to help grow talent or keep it from leaving. Where a few years ago employees were loyal to the company and that loyalty was returned, the company has completely eliminated that loyalty. As a result, the company keeps losing great talent and keeps hiring new people who underperform and embarass those of us who strive to be great at our jobs. 



While all of the above things are common among businesses and I have, as most people, experienced similar trends at other jobs, what I will point out is that these problems were not institutionalized in a company that performs with mediocrity and accepts laziness in its overall perforamce. Anonymous is a top competitior in its markets and a lot of its strength historically came from the loyalty to and from its employees. Anonymous has worked very hard to treat its employees with indifference and management -- from the very top -- has set the company afloat with no real vision or guidance other than keep trying to make things that don't work struggle to work.

Pro: Anonymous employs some of the brightest, most innovative and dedicated people in the industry.  The culture is high energy and fast-paced so you'll never be bored.  Most people are willing to step up and share their expertise while fighting fires (if you know which group/s and which person, within that group, to ask).  Most people in support/ops are required to work an excessive number of hours each week (usually 60+) but you can learn more at Anonymous in 1 year than you would learn at another investment firm.
Con: The culture can be highly stressful at the best of times but numerous Reductions in Force (RIF's) over the past several years have impacted morale and compounded the stress level.  Entire groups have been RIFed, regardless of the criticality of their function or their individual performance ratings.  I know of numerous high-quality, highly respected people who have been let go as part of the on-going re-org, so performance, dedication and a good review rating won't save you from a RIF if your group is a focus.  Reviews for bonuses and raises seem to be based less on performance than on the corporate review paradigm, which dictates that a manager must assign a specific number of satisfactory, sub-standard and outstanding ratings (example - a manager with 10 direct reports can be given the directive that of their 10 direct reports, they must have 1 employee rated sub-standard and only 1 rated outstanding.  The other 8 must be rated Proficient/Satisfactory, regardless of performance.  Due to Fido having such a high number of exceptionally bright and dedicated people, who step up when they see a problem, it is fairly common to find groups where the majority (if not all) of the team members deserve an Outstanding rating.  With the existing paradigm, only 1 can receive that rating and receive a fair bonus/raise.  Eight of the others will receive a Proficient/Satisfactory rating and receive very small bonus/raises.  And one of those 10 people will receive a rating of  N ('Needs Improvement'), which prohibits a raise/bonus and tags them as a probability for the next RIF - and you can't internally transfer if you received a rating of N).  Promotions are also tied to review ratings.  Before I left, the policy was that an employee had to receive 2 consecutive reviews of above Satisfactory/Proficient to qualify for a possible promotion.  That did not ensure they would receive the promotion, it just meant that they qualified for a possible promotion, if one was available.  There is little to no work/life balance and based on the review paradigm, there is no financial incentive for regularly sacrificing your personal life to protect their reputation and business interest.

Summary: "Big on Vision and Teamwork, Small on Compensation"
Pro: If you enjoy a team environment working with other highly motivated and intelligent individuals, Anonymous is a wonderful place to work.  The company survives on a high level of commitment from its employees, and has been incredibly successful as a result, even posting record profits during the worst recession of our time.  Particularly during the first couple of years out of college, Anonymous can be a rewarding and educational place to work.  Most people consider FIdelity a good training ground for better jobs in the industry that pay a decent salary.
Con: There are countless opportunities for advancement, but Anonymous has done away with most opportunities for actual pay raises.  All job opportunities are positioned as "Stepping up and contributing to the needs of the business", with vague promises of "potential merit increases" which never come to fruition, or "increased bonus opportunity", which likewise never comes to fruition.  Raises are only given for major job promotions, such as from manager to director, and even then they are minimal.

Pro: Anonymous has hired some excellent and very qualified people.  They created a very strong brand name through a focus on technology and
Con: Because of the size of Anonymous there are numerous levels management. Each level needs to prove their importance and thus creates and changes various policies, programs and guidelines. Anonymous is constantly changing  how they do business along with moving upper management in and out of various roles. The message to our clients is we are consistently changing how we do business. Due to so many various groups, any change in one effects the other. There is constant fixing of issues and solving shortcomings in the system. Our current issue relates to rolling out the "pod" as it was made to be a success  even before it was rolled out. It was over staffed, over funded, few clients and support both from internal as well as external OSG groups. Once it was declared a major success the remaining tiers of service were rolled out. This time all support was cut off from the out side groups, causing all internal groups to design a path in how to facilitate various "how toos". These new PODS where to handle the same amount of work with 3-4 times the number of clients. Where the average rep took- 10-15 calls  a day the new expectation is 35-50 calls. The service groups are now required to work overtime and find a way to get it done. Just as any change takes time to work out all the kinks we will find a way to make it work.  However in the near future upper management will change again and we will be following a new model. Management will need to prove their worth and will create all types of policies, programs and we will be jumping through a whole new set of hoops. Our focus needs to be on the clients and listen to them and listen to the employees who are on the front lines and understand what they dealing with. There is a huge gap between the reality of what we do and what upper management believes we do.

Pro:
Great company/reputation for your resume. Very nice 401k match and profit sharing. Bonus's are great if you're in the top 5-10% of the company.  I believe Senior management is very good. The Johnson family has been good.



Kathy Murphy was a great addition to the company.
Con:
I find there is a complete lack of respect for the regular employee.  Very low pay and bonus's for most employees. As you move up with in the company a culture of superiority is fostered and encouraged. You have royalty and the peasants. 



Most middle management  has been brainwashed and this is their only professional experience, thus they think and act a like.....very scary if you've worked anywhere else.  If you ever express an opinion or disagree with those folks.....you're permanently branded.  You can do that with the highest levels of management and it would be respected (they are far away and only get to visit a few times a year). 



Employee turnover is unbelievably high (this is good for creating opportunity), however, it's a reflection of how employees are treated.  Management encourages people to be given warnings  to increase job performance vs. rewarding them.   



e.g. You have 10 business goals. You could be doubling your results with nine of them, however, you're just below goal with one that's not up on the list of importantance.  Instead of averaging out your overall performance, they will focus on that one thing again and again. The person who just barely made the goal with all 10 is far better than you are.



The company will waste money and spend lavishly all for show but a great majority of employees don't benefit from this.

Summary: "Anonymous sucks for me, will it for you?"
Pro: Job security. For the most part it takes a lot to be laid off or fired.  Benefits are good, which include profit sharing, access to HSA/Health Flex accounts, etc.
Con: You won't get any significant raises unless you make it your priority to move departments when you can. This requires you to apply and search for internal jobs constantly, which I have seen work for some people. To sum it up, there is no autonomy in your job. From the start, they want you to buy into the "Anonymous Culture." However, they have the money to spend to be a successful company - at least for the short term. So if you want job security this is the place for you. If you're looking for autonomy in your job and play an active role in the company you work for, I suggest you look elsewhere.

Con: If you work in a place with a lot of politics, it could be a nightmare.

Pro: the benefits are really good
Con: to many people interested in impressing the boss

Summary: "Good company to work for but needs more diversity within senior management"
Pro: The pay is better than average for entry level positions. They do a good job keeping up with technology which makes your job a little easier.
Con: Needs more diversity within management and other positions that pay over $50,000.

Summary: "A lot of manual effort from disconnected systems and lack of information goes into completing daily work."
Pro: It's a good way to get a wide variety of experiences and assignments. There is always so much that's broken, so it's ripe with opportunities for improvement. There is a high frequency of change, which can also be challenging.  The environment at Anonymous is very friendly for those who work and play well with others regardless of how poorly you do your job. Overall, a pretty safe environment.
Con:
Anonymous has a lot of legacy software and hardware platforms, so it's not the place to be if you are interested in getting experienced with newer technologies or automation. Anonymous is addicted to faulty systems which require high levels of maintenance and manual effort, because they can get them "cheaply" through volume discounts and enterprise licensing. Approximately 15% of your time on the job will be required for mandatory "ethics" and "compliance" training, double-recording your time and work results in disconnected, deficient, and faulty systems. The ethics training is as much a joke as the company's stated values, which include honesty. As long as you aren't tossing midgets or taking kickbacks, honesty is not even valued (especially amongst management), much less promoted in ANY way. I personally know of managers who are told by upper management to lie to their employees. I'm not sure how "ethics" can even exist in such an inherently dishonest environment.

By the time you complete all of the "mandatory training" and administrative tasks required, you will be lucky to have 60% of your time left to do your job. They will schedule enough meetings to consume another 20% of your time, but management will still treat it as 100%.  Of course, while trying to complete your job tasks in this remaining 40% of your time, you will also be expected to train offshore staff how to do your job.  The offshore staff is culturally trained to say "yes" to everything and then delivering on 10-20% of what they promise.  But it's okay, because they are perceived as being "cheap labor", even though they can't seem to work independently and require that you do about 40% of the job for them.  A significant amount of time on the job is also wasted "shifting gears", as management is largely incompetent and doesn't understand the costs associated with changing your mind and focus constantly. Often, fake deadlines are created and things given an overblown sense of importance to pressure employees into working late. Many times I have arrived at work and started to work on an "important" task perhaps less than 1 hour in duration and still struggled to focus through the constant interruptions to complete this before the end of the work day, which is often late into the evening. My boss interrupts me 6 - 8 times a day for "emergencies", and then becomes upset because "he doesn't know what I am working on".

Penny-wise and pound foolish, Anonymous purchases systems based solely on the purchase price and doesn't seem to know the 1st thing about TCO (Total Cost of Ownership).  They build lavish and expensive bathrooms, while looking for ways to cut expense reimbursement, benefits, and bonuses, while they make billions shipping American jobs overseas. They have contributed significantly to the infrastructure and economy in India while they add to the unemployment lines domestically.

Talk about a hostile work environment! Making your boss look good here is the only thing that counts. The company's core values are an absolute joke, as is their dental plan, "ethics", and "compliance" training. Rather than focus on getting results, motivating employees and doing the right thing, managers spend their time sneaking up behind employees to see what's on their computer screen. If they see a similar screen that might have been there 2 hours before, the assumption is made that you have done nothing else within that 2 hour period, even though there are electronic records of all systems usage. Why check when it's easier for them to assume?

If you are technically incompetent and can lie like a politician, there is a comfy home for you in management at Anonymous. Once you're a member in this exclusive club, it's all about you and other than committing career-icide through political folly, there will be nothing you can do wrong. 

Also, if you ever want to invest on your own, Anonymous will make sure that whatever gains you might make will be more than offset by the paperwork, administrative hassles and threats to your employment status from their "compliance" department. And that's only IF they pre-approve every trade that you make.

Pro:
1. Starting pay is at or slightly above market rate.  Total compensation package including bonus, profit sharing, and 401K match are relatively good.

2. Many benefits including 7% 401K match, computer purchase assistance, inhouse gyms, excellent facilities, subsidized lunches, etc.

3. Relatively lax work schedule heavily dependent on manager.

4. Challenging fast paced environment built upon a foundation of chaotic reorgs.
Con:
1. Year over year pay increases, as well as promotion-based pay increases are way below market.

2. Benefits are being cut as a cost-cutting tool.

3. Seasonality of work results in very slow down periods and very chaotic up periods.

4. Promotions are rare; must be aggressive to pursue career growth.  Inhouse promotions substantially smaller pay increases than external candidates.  Very very illogical promotion system.

5. Technology is the bane of Anonymous.  Too many platforms that do not sync with each other resulting iin a plethora of manual processes that will inadvertedly crash one day!

6. There are so many process people; decisions take aeons to execute

Summary: "Good experience then a big political debacle."
Pro: Brand Name. Location Location Location
Con: Pay is subpar to every other company in Finance. Promised promotions and advancement into investment roles however they only give those were only given to Ivy League graduates or through nepotism. Not worth your time after 2 years empty promises and no following through. Need ti be a Johnson or a graduate of Harvard or MIT to get anywhere waste of 5 years of my career.

Summary: "Fast-paced, multi-focused environemnt with too many top priorities that impede effectively executition."
Pro: Strong market presence; Depth of product and services; Financially sound and reputable business practices;
Con: Reduced profit margins are impacting internal business operations.  Day to day work of associates is more difficult due to managements lack of focus on efficiently and effectiving managinig core business needs.   Internal departments/companies act more as competitors rather than partners of the same company resulting in limited  effectiveness as well as limited professional opportunites for associates within the company.

Summary: "Seemed like a decent place at first but so glad I left"
Pro: Pretty solid benefits, SOME people I worked with were really fun to be with, great 401k options especially with the matching and the ability for a Roth 401k
Con:
POLITICS.  I am aware this happens everywhere but the amount of sucking up and brown nosing at this place is absolutely unbelievable.  The best way I can describe it is as a shark tank.  



Certain people would stop at nothing to stab you in the back.  If you ever did anything that could remotely be a mistake you would get a email from whoever found it and they would copy every manager that they could possibly think of.  This was not just in my area, it happened in every area I had ever been in contact with during my time.



Managers did not care about their employees (except for their "favorites") and never provided any training that could help you to move up through the company.



Advancing your career is basically impossible.  If you are content making a very low salary for an extended period of time while being stuck in an entry level job into your 30's (yes I saw a lot of this) then Anonymous is for you.



Raises were an absolute joke.  I know the economy is not in the best shape but it is insulting to get a "raise" that might increase my paycheck by a quarter.  Not to mention all employees received the same "pay increase" regardless of talent.

Pro: benefits aren't what they used to be bit still are good.
Con: they treat employees with little respect; its not a fun place to be.

Pro:
Opportunity to try different careers. I moved around from a contractor to full time then moved into 5 other types of positions within my 19 yrs at Anonymous.

Great benefits. I was able to use adoption cost benefits, PC purchasing 3 times, continuing ed assistance, fitness reimbursement, etc. while there.

Last job with Mondays off and remote work from home one day was great!
Con:
Company is downsizing and relocating workers in an ongoing basis for the past 4 years. Folks that relocated to NC found they were laid off soon after. 

They used to RIF in large volumes but appear to do 100 at a time now to go under the radar of media. 

They do have a great severance package though for those with many years.

Recently it's been more difficult to climg the ladder due to cost cuts.

Pro:
-- Prestige of getting to tell people you work for Anonymous Investments, which everyone knows to be a good company.

-- Good benefits/401k etc.  I cannot stress this enough.

-- Still better than many other companies out there

-- You get to see some VERY interesting accounts daily and have some very interesting conversations.

-- Some of the employees (read: not managers) are friendly.
Con:
-- Highly Tracked minute to minute punching in and out for every conceivable activity during the day.  This gets old VERY FAST.

-- Obsessive compulsive, paranoid, schizophrenic, micromanaged culture in which you are constantly under the microscope.

-- Damned if you do, damned if you don't culture.  They will find a way that you did something wrong, ALWAYS.  Especially trade support.

--  Pay not commensurate with job duties. (These financial phone conversations are extremely difficult, involved and stressful, especially with some of Anonymous's high net worth clients).  

-- Most of the managers are truly awful human beings.

-- Horrible work schedules, hours, and and team inconsistency.   Part of this is the nature of the beast, but they make NO effort to reduce the volatile and brutal nature of everyones schedules, teams collapsing every month, etc.  

--  Not much potential to truly learn.  They teach you the Anonymous Way, which is useless for the rest of the world outside of Anonymous.

--Poor work/life balance

Con: very much a micro management atmosphere, they squeeze so much out of the employee where it loses the joy of working.  Double standards often are applied, very very political, not always based on meritocracy.  Too many people (not all) have been promoted to management that were less than mediocre reps that are not qualified to lead an investment sales force.  Atmosphere is going towards  a robotic-like, lots of metrics/activity measures vs. just measuring performance.  Current atmosphere when asking for "feedback" is not to give honest feedback, but instead, it's to provide comments that you know it's what mgmt wants to hear.  Compensation structure is constantly changing and which creates a lot of anxiety.

Pro:

Training Support for staff

Lateral Movement
Con:
Compensation should be realistic and market standards to current employees too.  In some cases there could be major diff in compesation between existing employees and new employees who have similar skills and exp.



Technical competence in certain senior managers is not up to scratch

Pro: The benefits are amazing, the work environment is great and lots of good people to work with - very sharing and  helpful.
Con: There is no work/life balance. Workload is so heavy that I was never able to go on vacation without taking my laptop. Forget about taking a day off - the blackberry chirped constantly. Hundreds of emails daily and keeping up with everything was nearly impossilbe.

Summary: "Anonymous was a great place to work, I enjoyed my time there."
Pro: Anonymous does a great job of hiring people with compatibale personalities.  I have made life long friends with co-workers at the company, which made it enjoyable coming to work every day.
Con: Due to the volume of work, late hours occurred frequently.

Summary: "Great place to work.  Its a large enough company so there is plenty of opportunity to advance."
Pro: There is a lot of room for advancement and to move to different Anonymous companies.
Con: Pay started out relatively low compared to similar positions at other companies.

Summary: "Gud for ppl who want have less work pressure"
Pro:
Efforts are appreciated. 

Perfect work life balance. 

Nice company to stick for longer duration when you want to get settle down.
Con:
processes are quite slow in nature and things do take lot of time. 

promotion is a quite long process and it takes time to go to next level.

Summary: "Not the place to jump start your career"
Pro: great worlk life balance, great benefits
Con: poor management, poort to no talent management, no opportunities or fomal career tracks

Summary: "Anonymous was a great place to work"
Pro: Good team members, flexible work options, good exposure/visibility plans, thoughtful approach to development. Good opportunities to develop professionally, including coaching and training.
Con: Sometimes the pace was a little slower than I liked. Teams can be overly competitive, especially during down times. Like in many workplaces, strategic plans do not always connect down to day to day work/implementation.

Summary: "Good place to start...don't stay longer than 2 years"
Pro: Great on the resume, good comp & benefits package
Con: Little outside the box thinking, management view employees as replaceable.

Pro: Great Atmosphere, Managers are extremely friendly and knowledgeable
Con: Monotonous work, No focus on building soft skills

Summary: "Ok place, great benefits but lots of politics"
Pro:
1) Great Benefits

2) Ability to move within the organization

3) Great pay if you negotiate it upfront .

4) Good work life balance in some groups
Con:
1)  Lot of politics

2)  Frequent re-organizations and changes within the company. No stability in senior management.

3) New hires can be hired at much higher salaries.A person hired at a lower level could have much higher salary than yours.

4) Work life balance can be bad in some groups.

5) Lots of employees in IT are not proficient in their fields.

Pro: Private Company which provides a higer level of comfort during crazy economic times
Con: They are not a forward thinking company and everyone has worked there for 15+ years so they are VERY slow to react to new ideas on how to improves processes

Pro:
benefits are good - medical, dental, vision, short and long term disability, life ins, some locations have onsite gyms, most locations have cafeterias, time off, 

work life balance

opportunity for advancement
Con:
frequent reorgs create a lot of unnecessary noise

frequent manager changes cause day to day disruption, as you have to figure out how to manage your manager

inconsistent messages from first line management

lack of mentoring programs unless you are a new college hire

Pro: Ideal place to start career in investment field. Salaried position with outstanding benefits. Ability to get securities licenses.
Con: Work life balance Is sometimes lacking in fast paced environment

Summary: "A fantastic place to work with equality of treatment across levels"
Pro:
No discrimination of employees based on position.

Friendly Atmosphere
Con: Policies regarding employee growth need to be more quantifiable.

Summary: "A good place to work if you don't mind staying in the same position forever"
Pro: Benefits, profit sharing, shares (when senior management feels generous), people.
Con: No advancement, Sr. Management comes in and provides unwarranted praise and recognition without consulting mid-level management.  Don't expect many managers to step up to the plate for you.

Summary: "Several years of various mid-level management roles"
Pro:
- great people

- great benefits

- strong ethics
Con:
- slow to get stuff done

- hierarchial

Pro: good benefits, good place to start your career
Con: low pay, not in best location to work in.

Pro:
- Great benefits

- Great people
Con:
- Very difficult to move up

- People are treated as numbers on the balance sheet

Pro:
Good benefits

Great work hours

Nicer people
Con:
Low base

Older crowd

Bad management

Low turnover

Summary: "over all a great place to work"
Pro: tremendous benefits, reputable firm, highest integrity co-workers. Management works very hard to get the employee input and there's ample opportunity to participate in surveys and product feedback and opinion.
Con: There's very little incentive to stay long term in one role. You have to move around if you want to significantly increase your salary. It's also hard to move within the organization unless you are willing to relocate or lateral

Pro:
Work/life Balance

People you work with

Treatment of Employees by the firm

Compensation packages
Con: Constant Restructuring and intrusive background checks to get in

Summary: "Very friendly work environment and well paid"
Pro: Benefits - 100% match on 401k up to 7% of salary. 90% tuition reimbursement up to $10,000 per year if business related and very simple to get reimbursed- no run around. Can apply for new position every 6 months to a year. Management is very supportive of employee growth and input. The firm is very accomodating when it comes to rearranging your schedule for unexpected emergencies, anything related to your children or school related matters.
Con: The one downside is that most of the positions within the company are either  based on sales as some form of your compensation and performance review or the positions are assisting customers on the phone regarding their accounts and investments. There are occasionally positions that are non-sales and non-phone based such as marketing, accounting, etc., but very rarely are these position entry level. They typically require several years of experience and a  degree. But is you start your career in an entry level position on the phone or sales and get your degree while working you still don't qualify for these positions because you lack the experience and there is not a way to get that kind of experience (in non-sales and non-phone based positions) without leaving the company and gaining the experience elsewhere first.

Pro: Great people to work with - depending on your department, location.  Perhaps I've been lucky.  Despite a few tough years, Anonymous is still a positive place to work - and they have begin to hire back some of the people laid off.
Con: Not as many opportunities to try new things as there used to be.  Some of the very Senior management doesn't really understand the business properly - and some of the products have suffered as a result.

Pro: Anonymous was a great place to work, with plenty of opportunities for growth and learning.  It's also clear that they like to grow from within, bringing people along throughout their careers.
Con: There can be some siloing within certain parts of the organization, but this can be overcome with work and good communication.

Pro: Benefits are excellent, but that's where it ends.
Con: As far at the branch network goes...They are all about high pressure sales and pushing expensive annuities on clients who don't need them.  If you don't do it, you get managed out quickly.  Major change from what the firm used to be.

Pro: Large company with great Benifits
Con: Hard to understand eveything they are doing.

Pro:
Probably one of the best place to balance work and life.

People in Anonymous are typically very accommodative and supportive.
Con: Not so much for the company itself. It's the financial market is no longer in its golden age. Anonymous in turn, is forced to make many tough decisions which has impacted a lot on both morale and quality of work. Still, it's a big company and can survive without a problem.

Summary: "Great company, but non-phone jobs are very hard to get...aside from moving across country to a branch office."
Pro:
-Top notch benefits

-Industry-leading entry level training

-Pretty intelligent and social group of workers

-Name recognition

-Nice facilities

-Anonymous cares about it's employees
Con:
-Extremely difficult to get a job off the phones.(During the interview, they love to tell you that we promote from within. What they fail to mention is that literally 95%+ of the promotions are to other phone jobs)



-Getting into a branch/non-phone job is possible if your are willing to move out of state to one of about 100 locations across the country...even though most branches have a maximum of about 10-12 people per branch)



-Management is a loose term. Managers basically grade your calls from their desk and you get an email telling you to review your score.  Otherwise they are in meetings..  There literally isn't any "managing" or developing going on and self developement is rare b/c it's all about taking or making as many calls in a day as possible.



-Burnout is very common because of the monotonous nature of the job...one call after another all day.



-Many of the mid level managers were in the call center job for years and this is all they know and can be hard to relate to if you have ideas outside the box.

Summary: "Long days and high security but good compensation"
Pro: Salary and to learn more about finance and the systems behind it.
Con: Long hours which can be stressful.

Pro: The work culture is good . The management is flexible and supports work life balance. It was also an easy commute from my place.
Con: Salaries are average promotions are slow.  The jobs have dried up and so the opportunities as well. Not much to complain about

Pro: Senior executive leadership is really trying to do the right thing and make it right for the employees.  Due to the nature of the business, you learn a lot of knowledge that's beneficial to personal financial management.
Con:
Although the executives are trying, it doesn't get translated down the chain ethically.  There's too much bureaucracy in middle management and it's all about who knows who and not necessarily who's the most qualified.  Opportunities for growth is very limited and not based on your performance.  Also, they will promote from their "inner circle" first before considering anyone from the outside, regardless of the qualifications they bring.  



Many are set in their Anonymous ways and not very receptive to innovative ideas.

Pro: Good trainning and very nice staff
Con: Very long hours and require high level of dedication to work-ethic.

Pro:
- Great benefits

- Some of the best co-workers that I've worked with; well educated, positive outlook on life, you can tell Anonymous picks the cream of the crop.

- Decent salary; bonus is based on how well you treat customers rather then on sales.

- Great opportunity if you work hard; everything is merit-based.
Con:
- If you're not willing to move (out of state for example) it's harder to move into a branch role.

- Being tied to the phones is exhausting; doing the same thing day in and day out can get boring fast, which is the reason why everyone wants a branch job which in turn makes it hard to get into.

Summary: "They pay you a lot to keep you there, but the work you do is not worth it."
Pro: Great Benefits is the only good thing about Anonymous.
Con: As a Financial Representative, you are expected to answer phone calls 8 hours a day, without any indication of what issue is going to come up. You must handle everything from being cursed at, yelled at and called names, when management will say nothing to help. They expect you to be nice to those who are very rude to you on the phone.

Summary: "Always something new to learn but you are just a cog in the wheel"
Pro: Fair place to work -great co-workers
Con: Just part of the machine

Summary: "A place where the company cares about you."
Pro: There are amazing benefits. Water, tea, and microwaves are available. I even like the fact the place is color schemed to fit Fidelities colors. It's a pleasant atmosphere to say the least.
Con: There is alot to remember upfront and continued employment requires you to have the series 7 and 63.

Pro: Benefit package and 401K match
Con: No advancement, Managers that care more about themselves not employees

Summary: "It's OK, plan moving back to a software house."
Pro:
- Good Package and benefits

- Nice Offices

- Flexibile working options, working from home, time off

- lots of holidays
Con:
- Conservative banking culture

- Managers not very technical and look down at engineers

- Layoffs and Hiring taking place at the same time. Difficult to stomach the Anonymous cares about it's employees mantra. 

- Plan moving back to a software house soon and out of a big bank.

Summary: "Not for Freshers, Good for PM, SPM and above who wish to enjoy nice package without much work"
Pro:
Flexibility - Work from home, Vacation Time.

Great place for women to work if they need a perfect work-LIFE balance (Subjective - but true mostly).

Good if you have the passion to learn yourself - Domain, Technical.
Con:
Freshers and Tech savvy folks cannot learn much from their every day task.

Use of "Agile" to micro-manage.

Too many managers and sometimes for the same project :)

Pro: Great training, opportunities for growth and people
Con: fast pace, high pressure, competitive

Pro: Brand Name. Off on weekends. Plenty of OT if you want/need it. 401(k) - 1$ for 1$ Co Match up to 7%, plus Profit Sharing Contributions. Many Corp perks/discounts available. Family owned company. Huge on customer service 1st, profits 2nd. Classroom training (8 wks).
Con: Crazy call volume with recent market volatility. Call Center environment. Performance metric goals/standards are set too high and can be a challenge to achieve at times.Managers have way too much fun while reps are constantly busting butt. Managers are not proactive enough, so be prepared to take ownership of your development so you don't get left behind by your peers. Also, expect a new manager every 6-8 mths.

Pro:
some really good benefits, and hasn't cut its 401k or profit sharing

pretty flexible work environment re: in/out of office
Con:
IT base pay is not competitive

too many managers don't care how they are perceived by their team = if you kiss up right, you're generally OK

Stop telling employees about the great quarterly and annual results then insulting them with crappy raises

Summary: "It's a great place to work, in spite of what others might say."
Pro: I've been working at Anonymous for 6 years and it's still a great place to work.  Senior Management does sincerely seem to care about you and help you succeed.  The benefits are awesome and the people are great.  All in all, it's a dream job:  challenging, interesting, and rewarding.
Con: I wish we could keep good talent at the senior level.  It seems there's a lot of turnover at the top.

Pro: Good medical/benefits plans, multinational company, allows shadowing for lateral and upward movement through the comany, they encourage skillset improvement
Con: Can take more personal time unexpectedly

Pro: The salary and benefits are very good, including bonuses and 401k contributions and decent medical insurance.  The atmosphere is professional.
Con: The company is going through a transition and is moving people to other locations, especially out of the Boston area to other states.  The different divisions of Anonymous do not always cooperate with each other.  This makes it hard to meet goals.
Career growth is pathetic; need to have right connections for growth.

Pro:
Good benefits (7% 401K match, profit sharing)

Flexible hours (for both salary and hourly)

Nice facility (clean, secure, aesthetics)
Con: Middle and Senior Management (too many layers and not well-trained)

Pro: Anonymous is a solid company with a great reputation.
Con: Cubicle environment... managed by matrix.

Summary: "Good people, not high enough pay or advancement opportunities"
Pro:
Great people

Great industry

Fast-paced

Ineresting work

Important work

Great benefits
Con:
So large, not enough movement between departments

Not enough communication between departments

Not enough leadership development

Pay low compared to similar companies in industry

Summary: "Pleasant at times stressful. Limited ability to help clients efficiently and a glass ceiling after 2yrs."
Pro: Benefit structure is great. It's a safe place to work if you're just looking for a starting place to work, and you are content to grow a career somewhere else.
Con: work environment is placid, juvenile management techniques, limited respect for capabilities of employees. Employee morale and attitudes are negative qualities. Lower level management with limited to no brokerage and finance experience. Get the impression that the organization is afraid to take chances and people are afraid to put it on the line.

Summary: "Generally fine environment to work for the short term."
Pro: Generally very good environment to work with above average salary and benefits.  A great place to take advantage of company match programs and profit sharing.
Con: The firm is very bureaucratic and slow to get new projects, products, services accomplished.  There can be conflicting agendas and goals between groups which delay progress.

Pro: Well recognized stable company that is good to work for.  Good team work and support from everyone on a daily basis.
Con: There is a lot of beauracracy which can sometimes roadblock efforts to do work.  Diffiucult to deal with some groups at times

Pro: Great Benefits and matching 4012
Con: the owners and higher management have no clue what the people who work for them do and how their constance changing of expectins creates a hostile environment.

Pro:
Good structure for someone right out of college. 



Above average pay and benefits.
Con:
In my business unit, the majority of promotions were given to people who were *intimate* with the managers.



Not uncommon to have multiple bosses giving mutually exclusive directions.

Pro: Paid Overtime.  Profit sharing. Education reimbursement was higher than average.  Paid training.
Con: Base Salary.  Human Resource department is worst I have ever dealt with.

Summary: "My experience was satisfactory overall.  High pressure, long hours, low pay, good benefits."
Pro: Benefits, a good reputation.  Good people to work with, training and development opportunities.  Wide range of job choices.  Multiple locations.
Con: Pay was lower than my peers at public companies.  Long commute was difficult.  Lack of advancement opportunities in management since I was in Boston, and they have been moving out of Boston.  Inconsistent application of policies to employees.

Summary: "Pockets of strong talent, but too much general mediocrity and not enough merit-based turnover"
Pro: Private company (so no knee-jerk market-driven reactions to dumb analyst reports).  Pays well.  Some bright people in pockets.  Civilized and polite environment. Still strong franchise.
Con: Private ownership implies occasional arbitrary/crazy decisions.  Eg, the misguided "site strategy" (aka, kick 'em out of Boston) will drive substantial IP loss and talent bleed. Instability is on the rise.  Top-down decision making, run more like a club than a company. Entrenched passive-aggressive approach to discourse.

Pro: good health benefits, lots of advertising
Con: pay is poor for licensed reps

Pro: Good location,  very smart people to work with and learn from, the compensation is competitive, benefits are good too. You get enough resources to get your job done.
Con: Given Fido is an investment firm, the investment professionals get all the attention. As an employee from technology side, people may feel left out a bit.

Pro: Benefits are great, great management support, great work environment, friendly co- workers, etc.
Con: Strict but fair policies, wish it was more laid back environment, no off campus lunch, etc.

Pro: Benefits and educational opportunities are very good.
Con: Jobs open to outsiders when competent, loyal employees exist in house.  This practice must stop.

Pro: Job performance feedback is constant. Managers very willing to help. Goals are reasonable. Great work environment and benefits.
Con:
Need to follow the Anonymous career track - outside experience is not greatly valued. 

Compensation decidedly skewed to sales roles.

Pro:
Great Brand

Benefits

Good introduction to retail financial Planning and investments

low cost products

Generally client centric focus
Con:

Very political

Feels like change for the sake of change every 5 years

mediocre managed money products and fund performance

underlying pressure to sell proprietary products - i.e. FPP vs. WAS

You have to spend time in Boston to move up in the company

Pro: pay, the pay is good compared to other companies
Con: laid off,  heard people get laid off a lot

Pro: great brand, well established, high integrity
Con: low morale, difficult to navigate politics, a great deal of change, uncertainty, tolerating bad managers, siloed, slim opportuniities for advancement

Pro: Cool working environment. Independence , flexibility and benifts
Con: Limited technology exposure, lengthy and time consuming processes.

Pro:
Good Benefits for Health, Tuition, Profit Sharing, and Vacation

Easily accessible, 

Respects Employees and their Family committments. 

Allows personal growth
Con: High level of management politics. Career growth depends on the group you work for. Management policies flip-flop very much. Duplicate roles.

Summary: "Exposure to various technologies, infrastructure, poor recognition of work done, bad appraisals, less micro management"
Pro:
-No lay offs ever (in India)

-Respect for employees

-Salary not so great but not bad either

-If one is interested he/she can learn a lot on his/her own due to exposure to varied technologies and infrastructure.

-State of the art facilities

-Nice and spacious cubicles
Con:
-Less onsite opportunity (one particular BU is an exception though where employees get many onsite opportunities).

-Employees are not provided with the right information at the right time. Lots of things kept under the wraps.

-Less work and hence lesser change to grow professionally and technically

-Too much focus on not so important things (so many to name, check with the current and ex employees).

-Nothing much for folks from 0-8 yrs work exp in terms of learning

-Politics among management affects appraisals of employees.

-Favoritism and regionalism bias also there in certain BUs (not all BUs though).

Summary: "As others have said, It's a good place to start."
Pro: Benefits are great - 7% 401k match, 10% profit sharing, paid vacation and sick time, medical, dental, life insurance... All around great benefit package. If you want to work overtime it's there and it's abundant. A lot of great people and excellent training.
Con: No matter how much you enjoy people, the phone eventually wears on you... I worked with a lot of very great people but you quickly realize the only reason they're still there is because it's a way to make ends meet. At the Jacksonville site, the vast majority of the jobs are on the phone so there's very little opportunity to escape it. You will quickly find yourself wanting more out of your day to day and start looking for a job elswhere.

Pro: Benefits are outstanding, management is very respectful of employees, more ethical than other companies, and flexible with schedules if notice is given in a timely manner.
Con:
No advancement. It's all lateral movement. Hard to go vertical.



There were a few situations where individuals with consistently outstanding numbers never got promoted to positions they earned. I personally knew such a person and from speaking to him it was due to some issues with his manager.



Very family / religious environment. This can be a good or bad thing depending on your personally situation. 



When I was there, Anonymous implemented a terrible business plan which made service's function more like sales. It was done by making certain metrics, one is evaluated on, excessively high for sales like responsibilities. By the time I left, these metrics had been adjusted to more reasonable numbers. However, the service department still had a major roll in bringing in new money, without any compensation other than miniscule quarterly bonus.



Way to many metrics. You never know where you stand. I excelled in certain areas but average in others. My manager evaluations always made me feel like I was doing a bad job.

Summary: "Average Place to work, very mediocre senior management"
Pro: Good work life balance, High on team spirit
Con: Mediocre growth prospects, average quality of work

Summary: "Great place to start out from after undergrad"
Pro:
Working within the strategy function:

- Gain the full consulting skill set (analytics - quantitative and qualitative, presentation and communication to senior management, working in team settings)

- Be exposed to senior management within firm (BU heads etc.)

- Have great in breadth and depth in financial services industry (retail / institutional asset management, retail / institutional brokerage, retirement services / administration)
Con:
- Very political work environment: it's all about who you knew and who would go to bat for you

- Very hierarchical / many management layers

Pro: Good benefits and 401K, liked the coworkers, good location, good opportunities (apparently) at other sites, just none in North Carolina
Con: Stuck in the Raleigh area with zero opportunities advancement; the opportunities were few and far between, and if one did come up we have zero support from our manager.

Summary: "Long timer - been through the good, the bad, and the ugly - things are getting better."
Pro: Great benefits. If you work for the right manager and are smart and diligent you can make Anonymous work. You need to put your networking skills to work. Anonymous weathered the 2008 rather well considering others in the financial services sector. Anonymous puts a lot of stock in personal integrity and doing the right thing for the customer.
Con:
The company has grown a lot over the years and now is bureaucratic. It is hard to be heard and get improvement ideas through the system. There are many roles now that are high throughput and that can be hard on the people.



There is a lot of talk about investment in technology, but it does not seem to be focused on the right technology and there are decades old back-end systems that badly need some upgrading.

Summary: "A very customer focused company, but a tough place to work due to frequent reorganizations"
Pro:
High Pay

Great Benefits

Well Respected Company

Great People
Con:
Political

Spend a lot of time reorganizing

Likely to continue cutting costs in several areas (especially the benefits businesses) for some time

Pro: People are friendly.  Job is good. Salary is good. Overall it was a very nice experience and I would recommend joining Anonymous.
Con: No extra-curricular activities on the job site. There should be some opportunities for the employees to spend their time if they are tired.

Pro: Base Salary, Easy Lead Generation, Nice office
Con: Awful incompetent management, awful bonus structure comparative to industry standards, never satisfied with work, always something else that can be done, talk about big brother watching. I have never worked somewhere that everything, literally everything is tracked and used against you. Click this, click that, ok not good enough. Product push no matter what anyone says or what they make us tell clients, WE MUST SELL PRODUCT, including product that repeatedly underperforms but makes Anonymous so much money.

Summary: "Fast paced, performance driven, but long successful past performance can quickly be forgotten."
Pro: You are working at a company you know will do all the right and ethical things to succeed and win.  Great environment for working with some of the hardest working, brightest people I've ever met.
Con: Frequent reorganizations.  A lot of people do well financially and title-wise when at Anonymous, but many, especially in middle management are not prepared to succeed outside of Anonymous because a lot of success at Anonymous is based on learning how to navigate within it's unique corporate culture, not necessarily by learning and applying transferable best practices.

Pro:
Steady Paycheck, low variation of pay

Great benefits for families

Ability for internal promotion/upward mobility

Clear goals and expectations.  

Flexible to personal life
Con:
Gotta drink that cool aide!

Upward movement and career paths change frequently, leaving you behind, or with many more hoops to go through, makes it feel like you are treading water with your career.

Increased job responsibilities, reduced compensation.

Pro: Wok environment is great and Definately very good place to work ................................
Con: iF YOU STAY LONGER then may lay-off as age increases and salary increases,

Pro:
great benefits - 401k, profit sharing, health coverage

numerous locations

good training in phone sites

good products - feel confident to back and suggest to clients
Con:
compensation

poor training in investor centers

job opportunities not communicated

Summary: "Good place to learn but not stay"
Pro: Benefits, Vacation time accrued, Bonus/Stock
Con:
Not a lot of promotion paths unless you are a favorite

Jobs will go away once they feel you make too much and you are then replaced

Summary: "Fantastic benefits, but difficult at times to move within the company."
Pro: Benefits package is second to none.  Private company allows for long term strategies.
Con: Can be difficult to transition within the company.  5-year plans rarely get fullfilled b/c of high management turnover.

Pro:
Domain exposure to mutual funds

The Business users are quite knowledgeable

Feasibility of moving into different technology streams
Con:
No career growth

Management has very short term focus & memory

Appraisal & promotion process is absolutely biased

Pro:
Great team coworkers, and middle management. 

Resources easily available

Decent work life balance

Good Benefits.
Con: Upper Manangement could communicate better.

Pro: The Financial Representative position is a fantastic entry level position at Anonymous. It exposes you to customer's fears and educates you on how to fix them. Expects you to get your licensing exams in a timely fashion with tremendous support. Overall, this experience laid the foundation for my career in financial services, would recommend it to anyone graduating.
Con: Repetitive. Almost too lax of a culture, professional standard sways

Summary: "Great company but little room for advancement and low pay."
Pro: On-site gym, great facilities, great benefits in terms of insurance and 401-K matching (7%). Ability to work on a flexible schedule and analysts are able to work very independently.
Con: Low overall compensation. Little room for advancement except through putting your time in as an analyst. Very hard to transfer from back-office to either middle or front-office.

Pro:
Anonymous Inv as a culture seems really promising

Benefits are amazing

Pay, training

Oppurtunity everywhere
Con: Management incompetence led to chaos and work-place resentment.

Summary: "I learned a lot about life in a large corporation."
Pro: Anonymous has an easy going atmosphere.
Con: Movement between divisions is difficult.

Summary: "Great place to build a strong foundation in the investment industry"
Pro: Very comfortable corporate environment with individuals of extremely diverse backgrounds and expertise.
Con: Individual career growth is at times hindered by the number of employees vs. actual opportunites available.

Pro: Transparent ; Respect for Employees; Great Culture
Con: Lack of growth opportunities after a certain level

Summary: "Fair but lackluster with a hint of mindlessness."
Pro: Perks and job security. Great for middle aged employees.
Con: Cube farms and the oppressive corporate culture.

Summary: "Wonderful place to start and grow; now at a ceiling"
Pro: Job Diversity. Many opportunities to move around.  Ability to interact with many different businesses, people, walks of life. Fantastic employees - brilliant, innovative, passionate! Strong ties to community. Great salary and benefits.
Con: Recent (last 3 years) Market downturns, recession, and significant turnover in upper management coupled with major layoffs have seriously dampened morale.. the "IT Transformation" and 'transparent communications' failed.  New management is now getting settled and there is some optimism that the ship will be led by a strong leader and things forgotten and sour will be 'righted'.

Summary: "It is good place to initiate your career in smooth way."
Pro:
Gain in knowledge about financial sector.

Grasp in lot of discussions on IT Information .
Con: people should aware of its technological center in India. so, Slow marketing of fidelity bussiness services pvt. ltd. is one of the downsides

Summary: "Not the best run and most innovative place to work at, but benefits and people are good."
Pro: FMRCo has good benefits and good people. In general, people really try to think thru their actions before acting. One can pick up a lot of good habits coming from a smaller less structured company.
Con: There is a lot of politics and things sometimes take a while to get done. There are days where you feel like you are in a meeting all day and got nothing of value accomplished.

Pro: work from home is good option they give to employee.
Con: i didnt find any cons...but they have lot of meetings

Pro: Benefits are very good with a 7% match
Con: Almost impossible to change careers within company. Much better chance if you are an outsider.

Summary: "Good for work experience and life work balance"
Pro: Good compensation, benefits and work experience
Con: No growth for employees hired out side of Anonymous

Pro: Great environment, plenty of room to grow
Con: A lot of competition for new positions

Summary: "gained a lot of knowledge working at Anonymous"
Pro: Generally fair treatment of the employees; if you perform well, you will generally be recognized for your work.  Learned a lot in my 18 years working here.  Some good benefits.
Con: As with any large company, there can be some politics where you need to be careful of what you say.  Getting pay raises can be challenging.

Pro: The culture, the desire to "do what's right" for the client, great training.
Con: The pay is a little below average, especially the bonuses.

Summary: "Very enjoyable internship, great people and a good learning environment"
Pro: Learned the ins and outs of the Financial Representative role, helped operations staff support account executives and sat in on company seminars, meetings etc. Manager was more than willing to help me learn about financial planning and understand how current events in the financial markets effect everything. Everyone I worked with was welcoming, friendly, helpful and enjoyable to be around.
Con: Some down time, not busy the entire day. Could have more interaction with interns in other branch offices and programs going on at headquarters in Boston.

Summary: "I love what I do and Anonymous is a great place to do it."
Pro:
Great benefits, lots of opportunities to be involved in special projects.

Management is very interested in helping you make the most of your abilities.
Con: Limited opps for advancement in Florida.  Very confusing about which Anonymous I work for when the other Anonymous (Anonymous National Financial) is also headquartered here.

Summary: "Job Growth at the company has disappeared"
Pro: Benefits, flex work opportunities.  More opportunities on business side than IT side.
Con: No opportunity for growth or promotion.

Summary: "A good run, but not enough opportunity"
