Summary: "Micro management, double standards, and politics reign supreme."
Pro:
~401k and profit sharing are excellent. 

~Education reimbursement. Will pay 90% of CFP certification.

~Health benefits are good, but a bit expensive, and in order to reduce the expense quarterly, you must engage in an online "wellness" program.

~High volume business allows for lots of opportunities to hone in your investment and retirement planning skills.
Con:
We are hired for our past successes in planning, sales and relationship management, but then mircro managed and questioned for every single action beyond belief. It is hard to work here and maintain a sense of self respect and dignity! 

~Phone calls are listened-in on by management, and then your conversation with an existing elderly client is called in to question, like, why did you waste 5 minutes talking to her, continuing to build that "relationship", and looking up the status of the TOA for her, when you simply could have forwarded her to the call center cust service team? Seriously? Every rep in my branch has suffered a similar type of encroachment.

~Management will occasionally either sit in to observe an appointment, or they will have you dial their extension and listen remotely from their office phone. It is an arbitrary and random decision as to which appointments they "join", but really, nothing shakes the confidence of a HNW prospect more than thinking the advisor they are here to see is undergoing some sort to management oversight!! It doesn't matter how well the manager justifies it to the prospect, they are thinking, "run"!! Every rep in my branch has suffered a failed appointment due to this hideous micro-management.

~Anonymous preaches the relationship model, putting the customer needs first, holistic financial planning, blah blah, then really only cares about what products you "sold" to each client. Management is very very short-sighted. An appt where you meet with a multi-million $ prospect preparing for retirement in a few months, building the relationship, developing trust, laying ground work for all future wealth planning, is not regarded as a successful appointment or very good use of your time, because it did not result in actual "business" today.

~Anonymous is bombarding their clients with a never-ending barrage of email, mail, just non-stop marketing, all on the S/AE behalf, which drives most clients absolutely nuts.

~They only care about whether or not you are completing the menial "tasks", like clicking all the appropriate buttons in siebel. You are tracked and watched and measured on every single little thing you can imagine. How many clicks you clicked. How many times you dialed out...And all your numbers that are tracked are not only to ensure you are being a busy little bee, but the manager is rated on how many little clicks and menial tasks his/her advisors are doing. It's really all about how to make the manager look good to his/her manager!

~Management at the branch level is extremely lame. They want to treat you like a child, and keep you fearful, knowing every little move is being tracked and watched. Like I said, it is hard to maintain a sense of dignity and self respect in an environment like this. Those who can brown nose management, and are otherwise spiteful, political and backstabbing (to fellow colleagues) do well here. Success is: just tell management what they want to hear, and slam clients into products to satisfy management... Those with little talent and integrity stay, endure, and ultimately get promoted, perpetuating the bad leadership. They stay, put up with the games, and endure because they realize they could not make it anywhere else (except, perhaps, on a used car lot). Those with talent, integrity and truly good planning skills leave for a saner environment. 

~Clients in the S/AE book are very frustrated by the fact that every time they get assigned a new S/AE, and they happen to like that advisor and feel that they are working with someone with knowledge and integrity, that advisor ends up leaving. They keep getting turned over, until ultimately, they will end of in the book of one of the talentless, low-integrity bozos that never leave, or, they will just TOA out of Fido.

~Management, by their own admission, have never worked in our S/AE role as it is currently designed. The "relationship" model is relatively new, and as reps, they only served customers that were fed to them by the "green machine" on a transactional, not relationship, model. I think that disconnect helps explain the double standard; why they focus on tracking/forcing transactional business while falsely preaching relationship development. They like to talk about how successful "they" were in the role...but yeah, if all I had to do was take inbound calls and leads, roll the assets over and slap the client in PAS, funds, and/or FILI, then just move on to the next one with no follow up or relationship accountability...well, heck, any moron could do that.

Pro:
- Great benefits

- Good learning experience in the financial services industry

- Leave work at work..no stress when out of work
Con:
- Sit in a cube all day..constant grind

- Prepare to be attatched to a phone all the time besides 2 measly 15 min breaks and a lunch

- Glorified customer service

- Managers for the most part are self appointed by who the upper managers "like" and shouldnt be managers...everything is delegated like this from upper management, down

- Forced to work OT because they don't hire enough people

Pro: Easy Series 7 training.  The benefits are pretty decent.
Con:
Phones, phones, phones, phones.... get the picture?



This job is mundane at the core.  Every single task is repetitive.  It is a constant stream of taking glorified service calls over and over, with the same requests again and again.  



There is very little outside opportunities, or work responsibilities.  



Managers are nothing but micro-managing and just want to see themselves go up the ladder.



All promotions are just another form of phone job in a service or sales related role.



How many times do you have to explain rules of IRA distribution before you go insane?

Summary: "Borderline discriminatory management. Mediocrity at its worst!"
Pro: Nice campus, free coffee, free parking. Quarterly appreciation event with cupcakes and games.
Con: No career. Politics counts for 90%, which hurts the evolution of projects and deliverables. Improvisation, lack of leadership skills, and management that plays favorites, not with those that contribute the most, or who do the best for the company, but those who kiss the boss's behinds more often. People will often take credit for your deliverables, and will also blame you for their mistakes and snafus. Performance reviews are a joke in all areas of the company, and the employee has no chance of refuting the facts. Management is often clueless, and worse, it often lies about status of projects, impacts, deadlines, or deliverables. Everybody is a VP. The less degrees you have, and the more bs you can talk, the better.

Pro: 40 hours, once you leave work you have no worries.  Good culture, a lot of opportunity to move up quickly
Con: Phone job, but can move out of phone role if you work hard and want to

Pro: Good people, good benefits, generous 401k
Con: Metrics seem to be off, workload is often tough to keep up with

Pro: The first 8-10 of my 16 years were good.  Work was challenging but rewarding.  New ideas and approaches were encouraged.  Teams of talented, hard working professionals defined the company.  Employees were told that they were the number one asset.
Con: Too much focus on process and too little on work that added value to the firm.  Offshoring and dumping people in Texas has eliminated nearly every tech job in Boston;  any honest audit of the 'site strategy' will show that it has been an ill-conceived disaster.  The costs are much higher and very little is getting done.

Pro: Consistent bonuses, merit based, occasional voluntary time off
Con: Heavy metrics goals like handle time and lead generation.  High pressure at times.

Pro: Great Benefits, Company really does want to take care of its clients, and the people you work with are great.
Con: Pay is not great compared to industry average, not exciting, some managers are very mediocre, it is very difficult to get recognized by upper management. very tall corporate structure.

Pro: It is a very fast pace role with hundreds of phone calls and trade issues need to be addressed on the daily basis. Such environment is good for a entry level individuals who would like to establish his/her career in trading. The team that I worked with are fabulous individuals with great industry knowledge and years of experience.
Con: Since it is family own, you really have to play politics well to survive and move up. There are individuals in the management team that are really not suitable for their roles while others that are really capable got ouster after losing the political fight. Also Fido's salary is kind of lag behind the industry, so do expect getting paid a little less than the peers.

Summary: "Best place I ever worked. So far ..."
Pro:
Great work environment. Promotes advancement, continued learning, and a healthy social work environment. Compensates well for the employees that work hard to make the company successful. 



Pay was on the higher end of competitive work. We had potlucks and team meetings. I always felt like I could talk to any of the managers. Sometimes we would go to 7 eleven for treats like little kids. I met several life long friends there and that really made it a worthwhile place to work.
Con: The financial industry isn't really my thing. So I don't really have any cons for my time with fidelity.

Pro: Good scope of work, opportunities and good people to work with.High end technology available and opportunities to excel are there.
Con: Bureaucracy, managers not backing employees and more ruled by client feedback

Summary: "Great Company but primarily phone based interactions with overbearing emphasis on tracking every number possible"
Pro: Great pay and benefits, good for career start
Con: Way too focused on phone based metrics - bonuses based largely on emailed client surveys and excessively tracked metrics - phone jobs are 100% phone based so no break to do other duties

Summary: "Great firm to start financial services careers"
Pro: Tons of support, great leadership, plenty of room for career growth.
Con: You can feel a bit micromanaged in certain roles.

Pro: Good life work balance and flex time. Benefits are good but not what they used to be. Business casual dress code with jeans on Friday.
Con: Upper management often makes changes or asks staff to participate in projects. These changes and projects have an obvious negative effect on staff ability to get their "regular jobs" done. First line management is required to support these changes and generally does not support staff. There are too many power hungry, hostile managers at all levels.

Summary: "It is a very good company to work"
Pro: Work Environment is very good. It will create coordination between the employees
Con: I don't have any idea regarding this.

Pro: Work-life balance, professionalism, stability, very generous retirement, very good other benefits (health, life, disability insurance).  Lots of opportunities around other parts of the company,
Con: Big company means many layers between you and decision-makers.  Not growing quickly, so growth, though good, not as good as if it were a faster-growing company.  Salaries not very high.

Pro: Its all process oriented, so if you are good at following orders and maintaining the company policies with no questions asked, you may have a go.
Con: Very orthodox and not employee happy place

Summary: "Amazing company that actually takes care of their own."
Pro: Extremely competitive pay and benefits. Paid training. Company actually practices what they preach when they say they balance employees, clients, and the firm.
Con: Working for a large corp means sometimes your interests can get lost in the infrastructure, but its easy to get lost at any big company. Anonymous goes a long way to try and make you comfortable.

Pro: Great benefits including 401k match, bonus, and in-house health & wellness center.
Con: Jobs and departments may be moved to different states -- depending on current need to meet state tax break requirements.

Pro:
Great pay and benefits

Great team outings when there is funding in the budget
Con: Policies are only enforced for some employees.... others can do whatever they please!

Pro: I really did not see any advantage
Con:
Above all Pros only if you get into a good team.

More of bureaucracy. Just like a democratic law system. People who knows the management best will take advantage.

Politics here and there. 'Be as Roman while you are in Rome' perfectly applicable. Experienced new joiners will have a tough time.

They have a weird dress code where they decide the length of dress for girls, the material to be worn.



The worst was they even told us in induction how to wash clothes. It was a bizarre experience for me when I had gone there with good work experience. They are never ready to take any feedback and the hr mostly gets hostile and uses cheap language if you try to give feedback.

Pro: Anonymous is a great place to start your career in the financial services industry.    They will take you in, get you licensed, teach you all of the fundamentals, instill great work ethic in you, and always encourage career development.  And with how spread out the company is, you can essentially work anywhere and know you'll have a great job with great people.  The pay is ok, but the benefits are amazing which is truly what helps you setup your retirement savings.  They offer 401(k) match and profit sharing, and that all adds up quickly.  Many people spend their entire working careers at Anonymous.
Con:
There aren't a lot of cons other than some of the people--a lot of middle management can be extremely obnoxious with inflated heads & egos, and they are also the ones who somewhat control your career, besides yourself, of course.  

Anonymous is way too conservative too, which can also be a 'pro.'  And their compliance policies are some of the strictest you'll see anywhere.  

They need to show their employees how much they value them with better pay--a lot of the positions deserve to be paid a bit more for the hard work that is expected, but again, it's hard to complain about that b/c of everything else that is positive about the company.  

Even with its cons, I would recommend Anonymous to anyone who is a solid, sharp, hard working, & committed worker.

Pro:
Equal opportunity company

Less politics

Decent benefits
Con:
Losing good work

Management become worse

Pro: Great reputation with solid financials to support the company. Good ethics.
Con: Too many layers and too difficult to get things done.  Also, too many people in upper managment are more concerned about the status quo than thinking outside the box.  Effectively, the company makes money by sheer inertia not because of creative thinking on the part of management.

Pro: we can learn a lot about markets
Con: its all depend on how you take it.

Summary: "Like most very large companies, it's very hit or miss."
Pro: Anonymous is actually a bunch of smaller companies. If you're in FIMT or one of the trading companies, you're going to have amazing benefits, great pay, even free Cokes, Izze's, and cappuccinos in the break rooms. If you have a good manager, the sky could be the limit when it comes to advancement and opportunities. They do generally take very good care of their people.
Con: If you're not in FIMT or one of the trading companies, you wear the badge, but don't necessarily have the good pay or benefits, and you can expect to pay dearly at the cafeteria. Anonymous's companies are VERY siloed, so if you want to advance from one group to another and don't know someone there, or your manager doesn't have strong connections, you are actually at a disadvantage to outsiders trying for the same position. If you aren't under a good, well-connected manager, expect to slave at your current role forever.

Summary: "Cushy jobs, but not an IT industry leader"
Pro: Great office facilities. Good benefits. A pro and a con, the office is empty at 5pm, literally. Good if you've got kids, bad if you're a workaholic. The company belongs to the Johnson family so you don't have the "make the quarter numbers or bust" attitude you'll find at publicly traded firms.
Con: Sparse vacation, only 15 days a year. Company is constricting, merit raises were half of inflation across the IT groups this year. Technologies used internally are well behind the leading edge and well behind peer institutions.

Summary: "Great Company to Start and Finish a Career"
Pro:
Great benefits, especially retirement savings.  $1 for $1 dollar match on first 7% plus annual profit sharing contribution which has always been 10% of compensation.



Since the company is private, management is not working quarter to quarter.  



Anonymous offers a wide range of job roles.
Con:
The company can be on the conservative side.  

Weak internal employee development.

Weak middle management.

Outside local investor centers, Anonymous has only a handful of campuses.

Pro: Great company, excellent benefits and work environment
Con: Low starting salary, random shift assignment

Pro: Excellent talented people.  Great benefits and training opportunities.  Good company to start your career with.
Con: Company has frequent RIFs just small enough to not attract media attention.  New England is not strategic unless your company is headquartered here.  Dedication and loyalty are not rewarded.  Paltry merit increases.

Pro: Great Benefits. I love this company
Con: Sometimes the work is very intense.

Pro: Better work environment than my previous employer.  Good benefits and most people are nice.
Con: Poor management.  Managers constantly favor their friends over more qualified people when it comes to promotions.

Pro: The quality of the experience is good
Con: Lengthy Works hours and poor mid level management

Summary: "Good compensation, work-life balance. Bureaucracy and favoritism take a toll."
Pro:
1) Good compensation as compared with peers

2) Great work-life balance - excellent place for employees with family commitments

3) Flexibility to move within the organization
Con:
1) Bureaucracy across levels, especially support functions frustratingly slow down day-to-day tasks

2) Growth within the organization is a strong function of favoritism and tenure within the organization - talent and capabilities be damned

3) Lacks purpose - sometimes feels like a government organization; little or no communication from senior management about strategy goals and organizational challenges

Pro: Great training, and good job benefits
Con: Extreme micromanaging, not transparent about the actual role you take on.

Summary: "Vibrant, strong firm, may be drifting from historically strong investment values"
Pro: An energetic, vibrant firm, drawing very bright people and giving them incredible resources to do the job.  Offers numerous opportunities and career paths.
Con: Historically strong dedication fiduciary values is softening.  Asset gathering and internal politics are eroding strong values.  Middle manager quote:  "This is not a meritocracy."

Summary: "Anonymous was THE place to be years ago but has gone downhill the past 6-7 years"
Pro: great people to work with. recreational facilities are fun for sports leagues. nice walking grounds and nice rural location.
Con: instability of job. constant relocations of jobs going to Texas drives morale down.

Summary: "Very corporate culture, great benefits and pay, lots of bloat"
Pro:
Excellent 401K matching, but you're not fully vested until you hit your five years. Very good pay and benefits. 



Culture depends on the division you're in -- I used to work in Strategic Advisers, Inc. (later rolled up into Asset Allocation) and the majority of the people that I worked with in that group were incredibly nice and smart. I'd heard not-so-great things about some of the other divisions at Anonymous, though, so I counted myself fortunate. Compared to the other floors in my building (245 Summer St), my floor was relatively casual and the floor plan was more open -- large half-cubes instead of the cube farms at the Smithfield, RI campus. Because I worked on a floor with portfolio managers and other members of investment management, we also got nicer drinks in the fridge.



I also had a very kind and nurturing manager and a good team.
Con:
Even within the division that I worked in, there were a few deadweights -- people who had made it to middle management after being at the company for 15+ years and were really just complacent and there for the paycheck. Those people were always a drag to work with; fortunately, I was able to minimize my dealings with them and usually partnered with the research and investment teams, who were filled with smart, driven people.



One other con was that it IS a big corporation, so change does come fairly slowly, and there are constant re-orgs and re-branding initiatives, which can get a bit difficult to keep track of. It can also be hard to get things done in an efficient manner because there are always a million stakeholders on each project.

Pro: The best benefits I've seen. Great training. Many opportunities for career advancement. Fun working environment.
Con: Income ceiling is lower than most financial firms.

Pro: Good work culture, good work life balance, good hike every year
Con: opportunities for learning is limited

Summary: "No merit increase in salary this year"
Pro: Fairly good job security considering the economy
Con: Not well paid for what I do

Summary: "Great company, but improve the career path and pay."
Pro: Excellent work environment! Manager/Employee relationship is on the same level. Work well with outside schedule. Very customer focused vs sales focused.
Con: Lacks a healthy, competitive work environment. Lack of frequent communication from top management. If your "brand" is damaged, you will be stuck in your roll. Rigid career path; you cannot necessarily skip ahead even if you are experienced.

Pro: Pleasant work environment, good compensation
Con: Overtime often required, hard to schedule vacation time

Pro:
Great Benefits Package

Training 

Starter company. Once you get training and experience look elsewhere for promotions
Con:
Compensation is fairly low so start here get trained and move on.

Employee development

Most moves in the company are lateral in pay.

No room for growth

Culture has been tainted in recent years. Everyone is out for self.

Pro: Flexible scheduling, great gyms and equipment, outdoor courts for volleyball and basketball, great track around the site to walk or run.
Con: The bus schedule is too long.

Summary: "Customer first mentality in a financial services firm"
Pro: Great retirement benefits, great work/life balance
Con: Ongoing regionalization away from Boston

Pro: Beautiful building, casual Fri, special occasion snacks, thorough training
Con: Call center cons: logging in/out on time, breaks at odd times, mandatory OT

Pro: Decent benefits overall but more expensive than other firms in the industry. You will learn a lot if you know nothing about the business to begin with.
Con: Overcrowded, work area is smaller than an elementary school desk. Advancement is based on arbitrary targets and how much networking you can fit into your 30 min lunch. Previous education, experience and overall ability matter very little and can be detrimental as everybody starts in the same place. The entire organization has a culture where they have customers and most employees believing they are all about service and not profit.

Summary: "Gave my all to a company that didn't give it back."
Pro: The salary for entry-level associates is great and there are a lot of benefits given to the employees
Con: Anonymous's quality and effectiveness goals have been increased steadily so that even one misspelled word, missed punctuation, or keeping a client on hold more than 30 seconds can cause you to get written up. Also there's hardly ever openings for promotions.

Pro: Some great people have gone through the doors at Anonymous.  Anonymous has traditionally invested heavily in technology and smart people.
Con: Unfortunately the company is relocating its IT jobs out of Boston and loosing its talent base and domain knowledge in the process.  The company is currently focused on cost cutting and outsourcing rather than talent retention.   A large inventory of legacy applications is a drag on innovation and its IT budget.  More cost effective products from competitors, such as ETFs, threatening their business model.

Pro: The culture is the best of any company for which I have ever worked.  They truly care about their employees and their customers -- It is not just lip service like at so many companies.
Con: Working in a call center the schedule is regimented, but it does make the day go fast.

Pro: Pay for the area is high, easy to get into an entry level job.
Con: Constant policy, goal and upper management changes.  No work/life balance, always what can you do for me attitude.  uses its employees up and then spits them out.  Company promises the world and delivers nothing.  Company severances several times a year, only to expand and hire new people at lower pay.

Summary: "Great way to get into the Finance industry"
Pro: Structured promotional path.  Hard workers are rewarded.  Licenses and training paid for.  Great benefits and plenty of other perks.
Con: No cons at this time.

Summary: "Company with great benefits package gave little else in terms of advancement and innovation."
Pro:
Benefits are great.

Investment platform is the cream of the crop.

Mutual funds given in managed accounts are truly the right ones for the client.
Con:
You have to be friends with the right people to advance.

The company makes it very difficult to find a job outside the call center.

Feedback from managers is a drag -- managers love to point out what you do wrong.

Management are a bunch of puppets who have to do what they're told.

Managers (and senior managers) don't fess up to their mistakes.

Trade Support is ruthless.

Summary: "Outstanding opportunity to grow within the industry"
Pro: Culture is fantastic, ability to move outside of your role is encouraged. Training is second to none.
Con: There are still some politics involved, doing the right thing for the client doesn't always mean the best thing for you.

Summary: "World class company and always keep their standards"
Pro: Amenities are awesome. Keep standards. Worlds number one in mutual fund industry
Con: Indian management is region specific and favoritism to regions

Pro: Company has good benefits, good work life balance, and is still privately owned
Con: The majority of middle and senior management basically just talk about stuff and are great at producing nice presentations.  The majority of people are like sheep and do not want to speak up.

Summary: "Slow moving, bureaucratic company with great benefits and respectful people"
Pro: Profit sharing, retirement benefits, many departments for lateral moves, low stress, respectful culture
Con: Constant reorganization, no appetite to take on risks more focused on to till the line and not rock the boat, lacks passion, staff is not very intellectual, when they want to remove someone from a position, them demote them instead of laying off which is humiliating

Pro: Many diverse businesses, extensive training, private company status enables long term investment in technology, products, and services.
Con: Has moved a lot of jobs out of MA, fund performance has lagged for a long time which threatens competitiveness

Pro:
1: if you are able to do politics , then join the company. you will be the master.

2: heaven for women employee.

3:flexible work enverionment.

4: Good pay package for some Business UNIT.

5:They will make you feel you are working in google like companies.

6:good to learn for finanacial domains.
Con:
1:Job security.

2: You would not be sure , when your job is going to terminate. 

3:always do butter policing if you want to persist.

4: some times they will make you work for their BPO , if you will not find a project.

5:No proper IJP.

6:the people who are their for 6-7 years and not able to change the company because of incompentency , plays lot of politics to survive in the company.

Pro: Good steady base salary and benefits. Matching of 7% and 10% profit sharing after 1 yr.
Con: Bait and switch of promising you account executive role with an IR position saying that you need tolerance the FIdelity way first before promotion to AE role. Once in IR role, it's really ur luck whether position opens up and ur relationship with ur manager and your numbers compare to the rest of the IR ranks. (Have 8 yrs of exp) I don't need this crap...

Summary: "Great pay but employees not valued in layoffs"
Pro: Great pay and benefits, very easy to get to and a commute you can really be thankful for. They spend money on technology where needed and help you get your job done.
Con: Who in management knows about you and what you do is somewhat luck when new mangers are always coming in. The review system is awkward and can't possibly reflect your achievements correctly.

Summary: "The pay is okay. Its all about who you know."
Pro: Good 401(k), profit sharing, Tuition reimbursement
Con: Boring work, micromanaged, not much room to move away from role for example from Financial Representative to business analyst. Many in middle management are lifers and do not have strong education backgrounds. Most of the skills acquired are non-transferable. Leave once you get your series license.

Pro:
1.) The company invests a lot of money in Learning and Development including paying for your licenses and maintaining them in 53 states.



2.) The morale of the place is very encouraging for the most part. Upper management really does well at maintaining a positive work environment that is uplifting for its employees.



3.) Benefits package is pretty spectacular if you stay for over a year.



4.) You take so many calls that you are forced to learn ALOT and FAST! It's very good if you don't have a finance background like myself.
Con:
1.) Low Pay

2.) Small Bonuses

3.) The micromanaging of call stats

4.) On the phone all day and since the company is the biggest in the financial industry the calls never stop coming. ever.

Pro:
1. Great work place and High Values 

2. Attractive Salaries and Nice Hikes (Mostly you will get double digit hikes)

3. Good technology and work Life balance. 

4. Good Bonus pay and Brand name and strong management.

5. No Politics and Pure transparency in reviews
Con:
1. Weekend work is Must for Unix/DB/middle ware teams. 

2. Gap between Top management and employees

3. Have to wait for Years To get Promotions

Summary: "Can be good, depends on what group/product you end up in"
Pro:
Good work/life balance

Remote work option

Nice offices/facilities
Con:
Slow moving with regards to latest technology trends

Tendency for management to manage upwards and focus on their own prospects/careers

Not much effort made to build team spirit/morale

Compensation not very competitive

Pro: Great Company. Great Co Workers. Great Food.
Con: Low Money Low income Low Raises. Low Bonuses

Pro: The company has tremendous resources.  I had the opportunity to work with some very smart and capable people.  Excellent work/life balance, and the benefits were very good.  Decent career opportunities *IF* you're willing to live where the company wants you to.
Con:
Not long after I was hired, the company went into a cut & outsource mode.  Salaries stayed flat during my tenure, as with most of the financial services industry at the time.  Too much of my time was spent changing jobs to avoid being relocated. 

Truly horrid 'Human' Resources.  While driving my child to school one morning, I learned of the latest RIF over the radio.  My child looked at me and asked, "Are we okay?".

Pro: Good work, Good hikes , work & life balance
Con: growth is not there. not much projects

Pro:
Well maintained company structure. 

Lots of room for internal movement. 

Great benefits.
Con:
Unrealistic company expectations. 

Very high pressure atmosphere. 

You will feel "chained to your desk".

Summary: "Lots of opportunity for those who are hard workers and not afraid of change."
Pro: I was able to grow into a career in software development, thanks to in-house and on the job training and opportunities.  The size of the company affords a great benefits package, with tuition reimbursement, and a variety of health plans, 401 K etc.   Because the company has so many different areas of business, employees can gain experience in different business units via internal transfers, and grow their career within Anonymous. Different areas almost have different business "personalities." The company also welcomes back any "alumni" who had left on good terms. There is a commitment to excellence and integrity to their customers.
Con: You will never work so hard!  Underachievers need not apply. If you don't like change, don't work at Anonymous!  (however, some people enjoy change, so this is a pro, not a con!)  Business units reorganize, individual jobs transform.  Depending upon the business unit you work in, there may be lots of bureaucracy or it may resemble a start up - this is why Anonymous is hard to generalize about.

Summary: "Good company to learn on your own, building network and relationship"
Pro: excellent environment, HR policies, flexibility, good company for retirement, very less pressure in general (with some exception)
Con: Not at all good company to start the career, keep on changing strategies, appreciation for ECA rather than for deliveries

Summary: "great company with above average pay and benefits"
Pro: Salary, benefits, people, culture, fun
Con: It was a very busy place and short staffed. Some of the senior managers were difficult to speak with, stubborn and unapproachable

Pro:
Great culture

Autonomy to employees

Good regular trainings
Con: Management - especially offshore - Directors and above - need to work closely with partners

Pro: Good pay; Dedicated Workers; Good Benefits
Con: Long Days; Abusive Customers; Inter Anonymous groups do not get along.

Pro: Benefits, large co that spends on tech, fast paced, lots of areas to work in, challenging
Con: Change is constant and can be draining or derailing to programs, work life balance is hard to maintain with intensity expected, chance of relocation is constant

Pro: Very professional work environment, talented technology resources using cutting edge applications
Con: Lack of communication across groups.  Wasted money with on-going duplicate efforts.

Pro: Career Pathing, Growth, Facilities, Work Life Balance
Con: Nothing at this moment, its been doing well across all areas

Pro: A great place for entry level positions. Fair pay. A lot of female leadership. Many opportunities to move between groups within the company. Very little micromanaging.
Con: There is some bureaucracy in promotions. Employees ratings are expected to fit within a bell curve, so some employees may receive low ratings because "someone has to get it." Company changes are never done within the time frame that is set. Very little support from senior lever management

Pro: Good pay, good bonuses, promotion opportunities, genuinely cares about customers and providing the best service.
Con: Job can be difficult, especially if you mind sitting on the phone all day

Pro: Everyone is super nice and super helpful. If you need help with anything, people will not hesitate to help out.
Con: Only con would be the amount of time it takes to get clearance.

Pro: They are nice bunch of people to worth with and friendly enviornment
Con: If you want to grow there is limited upside due to location.

Pro: loved the people whom I worked with, benefits were great, pay was little.
Con: I had 7 manager in 3 years, the last one was the worst so Its a luck of the draw, very limited mobility, new employees are more valued than tenured ones.

Summary: "Very positive. Great way to get into the financial field."
Pro: Private company, no shareholders to please. Focus on employees and clients strictly. The westlake building is brand new and is a great place to work. Any financial goals you have can be achieved through Anonymous
Con: None. A great company to work for if you know what you're getting into.

Pro: People friendly. Respect for individuals.
Con: Gets slow paced at times but is dependant on the employee how he/she paces himself/herself to grow in the organization.

Pro:
Nice People (most of them) 

Workplace flexibility (working remote)

Good benefits
Con:
Pay is so-so 

Tough to advance – you move jobs if really want to get  any significant pay increase

Pro: Good work culture and great people
Con: Don't have anything negative to say

Summary: "Great organization with teamwork and sales as a culture"
Pro: Leading financial service provider that does what is right for the client. Feel good about positioning products that you know are a great value to the customer. Good culture and recognition of accomplishments.
Con: It's a very large organization and at times there are many people going for the same positions to advance. You could make more in plain salary and commissions working elsewhere in the industry.

Summary: "Do not be attracted to their well known name"
Pro:

Summary: "Working in IT at Anonymous will be the death of your career if you are a true Tech Person"
Pro: Generally competitive salaries and good benefits.  If you are very good with Technology no one is likely to ask questions as they wouldn't want to reveal how little they know themselves.
Con:
Anonymous is very political and top heavy.  Over 25% of IT people have titles of Director or above, however this is not because of ability, it is because it is the only way Anonymous can retain staff.  These people would not cut it at technology companies where engineering and merit are central.



In order to accomplish anything at Anonymous, you must have countless meeting with many groups of people, most of whom will not understand any technical aspects of the discussion.  Instead decision makers will rely on people with inflated titles whom they believe to be technical gurus, but who are simply the best at appearances and politics.



Anonymous is extremely title, appearance, and politics conscious.  Your actual ability to innovate, be creative, or lead is secondary to these factors.  If you are a true lover of technology who wants to learn and grow, then you should make every effort to join a proper technology company.  Avoid Anonymous at all costs.

It

Summary: "Anonymous is a great place to work."

Con: Constant consolidation and cost cutting.  Do more with less.  The more you cut the more successful you are.

Con: Like most companies, there is a resource crunch in some areas. Company is very focused on standardization across groups. This can be a good and bad thing.

Working location in Boston is very good, right next to South Station
Con:

- Stupid and long-term relocation policy that alienates all IT workers. 

- Mostly a waste of time for any young IT professional I have talked to. Everyone left the company within 2 years. 



If you are a IT professional under age 30 and looking for a career, and not just a job that pays the rent, please stay far away from Anonymous. Do not believe anything they say. I once thought that a peaceful corporate environment would be okay. But I learned how a toxic environment can affect a worker's life and career potentials. It is not going to be worth your time to work in a company like Anonymous. I felt so much happier when I leave the place.

Pro: There are some smart people there, and the pay is above average.

The result is small groups of people that prevent senior management from seeing the real issues that prevent true growth. Everyone in the 'group' is doing the best possible job, and any poor results are the cause of non-group members. Poor results are rarely reported voluntarily.

Pro: Salary, benefits, severance package.  Committed to continuous improvement.  Invests in improvements, particularly technology.
Con: Does not hire the most talented, let's mediocre players stay for 10-15 years.  Mediocrity begets mediocrity.  Conducts  disruptive purges when strategic priorities change.  Cross-functional collaboration is fraught personal animosities.

Pro: Anonymous is a great place to learn how to be effective in a huge organization. When I worked there, the company was eager to show off its design group--we were allowed to wear jeans every day and had very cool hexagonal cubes, because the company wanted to showcase the fact that creative people worked at a financial institution. There was also a full usability lab, which is rarity in any industry.
Con: It was really easy for people to do very little work. Inefficiency was literally built into the design review process; I had to run every finished design by a designer--a Anonymous veteran, natch--who might have half my skill level, despite their years of experience. I left because I knew that I wouldn't learn anything there, and my skills would inevitably get stale in an environment that lacked innovation. The management was just getting excited about Flash at the time, at the moment when the industry was moving toward abandoning it! Additionally, diversity was a problem. Anonymous had very few non-white/non-Indian people, at the time, and I don't think anything has changed. One buffoon of a manager (white) thought it was hilarious to spout "ebonics" at every opportunity. It was cringe-making, at the very least.

Summary: "Great Company, but phones are too much."
Pro: Great benefits, 7% 401k matching, excellent healthcare with HSA, Fun & smart people co-workers, good location.
Con: The phones are awful, I hated having set 15 breaks and a scheduled lunch that rotated every day. They try and make you believe you have growth opportunities in Jax, but don't be fooled. It's all on the phones. If you like that, great, if you hate the phones do NOT take this job. Managers rotate way too often. They bring in a new manager every few months, ones that have no clue about your subject matter.

Summary: "Company strives for continuous improvement however is very demanding expecting much more from employees."
Pro: Good salaries, good benefits. Good company to begin career with as there is growth potential for those who stand out.
Con: Expectations are high. With layoffs employees are expected to do more work as terminated employees are typically not replaced.

Pro: Supportive Management. Excellent Training Program. Great Benefits. Consistant Feedback. Career advancement opportunities are available for those who put in the work. Flexibility is key to being successful.
Con: Managers can sometimes overlook hard-workers. Some shifts are late since the TEM department is open until midnight. The environment is constantly changing (may be a good thing for some).

Summary: "This is a great company to work for with awesome benefits and thorough training."
Pro: Very nice, non-backstabbing people, lots of upward mobility, fun company and team events, stable company, great training. This company working here for a few years looks great on any resume.
Con: It's average pay, mostly phone roles, it feels sometimes like there are not enough representatives on the phone to handle all the calls coming in back to back. Most roles are very structured.

Pro: Most people want to do their jobs well. Upper management receptive to changes if you know how to present the business value.
Con: Some people are stagnant so difficult to move positions.

Summary: "Other departments may be better, but avoid the Defined Benefits area"
Pro:
Receive bi-weekly paychecks...

When you have down time due to testing environments not working, you have some time to build worthwhile skills for a new job.
Con:
Test environments are horrible - It is impossible to actually test. They are always changing code that breaks things with no accountability. Client Configurations are always getting messed up. It's impossible to test a product completely. Random error messages every day. It is extremely frustrating to be in this type of environment and you will be stuck waiting for dev/systems to fix issues on a daily basis.



No advancement opportunities within DB - They will gladly allocate you to 120% because they like to "run lean", but they don't like to actually recognize employees monetarily. If you ever do get a promotion within the team, don't expect a good pay raise.



Atrocious raises - With each year the raises are getting worse. After leading major projects and putting in a bunch of overtime, I was presented with a 1.5% raise. Others received worse percentages. Make sure you haggle on your starting salary, because you will be at that same pay until you get out of the department.



No incentives - The only incentive is if you are hourly and can work overtime. Otherwise, you won't get recognized and there will be some time of excuse why raises/bonuses are low despite making record profits. I don't know many coworkers that want to stay in the department.



Cheap - When they do encourage team bonding, they make it known that it is NOT funded and that you have to pay. Example - lunch outings with new teammates will be talked about for a week in advance and is highly encouraged to attend, but you will have to pay for yourself. When they used to acknowledge birthdays within the group, the cakes had to be bought personally by management without being able to expense them. 



Benefits - There are health benefits, but they have increased ~220% within 2 years. So you make less money by staying with the company. If you want any type of health reimbursement, you have to track your daily fitness/diet/etc; which they do reimburse $125/quarter, but it is very time consuming



Menial tasks/job - The job itself is very menial. Other departments test a lot more that seem to overlap. You will not build any skills with this position. The hardest part of the job is understanding the complex systems, and when you have a good idea how they should function, they do not actually work. You spend most of your time writing defects. Each environment has limitations that seem to fluctuate per project. You will not build any skills that will help you develop professionally and could hinder future opportunities.



Access issues - There are so many different systems that you need access to. You will not know that you need access to a specific table/environment/program/system until you lose it and can't access something. Then you have to wait days in order for them to give you access permissions again. 



You will be "voluntold" to participate in certain tasks that are not related to your role (or even department), have no prior knowledge of and are projected to "only take 4 hours", but they end up taking multiple weeks while you still have project work to maintain. That will be on addition to the 120% allocation that you already have for projects as well. 



The main application used in DB is 20+ years old. The code is basically all patchwork to fix problems on top of problems. There's "known issues" within certain functionality that isn't actually known among teams until a high-level dev informs the teams.

Pro: Part time shifts available ghhh
Con: Matrices matter more than people's careers

Summary: "Great place to work if you are in the right role."

If you find yourself in the right business unit at the right time Anonymous can be an amazing place to work.  While base salaries seem low, if you are in a role where you are compensated on performance (commission, cash bonus, stock awards) you can find yourself making a great living with a great work / life balance as compared to the rest of the industry.
Con: Entry level and back office employees are not paid very much and are not eligible for many of the performance based compensation incentives (stock awards, cash bonuses etc.).  This means that if you find yourself in the position of being dependent upon one of these people to do your job, you are frequently greeted with either incompetence or apathy.

Pro: Market or better pay, good benefits, and open feeling office space.  Lavish christmas parties and more than most company fun events.  A "Nice" place to work where nobody is allowed to look too scruffy. You can't wear jeans or baseball caps or certain items of clothing.You can feel the money. If you are interested in understanding how big brokerage  companies like Anonymous manage to keep track of it all you would like it.  You usually feel engaged. There is a lot of software development so it's not always legacy applications if you work in technology.  Generally you will be thanked for your work and told you are doing well (unless you suck at your job) . There are lots of kitchens scattered around and there is lots of free food there often leftover from being served in meetings. Whenever you have to  work nights you often get to order out free food.It's a cube farm, no way around it. Cube walls are not too low but not as high as other places.
Con: You have to work hard there, sometimes nights and weekends, there is a bit of the workaholic culture there. Sometimes for extended periods for a big important project. The job security tends to wander with the market. When it's up you're okay, if the economy is really bad watch out. Sometimes people seem a little mean, like they don't screen for it very well in employees,  You always have a long walk from the parking lot.  Much better to be a contractor so you don;t have to work extra hours as much.

Summary: "Overall, its a great company to work at - if one is looking for stability."
Pro: The company is extremely customer focused. The management team is always trying to re-invent themselves to ensure they remain competitive.  The firm is also employee friendly and has the power to weather the economic ups and downs with minimum impact to employees.
Con: Change is constant.  Career growth prospects are extremely limited.  Anyone who is looking to move up the ladder will find it takes many years to get a promotion. In the past 5-7 years, the company's focus on cutting costs and improving productivity has resulted in fewer people working a lot more with no significant improvement in compensation. This is not a company to look at if you are looking for a 9-5 working day.

Shortly after, they restructured, brought in the car salesman (ax man) and it has all been down hill from there.  Took away the pension, didn't even grandfather people in - absolutely ridiculous, changed benefits, rules, compensation, and basically took the "You are lucky to have a job" attitude towards the employees. Summary: "Good Company for building up your retirement money"
Pro: Great Benefits. Fair Salary. For very good to excellent workers the annual bonus is nice. They provide 4 weeks vacation after 5 years on the job. Excellent 401K match at up to 7% and annual profit sharing at 10% of base pay or salary plus 3k yearly for a medical retirement account. They also have other benefit perks. They provide flexible work hours that take family issues into account.
Con: For at least the past 6 years advancement opportunities were limited. Merit raises have been meager. Due to cost cutting, departments are not budgeted fully (over the past 10 years or so) and goals of individual departments are not aligned to the corporate goals (except when it comes to cutting costs). This misalignment of goals causes friction and completion between departments.  Management is more top down as the company matures. Management tends to value, in all ways, those they consider superstars and "Outstanding" while ignoring the hard workers who come in every day and keep the company moving forward.

Pro: Excellent company to work for with great values. Management cares for their employees and their career development. Its a great opportunity for a recent college graduate to learn about the financial services industry.
Con: I was interested in a career change and had a difficult time moving into a different position within the company. There is a specific career path for Financial Representatives and is difficult to move into other positions that fall outside of that path.

Pro: Very committed team, focused on quality, results driven
Con: Easy for net negative producers to slink by, double booked time is common, expect to be over allocated and under appreciated

Pro: Work Life Balance is good. Salary matters on the BU one joins. Focus more on domain expertise. Probably good to join at higher position, promotions at higher level are too fast, if you have networking in office, this matters more than hard working
Con: Career Growth is challenge, Office Politics.

Summary: "Define Contribution Representative, working in the call center managing retirement plans"
Pro:
They sometimes give free food when you have to work overtime.

They REALLY care about the customer.....(not so much the worker)
Con:
There is mandatory overtime during the months that there is high call volume, i.e. January is when they send out 1099 R forms, customers call in for tax questions as well as statement questions. This is the time that the only way to get out of working overtime is to obtain valid permission through the program director. The overtime is 11 hours.

Another con is the phones are constantly ringing there is no break between calls as soon as the caller hangs up the next call is already through and you have to be ready.

If you want a job outside of the field you are in you have to wait a year to get to a different sector.

There are so many goals they want done on every call, you have to maintain a relationship with the caller, ask protruding personal questions of why they want to take out money out of THEIR 401ks, you have to get a guidance opportunity in where you feel like a seller, you have to get a PCC in where you talk about how much they are putting in their 401k...etc, etc. the list goes on, you have to get so much done in one call, every call.

Pro: Benefits for employees eligible for profit sharing
Con: Not much job security, even if you are a top performer

Pro:
Good Perks for freshers

Good Work Life Balance
Con: No growth in middle management levels

Summary: "If you are willing to relocate multiple times you'll do well.  If you want stability, look elsewhere."

Exposure to some brilliant and highly educated individuals

Good benefits and programs such as healthcare, profit sharing, on-site fitness and health centers, fitness and computer reimbursement, bonus opportunities

Can achieve work/life balance but usually not without paying a price (limited or no advancement opportunity, limited or no pay increases)

Under-achievers often get recognized and promoted if they know the right people and can play them to their advantage

Jobs are constantly relocated or eliminated on senior management's whim with little regard for the impact to the people or businesses they support

Con: Looking at a computer all day. Yet defined to my current position

Summary: "Was a great time. Had a fantastic team who was invested in my development."
Pro: Great pay. Tons of kids your age to hang out with. You will get some leisure time (which you should use to develop your skills to help the team).
Con: A very traditional company with lots of bureaucracy, which at points was slightly annoying. Still not caught up to many of the latest tech trends.

Summary: "Decent place to start your career in finance"
Pro: Good manager for myself. Nice people.
Con: Nothing really specific to Anonymous. There are some things that are just inherent to the job and industry.

Summary: "Decent jumping off point for new college grads"
Pro: Good flexible hours, overtime easily approved
Con: no real upward mobility. management non responsive in furthering careers of employees

Pro: Security and takes a lot care on employees
Con: Less onsite opportunity for employees and it too depends on the team you are put in .

Summary: "They should change their name to Infidelity"
Pro: Decent pay, decent benefits, workable facilities. It is difficult to find another fourteen words to meet the requirements of this posting.
Con:
Good old boy type of culture there. 

If you are the type that enjoys getting credit when deserved, you can forget that here, but they will let you know if they don't like something you are doing. 

Too much fraternizing with co-workers going on, and not just hanging out (Holiday Parties are for employees only, this is where a lot of the Infidelity comes into play).

If you are relying on your merits to take you places, you can forget that here. It's all about who you know and who's jokes you laugh at.

Too many double standards (what is good for one person, is not good for the next even if they are suppose to be a level above you.)

Middle management needs to be thoroughly investigated.

They throw around the VP title to anyone; deserving or not.

No promotional opportunities unless you know someone.

HR is a joke; not really a support system and they are somewhat difficult to reach.

Fear is often used to try to get you to conform or become friends

Pro: Excellent employee care. Engaging team building activities.
Con: Ill maintained Work Life balance. Lack of transparency between US and India associates.

Summary: "Respectable Environment but moves a bit slow"
Pro: A very respectable environment. Employees are strongly encourages to treat each other with utmost respect. A very good work life balance is encouraged.
Con: Moves a bit slow as far as acceptance of new technologies are concerned but that is just a character of the company to make sure that they roll out solid products.

Pro: Great integrity.  You can leave personal items out among hundreds of people and not worry about theft.  Many intelligent people.  Great benefits.
Con: Huge on metrics.  You must stay within a few minutes of an ever changing schedule.  No face to face time with clients.  A call center for promotion after promotion.  Very few investor centers so chances of working in one are not great.

Summary: "Upper management tells a great story, but it's just window dressing"
Pro: Great training for getting Series 7 licensing.
Con: Anonymous is interested in hiring young people who are willing to live in fear just to keep their job. If you have a personality or are creative and think outside the box , you are not valued here. Super uptight environment, everyone is terrified that if they make one wrong move they will be in trouble.  If you are a yes man robot, without sense of humor, this is the place for you.

Summary: "Brilliant teams with great work in a"
Pro: Great teams and good development projects
Con: Low flexibility for faster innovation.

Pro: Gain tons of market knowledge and get great training. Work with good people, and it is a respectable firm. Good place to start a career
Con: It is hard to advance within the company some times. They don't pay fantastic and if they hire someone into the same job you're doing from an outside firm, expect them to be making a lot more than you.

Pro: Good benefits, good people to work with
Con: When it came to advancement, it was about who you knew, not how much you know

Summary: "Great company to work for, most of the time."
Pro: Competitive pay, treats employees well, lots of unique benefits, continuously improves employee experience & opportunities, strong ethical standards.
Con: Many policies set in stone without consideration to individual employee situations.  Loyalty is not always rewarded.  Very competitive and sometimes political internal advancement and mobility.  Strict & methodical salary grades.  HR screening process for applicants could be better.

Summary: "Lot's of career path opportunities. Great benefits. Great compensation."
Pro: There is a lot of focus on helping you advance your skills and career. They reward hard work and the people you work with are typically very professional and passionate about what they do. It would be very hard to leave the generous benefits and compensation once you have moved into a more advanced role.
Con: Sometimes it feels that senior management doesn't realize that their metrics and standards actually make it harder to help clients. They are great at taking small rocks out of the way, but the bigger rocks are next to impossible to move. Even when it is clear that they should be.

Summary: "Used to be a great place to work"
Pro: great work environment and benefits; on campus cafe was top notch; plenty of budget money to get things done the right way.
Con: management has turned into a seas pool of back stabbing weasels; no opportunity for advancement if you are not part of the 'club'

Pro: Great benefits (401k match, tuition reimbursement, fitness expense reimbursement, computer purchase reimbursement).
Con: Once you work at a call center, it's hard to transition to a position outside of the call center. Old boys club culture.

Pro: very diversified providing many opportunities; pays for performance
Con: inconsistency in how Managers lead/manage

Pro: Excellent compensation and benefits. great use of new technology
Con: Budget cutting, near shoring and off-shoring has resulted in most technology jobs being moved out of Boston. Middle management up to senior VP level has no input on strategies so it leads to bad morale. The remaining Boston tech groups are just waiting for there turn to be moved

Pro: Work life balance (flexiblity), nothing really more on pros
Con: No onsite travel, company politics, No promotion/growth

Pro: Fabulous long term compensation, career growth, and intelligent and trustworthy colleagues. Private ownership and high profitability has translated into high investment in people, offices, and technology.
Con: Regional diversification is putting strain on finding new opportunities while putting your current role at risk. Alot of movement and reassignment of business units to various national and international sites

Pro: Growth opportunities are for real
Con: None at the time i used to work

Summary: "My start in the financial service industry with Anonymous has been an awesome experience"
Pro: Great culture, top-notch benefits, good compensation, excellent training program
Con: Compensation for the amount of work can be better

Pro: Steady work.    Great retirement.
Con: Heavy middle management that has too much power.  Too many chiefs and not enough indians.   Plays favorites.  Review process is a joke.   Moving up or lateral takes forever if possible at all,  unless you have some kind of relationship with the management.

Pro: Great training and benefits. A good place to get started in the investment business.
Con: Limited scope of business and not truly client centered. Boxed approach in sales. But a good place for clients who are independent and want to manage their own investments.

Pro: Good way to get your series 7 and series 66 as they sponsor you for any exams.
Con: Dealing with obnoxious customers is frustrating

Summary: "Decent company to work for. Be wary of restructuring"
Pro: Co-workers are knowledgable and competent. Lots of resources for learning and job development. Technology is kept decently up to date.
Con: Not much interaction between departments. Management can be rigid. Constantly restructuring.

Pro: Back in the "day", great 401k matching and shares pay out allowed me to save a lot of money.  Good luck with that now!!  No more "golden handcuffs".
Con: The day after I left, due to my job being "site strategized", I moved every penny of my 401k to another financial firm.  Being an insider and seeing how the company was being run into the ground, there is no way that I would trust them managing my retirement nest egg

Summary: "Great company to start- plenty of ways to move around."
Pro: work/life balance, benefits & culture. It' a great company to start your career in a financial industry. It's also a private company, you do not have to worry about being laid off because the company's stock tanked.
Con: pay is horrible- it felt like a battle to get more than 5% bonuses.  All of the important roles are (upper management/decision making roles) and will always be in Boston. Jobs are relocating to NH, TX, or RI.

Summary: "Overall a great place to get started in the Financial Services industry."
Pro: Management is supportive of personal development.
Con: limited mobility if you don't work near major hubs (boston, westlake, merrimack)

Pro: Work life balance - work at home option
Con: would like more than 4 weeks vacation after 25 years

Summary: "Great company! Stay out of the branches. Phone sites are amazing."
Pro: Benefits. Health care is great. Fitness reimbursement and computer reimbursement.
Con: Its hard to fire people so management can be awful in the Branches.

Summary: "Anonymous is a great place to work"
Pro: Solid company and good benefits
Con: Annual salary adjustments are minimal

Con: Limited exposure to work and low quantum of work

Pro: Opportunity to work on latest IT technologies

Con:
The human resources group can't seem to set an example for others.  They have leaders to lie and treat others poorly.  These leaders twist stories and examples to benefit their own agenda.  



Constant change in company direction and leadership.  Lots of wasted time and money.

Pro: Great career opportunities, training encouraged, generous 401k and other savings vehicles, ability to work in many aspects of the business.
Con: Your job may move out of state.  Great if you are looking to relocate on the company dime, otherwise you hit the pavement.  Downsizing in Boston.

Con: Micro management. Annual pay cut.
