Summary: "Great place but only if you have a strong manager."
Pro: Compensation, benefits, ability to move around.
Con: Limited growth, lack of manager training, high stress environment.

Summary: "A great experience if you are willing to sell your soul"
Pro: Fantastic learning opportunities.  Lots of training opportunities.  Superb on the job experiences.  Great systems and infrastructure.   Plenty of very smart people (though not everyone).   Like any place, you can always find good decent people whom you will become friends with.   There is so much that the company invests in to support its growth, its customers and its employees.   A very dynamic company, in many cases cutting edge in its industry.   Very good pay for most people - in some cases, truly outstanding pay.  And great benefits for everyone.
Con: The culture is insidious.    Terribly dysfunctional, paricularly the more senior you become.   Its simply not about how well you do your job - many people have realized that doing well and being rewarded is as much about making the other person look bad to make you look better.    If getting ahead for you means throwing your co-worker under the bus, then this is the place for you.   Its such a shame, because the company could be so great, but the culture of fear is simply gripping the place so that people are terrified, yet in many cases they are paid so well that they are equally afraid to leave.   Someone who left once told me that working there was like being in an abusive relationship - and you don't realize it until after you have left.   So many examples of people who on one day are viewed as superstars, and the next day they are suddenly viewed at the bottom of the heap - in many cases this happens when their manager leaves, and the former manager loved them, but the new manager doesn't value them and wants them gone.  So, you come to realize that the ball can drop on you at any moment.   I remember one executive saying, verbatim, "we all have a bullet with our name on it, and its only a matter of time until it hits you."    Senior management used to be very inspiring years ago, but no longer - it really changed for the worse around 2008 and from what I saw and continue to hear, it keeps going in the wrong direction.

Pro: Great benefits and a great network of employees all across the country, willing to listen to employees
Con: Not being able to carry over vacation time seems irrational/encourages employees to use all their vacation days at the end of the year

Pro: Nice environment to work. And the best place to go
Con: Nothing to complain about anything

Summary: "Experience varies greatly with different groups, overall a sweat shop"
Pro: Good exposure and opportunities to learn in the Financial Industry. Anonymous is extremely dedicated to it's customers.
Con: Staffing reductions and off-shoring combined with constant reorganization and relocations make employment very precarious unless you're willing to up and move to Raleigh or Dallas. SME experience is undervalued. Bureaucratic and dilbert-like.

Summary: "One of the best companies to work for"
Pro: High ethical standards, respect for employees, opportunities to play diverse roles across multiple financial domains, frequent travels to US.
Con: High emphasis on people management. Credit sharing. Slow growth.

Summary: "Decent place to get your financial licenses, and thats about it."
Pro: Paid study time to pass exams.
Con: Anonymous is one of those "we grew too fast for our own good" companies.  From 1990 to 2000, the employee base grew exponentially and alot of people who had no business being in any sort of management role found themselves in charge of other people in management.  Anonymous now cannot care about their new recruits having bachelor's or master's degrees, because many of the site directors have only high school diplomas to their name.  The national director of phone centers is working on a bachelor's degree.  There is no reward for education or effort, and for a while the quickest way to get into a manager position was to be female--hardly any other qualification was needed.

Summary: "Great place to start an FA career, strong structure in place and very smart people."
Pro: Great expertise, structure, environment, opportunity
Con: Limited exposure and recognition, silo'd structure results in limited areas of involvement

Pro: I have been working for around 2 years. Pros - free cabs, meals and work life balance.
Con: lot of politics by Senior management, poor work culture, you wouldn't get growth even if you are working hard and providing solutions if you are not buttering up your boss

Pro: Amazing employer and great benefits
Con: hamster wheel and most days feel like groundhogs day

Summary: "Four stars for the company, two stars for the job."
Pro:
The people that make up this company are really great and not only care about their coworkers, but the surrounding community as well. I made life-long friends here.



The training teams were very helpful in helping my entire new-hire class pass our licensing exams and the information I learned has been very helpful for my life in general. 



My managers seemed genuinely interested in helping me find the right job internally--ironically this helped me realize that my dreams lay outside the company.
Con:
At its core, this is a call-center job--8 hours on the phone (or more). The information you discuss with clients is more complicated than other phone jobs, so you'll be relying on internal information systems since you can't know every little policy or acronym.



There's little time to breathe between calls at certain times of the year.



Meetings and coaching get cancelled all the time right when you're ready to take a break from the phones. I really could've used some help to improve the work I was doing.

Summary: "Was a great place to have a career in Boston MA."
Pro: Very professional environment, Ability to advance quickly. Great benefits. If you are lucky enough to get a job that will remain in the Northeast, take advantage of the very generous 401K and profit sharing.
Con: Not much bad to say here. Wish they weren't moving the employee bass out of the northeast to Texas and North Carolina. Also if you are a technologist be prepared to perform all of your change control work after hours and weekends.

Pro: Great people, challenging projects, best technology
Con: long hours, not a lot of support/consistency/planning from senior management

Pro: Probably the best training I've ever been through. I was hired on w/o my securities licenses and spent the first few months of work studying and in the classroom learning the Anonymous systems/culture/etc. (white getting paid). They hire great people, so everyone you work with knows their stuff and is enjoyable to be around. The company is extremely generous (10% of salary profit sharing bonus every year, fantastic benefits - I even got a $100 xmas bonus 2 mos. after being hired). If you're looking to get into the securities business this is a great place to get your licenses and cut your teeth.
Con: This is a phone center job. Your schedule is 100% set for you, down to the 15 min breaks before and after lunch, which is understandable, your job is to answer the phones. Most of the day you're not placing trades for customers but doing some sort of account maintenance (pw resets, IRA distributions, sending them forms, etc.). Everything is tracked and monitored (again, understandable, just be aware before you take the job). After training when you're on the phones all day you don't see much of your coworkers, it's mostly about talking to customers at your cubicle/desk. The job becomes very monotonous quickly.

Pro: Great long term benefits, collegiate environment, good work, company really cares for customer. The firm is in a very unique and strong position in the financial services industry
Con: Average compensation (and very slow growth), slow vesting schedule for profit share/contribution matches, bureaucracy

Pro: Strong benefits packages, many smart people, top technology,.   You will be challenged.  Lots of exposure to a variety of issues in financial services
Con: Ever since the economic meltdown, coupled with mediocre investment performance, and significant competitive pressures, Anonymous has turned into a place where most people are constantly looking over their shoulder for the next RIF, or move to another locale.  A lot of management by fear which eliminates any real risk-taking by employees.

Pro: Good benefits, decent salary. Good training.
Con: No matter how you slice it, you are working in a CALL CENTER. This means you will be micromanaged, treated like a child, and forced to work overtime because the firm refuses to staff properly during tax season. You can choose the flavor of calls you want (i.e. trading, advisory, service, retirements) but at the end of the day its still just about AHT, ACW, and the same old call center crap.

Pro: Overtime, Healthcare, Profit Sharing, Compensation
Con: Cold as ice management - lots of undue stress

Summary: "Great company but do not see myself here in the future"
Pro: Benefits: 401k, IRA-Roth, learn A LOT of how to effectively manage your money (don't even have to be an advisor to learn strategies--it just becomes innate after the frequent conversations and projects one participates in), Corporate Perks/Discounts, Corporate Amex (if applicable),
Con:
If your passion/interest isn't in financial industry, this career quickly becomes a job.

Corporate bureaucracy-- everyone seems to hate their job but will quickly act like they love it when asked -_-

Tuition Reimbursement- Continue education 90% reimbursement up to 10,000...seriously what "good" graduate school, B-School , etc has a tuition of $10,000/year...none

Pro: Education of Financial Industry and Products.
Con: Call center.....sit at desk all day taking phone calls with little to no time between calls. Extreme micro-management.

Summary: "Great and efficient company. Very pleased so far."
Pro: Tremendous brand-name industry recognition. Even though it's a large Co with a lot of layers of management it's actually very nimble and efficient when it comes to finding solutions for clients' needs and that keeps clients and customers satisfied.  The company spends a lot of $$ on innovation and technology and it's refreshing to see how it keeps clients' needs above everything else. Client is #1.  Benefits are great: 7% co match in 401k (dollar for dollar) and also a 10% Profit Sharing (on average) after 1 year of service. HSA contributions, plus incentive performance awards are above industry average. The culture is very conservative but they do respect all people no matter the associate's  sexual or religious background. Last but not least, the company is very committed to integrity and compliance standards so it stays out of negative headlines and it's extremely well run.  It's been a great place for me to work here and I'm very pleased to be part of this organization.
Con: Very large company so it's hard sometimes to get a lot of visibility and may feel lost without proper mentoring.

Pro: Great company with good culture. Good retirement benefits. Team collaboration is great that    provides good learning opportunities for the employees. Company has a great reputation and is growing very fast.
Con: The biggest challenge is the career growth. If you don't join at the right level, then you will struggle for a long time before making your way up. You may find several growth opportunities within the company but you can't negotiate even if you are well qualified for the position.

Summary: "Anonymous business services: not a good place for technical guys"
Pro:
Benefits

Less work(work life balance is good)
Con:
If you are a technical guy never join Anonymous Business Services which is in EGL. You have to work under managers who doesn't have any technical background, they will screw you to death. Especially do not join 'WI-Business Performing Reporting' which is full of a**-licking mangers who are simply surviving with out any knowledge on process or on technology. They don't understand your problems, they are like blind-bulls. 

Inter process movement with out any prior notice.

Managers do not give respect to your thoughts and ideas.

Pro: Excellent work-life balance. The people are very laid back and everything moves at a leisurely pace.
Con: the management is very bureaucratic. There is a culture of being nice and merit is not really valued. the company just looks at the time spent and not the value added.

Summary: "Good People, Great company, Learning experience . good employer great benefits great 401k matching for great future."
Pro: Work in the heart of financial district. you get to learn a lot of financial knowledge and expand your horizon.
Con: same work goes around. Slow scope to grow.

Pro: Best benefits out there bar none.  Great company to work for if you have a good manager (as is with most companies). Career advancement can be difficult in some locations so might have to be willing to move to advance. Overall great place to work.
Con: CAreer advancement can be difficult unless you are willing to relocate.

Summary: "Good at first,  then downhill from there"
Pro: I will say that the Series 7 training that they provide is excellent.  Ok for a year, if it's your first job out of college.
Con: Upper management does a great cheer-leading bit but the real world is quite different. Every move you make is recorded and monitored, if you make a rookie mistake they make you feel terrible,  very little praise without a "but". Lot's of nitpicking criticism.  You have no time to socialize because every minute is accounted for.   The work itself is ok but quite a grind when you average 50 calls a day with only 2 15 min. breaks.   Grueling for little pay.

Summary: "Learned a lot, hate being on the phones."
Pro: You get to learn about a lot of the rules in the industry. Pretty good training, and very extensive. They have flexible schedules and working 4 days a week at 10 hours a day is a perk.
Con: Phone center with nearly no time to breathe between calls. Can get pretty tedious towards the end of a 10 hour shift.

Pro: Anonymous has a great benefits. Technology just okay. many old applications and technology  are still exists,
Con: layoff many experience workers and rehiring no-experience with associate level. I don't know if this is a good strategy, but it happened. so your work loads will be heavier and  harder to handle. Plus you have to train the non-experience person. you will feel very stressful and demanding are very high in there.

Pro: Great culture, easy and comfortable atmosphere. Currently fast flow through to higher positions.
Con: Lower than average pay for similar positions elsewhere.

Pro: private company customer focus, most employees try work for the client and not the firm.
Con: slaes driven, wrong manager can ruin a good thing.

Summary: "Highly Political, Layoffs Often, No Job Security"
Pro:
Very good competitive compensation and benefits package.

Interesting and challenging work.

Reasonable work demands in most departments.
Con: Anonymous is highly political.  Basically no matter how high the quality of your work is, if you are not "liked" especially by your direct manager you will not be around for long.  Department and company reorganizations are often and many.  It is during these times you risk falling out of favor and run the risk of frequent job eliminations. Once you are out of the company due to a layoff or job elimination you are pretty much out forever - unless you have a contact manager that will hire you. There is no job security no matter your position or length of employment.  Anonymous will never win any best places to work awards but the they pay well.  If you are looking to be loved, respected, or for a friend - buy a dog.

Summary: "Overall good company to work for.  Great benefits."
Pro: Great benefits. Good company values, very customer first driven. I enjoyed my co-workers, very professional.
Con:
No work/life balance, especially in sales. You're required to pull in the same level of sales when you're out on vacation. Unfortunately, you feel stressed going on vacation and/or when you come back. 

Promotion is based on who you know, somehow the hiring manager forgets what you're past accomplishments are.

Great work life balance 

wonderful work life balance 

lot of focus on people
Con: Slow on execution and decision making

Company is generous and I will retire here.

Pro: Benefits are fantastic. 7% 401k match and 10% profit sharing dump. Great health plan. Lots of vacation. Job Security. Great place to begin a career in Sales/Financial Planning. Great customer focus (in terms of interactions and handling issues). Great Integrity. One of those companies where it would take blatant action to intentionally hurt the client interaction to lose your job.
Con: Middle to Upper Middle management are pretty unqualified. When there is a problem with a system or process the resolution is to take down a list of everything that's broken, sit and wait to see how many customers complain about it over the course of 1-3 years, then prioritize funding to fix the issue, then make a video about how terrible the process is and show it to all of the employees in some sort of a backwards way to show their great problem resolution technique, and then maybe after 2 years its fixed. Meanwhile, front line employees have to constantly make excuses to clients and maintain a "can do" attitude.

Summary: "I'd work at McDonalds or D'Angelos over this place (and some current employees have according to their resumes)"
Pro: It's impossible to get fired, but other than that there is not a single pro that comes to mind...how can there be pros when you have 7 long hours of customer service calls.  It's literarily call after call from clients who are pissed off and only call in because they have a problem.  Maybe flipping patties and making sandwiches isn't such a bad idea, huh?
Con:
The managers get paid to keep their reps in the call center aka prison.  You do not want to do a life sentence at this place because you'll wake up in 20 years and still be taking 7 hours of phone calls and making 40k a year.  There is no advancement at all!  This job will not help you get your foot in the door to move through the company...it will get you in the door to move from phone center job to phone center job to phone center job aka lateral movement with new job titles and more annoying clients.

This place hires photography majors, geology majors, heck even people without a college degree, so if you have a finance, accounting, or econ degree, look elsewhere if you want to start a real career in finance or any business field because this place is like a kindergarten for adults (why else are the walls painted mac n cheese orange, sun yellow, puke green?

Summary: "Rare supportive team culture for financial advisors"
Pro: My branch office in New England has an outstanding team culture where the focus isn't just on doing the right thing for your customer, but also doing the right thing to support your colleagues. The culture of collaboration  is rare in the world of financial advisors, but that's due to the unique branch office model which is based on a team effort and results. An added bonus - the branch manager publicly acknowledges staff who have done a good job in weekly team meetings.
Con: None. I've worked for 3 financial service companies and this is, by far, the best in the business for financial advisors.

Pro: 401k match, shares if they like you, salary, choices for health insurance
Con: I was told by my manager: "I'm not important, your work is not important, and no one cares about your job".  Management by fear and intimidation seems to be status quo.  Limited accountability.  Fido has a lot of lifers and most of these people are bitter and angry or just plain useless.  Talent is not rewarded and failure is not punished.

Summary: "Glad for having worked there, glad I'm no longer working there"
Pro: I loved working for a company that provided excellent customer service.  I felt proud of the products we sold and knew that people really put their energy into doing the best possible thing for the customers.  From the chairman down this was how the company operated.  There was never any question about that.
Con:
There is an unusual culture of politeness, but not in a way that is productive.  People nodding and smiling did not mean your idea had acceptance - outside of the meeting people nodding and smiling could work vigorously to defeat the idea.  The lack of openness and vigorous debate was unusual.  



The compensation at the executive level has a highly variable component based on the company's performance.  People who had been successful getting internal "shares" tended to become more and more protective of their position and their turf.  They had to continue to look good to get more and more shares and would actively undermine anyone with ideas different from theirs.  I think this compensation model stifled innovation.  People who rocked the boat didn't last very long; many of the people I admired in the executive ranks were eliminated during "reductions of force".  There are antibodies to thought diversity that are really difficult to overcome.



I'd thought I'd be a lifer, but lost my job after 15 years during the 2008 recession.  Since then I've had a lot more personal freedom than I experienced working at Anonymous with a more rapid pace of personal growth both consulting and starting a company.  I am far less secure financially, but am happy.

Summary: "Great company, spent over 20 years working with very smart and talented people."
Pro: Engaging work, great opportunities and benefits.
Con: Businesses shift workplace locations regularly which could be an issue if you're not willing to relocate.

Pro: Very strong franchise with good product support in an exciting marketplace.  Excellent benefits too.  Culture is outstanding, everyone is motivated to work as a team.  There are products and services managed for the local market and also managed for the larger market south of the border.
Con: Market pressure is intense.  Competitors are strong and Anonymous Canada is not one of the biggest players.  Investment management is not a business know for having a lot of natural work life balance so be prepared to work hard and sometimes long.

Summary: "I love the company pay and benefits"
Pro: Great benefits and pay they also care and recognize thier employees. Great development if your a finance buff
Con:
None.



I need a job that isn't finance

Pro: Great benefits, great coworkers, clean campus,
Con: Managers only manage up. Pay quickly stops after several years to a grinding halt, even with stellar reviews. Most of these positive reviews are from newbies who are the only ones fidelity invests in. After a couple years, trust me, you'll be begging to get out of their militant and lack of resource style. Managers know nothing about your role, as Anonymous typically hires managers with no knowledge of the role as they believe managers are their to "manage" and not need be experts at the technical aspects of the role. With that said, where do you go for guidance? Glad the police, fire department or pilots aren't hired Anonymous style. Who is the go to contact if your manager doesn't have a clue about the day to day of your job? Being a manager is a great deal at Fido as they have zero accountability and throw you under the bus if need be. I've been there 7 years and have a rockstar performance record, so this review is not in spite, rather it's just reality. Get in, get your license and experience on their dime, get out. Was a great employer years gone by, but as Ned once said "Our employees are our biggest asset" has not been heard in years and years. They burn you out, WANTING turnover, just to hire somebody for half your salary.

Summary: "I worked for Anonymous India since its inception in 2003- 2004 and for 10 years."
Pro: Great company to work for (minus the insecure managers / management). Provides amazing work culture and employee benefits.  Brand matters a lot. A company which focuses on learning and allowing its employee take up challenging assignments.
Con:
No longer employee friendly company.  Lot of high level (senior management) politics played in a dirty manner. Senior management's insecurity drives tenured and talent people to move out in search of better opportunities.

With recent changes, the sense of US wanting to control all its offshore operations is very evident, unlike how things started back in 2003 - US had confidence and trust in the Leaders recruited then.

Summary: "Great place to work - you're expected to work hard but are rewarded in return!"
Pro: Opportunities abound.  It really is what you make of it.  You have the opportunity to grow - tuition and training are supported by the organization - allowing you to grow and create your own opportunities.  Benefit programs are the best in the industry.  Innovation is encouraged and rewarded.  Organizational success is celebrated.  Client focused culture that respects the employee contribution.
Con: It is not easy - but nothing good ever is.

Pro: Awesome benefits, cool people, leadership gives feedback and isn't afraid of feedback.
Con: they work you like a horse, but as long as you make numbers, they don't care what you do with your time.

Pro: Benefits - great package and bonuses.
Con:
Politics. There are people there who I honestly didm;t what they did. Once someone is entrenched there they never leave. Everything takes forever to get done. Toxic culture. 

They claim to be entrepreneurial but that couldn't be farther from the truth.

Summary: "Anonymous is a great place to work"
Pro: Great benefits and 10% profit sharing. Anonymous is very big on promoting from within. I've been promoted 3 times since starting in 2010 and have had some of the best managers of my career.
Con: The only challenge I find is the limited types of positions available in California. There is definitely more opportunity for growth in others parts of the country.

Pro: good compensation, large company, hard work but it is worth it
Con: may not get noticed due to size

Pro: As an IT professional, this is a great place to work.  The company invests in technology a lot and is proud to be one of the best companies in the technology field in the tech magazines.  Benefit package is one of the best in the industry, with exceptional company match/profit sharing for retirement.  Abundant opportunities for training.
Con: The general salary level seems a bit lower compared to the industry average, which is compensated by the great retirement benefit package.

Pro: One of the only financial firms in the industry with values.
Con: The only way to get off the phones in SLC is to be at the company 10 years (or so)

Pro: Excellent training, good work life balance, easy to move around within departments
Con: Slow growth, very bureaucratic. A lot of approvals take very long and the process is very tedious. Promotions take time.

Pro: Cab service, work from home and lax work culture(beware, can make you lazy)
Con:
Incompetent Management, Poor leaders, Weekend support, Off-hours support.

Decisions never made in India. 

People with ambitions to grow will be left disappointed for lack of roles and growth opportunities.

Management tends to make scapegoat of resources to serve their needs.

Has a head count cap- Means organisation cannot grow beyond a certain number

Pro: good work culture, good people
Con: not much on flex work schedule or remote work

Summary: "Anonymous Workplace Guidance Role in Westlake is a Major Disappointment"
Pro:
Excellent benefits.

Wonderful location on beautiful campus with amenities.

Opportunities for advancement.

Workplace Guidance role inspires reps with mission to help customers with onboarding within their employer sponsored 401k plan. 

Top-notch facilitator teaches principles involving the use of consultative selling skills to facilitate deeper, needs-based analysis in order to better serve customers.
Con:
Unfortunately, when training ends, the reality is that associates must position Anonymous IRA's, regardless of whether or not enough information has been gathered from the customer to substantiate the pitch. Since there's no time for a consultative approach when managers expect you to take as many calls as possible--- and because there's no need for a consultative approach when an IRA is always the answer--- phone interactions result in the same canned pitch over and over.

Managers and Guidance Support Specialists coach to numbers only. Customer satisfaction surveys somehow no longer matter. Site wide departmental sales performance reports are routinely e-mailed to the group and posted on white boards near team areas. Stats reports (number of calls handled, average handle time, etc.) are e-mailed daily. Associates are even required to keep a running personal daily tally and turn it in each week as a sort of unofficial reporting mechanism which is still e-mailed out to the team.

Within the Workplace Guidance business unit there is also a drive that pits all sites against one another, competitively speaking. Westlake prides itself on being "relentless" and even encourages dishonest tactics to provide an unfair advantage such as working unscheduled overtime in order to take more phonecalls than other sites.

Pro: Great place to start off a career because they offer so much growth potential in the financial industry. Management is excellent here and always respectful of their employees. Great benefits as well.
Con: A lot of the people I worked with were lazy and constantly trying to get out of actually having to work, but eventually that's why they don't get promoted and those who work hard do. Also I've heard that the salary is a bit lower than similar positions within the industry, but they make up for it with benefits.

Pro: Great colleagues; good working environment
Con: Little training provided - new staff hired instead.

Summary: "Over the past couple of years things have gone down hill."
Pro: Flexible work options,  new campus, 1-1 match up to 6% on 401k,  profit sharing each year
Con: Areas have poor, indecisive leadership.  Benefits expensive, constant reorgs,  low career growth, execs out of touch with the masses

Summary: "The definition of Gamification of the workplace."
Pro: Do not need any investment knowledge.  Can be promoted simply due to "needs of the business".  If able to stick around for 5+ years, will be able to keep the 7% 401k matching and 10% yearly profit-sharing payout.  Great for recent college grads who have not developed professional workplace habits.  VERY hands on approaching to coaching and development; multiple people always providing career advice.
Con: Some of the lowest pay in the industry.  Previous experience is not respected once hired on; only benefits prior to being hired when qualifying for roles.  Micromanaged down to the smallest detail.  As the title of the review says, gamification of the workplace is in full swing (look it up if unfamiliar; may not be suitable for all individuals).  VERY negative attitude towards competitors.  Upon resignation of the firm all previous connections will instantly dissolve.  Senior management uses smiles and positive speeches to squash any and all critiques/feedback of existing processes.  "On-loan" roles are overused in order to keep from permanently funding very enjoyable roles.  Lower management uses toys (slinkees, pom-poms, hello kitty candy dispensers) to "encourage and motivate" their teams while in the middle of tax seasons.  Overall, very immature and unprofessional work environment.  Attrition is a constant battle that is verbally ignored and spoken against.

Pro: Surrounded by motivated, performance oriented, and competitive individuals
Con: Feel pulled in many directions, stretched thin, hard to find work life balance

Pro:
- Lots of training opportunities.

- Good work from home options

- Free transport

- Great place if you want to build your financial domain expertise

- Respect and trust runs high
Con:
- This company needs people with good exp to work extremely closely with US counterparts. But people with good exp. people will need growth - which can be a challenge.

- This org is risk averse

- Red tape is high, hard core techies will find it tough to do some get their job run quickly because of the endless processes. 

- Company has a mandate to not increase the headcount. Hence the challenge for senior management is growth for employees.

- Global work opportunities are limited to US.

Pro: Salary could be better, however, the benefits and opportunities provided by the company more than make up for that. Have already been promoted twice since obtaining series 7/63 just four months ago.
Con: Tax season overtime requirement at 10%. Salary could be better.

Pro:
Free home pick up and drop

free buffet lunch

nice work environment

work life balanca
Con:
unstable management

too many re-orgs

poor planning of projects

Summary: "Overall Anonymous is a good company to work for, however not all departments are run the same."
Pro: Anonymous pays well and has great benefits, including generous time off and provides a year-end bonus based on performance.  The company also has a year end celebration every year, which is always well done.
Con: Upper management does not always recognize problems that may be in the department.    An awful lot of company politics.  No cafeteria can make it expensive if you don't bring your lunch.

Summary: "Great company to work for if you are in it for the long term"
Pro:
-Very transparent for the client unlike a lot of Wall Street banks

-Excellent brand name within the marketplace and the general public

-Benefits 401k and work/life balance

-Quick opportunity for advancement, especially in the last few years
Con:
-Salary: The phone roles are grossly underpaid considering the amount of responsibility and the value the role adds for the company. This role is one of the most difficult in the company and is compensated the least.



-Extreme micro-management on the phone roles especially with metrics, breaks and lunch



-Lack of communication: Often times as employees we find out about breaking news/advancements the company is involved in, at the same time as the general public

Pro: The benefits and compensation are among the best. A place were you can grow professionally and as an individually through hundreds of online enrichment courses. A great company that has a clear vision of its future through the leadership of its CEO, Mr. Ned Johnson and his family.
Con: Due to its constant change and forward visionary; work-life balance can become a challenge for some associates.

Pro: good benefits, they paid for lunch several times.
Con: It's a call center!!!! If you think there's the slightest chance you wouldn't mind working in a call center, even if there are good benefits, think again! This. Job. Sucks.

Pro: Good workplace, good benefits, Very good trainings and many more
Con: Not many cons here.. If I have to mention one, its my late ending shift time which impacts my Work-life balance

Pro: good salary, good 401k contribution, good bonus and good profit sharing.  Excellent  opportunities for career growth.
Con: some times too much process oriented

Pro:
great wages,

flexible hours,

benefits,

some opportunities to travel (but rare)
Con:
boring

more time spent on office politics then Developing

Summary: "Great place to work and the people/ managers are really nice."
Pro: strong solid company with great reputation. managers really help you succeed and progress in your career/ goals. flexible with your schedule and work with you if something does not go as plan within work and outside. paid training.
Con: the compensation could be much better for the amount of tedious work and dedication to ensuring customer satisfaction.  large corporation so politics are often involved in decision making.

Pro: Stable family run company, great retirement benefits, investments in future. Folks seem to stay at fidelity for 20 plus years and culture of people leaving the company and coming back which is telling.
Con: Stagnant pay, difficult for upward mobility, company feels too big and you are too anonymous at times. No transparency into how decisions are made concerning salary and promotion so difficult to know how to advance.

Pro: Great company to work for with lots of opportunity for personal development. The company is full of incredible people that you will know the rest of your life.
Con: Personal I would like more remote opportunities. In todays world you are seeing more flexibility in scheduling and working from home. Anonymous is limited in this area.

Pro: The 401k match is great
Con: Everything else is not great

Pro: Good perks, latest technologies, challenging environment
Con: More visibility, promotions and training

Summary: "Good company, but limited mobility up and across."
Pro: Benefits, team environment, employer-provided training and certification, over-time, bonuses
Con: You get silo'd making it difficult to move into a different division. Working weekend and holidays if you work in the call-center.

Pro: Great place to start! Great training and plenty of opportunities. Benefits are great and salary is fair for opening positions. Easy to move within the firm if you're hard working.
Con: As with all large firms, there are some politics involved in promotions. Fast paced environment that at times can be overwhelming.

Pro: Really great culture and wonderful people to work with and alongside. Benefits are great, and the work-life balance is more than you could ask.
Con: Depending on the manager, they may not be as invested in your growth. In my time, I've been under three managers, two of which were great and one not-so-great. It's difficult to move within the company, but there are an array of possibilities, so as long as you know the right people and where you want to go, you can move around.

Pro: great place to start career, great benefits, good training
Con: lack of middle management focus, branch management turnover, salary much lower than competitors and is always changing

Summary: "Fantastic, everyones very kind and hard working. Food in the cafeteria is great and reasonably priced. Well managed."
Pro: People as well as the opportunities to change roles within the company. Everyone here seems to work hard and their are few shortfalls with the benefits that we receive. It has personally led me to grow as an individual as well as gain valuable experience in the financial services industries. I personally feel lucky that I had the opportunity to work at such a wonderful company and hope to continue my career here for years to come.
Con: Can be stressful with the workload, half the time it seems like your in meetings receiving work than you are actually doing work. Will have to work late hours a lot to make up for the work you could not complete during the day and sometimes you are working 60 hour weeks to keep up with the demand. It is manageable but it can lead to stress, less sleep and worrying. The paycheck does make up for this however as they are a company that does pay pretty well.

Pro: They provide an above-average salary for a not so demanding work load. it is also a fun work environment.
Con: Temporary contract position with not so great benefits. Not enough responsibility.

Summary: "Awesome place to work with thoughtful long term diversified strategy"
Pro: Excellent bonus structure. Never missed the annual bonus.. ever.. Huge 401K benefits package. You have to experience the 401K benefits to believe it. High performers get private company shares which are worth A LOT over time. This company does not think short-term both in their strategy as well as in their benefits & compensation structure. Apart from benefits, the company culture and treatment of employees is genuine in nature. Company strives for people to move around & encourages it. So, you are not stuck doing one this for a long time.
Con: Promotions might be very hard to get due its flat structure, but compensation overall is good given its broad base. Things will get frustrating because it is slower to move on important things, but its understandable in any large company.

Pro: Flexible work schedule and health insurance even if you are part-time.
Con: They are always changing things whether it is protocols, standards, or leadership.  They don't value their hard working managers.

Pro: Nice work life balance and working culture
Con:
growth is less

hike are based on the business unit you are working.

onsite opportunities are less

Summary: "Stable and still a good place to work"
Pro:
Private company provides stability, and strong values allow true customer focus. 

Rocket-paced growth of the 90's has been replaced with slow growth and stability. 

Consistent organizational improvement. Sr. Management has improved over the last 10-15 years - the bad ones leave and the good ones stay are rotated through different areas.  

Although challenging personalities and work goals exist (as they do anywhere), respect and professionalism wins over personal ego at this company.  

Very good benefits, excellent 401k match, but health cost have risen substantially in past few years.  

Average employee tenure has risen substantially due to high retention rate and slower growth.
Con:
Long tenure in many areas limit promotion opportunities. 

Salary less than some competitors (but offset by benefits).

Management positions tend to be stretched thin, so expect some long hours.  Definitely some gaps in HR defined positions defined and business duties required. 

Salary growth has been non-existent since 2007. 

Hourly positions tend to have seasonal overtime which can be quite high.

Historically has been known by customers as a 'many-headed Hydra' due to independently managed business units and departments (this is changing due to customer focus).

Summary: "Great company but less opportunities than before"
Pro: Meritocracy, Highly motivated culture, Efficient system, lean organization structure for the professional to focus on the work itself
Con: Less promotion with limited career opportunities, less competitive pay for the job, short sighted human capital management, difficult to find work and life balance

Pro: people and work enviornment is good, everyone wants to help other succeed. demeanor is in good standing and work is steady.
Con: pace is a little slow for my liking but i can see others around me working very diligently and for extended periods of time

Pro: Professional and dynamic financial services management
Con: Slow to move on some real world technology initiatives

Pro: The company provides exceptional customer service training.  It will give you the training to enter into any service related field and hit the ground running.  Being a privately held company has great benefits as well.... you're not constantly held to shareholders opinions.
Con: The salary was average, but nothing exceptional.  The company does provide good health benefits and retirement benefits to factor into the total compensation.

Pro: Several job opportunities to advance and improve resume.
Con: There are similar jobs elsewhere that pay better.

Pro: Structure for growth opportunity, strong internal support, great benefits
Con: Working on Sundays.  I understand we need to be there for our clients 24/7, but 5am on a Sunday is rough

GOOD work-life balance: very rarely expected to work overtime.  I have seldom had to work beyond my 45-hr week in the 18 months thus far

Small company; hence easy access to higher management - no proverbial "glass ceiling"

Work roles mostly very well defined for most roles

Company sponsored transport (which now is almost a given with most MNCs)

GREAT cultural tolerance amongst employees and management

Opportunities for short onshore business trips for certain roles
Con:
Compensation stable - neither too good nor too poor

Annual revision in pay relatively low; annual bonus at par with industry

Very high attrition in Operations

Summary: "Strong organization with smart people and many resources"

Summary: "Worked there for over 18 years and enjoyed working with others there."
Pro: Solid company values and compensation
Con: Westlake was to be one of two areas to grow and be center of excellence but didn't happen.

Pro:
As a fresher you have to join this company. It will help you to understand the meaning of pressure at work.

It will help you in Multitasking. It will help you in planning your leaves, a day's schedule. Freshers can work here for  2 years. If you really like the Company and want your career to grow then start preparing for your IJP.

Bonus will be good but there will be minimum change in your CTC. You'll find good friends in your Cab but not in team. If you feel there is no growth in your job or not interested to do the record keeping job then please move on. Yes fun factor will be there only if you are in a fun team. Competition is High so Beware of your Co-Workers.
Con:
I think the pay-scale and bonus. It's very low for the people who work consistently and who do not work will earn a higher bonus.

There is favoritism if you belong to the same community.

Even if you don't like gossiping, you have to be present with the team when they are doing so.

Team leaders have to improve on their process knowledge. Leadership skills are important but it does not mean it is unnecessary to learn the process.

Working on Saturday's and Sunday during peak seasons.

Never buy food in Cafeteria. It's tasty but your stomach will start bloating after an hour. Every food item is prepared with Baking Soda. Chapatis are fine to have but get your gravy/subji.

Summary: "A Cesspool That Sucks The Life Right Out of You."
Pro:
There's a roof on the building, so you don't get wet when it rains. 

The knives in the cafeteria are not sharp enough to slit your wrist if you feel the urge.
Con:
It's culture of lip service, where you're not exactly telling lies but close to it. 

The pay is horrible. I was paid $20,000 under the industry average. 

It's  a political game from Day One.  If you want to get anywhere, you'll need to invest in a set of knee pads.

Summary: "Global financial firm with large in-house technical divisions"
Pro: Pay scale is towards the top of the range to attract a good talent pool & fill positions quickly & easily and benefits are very good. There is also the opportunity to move around to a wide variety of different jobs within the company if you want to change the focus of what you're currently doing.
Con: On the technical side of things, the company's top leadership ends up being mostly reactive rather than proactive, so much of the tech work revolves around putting out fires, instead of building toward the future. Top leadership does not have a clear vision on how to build, organize, or manage the tech divisions to leverage their power & look toward the future, instead choosing to focus on old school approaches that historically have not been effective. Unfortunately, the very excellent & innovative ideas that abound at the employee, & lower & middle management level at the company are lost due to a lack of vision or understanding within top leadership of the tech division.

Pro: People are nice, fantastic benefits and decent pay
Con: Risk profile makes innovation difficult in some areas.  The environment is also difficult for getting your work done.

Summary: "A good Company to Start your career with"
Pro: Friendly Environment,Respectful Culture,Good training Experience.
Con: Nothing much of cons,If i find anything in future i will share it with you in here

Pro: Work life balance is good"................
Con: Not for aggressive folks who are focused on their careers..... Outsourced model, no decision making in india

Pro: Very much employee friendly company
Con: I didnot find any such cons

Summary: "Good first job, but there are drawbacks"
Pro: Good benefits to regular full time and regular part time employees in terms of medical, dental, and vision- the higher coverage plan has a higher cost passed onto the employee. 401k plan available with matching.
Con: In the Albuquerque site, favoritism runs rampant. Managers play favorites with staff and will ignore employee concerns, this problem extends up to directors as well. Also, Albuquerque is excluded from the profit sharing benefit that ALL OTHER SITES enjoy and pay is low for the job. They will try and convince you the pay is appropriate, however, compared to other call centers it is lower starting by far. To be clear, this is a call center job, while it may have different ways of doing things, metrics are the only thing a manager has to use to grade your performance. If your manager doesn't like you, they can find a number of ways to get rid of you.

Pro:
Flexibility,

Work Life Balance

Good Compensation

Better Facilities

Easy going teammates
Con: Not a strong base for analyst in India

Pro: The company is employee driven. They bend over backwards for their employees. The theory is happy employees, happy customers...
Con: There are not any cons to my knowledge.

Pro: The company treats its employees very well. Growth potential is always there, if you have the right drive. Coworkers were mostly entertaining and a great resource for moving up in the company
Con: Can be very repetitive. Some variance would be nice. Once you are in a role, it can feel like you get stuck. Expect to be in some roles that are incredibly busy and quite unfulfilling for a while, but you can move on from these lower roles if you really network

Summary: "Good place to work. Company led by a great family, the Johnson,  who do things the right way."
Pro: Decent pay, especially for younger employees who work hard. Great benefits. Ability to move up quick and get experience in many different parts of the financial industry. Amazing training.
Con: Goal and compensation change frequently. Management is constantly focusing on something different. At one time my goals consisted of how much money i brought in, how much went into product (mutual funds, managed accounts, annuities, fixed income), how many referrals i received, how many retirement plans/ income strategies i went through, and so on. It it impossible to do great at everything which means management is always stressing something.

Summary: "Be careful not to think outside the very small box"
Pro: They offer excellent medical and educational benefits.
Con: Working at Anonymous will be frustrating for anyone who likes to think for his or herself.  In the call center, you are considered close to a trained parrot, and the only value the company recognizes is your ability to regurgitate the same lines over and over.  Even after considering very carefully how to word certain items with customers, a management intern with weeks of relevant experience who has very little understanding of your job will listen to your calls and tell you exactly how they want you to speak to customers, down to exact lines of text that won't work very well and will cause you more problems with customers.  Thinking people will hate this.  Work is very boring and rote.  The tools provided to get the job done are poorly designed, and can hurt your call statistics.  You will be assigned a queue for a specific pool of customers, and some are far worse than others.  This too will affect your statistics.

Pro: Work life balance, Technology and benefits
Con: did not noticed any cons working in this company

Summary: "Great Company with not so great work"
Pro: Relaxed Environment, Respectful work culture, Friendly staff
Con: Laggard decision making, Very less work load

Pro: The office environment is great. I love just about everyone there. You even have the chance to interact with the Senior Management Team from time to time. All employees are very knowledgable. Always open to new ideas and the Work/Life balance is great.
Con:
Compared to other places the base salary is not that great.

Unnecessary training

People with less seniority seem to do more of the administrative work

Pro: Excellent work experience as there were many bright people to work with and many good tech projects ongoing.  Trading floor environment was fun.
Con: Manager had a problem with bright analysts.  There was a culture of good ole boy network

Summary: "work-life balance, friendly people,overall a good company to work for."
Pro: Very good work-life balance, best for experienced peoples, one of the good place for a women to work in, gives good travelling opportunities.
Con: Not for freshers,  sometimes lack of leadership shows off,sometimes work becomes boring

Pro: Good benefits and stable job. Managers give you training and opportunities to learn.
Con: Doing routine and processing working which is not challenging and can get  old after one year.

Pro:
Work culture

Nice team to have and nice people around

Respect for the employee

Excellent Brand name
Con:
Salary not up to mark. Sometimes less than industry standard.

No Onsite

Politics in some of the team.

Pro: The training you receive at a job says a lot about your employer, and Anonymous invests a lot of time and resources in their new employees.  Throughout your training there are constant opportunities to sit down with your on-boarding manager to talk about your progress and career development, including what direction you want to take after your current position.  It's almost as if Anonymous wants you to improve and move onto bigger and better opportunities within the company more than you do.
Con: At the start there is a lot of time commitment that you need to make outside of the workplace.  Getting securities licensed takes a lot of time at work and a lot of time at home.  If that's not something you are used to or don't have available it can be a big adjustment.

Pro: Good company! A lot of opportunities for career growth.
Con: Micro managing has been something that has been ramping up.

Pro: The starting pay is good.
Con: They lie to their employees and don't care about them or their families.

Summary: "FIis reliance hiring ffriends and family made it a very cliquish place to work"
Pro: Anonymous investments is a very generous employer.
Con: FIIS management preferred recent college grads who were living  in their parents basement.Any employee who was over 35 and did not suck up to management was treated like a leper.

Summary: "Pathetic company to work for if you strive for excellence"
Pro:
- Free Cab service

- Minimal work pressure (If you want to chill out for the rest of your life with zero learning its the best place)
Con:
- Incompetent & old peer group who are out of touch from new technologies

- Hardly any technical or innovation related discussion on the floor, all discussions are about "what time are you leaving home today"

- Focus on show-off & oiling your manager instead of quality and excellence 

- Use of obsolete technologies whose experience doesn't count in the market anymore

- Too much red tape in the organization. In the name of risk and compliance the management has created a maze instead of simplifying things. If you ever had an yearning for working in a government job, you can get the first hand experience in Anonymous

- Too much restrictions on trading activities. Cannot participate in IPOs

- Pathetic salary structure. For majority of the employees the salary structure is {Basic + HRA(60% of Basic) + Other Allowance (30% of Basic) + Bonus (15%+ depending on designation) ... guess what the only non-taxable component of the whole salary is HRA, that too you can max claim upto 40% of Basic as Bangalore is a non-metro.

- The average bonus payout is 75-80% for the company and again 75-80% based on your performance. So, if your bonus is Rs. 100, you are paid Rs. 100 *.80 (company payout) * .80(your performance) = Rs. 64 you could see for yourself how the company fools you with its bonus calculation

- Zero flow of information and knowledge - The work culture has been designed in such a way that you hardly talk to your team mates as you are mostly an "individual contributor". Majority of the time your manager doesn't have a clue on what you are working on and hence don't expect your colleagues to know much of it. 

- In my line of work "Business Analytics" they take in good talent pool and make them work on pathetic projects on obsolete tools and technology. Hence, majority of the newbees leave early

- the company is overstaffed with employees, as more FTEs ensures fat bonus of the VP or Sr. Director. Hence, majority of the times employees are sitting idle doing nothing

- Zero growth opportunities

- There are 'Silence Please' boards at multiple places on the floor --- U think I am kidding r8?? Go and check for  yourself

- No more frequent US trips after Infosys case

 

I think I have mentioned enough. Don't want to scare you guys with more cons although I have a lot more

Summary: "Emotional rollercoaster thanks to bad program and management"
Pro: Profit sharing is 7% after you have been there for 1 year. They will reimburse you for college and even 25% for a new laptop and printer.
Con: Do not believe or support employees. On-boarding managers are unprofessional and condescending.

That kind of behavior doesn't help a company move forward. They are also way too conservative and never want to take responsibility. Instead, they make decisions by consensus so that no one is to blame if something goes wrong.

It is not very dynamic to the technology changes but they tend to apply latest technology.

Extremely political atmosphere - most employees are afraid to raise concerns due to repercussions from senior management. There are some very good managers within the company however locally, our managers were very unprofessional and morale within the office was very low as a result. High turnover within company as a result.

phones

raises are low

Summary: "This is not a career. Use it for experience only."
Pro:
It was easy to get hired. I made some mistakes and they still hired me. I really needed a job so I took it. 

I really like the people I work with. They are intelligent and genuinely friendly, except for a few people, who happen to be in decision making roles. A college education is encouraged and most people have that or have had years experience in customer service, business or finance. This makes for a great group of coworkers, but makes it more tragic given the cons.
Con:
I have been at the company for 7 months as a 401K associate.



I feel like the culture and environment turns my good co-workers into fearful drones looking out for only themselves. 



And now from here down are just facts:



You have to have your computer system up and running with 4-5 applications by the start of your shift. if the computer locks up, which happens at least once a day, more for others, you cannot let the customer know, keep talking, reboot, refresh etc. they are now transitioning us into a different computer system but coming up this month. I'm not optimistic. 



My Veritude hired co-workers were on the job for 6 months until transitioning into non-Veritude, or I guess "regular Anonymous employees" were not eligible for the mid year review raise. Also, the day they transition, their computer systems were locked up and it took all day for IT to fix. The company was not prepared. This is how I found out how many there were at my site it was about a quarter of the DC associates. Many of these people were some of the best members of my team. I didn't know what Veritude was until I read Glassdoor this evening. it is actually a Anonymous hiring department. It is a temp to hire. So Anonymous hires some employees and gives them the same job as other regular employees but they do not get the mid year review raise or quarterly bonus.



My manager purposefully plays politics and does not hide it.



The salary is very low. 



You get sick leave throughout the year but each time you call in sick it counts against you as an "incident". Each manager has discretion on what will be used against you. This is unfair period.



The company match is 7% on the retirement savings acct. but only after you have worked there 1 year, and you are not 100% vested until five years. 



Each site in the nation has only specific job roles available. 



Our job is to go above and beyond for the customer and work for the customer, which, if done right, means printing out statements and literature by hand and sending them in envelopes or calling out to our solutions desk to do research on complicated issues or submitting research requests which are complicated forms where we have the least bit of training on. Any work done that is not on the phone is going to be counted against your hold time, your idle time or if you are unlucky and do not take your lunch on time, your adherence time.



We get two 15 min breaks and 30 min lunch. It takes 15 min to walk down to the cafeteria to acquire food after standing in line with the slowest people in the world (management knows this) You eat in 10 min, go to the restroom and rush back to get system ready to start again. that is assuming there are no tasks to wrap up after getting off the phone and starting your lunch clock, and there always is, along with some trying to talk to you.

Summary: "Processing instructions received accurately and within the expected TAT.Supporting projects effectively."
Pro: Anonymous is an excellent place to work. Members are really very supportive and it conducts fun meetings frequently to cheer its employees.
Con: I do not find any Cons in Anonymous. It is a good company in terns of employee benefits,working environment.

Summary: "I've had an amazing career here for the past 15 years!"
Pro: The continuous investment back into the employees and customers.
Con: Very conservative company with LOTS of type-a personalities. Everyone works hard and struggles with balancing time away.

Pro: Good culture, life balance, learning oppotunities
Con: Management politics Bad rating system

Pro: Great variety of programs available to foster growth and development, for those looking to start a career. 401k match is above par and profit sharing is phenomenal!
Con: Company culture is very strong here, the ability to play nice and your connections will take you places. Work/Life balance, isn't. It's work work work...

Summary: "Anonymous is a leading company in the financial service industry."
Pro: Great benefits and superior compensation.
Con: Anonymous is too political to retain the really high performers.

Summary: "Not a place to work Long Term"
Pro: Its a great stepping stone in your career, they do have a flexible work environment depending on where you work, Boston is hectic and down sizing all the time whereas North Carolina folks are more laid back and slow. Ample parking space in North Carolina
Con: Very little professional growth if you towards the bottom of the totem pole, very high turnover rate and employees are constantly playing musical chairs with regards to cube assignments or reorg in the company. Some professionals are given too much power and run the place like total dictatorship. Would never want to work here again nor would I want to invest my savings with this firm. Loyalty, reliability and professionalism has no value here.

Pro: I would say that the best part of working at Anonymous are the benefits and the culture. The benefits are unmatched for New Hampshire (I would imagine the same for Florida, Kentucky, Ohio, Colorado and Utah but I'm not 100% certain). The culture is awesome. Lots of positive people and I've definitely gotten my share of great managers that like to promote within. I believe that management culture does trickle down and inspire new and up-and-coming managers. Being positive at this company will certainly get your far. I tend to be a naturally positive person who is extremely driven. That speaks volumes.
Con: It's stressful at times. The pay could be a little better, but it's not horrible by any means. I still feel like upper management is slightly disconnected to what we have to do vs. industry standards vs. their expectations. Lastly, we have an internal feedback board we can utilize to provide customer as well as coworker feedback, however the time frames from when the research of a project starts to when it completes can be well over 1 year. For a multi-billion dollar company, I'm not sure if that is truly acceptable.

Pro:
Stable.

Good Work-Life Balance

world-class 401k and profit sharing program
Con:
Lack of clear vision

Too Conservative

Raise does not relate enough to performance

Pro: Is a great company to work for will help you get your security license and teach you good sales skills.  Opportunity to move up if you are willing to look for it and flexible to move. Also the benefits are excellent,
Con: The salary is less than you might find in similar positions and apart of the variable compensation is up to the  managers.  You also have to wait five years to be vested in the 401k.

Pro: Great colleagues and work and environment.
Con: I can't think of any cons at all.  It is a great place to work.

Pro: Benefits, Executive Leadership, Johnson Family
Con: Some pockets of very heavy management waste

Summary: "Great Company to work for. Beautiful campus in Westlake TX"
Pro: Great benefits, wide array of growth opportunities, excellent management and leadership, offers a good employee welfare package: bonus, profit sharing, tuition reimbursement, etc. The work environment is very serene and beautiful.
Con: Basic compensation can be improved upon.

Summary: "Anonymous Investments is a really great place to work!"
Pro: The people are very nice and supportive, especially my manager. I had a recent death in my family, and everyone was beyond supportive, which meant a lot. You may expect an investment company to be stuffy and old school, but Anonymous is quite the opposite! The perks and benefits are great, as well as the pay.
Con: Coming from a creative background (art and theater), being in a very corporate environment can be sometimes challenging for a right brained person.

Summary: "Merrimack Call Center: Worst job I've ever had!"
Pro: Nothing, unless you're a masochist.
Con:
Big Brother is watching EVERYTHING you do.  All phone calls and all computer use is recorded, timed, measured -  Anything you say or do can and will be used against you.  Metrics for everything and anything - Did you leave for break on time? (doesn't matter if you're on a call with a client);  How many and how long were your bathroom breaks?;  Constant coaching of what you said on calls with clients.  If you're not perfect, you don't get a raise.

They want drones, not humans, you're expected to say the exact same script every single time, no matter what.  They should just have employees monitoring calls from clients and push "Button #27" for the script for that question, "Button #92" for script for this question...  As soon as you hang up from one call, the next call is coming in, virtually non-stop the whole shift.  I'd be surprised if they don't run out of people in the area soon to fill those jobs - they've burned out so many and/or fired so many for miniscule infractions of their rules.  Doesn't matter how many 'Kudos' you got from clients that were happy with your assistance.

Summary: "For the Cincinnati area, it's not a bad place to be"
Pro:
The people you work with are great. All focused on the customer.

Nice regional campus.

You can build career there without moving.

Invests in the people and technology.

Decent benefits.

Supportive of development of the people.
Con:
Hit or miss with SVPs. Some are great (visionary, smart, approachable, open, advocates, fair). Others will do what they can to take care of themselves at the cost of others.   The HR rules to not apply to that level and there are known issues that are kind of ignored.  They are hired for driving to metrics and not the ability to manage, lead or inspire. Just do your homework to determine if the leadership of the function will align to what is important to you.



Also understand the bonus opportunity and how it is structured.  Your bonus percent is always immediately reduced by the funding level (fund at 85% for example)  and then you get  a percentage of your bonus eligible amount depending on performance. .85 (funded level)  X .85 (decent bonus based on performance) X.40 (eligible amount) = 28.9% is really what your 40% "bonus opportunity" turns out to be. And that is for a solid performer. Just be fully informed as  you negotiate your salary.  80/20 rule applies here -Only 20% get the top bonus which means you actually get the "opportunity" tied to your grade level. Don't get me wrong here - is 28% a nice bonus? Yes. Is it far away from 40%? Yes.  What is supposed to be motivating you to perform well just becomes exhausting.

Summary: "Good Work Life Balance, decent salary but cheap politics"
Pro: Good Work Life Balance, decent salary, professional environment
Con: promotions, Cheap politics, less trainings,

Summary: "Good working experience but good for experience people(such as senior ..) or management roles"
Pro: Flexibility, work-life balance, work from home, follow very strictly company values and ethics
Con: slow growth, not much career options, performance review is not depend upon on skill , this is not a company to start your career.

Summary: "Financial Representative aka "this is not a sales job but it sure as heck is""
Pro: There are many positive aspects of working as a financial rep at Anonymous Investments. Even though it is a call center job with stringent metrics and every move and word measured and recorded, it's not horrible. The pay is above average and so are the benefits. The standards are transparent. Not the easiest to meet but no smoke and mirrors except in one respect. When I was hired I was told that this is not a sales job. I was told that is customer service. Told the same thing in training. The truth is different.
Con: After about a month or two on the floor there began to be a lot of pressure to discuss about people increasing their contributions and trying to get them to speak to licensed representatives. We the "guidance" as a plan benefit that is a feature that doesn't cost anything but we're really selling the additional Portfolio Advisory Services that costs additional. Regardless of whether it is a good plan, and I do believe it is, I still feel it is misleading I also feel misled about what I signed on for when accepting the position. I said in the phone interview and in person interview that I did not want a sales job.

Summary: "Decent first job out of college but do your research on what career path you would like to take."
Pro: Great people to work with. You go through extensive, thorough training with people you will get to know very well with great facilitators leading your class. Great benefits such as 401(k), medical, dental, life insurance etc. You may also attain a number of professional licenses in the financial industry depending on your position. Good opportunity for advancement if you are the type of person that can handle taking calls.
Con: If you work in one of the call centers, the work can become repetitive. You have to adhere to rather tight schedule requirements such as 15 minute breaks and 2-3 hours at a time taking inbound calls. Also, you are evaluated on criteria such as how many calls you take in a certain time frame and how long the conversations take you to complete. If you like speaking with people over the phone, however, you may enjoy it.

Pro: Family owned business that places customers first. Encourages a values and ethics based corporate culture
Con: The big size of the firm causes silos in certain departments / businvess units, resulting in poor management styles and non-meritocratic environment. Career advancement becomes difficult as one progresses up the ladder.

Pro: Great training, generous benefits, caring managers and training facilitators.
Con: Low salary, micromanagement, not much room to grow.

Pro: Smart, driven employees. Everything isn't governed by quarterly earnings like most investment firms. Leader in almost every space it operates in. Lots of opportunities to move laterally, explore other career paths. Multi-year phantom stock grants create super sticky employees. Great internal training and development programs.
Con: Competition can be cut-throat at times, advancement (in responsibility and earning power) can feel overly orchestrated and prolonged. Longevity of some employees can create inertia within middle management.

Pro: Good benefits.  Flexible work hours and ability to telecommute.
Con: Constantly watching my back.  When something goes wrong there's a lot of finger pointing.  It all about who you know and how well you cover/kiss butt.  BEWARE of the "Judgement" meeting.

Summary: "A great organizational with a lot of great managers."
Pro: Competitiveness, best practices, learnings, good salary and good managers
Con: In depth case study by leadership should be done for cases dropping ranks from 1 to 5.

Pro: Company values and leadership makes the best place to work. Huge online training resources makes the employee motivated and to update the skills on regular basis.
Con: Need patience to catch next level

Summary: "Great pay/benefits and work/life balance, poor everything else"
Pro:
Pays well, and benefits are best I have ever seen or heard of since.  10+ hours of overtime were offered almost every week, optional if you wanted to make more money.  Flexible schedule ranging from 7a-midnight, also 4x10's available where you work 4 days a week for 10 hours each day.  2 weeks vacation, might have had 3-6 months waiting period for it, I don't recall. 



You are taking phone calls and there is a call model to follow but it merely guides the flow of the conversation, it does not generally have things you must say word for word, therefore you don't sound and feel like a robot despite the extreme repetitiveness of taking phone calls.  



Looks great on a resume, and is a foot in the door for the finance industry.
Con:
Disorganized between departments, as well as possible and probable deliberate deception of employees, dangling the carrot so to speak.  And as most places have, occasional incompetent managers.



This specific role was all inbound phone calls which were randomly graded by customers and managers.  Managers who graded your calls were inconsistent with each other, one would give you high marks for a chosen course of action while another would mark low and suggest an alternate route.  Or there was the occasional manager who would mark lower than average scores across the board compared to other managers.



Myself and a few others were selected to get our series 6 & 7's and moved to a different division of WPI (workplace investing, you deal with 401k's and similar accounts) where we made a new team with a new manager.  One week later we are all told there was an error in planning, and nobody in our newly found division would be getting licensed.  However, the division we left would all be getting licensed.  When I asked, I was told I could not be moved back to my old team, or join the training and stay in my new role.  A few months later our new division was told we would all be getting licensed as well, only to be told a week later, again, that we would not be getting licensed.  



You are always expected to probe for outside assets that could be brought to Anonymous.  If there are assets which can be brought it, after finding them you must transfer the call to a specialist who makes money based on how much he brings in.  The numbers you bring in to this department, as well as what actually comes into the company from these leads are tracked by Anonymous, and unable to be viewed by yourself.  Management says it doesn't matter what you bring in because it's not your job, but again, these numbers are tracked and managers have access to them, keeping them high will most likely open new doors despite what is said.



Corporate culture seems that Anonymous wants cheerleaders more than employees.  Make the customers believe we're great and you will be too if you give us your money.  I came here to help people, and I was naive.  It is all about getting more money in the door.  But if you can make a lot of money working for Anonymous, and have relatively good job security.

Summary: "Extremely disappointed at every level in every possible way."
Pro: Read the "CONS" and "Advice to Management" shown below. I have nothing positive to say about this place. I give it LESS than one Star.
Con: VERY POOR performance evaluation structure. Often times the best, most reliable, and hard working employees are left behind while the YOUNG with "beautiful smiles and fake loud voices" continue to advance. EXTREMELY political and extremely poor management throughout many business units.

Pro: Nice to finally work for an investment company that is private.  Clients first, not shareholders. Thank you Johnson family!
Con: Work life balance  is not competitive with other like-compensated options.  My SF Bay Comp is mirrored to those in lower cost-of-living parts of the country.

There is an issues for the people heired at managers level or technical consultant level..These people are hired just to assure UK people that we will be deliveirng the propject under new hires however they make sure the new hires are made scape goats and projects under them are failed by some game plan.

This is done to safeguard exsisitng managers jobs..their is a stiff competion at BP-20 level (intenal level) and to safe guard old employe this is done..

It was done with me  and I understood the issue ..but the senior management after hearing the issue threatened me to resgin from the company..

Con: The promotion opportunities are not direct, they promote more of a 'lattice' structure. Best advice is to be involved in projects, extra tasks, etc. this opened several more doors and expedited my career with Anonymous.  Some of the leadership is quite weak and the politics can outweigh the actual business at times, unfortunately.

Pro: Great co-workers, everyone is willing to help one another, talking with clients on the phone they're always willing to get you the information you need.
Con: Can be very stressful. Calls have been growing as numbers have been decreasing in the CSA role.
