Summary: "Excellent benefits, decent compensation, responsible for own career."
Pro: Retirement benefits are unparalleled, paid time off from day one, fantastic training, beautiful campus and facilities, wonderful co-workers, own your own development, great place to gain experience and start a career, great team atmosphere, weekends and all holidays off are a definite plus.
Con: Hard to get help on career advancement in such a big company, unrealistic sales goals, slow to adopt new technology, high turnover, almost impossible to get ideas implemented, annual merit raises not in line with costs of living increasing, management has so many of their own projects that it is difficult to get guidance, hard work not always recognized.

Pro: Anonymous, Gurgaon is a step sister of Anonymous USA (FMR). Being a multinational company, you can see big name. Anonymous has many names, but if it comes to Anonymous Gurgaon, Cyber park office, than think it’s the one we are taking about.
Con:
No work life balance. Almost all weekends are working. They say that you can take comp-off. But when you ask leave, they talk about the work load and deadlines. 

Long working hours. Though you leave home on time, you have to carry lot of work with you to complete from home.

Managers openly threaten you for sacking.

Very high iteration ratio. Almost every MONTH, good %  of staff are said to leave (including contractors) which is way beyond our imagination. Here when I say contractors, it does not mean that their contract is over & then said to leave. They are forcefully said to leave. 

Higher management are very rude towards employees. 

Employee has more work pressure than contractors. Managers blame employees if something is not going good even though contractors are working on that subject.

Few departments are even worse like TIS(infrastructure), retail, web etc.

* HR  department is out of touch with many employees.  They live in a different world and unapproachable

Con: Promotions is not much frequent. Work-life balance totally depends upon the team for which you work .

Pro: Extremely well managed. The training I received was by far the best I received in any corporation I've worked in. There were constant opportunities to add more training. Once you've been in a position for at least six months you can apply to transfer departments or advancement.The process was easy. Management was generally hired from within.
Con: Even small infractions of company policy or procedures were a permanent part of your employee record. Even these minor things came up in my department transfer interview. In spite of this I was still successful. During a training week I was given a written warning about using foul language. I never had. That was someone else, but I was written up despite the fact it wasn't me. There was no process for defending oneself when accused.

Pro: Good pay and good co workers.
Con: I was hired to help start futures for retail customers as a Compliance Director and was relocated from Buffalo Grove, IL. to Providence, RI. After 18 months Anonymous decided not to  go forward with futures for retail customers and was laid off. Prior to accepting the position I asked HR and the senior managers that I interviewed with if there was any chance that starting futures would fall through. They said that was impossible.I jokingly said I don't want to live in a teepee with my son. I left a good position at Prudential, sold my home and moved for what amounted to the biggest mistake of my life.

Pro: Learning culture is the best part
Con: Captive and resulting natural limitations

Pro: Stability. You have a steady paycheck. Good benefits and 401k. Opportunity to make a lot of extra money on overtime if you're willing.
Con: You literally do the same job over and over and over. It is a glorified white collar sweatshop. If you want to advance, you can.

Pro: Worked 8 years. Great benefits, time off & 401k.  Great training.  "Advocates" healthy work life balance. "Promotes" integrity. "Promotes" a great culture.  The people are great and, even at the phone sites, you do get the general feeling there is a consistent strive for a happy, healthy workplace from the CEO & other corporate executives. You're always aware of the direction of the company.
Con:
I loved working for this company, just not the management in charge of the phone sites. 



Overall, poor support of all the main themes they advocate: work life balance, integrity, culture.   The process that managers are required to maintain a working relationship with their employees doesn't apply with upper management.  They put out fires and congregate only when corp executives are paying attention.  Huge inconsistencies in OT needs vs. life balance, actual job role vs. what you're responsible for, company processes vs. actual process.  



* A lot of managers confused, uncomfortable, and/or constantly feel their job is at risk.   



* The allowed leniency within each business unit makes for huge discrepancies. 



* A lot of complaints from employees and management that there's a clear disregard to promote people who are actually qualified.



* Compensation was below average locally and nationally across multiple roles.  Team that up with OT + added responsibilities + inconsistent processes + mixed communications and you get high stress for less than average.



** It has a lot of the typical political messes a job like this brings.  Advancement is possible, but, similar to most companies, you must be liked by the right people.  Compensation is comparable if you're one of the top 15% who are selected for one of their prestigious sales roles.



** A lot of peers or co-workers outside of the phone sites are relatively more satisfied with the company overall.  So, aim for a corporate role or one outside the phone sites is my recommendation if considering this company.

Pro: Great company with many befits, however you start off in a sales position.
Con: There was a lack of information coming from management, which made it hard to do my job. The recruiter that recruited me was as pleasant as can be, but thats where it ended.

Pro: The Benefits are good, that is after all a major product offered by the company. This is a respectable company and a leader in the industry.
Con: Work life balance is non existent in the support software support role. The office culture is fairly hostile to change or improvments. Constructive critisism is a foreign concept, conform or be ostracized is the unfortunate successful path. The job role, responsabilties continually expand while the workforce shrinks.

Pro: Good Salary and other benifits
Con: Avg Career growth and limited opportinuties

Pro: Good hours and good people
Con: Poor pay and awful CEO

Pro: Great Benefits, Employee friendly, but sometimes overkill with thousands of policies.You many not get monetary benefits, but they may give you back as 401K. Good employer contribution on 401K. Profit Sharing Plan is very attractive.
Con: Techonology wise little behind in adapting. Very strong policy oriented company. Work culture is actually not bad.

Summary: "A culture of punishment and political posturing"
Pro: Good Benefits.  The work-life balance was good for most parts of the company.  Occasional extra hours for special projects.
Con: At the Ireland operation, upper management actively sought to destroy people's careers with lies and malice.  They were in collusion with HR, so employees had no redress.

Pro: Great energy, environment and benefits.
Con: Pay could be better for the level of discussion we have with clients.

Pro: Great office culture, training, and work/life balance
Con: Compensation was on the lower part of the industry, however, the benefits almost offset it.

Summary: "It was a great atmosphere and great colleages that wanted to get better each day."
Pro: A lot of training and upward movement in the company.
Con: Lunch is only 30 mins long, so it feels that you get no break at all.

Pro: can work here for decades with satisfaction from all angles.
Con: nothing, life goes on and on.

Summary: "Great Company to work for long term"
Pro: Job Security, Great benefits! Good training and support, fast advancement if work hard
Con: Average Pay, but have opportunity to increase after time. Base plus bonuses/commissions

Pro: Internship, very relaxed, with a few presentations. They let you have a lot of free time and you could really do any sorts of research you wanted to. A few easy, informative tasks and the ability to shadow financial advisors. There were 6 other interns, and we did some equity competitions as well as some bookkeeping for advisers. Many lunches were paid for and the interns were invited to alot of activities not in the workplace, which was really neat. the CAMPUS is GREAT
Con: None. I wish we got to see different positions and move around a little more but all in all it was a great opportunity and I really encourage everyone to consider Anonymous.

Pro: Long-term perspective, high quality employees, opportunities to grow
Con: Employees feeling of stability can be mercurial due to market/economic ties

Pro: employee safety, data security and work from home facility
Con: compensation is good , no issues faced

Summary: "Nice experience but too much of politics"
Pro:
Free ac cabs

Free lunch and diner
Con:
A lot of politics 

Very old technologies being used 

Not so welcoming company environment

Summary: "Extremely diverse and challenging company to work for - Anonymous invests in their employees career with the firm."
Pro: Anonymous places a great deal of emphasis on taking care of employees - from the on-site facilities, to health benefits, compensation packages, retirement, promotion of personal development, etc.  They are the most employer centric companies I've every worked for.
Con: Depending on department or your work background, it can sometimes be difficult to move between jobs.  Also, at times the work/life balance can be lacking.

Pro: Unpredictable and unstable environment where vision is hard to believe given how often budget changes.
Con: Cronyism is dominant culture.  Lots of politics and fear.

Summary: "Good benefits and compensation; sweatshop environment; they own you"
Pro: Excellent compensation, benefits and bonus.
Con: Company has you tethered 24/7 with remote and mobile access technology; highly political environment; tough to get ahead; co-workers compete with one another; company only values highly aggressive associates without regard to whether they are of good character; people always looking over their shoulder in fear of losing their well-paying positions; not a team-oriented environment and not for the faint of heart! 40-hour workweek uncommon. High burnout employer.

Summary: "People and organization are great job is monotonous."
Pro: There are great benefits and a lot of really nice people, training programs are excellent.  Because there are so many locations around the country if you are willing to relocate there is a lot of opportunity out there.
Con: Call volume is too much, there is no way to enjoy your job when there aren't enough employees to handle the call volume.  They are understaffed and no one wants to be in the entry level position.

Pro: Benefits are hard to beat. The culture is results-driven and pretty laid back. Very easy to move around once you're in the company.
Con: Promotions can be pretty rigid, which gets frustrating. Some poeple get promoted without doing anything just because they've been there for a while.

Pro:
If you're married with kids and a house, and you want to go home at 4:45PM every day, Anonymous is for you. I've never worked less anywhere else. When I've had visitors in on a Friday in the summer, and only 6 of 30 team members are in, they ask "where is everyone" and I have to explain that this is normal. Largely "Working From Home" is used more than it should.



As far as ambitions go, Abby and Ned own the company. What they want goes. As such, you can expect fiats from on high and many people and divisions shuffling along, getting by. This is not a terrible thing, but you'll not find floors of teams rushing to "get it done" and invent the "next great thing" despite the corporate newsletters the champion such internal trends. Rather you'll find bureaucracy, process, and more process taking weeks to do something as simple as write a single line query. One fiat was all applications moving to Linux servers from Window servers. Why? Ned had met Bill Gates at a conference and decided he didn't like him, so we needed to get rid of Windows.



Pay is slightly below market, but health benefits are good ($140 for top health plan), bonuses not bad, and the hours are great. Good training budget. OK vacation policy (15 days). Nice facilities.
Con:
Big Warning: Anonymous is divesting in Boston and New England. They are moving all the jobs they can to Raleigh (NC), Westlake (TX), Ireland, China and India. Every year more Boston teams get sacked and given the "chance" to move 2000mi or more, though usually only 10% take the offer. Be careful if you're not deeply entrenched in the front office, your days are likely numbered.



Everyone keeps to themselves. Passing people in the hall, they stare at the floor. In the elevators you could hear a pin drop. Folks are not outgoing and I've seen many teams that sit 10 yards apart and don't know each other at all. This helps breed the internal silos and technical fiefdoms. If you behave gregariously, people will be surprised.



Anonymous IT loves to talk about Agile, but we actually use FAM, the Anonymous Agile Methodology. During your interview, ask deep questions about how so called "Agile" teams work and you'll be in for a laugh. FAM is a broken application of Agile and little better than classic waterfall. If you've really learned Agile elsewhere, people are going to laugh at you your first few weeks here.



If you're looking to grow rapidly in tech, look beyond Anonymous. Our systems are laughably behind the times, though our "architectural conferences" will swear they're cutting edge (i.e. IE8 anyone, Java 6, Tomcat 5?).

Summary: "Great company but no loyalty to their good employees"
Pro: Great pay, benefits, bonuses, PTO.  Great opportunities exist if you're the right kind of people and you can avoid the RIFs.
Con:
Training is pretty much non-existent - it's sink-or-swim when you're thrown onto a project.  



We're told it's easy to move around and try new things within Anonymous to progress in our careers.  I never found this to be true.  When I applied to jobs within the xxx division, I was told by the internal recruiters that the hiring manager was looking for candidates who had xxx division experience.  It didn't matter that I had over 10 years of valuable experience in Anonymous with plenty of other transferable skills.  How is someone supposed to get the xxx experience if you're not given the opportunity?  



Way too many re-orgs and RIFs with the loss of really good people. This leaves others to pick up their work when employees are already overloaded with their own work.   



Frequent changes in  managers leads to inconsistent annual reviews and constantly changing goals. It's difficult to know what one has to do to get promoted.

Pro: Anonymous's strength in its core markets, powerful long-term networks within the company, opportunities to change roles within the firm
Con: Veteran networks can sometimes inhibit change, be protective of their own interests

Pro: Great work/life balance.  Great co-workers.  There are moments where you can learn a lot, and working in a global organization has great benefits.  Bonuses are really good, along with profit sharing.  Shares are harder to come by, which is a shame.
Con: Very political organization.  The leadership of the technology organization is more concerned about their own personal gain instead of actual technology, and make decisions at the expense of actual development.  Too many roles, hard to get anything done in a reasonable amount of time.

Pro: The benefits package is really good and there are many opportunities to advance internally.
Con: There is no clear career path to advancement, especially management.

Pro: Lots of help throughout training...great place to start out.
Con: Base pay to start out is not great..once you get through the first year it gets better!

Pro: Great managers who will help you achieve your goal. Amazing perks and benefits.
Con: Large firm that it's hard to stand out.

Pro: Everyone is there to help you learn
Con: Management may not be the brightest individuals

Summary: "Great place to start, struggling to compete in the new world of investing"
Pro:
Great benefits for all employees.

401k match among best in the industry

Set schedule for phone reps

Overtime availability if desired
Con:
Bureaucracy at it's finest.  Nothing ever gets done without 150 groups needing to okay it.  

Extremely difficult to move from phone jobs to elsewhere, regardless of qualification.

Pro: Very helpful, genuine staff. Really go out of their way to teach interns.
Con: I did not find anything negative about my internship

Pro: Good resources, staff, infrastructure to perform job at a high level
Con: Limited growth and career development. Avg pay

Pro: Great benefits and a very team-oriented setting.
Con: Advancement opportunities usually only for employees who have been around for a long time, which is very discouraging for new people looking to make a career.

Pro: Privately owned company, offers a great benefits package, great online resources for self improvement, overall a great company to work for.
Con: Traditional management methods with chain of authority style and often it is challenging to get in touch with senior management to provide feedback.

Pro: Lot of opportunities to grow,  good benefit
Con: Could be relocated away from Boston

Pro:
Fair work environment.

Average pay structure.

Flexible work environment.

Highly matrixed organization.
Con:
Highly dependent on US for direction.

Excessive time spent on co-ordination.

Highly secure environment, to the level that it can be restrictive for innovation.

Summary: "Growth opportunities consistent of lateral movement only, not much else"
Pro: If you like working OT it is pretty much unlimited, especially during tax season
Con: Not much opportunity for growth beyond lateral changes within the company. With turnover so high, you feel like just a number.  You are very expendable and interchangeable for the next rep. The company is always understaffed so there are nearly always calls holding waiting for you to answer.

Summary: "Great place to start your career in finance."
Pro: Great work/life balance and core values to the company.
Con: Not a lot of thinking outside the norm. Feedback tends to get lost in the either.

Pro: Great place to start in industry, pay for all your licenses. Team environment. Lots of support to develop as much as u want.
Con: Politics when it comes to advancement.

Pro: Innovative, strategic, friendly, Great values
Con: Top heavy, bureaucratic, Old boys club at the top,

Pro: You get great benefits - everything from health insurance, disability, to shopping discounts. It pays rather well considering that you don't need much experience beyond customer service to get hired here. Anonymous also embraces diversity and community service.
Con:
This company has an uncomfortably cult like environment. Everyone has to put on an air of completely loving Anonymous and loving their job like they are brainwashed robots; if you don't play along, you will have problems. If you want to reveal your true feelings about the job, or you have something remotely negative to say, think carefully about who to confide in. It's actually pretty vital to be over the top pro-Anonymous if you want any chance of transferring around or getting a promotion one day. However, plenty of people still don't get to move around or get the promotions that they deserve because they don't act brainwashed enough and/or they're so good that they are kept trapped in the call center forever. Some managers have all but lost their call center skills and they basically serve as cheerleader coaches. They might "coach" you on what to say, but rarely will get on the phone themselves and have lost touch with what the job entails.



In the call center you are micro-managed severely. Co-workers and managers will sit down with you and pick apart your calls word for word. You'll be invited to pick apart other calls as well. Every second on the job is recorded and timed. If your call extends into your lunch break or you have to take an extra bathroom break, you'll be out of adherence which you will be reprimanded for and which will affect your next bonus. Your bonus is completely up to your manager's discretion, by the way, which has quite a few implications. Your team will compete with other teams to have the best stats and you will receive judgment for yours, even though most of it seems nonsensical and/or out of your control.



Orientation frames the job as pretty great. You have a blast with your new co-workers and are spoiled with fun activities and long lunches. But once you are out on the floor and the novelty has worn off, you see the job is more about statistics than anything else. Customer service is heavily emphasized in conversation, yet all that really counts is call lengths, schedule adherence, how much your manager likes you, being fanatically pro-Anonymous, and being subjected to constant and excessive micro-managing and taking it all with a smile and nod. 



It's hard not to even have the support of your co-workers. The gossiping is incredible. For some, this place is really their life's career and they will never leave, so you must be careful about what you say about the company and you have to navigate the strange drama of people who have worked there for years. There are also so many people in the call center that you will regularly have other people's mistakes dumped on to you via a livid customer and/or will find that co-workers don't care to take a transfer or help you during a difficult call. Burnout here tends to make people curt and apathetic toward each other, which is no fun when you have a customer on the line and a manager who's constantly looking to find fault in your actions. I constantly felt stranded. 



I should mention that the job itself of answering calls is not easy. In short, there is an entire book behind every retirement plan. You have customers throwing all sorts of crazy and complex questions at you while you have to stall for time while browsing an extensive encyclopedia of information. You will find that your resources are incomplete, confusing, way too elaborate, and/or misleading on a regular basis, which renders a lot of stressful and difficult calls. Have I mentioned all the abuse you have to swallow from customers? They are way worse than customers face-to-face. Some days you feel like you are being attacked on all sides. 



Although everyone has to act like Anonymous is utterly amazing, give it enough time and you'll see what's really going on - the nonsensical promotions, people becoming trapped in the call center - denied every opportunity to take a new position, and unable to leave the company because they have no transferable skills - people's relief to get off the phones whenever allowed, the apathy, etc. it's depressing. It's the unhappiest work environment for a customer service job because you have to act completely fake all the time with everyone you work with and every single thing you say and do is watched and usually ripped apart by co-workers and managers. I had a lot of awful days on this job and was so happy to get ou. 



I guess this place is okay if you have no other options and/or you like being micro-managed in a corporate cult. Otherwise steer clear.

Summary: "Anonymous Investments is a great place to grow a career."
Pro: Anonymous Investments is the ideal place to begin a career. The top-down leadership approach creates a culture of trust, transparency, friendly competitiveness and excellence. All levels of leaders invest countless hours in the development of their employees and the support provided to enhance your career is second to none. The company's values are visible in everything they do. It feels amazing to work for a company that sets clear direction, empowers employees to excel and then recognize and reward those who achieve.
Con: The sheer size of the company can seem overwhelming, but this is easily overcome by having such great leaders in place to provide guidance to their employees.

Pro: Challenging environment, good benefits, great technology, always changing
Con: Lots of distributed technology teams offshore causes challenging time schedules if you want a good work/life balance.  Risk of New England based positions being moved is constant - but what is the benefit?

Pro: Company has great values and really seems to care about both their employees and customers. Good benefits including health and dental plus tons of others stuff like fitness, computer, tuition reimbursement; adoption assistance; etc. Spend a lot on training employees and focus on positive feedback as opposed to criticism.
Con: Bonuses are pretty good but their is room for improvement in the bonus structure.

Pro: Great learning and growth opportunities
Con: Busy schedule. Work life management is hard

Summary: "Good company if you like financial planning."
Pro: Great benefits, good pay considering you don't have to go out and get your own clients.
Con: Too political. Easy to be pigeonholed into something specific.

Pro: Decent, but expensive medical benefits, 20% computer purchase reimbursement, $250 annual fitness reimbursement, 7% company 401k match. Profit sharing.
Con: Pay below industry standard. They like to tell you that you are lucky that they hired you. Wear a short skirt, you can go far, or at least get paid for not working. If you make your CEI (Customer Experience Index) goals and lead goals, they raqise them so that you can't consistenly meet your goals so they don't have to pay you all of your bonus. Treated like your contribution is miniscule. This is a terrible place to work. Strange how so many young people are at Westlake. No one stays for very long. So many people just walk off the job, but they tell the new hires that "we're growing, that is why we're hiring". HA !

Pro: The people are amazing and company cares about progression.
Con: Internal moves may not be benefical to salary.

Pro: I heard many times that it all depended on which site you are located. However, in Boston there was a fantastic culture with huge support for career development from senior leaders. Lots of opportunity for growth if you put the work into it.
Con: Demanding workload, not much work/life balance

Summary: "your entire work life depends on how your manager is"
Pro:
-good environment

-transport facility

-great personal security
Con:
-horrible and self centered and technically incompetent managers who always try to take credit

-increment is very less compared to market standards

-not too many opportunities to learn when you try to look for long term future.

Summary: "Great company, great benefits. Willing to work with individuals to better their career."
Pro: Great benefits. Good career paths.
Con: Some middle management has little experience.

Pro:
Great benefits

Green Offices

Best health coverage for your money
Con:
No vision plan (for a job where you stare at a PC all day)

Excessive turnover

Management really does not listen to anyone but their closed circle of people

Egotistical Trainers

Low Wages

Manipulating statistics to make metrics

Lying to associates

Training is not as good as represented.

Trash talking associates who did not make the cut

Who fires their associates when they are driving their cars home?

Pro: The pay and benefits are above average.  Privately owned.
Con: Vertically Integrated and siloed.  Lots of ritual and tradition, vs. common sense.

Summary: "A great place for young college graduates to build a career"
Pro: The facility is very nice and the people are very nice, friendly and supportive.  The training is good and you get a lot of support.  Management encourages feedback and evaluation of everything.  Anonymous promotes from within.  If you are a young person just starting out in a new career, it is an excellent place to get started and move up.  They like to train people into their own culture and reward those who comply.  When you apply for other opportunities, they give you feedback if you are not chosen.   The benefits package is good.  Even though this is a call center environment and it can be busy, it is a pleasant place to be and I have never felt overly micro-managed.  The callers are usually nice and pleasant and management encourages helping the customer no matter how long it takes.  Customers routinely tell us how they appreciate the service they get.  There are often potlucks and employee appreciation events and fun things going on.
Con: The facility is in a somewhat remote location and is a long drive.  If you are an experienced person, unfortunately opportunities to move up seem to be more limited.  The company tends to prefer training inexperienced people instead of promoting people who have experience from elsewhere.  The recruiters will promise you career opportunities, but there are some interesting politics involved in getting the other opportunities that they do not tell you about.  There are a lot of very young managers who started out with the company, but who do not have a lot of management experience.  While everyone is very nice and friendly, sometimes they seem to be intimidated by older, more experienced staff and look for ways to deny opportunities instead of trying to fit people in where they are most qualified.

Pro: great name to have on the resume.
Con: there's limited upward mobility at this company.

Pro:
Compensation and benefits are good when you enter, increasing that remuneration is a different story.

Feels good when you leave.
Con:
Some middle management simply refuse to help people move forward with their career, both in work experience and career level - mostly because their own careers are at a dead end. A lot of talented people being kept low because of this.

Seems like a retirement home for anyone working in technology given how laid back it is and if you're anyway talented it's best you look elsewhere so that you don't get left behind in the industry.

People being promoted due to being incapable of performing their current role.

Pro: Worklife balance is good.
Con: Top management is very stable and breaking into the top management is really tough.

Summary: "Challenging and rewarding with many opportunities for self-starters to advance and develop."
Pro: Highly motivated colleagues, culture of integrity, private ownership, commitment to long-term projects, entrepreneurial spirit, opportunities for advancement and movement among many office locations, very supportive of education within and outside the company, positive involvement in community activities,  industry leader and innovator.
Con: Fast paced and demanding environment.

Summary: "used to be a better place to work"
Pro: Retirement benefits (401k, profit sharing) are strong.
Con: Too many managers / people in leadership positions because they are nice or play the game well rather than because they are effective.  Entirely too much focus on driving cost out that translates into non-existent or meaningless salary increases for employees.  Career opportunities shrinking and increasingly limited if you work in one of the New England sites.  Feels like endless reorgs.

Pro: Great pay and Flexable schedule. No cold calling.
Con: Once you have big book it can be difficult to manage existing clients while bringing in new clients.

Pro: Normal parameters of work are exceptional. Good facilities. Excellent communication with superiors. Great welfare
Con: Tight working hours. High targets which are motivational and help us achieve more as employees

Pro: Quality company overall, good benefits, vacation time, etc.  Great Christmas party, onsite gym.
Con: Variable compensation is more and more dependent on manager assessment with a focus on irrelevant things like number of calls more than 4 min long.  Can end up with poorly qualified managers.  For sales positions, your base pay will never get a COLA bump.  Seems like the comp plan changes every six months....and beware of the "it's comp neutral and you have a chance to make more money" song and dance from management.

Pro: good work team quite fast-paced
Con: less interactions sometimes overtime a lot

Summary: "Fine job if you can handle being in the phones all day"
Pro: Good advancement opportunities. Good training. They pay for series 7 licensing and study time.
Con: On the phone all day. I couldn't handle it.

Pro: Anonymous is a great place to work
Con: There is nothing i want to complain about

Pro: Good work life balance and good culture. Free transport.
Con: Still many products on obsolete technologies

Pro: Professional team, good compensation, good culture, grat firm
Con: At times not as fond of innovation as competitors.

Pro: Good experience to use on a resume, even though the job was absolutely horrible.
Con: If you want to work in a call center then this is the job for you! Mindless "diversified" managers who are absolutely clueless. They will say you are trained as a "trader" but you are only a client service rep working for crap money. They preach the "culture" and "what is possible". Well, the reality is the culture is corporately sickening and the fact that the ones who have a clue leave before the green Kool Aid totally zaps the life out of you. ISR managers are a joke. They call ISR a "sales job", but they are just phone jockeys who can only talk about target date funds. Good luck to any of you who get sucked into the rah rah! Get your experience and run away as fast as you can.

Summary: "A great company that focuses on hiring and training quality people."
Pro: An atmosphere that truly promotes personal development. I've never worked anywhere that cared so much about the services that they offer. I genuinely feel that everyone at Anonymous has the best interest of the customer in mind. Also, there is a lot of opportunity for growth.
Con: Entry level pay is low when compared to similar roles in the financial industry. The company can feel a little too big and that there is some disconnect between different functions.

Summary: "Sets you on the right path to success!"
Pro: Solid Training Program. Supportive Management from the start. Awesome benefits. Career advancements opportunities seem a plenty. Good work life balance with encouraging co-workers for the most part. Offer many different paths to the career goals you want to achieve!
Con: Communication of policies and expectations could be more clear. Leadership tends to play favorites at times which could work in your favor and not so much.

Summary: "Excellent place to plan a long term career"
Pro: Lots of different types of roles to work in; Supportive of internal movement; outstanding benefits - compounds greatly the longer you stay; Quality of associates; Management support for innovation; huge IT investment
Con: Lots of job movement to new sites.  If you are adverse to relocating, make sure you check on the LT prospects of your role.

Summary: "Great company to work for, but with call center setbacks"
Pro: Great benefits, pay is decent, and staff is great. They will sponsor you and ay you to study for the series 7 and 63.They have CFP programs if you want to go the sales route as an account executive.  Management actually really does care about employees, and listens to their suggestions and ideas. This is a baby call center opened in summer 2013.  There is good potential for promotion, however, only in client facing roles.  In other words, it is a call center.
Con: It is a call center and it is hard talking to people for eight hours a day about their finances.  Clients are often old and sometimes senile, often needing help online or setting up transactions. The work can be stressful.  It is busy year round and expect to take calls all day, with maybe the occasional meeting or coaching hour to break up the day.

Summary: "A very ethical company and generally a fair place to work in but a company that will no longer be a technology leader."
Pro:
Ethical: during all my long career in Anonymous I never meet anyone the would consider breaking laws, rules or regulations. In fact there was proactive approach to protecting customers. A great place to work if you have a good executive level manager. Benefits become very good the longer you stay with the company.

Genuine attempt to provide outstanding customer service.
Con:
Unfortunately upward management, confidence and spin rather than quality and quantity of work or good management skills is a very successful technique for promotion to the executive level. This results in some cynicism from smart observant lower level employees that see this happening. 

Strong movement away from being a technology leader to lower costs and operational excellence as a competitive advantage. So no longer an outstanding technology company to work in if you are a technologist.

The company is in a constant state of reorganization. This includes offshoring to India then China, downsizing, moving staff to new locations in the US. This creates huge waste and insecurity for many employees here and offshore.

Pro: Culture and people word word word
Con: some compensation measures word word

Pro: Tuition reimbursement, good profit sharing, 401k.
Con: Reliance on stats and metric in certain environments

Summary: "Great place to learn the business, but constant turnover of management hurts them."
Pro: Generous benefits including 401(k) profit sharing.  Many different positions to choose from.
Con: Too much turnover of management team.  Very often you are working for managers who have never done the job.  Sometime there are unrealistic expectations.  You find yourself wearing "too many hats" depending on your role.  Very compliance oriented.  Depending on your manager they will very likely not go to bat for you if an issue comes up.

Pro:
Very Good Working Environment

Good for Women Employee

A person who is looking for safer job security, this is the company
Con:
No matter your a MBA Graduate, they pay very less salary to freshers

No faster growth, there is no increase in ladder for years

To become Associate to Sr, Associate it takes 4 years

Pro: Flexibility, life-work balance, and benefits are great
Con: management, lack of promotions based on performance

Pro: Overall I think Anonymous is a great company, the fact that its privately own makes it more immune to market volatility and the year-end bonuses have been fairly consistent
Con:
The promotion process is a complete mystery and it appears to be highly political

Once you reach a certain level (director) within IT at least there are no annual market adjustments, so every year you are in theory making less money.  Plus there are no catch-up adjustments.

When applying to a job at the same level the policy is that you cannot get a salary increase, even if the job is vastly different and within a different business unit.  Which means overall you are stuck at your current salary unless you look outside the firm

Pro:

Summary: "Anonymous is downsizing Boston IT Jobs so be careful when looking here"

Summary: "Good for those looking for comfort over growth."
Pro: The environment is very comfortable. People are easy going and friendly. You get compensation for strtech hours in some departments.
Con:
Very slow growth.Management is biased and would prefer mostly those who they like over those who work well. Salary is very less and inadequate. Managers crib if you ask for leave. 

Don't expect a good hike in your salary even if you do exceptionally well.

Pro: Good health benefits for employees and families
Con: Poor management all your lunches are meetings

Pro: Outstanding career opportunities to match your ambition
Con: Challenging to break into management position

Pro: A steady paycheck. Some decent retirement benefits. Big whoop

Bonus points if you enjoy helping your company make billions of dollars but can go for years without a pay increase because you make "too close to the national average for your position." Yeah avoid Anonymous like the plague

Summary: "Decent company with small room for growth"
Pro: Some good people, management is decent,
Con: Not much opportunity for growth. Moving up in your position is difficult, very stingy with raises.

Pro: Good Reputation. Solid business history. Global reach.
Con: Constantly amazed/disappointed by the actions and behavior of the management and especially the GM for the branch. Compensation was extremely unsatisfactory for all but the select few of top managers. Work conditions were aggressively incompetent. (Although, I do think that my office was an isolated instance - other sites I worked with seemed to be much more organized)

Pro: Working for a private company is beneficial because most of the decisions by the company truly are for the benefit of the company and not shareholders
Con: You need to know how to network. A lot of the bonuses and ability to move up within the company depends on your ability to impress your manager.

Pro:
Good in CV, laidback company with little or no work

Decent wages and benefits

Lot of time for improving skill set for future job, if you stay low

Good place for people who can do "favours" to their manager (only way to grow)

Awesome place for people who have just "soft skills" but no or little actual skills
Con:
Totally incapable middle management (below VP level) especially in strategic data

Work place is polluted by ugly politics so very little air to breath

No recognition for talent or skill set

Performance is measured by opinions no other metrics

"Favours" and "favoritism" rules and thats the only way to grow in the company

Summary: "A great place to get your start"
Pro: Every branch environment is different, this is very evident in the DC area because there are branches in DC, 3 or 4 in VA, and 3 or 4 in Maryland and they each have different cultures. This is a great thing, but also plays a big part in branch metrics, promotions, and availability. I have learned a lot and met some really fantastic people! The benefits package is top-notch!
Con: Upward mobility is limited by the size and availability of the next job up within the branches. If one were to consider moving to another branch, or geographic location entirely, then the availability greatly increases. Onboarding is definitely not very great, they have an OTJ training mentality, which can be difficult in the DC area with "DC-type" clients.

Pro: Absolutely great company to work for and great atmosphere. Best retirement benefits and 401k in the industry. Great place to cut your teeth and learn. Tons of opportunity. If you enjoy investments it's a phenomenal place to learn.
Con: Awful and I mean absolutely awful lower management. Do not recognize talent whatsoever. Production means absolutely nothing. Initial management are the employees who couldn't make it in what they actually wanted to do or just wanted to be lazy. Upper management is extremely smart but lower management is very petty and very likely to be as young or younger than you when starting. Fight your way through it and it is very rewarding but it can burn you out initially. Just realize you will be above them soon.

Summary: "Great Company with wonderful benefits.  Hard to move about internally if you want off a phones position once hired."
Pro: Great Benefits and Professional environment.  They treat their employees well.
Con: Hard to move to different areas of the company as an internal transfer.  If you want to move off a phones position it is very hard to do.

Pro: They have a good benefits package including profit sharing and 401k match
Con: Their salary offering seems pretty low due to their "good" benefits package.

Summary: "Burn Out from Politics - Not from Call Center Work."
Pro: Health benefits are great, with different options/price levels to choose from. Great 401k/Profit Sharing. If you come in knowing little to nothing about finance - they are willing to train, if you are willing to put in the work. The sponsor & pay for licenses. If you are a personable person and like working with the public, you will enjoy the customer base for the most part. Their technology in the call center has come a long way since I first started, so those that might complain about it here with less than a year of service should consider themselves lucky. Finally, misery loves company - so you'll have some great camaraderie with your fellow employees!
Con:
I don't know about other call centers in the company - but in ours, they schedule overtime automatically into your schedule then you have to opt out by a specific time otherwise you're expected to work it. People on here keep calling the vacation time "PTO" but it's not truly. It's accrued vacation time, max of 4 weeks a year (depending on years of service), and it's use it or lose it (no carry over to next year). The NH call centers are "triple AAA" rated, meaning if there is a weather event or crisis in another center, we cover for them if they need to close, and if we have bad weather here - we're still open regardless. In the call center, you have to schedule your vacation time about a year in advance, but they do give you the option to change dates through the year. Vacation date availability is doled based on seniority in your "gate," but to be honest, this is really the most fair way to do it. Just don't expect to have any big holidays off in your first couple of years there is what I'm saying. 



There's little upward mobility. They have a Management Apprenticeship Program, but the people I've seen go into it aren't those that work their tails off - it's those that buddy up to their manager. When you come out of the program, you might go right back to your old position, until a manager position opens up - eventually. Also, on this vein - I started the company working a late second shift, but needed to change to a first shift for personal reasons. My manager at the time was resistant to have me move - not because we were shorthanded on the 2nd shift - he said 1st shift was reserved for those who "earned" it, and that it was a "reward." Now there are times when people are actually HIRED for 1st shift, so how is that a reward for those who are just hired? Nor am I a lackluster employee. 



As a rep over 6 years, I've probably had 10+ managers - and my position hasn't changed. So it's very hard to know what is expected of you, and to truly succeed. With having so many managers, any goals that I've set with previous managers have gotten lost and I've had to start from the bottom. If you want something for yourself, such as a new position, you better work for it, and work fast. Also, don't ever get comfortable at your cubicle, you will move. Alot. 



If you ever take a Leave of Absence, expect that when you come back, that the call center may have been reorg'd and your position as you knew it when you left is no longer available, and the new position that is taking over may not be offered to you. 



There are no COLA raises. 



Finally, if you ever have a problem with a manager, the burden of proof is entirely on you to prove you are being mistreated somehow. Management sticks with Management, and HR will listen but is more likely to provide "helpful" advice for conflict resolution than to step in, unless you're accusing them of a major infraction.

Summary: "Solid company with huge growth potential and wonderful benefits."
Pro: Benefits and pay are extremely competitive.  Solid training and leadership.  A very good culture with a ton of potential.
Con: The size of the company is a bit overwhelming, but overall a great organization.

Pro: Great co-workers, benefits, training, and great support overall
Con: The one thing I would say the company lacks is the discussion on career opportunities

Summary: "Good place to start, especially if you want to go into sales"
Pro: Great benefits, good work and life balance. They do a great job of training and helping employees get through their licensing tests. Lots of career advancement oppurtunities, especially if you're looking to go into sales.
Con: During the busy season (November to April) there is an ask that you work 8 hours of OT time a week, which can be difficult if you're working on a graduate degree, CFP or CFA. Also, it's a bit of a grind taking call after call that can wear on the employees.

Pro: Good brand value, good culture, good training focus
Con: Slow internal growth and conservative approach to decision making

Pro: Great Job, culture, benefits, training
Con: Have to pass the series 7 in the time presented

Pro: Laid back and friendly culture in most departments. Great work-life balance and retirement benefits. Plenty of opportunities for growth.
Con: Although Anonymous is trying to make technology a focus, at the end of the day it is still a financial services company and IT will always come second. Since Anonymous is such a large company with MANY security concerns change comes at a very slow pace, which can be frustrating as a developer.

Pro: Great way to work your way up if you are fresh out of college.  Bonuses are higher in fin'l services than other places and Anonymous will pay you quarterly bonuses plus profit sharing bonus.  Anonymous teaches you how to ask questions in discussions w/ clients so you can better understand who your client is and what solution fits best. Good career path for goal driven young people as they can become managers.  Recreation room with video gaming system and ping pong tables. Company loves to hire internally for regional offices.
Con: Unfortunately to excel you simply have to take more calls than anyone so you can outperform in your metrics.  A 45 minute discussion w/ your client about how best to invest his/her money is a stat killer.  Big focus on pushing people to 'do it yourself' online. I've been in fin'l services for 9 years...young managers aren't good managers. Anonymous does allow people to become managers when they are not skilled enough to do it. As a seasoned outside person who started with Anonymous, their max starting salary to outsiders was $45k...below what seasoned people make.  Phone center will always suffer from the need to have people adhere to their schedules 'on phone' times.

Pro: Good work ethics culture , Friendly environment
Con: You may get too complacened and bit bored with daily chores

Pro: Quarterly bonuses and good benefits. If you stay at the company for 30+ years, you're all set for your retirement.
Con: Sales skills required for advancement. Essentially required overtime in tax season. Not a lot of room for advancement, despite management's statements. Desirable positions are highly competed for. Same positions at other companies have higher pay.

Pro: Good benefits and this is an ethical company
Con: Being young is essential for advancement here.

Summary: "Great company, strong future outlook, great career opportunities"
Pro: Leadership, values, integrity and career.  Leadership is plugged into the employees and making significant investments for the future.
Con: Vacation policy is a little outdated

Summary: "Good overall environment on a daily basis, but zero hope of ever affording cable TV."
Pro: Work atmosphere is good.  Honestly didn't mind going to work.  Low pay, after years, just wore down my morale.
Con: Horrible pay.  Total acknowledgment that it's below going rate, but they don't care.  They'll find someone else!!!

-Quality focused mostly on functional testing

-Product developed on moving target often makes planning difficult.

Pro: Great Learning Opportunity with mutilple technologies
Con: Work-life balance is good , having work from home flexibility

I have have been working with Anonymous Investments for more than 3 years & my experience has been wonderful. The company adopts to latest technologies, thus keeping us techies in line with the latest happenings in technology.

My personal experience has been great, where in i have been promoted multiple times have joined as an Associate straight out of Masters Program. The company recognizes talent and promotes the same, through opportunities for learning & perks.

Pro:
Good work environment

Employee friendly

Good support to newly hired employee

Quarterly Team outing

Sodexo food coupons every month

Good and secured transport facility



Working in fidelity investments makes you feel good because of these advantages mentioned above. The company is located at very good place. I worked in Embassy Golf links office. It was really cool.
Con:

Growth is for only those employees who works consistently

When there is heavy load of work, you cannot leave the desk

Pro: salary, benifitts are good for associates
Con: communication, strategy are lacking for associates

Summary: "Very good, but could be great with some improvements."
Pro:
Private ownership and long term investment.  

Strong corporate values that are mostly lived up to

Fantastic benefits for those that want to make this a life-long career

Broad businesses to move to many different areas.
Con:
Very large size = very large bureaucracy

Too many leaders with golden parachute of great benefits - should leave but never will and hang on too long.  As a result don't aggressively drive change (go with flow is dominant and safest choice that too many make.

Less meritocracy more, play safe and conservative and survive.  Hierarchy more important than ideas.

Pro:
Great technology

You have your own office

They have billions under management somehow
Con:
You are constantly told that if you are in the top 10 on the regional ranking reports that you will be promoted (this is totally untrue as I witnessed numerous people at the bottom get promoted over the highest performing colleagues).  

You are driven to set as many appointments as possible (and tag as much business as possible) so that you look better than your peers

The only way to get ahead is to brown nose your superiors and those that have access to give you potential leads (thus people are being promoted on the basis that they were  "liked" in the company and not by their performance).

All that matters is your Anonymous "Buzz" 

There is very little to no upward movement for promotions.

Pro: Good work/life balance, most of the people were very nice want to see you succeed. I think my experience was a problem at the branch I worked in rather than the whole company.
Con: Terribly run office, clear training structure not in place, letting one nasty angry employee affect the culture of the whole branch. Management did not have an effective way to deal with a problem employee. I was hired with all my licenses and 4 years of experience into the financial rep role to eventually move into a sales role (after 9 mos to a year). After 3 months I had been repeatedly told by management that I was not filling the role "effectively". I received almost no training and was expected to not make a mistake. The job is not hard but being "written up" and receiving "warnings" for every mistake caused a lot of issues. They did not use me for the talents I had, I started looking for other employment within 60 days of starting. I have worked at 100% commission and was less stressed out than here. Basically I was a scape goat because the manager could not stand up and lead the office.

Pro: Good benefits, plenty of opportunity to work in different roles and a good place start off / learn about the financial industry.
Con: The company is organized and run like a bank which has a negative impact on the technology divisions. There are multiple layers of management who don't really know anything about technology. Unfortunately they get to make the important decisions which leads to expensive and wasteful engineering practices. Good engineers typically get frustrated with all the politics and beauracracy and leave after a few years.

Pro: A great company and with very competitive salary.  A very good benefit structure.  High percentage 401k match.  Very family oriented.
Con: A lot of bureaucratic red tape.  Different organization structures.  It was difficult to get new ideas or processes moving as many are very set in their ways

Pro: Great benefits and work culture .
Con: Too much Bureaucracy and Process which is killing work life balance.

Summary: "Good place to start, but do not stay here for long."
Pro: You have the potential to learn a lot about the business very quickly
Con: There is almost no upward job mobility, and the pay is very low for the industry. There is also a complete lack of job security.

Pro: They pay for your 7 and 63 right off the bat. Young corporate culture, lots of room for growth
Con: Room for growth limited to positions in the call center. They will talk about other areas career-wise but those positions are extremely rare and very taboo to get into i.e. Branch, research, rotational programs, marketing etc. Hard time retaining talent because of pay scale and willingness to pay external hires much more than the people they hire in initially. Entry-level service managers come off arrogant and micro manage to the point the job is unbearable. Boast about retirement benefits when in reality you do not see profit sharing nor match for the first full year and none of it vests immediately after that. Job itself incredibly repetitive and not empowering for someone with a college degree.

Summary: "It was ok. Good place to do time but better place to leave."
Pro: Paid well. Very good benefits. Top of the industry so good learning opps and street cred.
Con: Limited creative thinking and ability to make a difference. Claim they want to be high tech leaders but wait for leadership to tell them what to do.

Pro: People are super professional and willing to share knowledge. Great teamwork environment.
Con: Commuting into Boston is not easy for me but that's just part of living outside of the city.

Pro: Profit sharing payouts are great and year-end bonus is nice. Anonymous provides matching 401(k) contributions too.
Con: Average pay for this industry. But when you take into account their total benefits package, Anonymous is above average. Talented people are not properly recognized for their contributions. As with most companies, the most popular people get promoted before the most qualified people.

Pro: It was a good place to start and get licensed.  Strong family owned company.
Con: Middle management is terrible. Power hungry and will step on anyone to get to the next level. Watch your back and be careful who you trust.

Summary: "Decent compensation but all advancement is purely political."
Pro: Compensation is comparable to other large financial services companies.  Benefits used to be among the best in the industry but that has fallen in recent years.
Con:
In my department advancement, whether in the form of formal promotions or stretch assignments, go only to those with contacts at higher levels.  Midlevel managers routinely tell subordinates that they believe the subordinates deserve advancement but that none is available unless the subordinate can figure out a way for senior managers to take notice.  Senior managers don't believe this is a problem because they see promotions going to the people they know are good.  They are oblivious to how many good people work there that they don't know.  That is because people rise to the top at Anonymous by managing up, not managing down.



There are two types of senior managers.  One is the Anonymous Lifer who understands how to play the game.  Don't try to change anything, don't take any chances, figure out how to not get your finger prints on anything that might fail and know that after 20 years you can retire extremely wealthy.  The other is the short timer who comes in from another company expecting to get things done.  They take chances, they get involved in new projects that take the company in new directions and they are the first to be blamed when things fail.  These people rarely last long.

Pro: Profit Sharing, Health & Dental Insurance (prices have gone up a bit though), Tuition & Fitness Reimbursements, Decent Pay with good performance increases.
Con:
Can be long hours depending on your role, group, etc.  They'll try to focus on work/life balance but its never what an individual expects especially those who are salaried. If you're hourly though, then one could benefit with OT pay.



Perceived job promotions, movement, reorganizations are more lateral movements.

Summary: "reputable company to work for and good overall financial philosphpy"
Pro:
lots of opportunities

brand recognition

great benefits (401k match, profit share)
Con:
highly metricized

larger organizations sometimes loose focus of their people and become too numbers driven

Summary: "Great benefits and peers, poor judgement when selecting managers."
Pro: Great retirement benefits, above average insurance, and generous when it comes to professional training. Very customer focused, which is a pro if you are a customer/client.
Con: My manager loves to over coach you to the point you feel as though you are incompetent. There are others that do the same. This is part of the coddling Anonymous does to their clients. If you are in a service role in a phone site you will be expected to place trades that fall into the complicated and varied internal rules that often defy logic. If a client wants to place a trade and you place it without questioning the client on why and how they are wanting to place it, you will be scrutinized. Anonymous's internal trading and distribution rules imply that all of their clients are idiots and we must save them from themselves. If you miss the opportunity to save the client from their own actions you will be charged an error. They will tell you how easy it is to exceed the quarterly bonus and get a full payout, but it is far from the truth. You have to trade error free, have efficient calls, meet sales lead goals, and have positive client surveys. The entire team has to meet their goals in order to maximize payout. Without significant experience most error free traders don't have efficient calls, because they are spending ten minutes a trade to make sure one of the silly rules isn't being violated. If you receive good surveys then your probably not meeting your lead goals, because despite the belief, not every client wants to be probed for opportunities. I am currently seeking a non-phone based finance job elsewhere.

Pro: Visionary leadership, unlimited opportunities for those who work hard, excellent training programs, personal and professional growth is unparalleled.
Con: There are no cons, it's a wonderful place to work

Pro: Its really cool as a starter. But after 4 months it is enough. But learn a lot
Con: Its cool to work in a big team with nice people. U learn a lot and u getting better and better!

Pro:
Private company who is not making decisions based on the fluctuation of their stock

Amazing benefits

Great funding for product development

People and potential

Great facilities (environment, art, landscaping)
Con:
Incredibly political environment

Change is a buzzword

Too many people who avoid decision-making and play the "I told you so" game

Risk averse

Entrenched product silos create friction and can dilute the potential for new offerings

Summary: "Moving in the wrong direction as they try to capture more of the DC and pension of the retiring baby boomers."
Pro: Great Benefits. Client surveys are extremely important, almost too important. Company is strongly client focused and looks out for the clients at most levels. Walking a fine line between companies best interest and clients best interest as of late.
Con:
Lots of shuffling around, but little advancement. I see the same co-workers and management moving around, but little advancement, even at the VP level. Managers are chosen by metrics and "Personal Brand" which is simply hear-say. Advancement is limited to very specific paths. It's rare to see someone move outside of these paths. 

So many managers with so little formal education in management or prior experience. Stunned at lower level management incompetence, although they are powerless to promote change as upper management directives and metrics are etched in stone and beyond reproach as the higher level VP's strive to hit their own metrics at the expense of their departments well being. No happy work balance here. Voluntary/mandatory overtime is the norm, as the company is completely understaffed on the front lines. Do not give your opinion if asked, it can and will be used against your for the rest of your career and becomes part of your "Personal Brand". Better to just enthusiastically agree to whatever one of the many changing priorities for the month, smile and give your whole hearted support.

Summary: "It was fun for the most part. A good place to start your career."
Pro: People are generally really nice.
Con: Promotions are hard to come by once you are a senior developer

Summary: "Working at Anonymous is just like high school.  High turnover rate"
Pro:
Benefits are slightly above average, just as good as all other big companies.

They will hire anyone.

Good Training

Anonymous is a great place for a customer, great products, customer first culture is awesome.
Con:
The office politics are really bad

Very high turnover rate, highest in the industry

the computer technology is all over the place

Anonymous cares way too much about email Surveys.

Not much promotion from within

The promotions are like little baby steps and often never include a pay increase

Summary: "Great career jobs with layers of bureaucracy"
Pro: On-boarding process has plenty of Kool-aid to drink (aka. "we're amazing and nothing wrong") that gets you excited for your new job, Plenty of movement during certain periods of the business cycle, lots of cross training, great retirement benefits and health plans, investment in employees, pay is great, clean, bright work environment.  Perfect for a long term career employer.
Con: Leadership is sub-par, upper management is extremely disconnected with the front line representatives and doesn't enable mid management, lots of politics, office culture seems inauthentic, very low flexibility on work schedule, forecasting always off, talk about providing best customer service in industry yet not providing tools or hiring sufficient staff, extremely restrictive of employee trading (no "bearish" positions, very hard to qualify for upper level options trading) due to policy not regulation, few rewards for service reps - mostly available in sales.  Very hard to effect any real change.

Pro: Dynamic environment, Established processes, work life balance, social commitment
Con: Lot of small groups, takes lot of coordination

Pro: It was a great company to work for, lots of opportunity to move up. Great leaders/managerial support.
Con: There is a bit of politics between some supervisors when trying to move up. I was hired on a contact with the likelihood of becoming full-time. The decision was left to supervisors, some supervisors have only worked with some for only weeks.

Pro: Anonymous has alot of benefits. They have great 401k match! They care about there employees.
Con: The pay is crappy. Not enough off phone roles in Jacksonville

Summary: "My experience at Anonymous has been an enriching one, full of learning and self development."
Pro: Good working environment, A great place to learn, Company Cares about the employees, Safe place to be during bad times, Flexibility
Con: Growth opportunities are limited, Top heavy, Slow to change

Pro:
Benefits , Job Security, 

Learning

Technology

free Cab :)
Con:
Salary is less

Few managers decide everything on appraisal

Pro: Benefits are pretty amazing, 7% match dollar for dollar and 10% profit sharing as well.  great options for health insurance as well.  Training is also pretty good and you get a great opportunity to learn the industry.
Con: Depending on your role you could get stuck there for a while if there are no other job openings.  It's also pretty hard to move throughout different business units, so once you're in a certain business unit you're pretty much stuck there.  There's not a clear understanding of what other business units and do and what jobs are available there and how they pay.

Pro: Benefits are great. Many good on-site facilities.
Con: Management does not care about employees at all. They expect too much and always think that you are not meeting the goals which are never clearly defined.

Summary: "Above average pay, but responsibility is minimal, positions are dead ends, and leadership is poor."
Pro: Cushy job, above average paying role.  Occasional travel to conferences once you have experience.  Abundance of opportunity to learn if you apply yourself.  A good job out of college for a few years and then it's best to move on.
Con: This particular position is a dead end, but management may lead you to believe your responsibility will improve or that you are doing work that is important.  The work is simply making charts and analyzing numbers in Excel, which others will use to make decisions and this gets boring quickly.  The people you will work for can be high strung and passive aggressive, so they will ask you to do something and then hover over you until it is done, or they will be short with you and then friendly later on to make up for their initial rudeness.  Few of them have the time to teach you, so be prepared to learn on your own.  The corporate culture is poor because the main hires are highly intellectual people from top universities who typically have limited social ability.  People in my department went through the day with little social interaction and when they did interact it was forced and awkward.  The managers are better socially, but they don't know how to lead people because their prior roles were individualistic assignments.  Those assignments didn't allow for the opportunity to hone people management or leadership skills.  Instead of rolling up their sleeves and making the occasional tough call, managers sometimes pay people lip service and kick the can down the road.  Management's personnel decisions come slowly or not at all for fear that those decisions won't work out and it will reflect poorly on them.  Upper level executives are slow to make any drastic or necessary operating and strategic decisions, which are required in this rapidly changing industry.  The company is strategically behind the 8 ball as a result.  People usually stick around for so long because it pays well and people sort of muddle through New England life at this company.

Pro:
Series 7 & 63 are paid for and the training program is excellent, they are paying a lot of money to license you and really want you to pass.

There are multiple shifts available to you which you bid for, and most people receive their first choice in shifts.

Amazing, supportive co-workers.

The best technology I have used in the Finance industry.

401(k) matching is among the best in the industry, but annual salary is not competitive.

Good work/life balance.

Team outings each quarter.
Con:
The call volume is ridiculous, and you spend most of your time resetting passwords, even once you are on the full-trader gate.

Anonymous talks a lot about career development, but team meetings and one-on-one coaching sessions with your manager are constantly canceled due to call volume.  A manager cannot develop his/her employees without ever speaking with them.

Even when you are promoted you do not get a raise, you get an increase in variable comp, and that is determined by whether you hit your metrics.  You can get a "promotion" without ever getting a "raise".

Management is hit-or-miss.  I worked for a couple of amazing, hands-on managers who were very engaged with their teams. I also worked for a few managers that appeared to do nothing other than sit around and play games on their phones all day.

A lot of push-back from different departments when you try to transfer calls.

Metrics are constantly changing.  What is important one quarter may be meaningless the next quarter.  It makes it very difficult to try to establish a routine on your calls when you don't know what measurements your bonus will be based on.

This is a call center job.  Don't try to kid yourself, you will be on the phones 8 hrs/day.  Unless you get a position in a branch, you will be on the phones, even if you are "promoted" to another role.

Pro: Quality products, strong corporate values, excellent benefits, private ownership, long-term perspective, generally nice people
Con: Heavy competition for more senior roles, investment management organization overly dominates decision making, long-time executives spoiled by past success, slow to make decisions, too many reorg's

Pro: Work culture is awesome :)
Con: No good hikes and no encouragement for jr developers

Pro:
1. Very Good work life balance,

2. Pretty Decent salary.

3. Focus on innovation.

4. No compromise in the company ethics and values.
Con:
1. Very poor employee engagement activities/fun activities.

2. US employees always get preferential treatment over India employees.

3. Very poor personal growth rate.

Pro: The initial training in attaining your 7 and 63 is unbeatable. The support system is great, they don't just hand you the books and tell you to go study, they stay with you throughout the process to ensure you get licensed. Theres an initial self study period followed by a class that, if you put the work in, will thoroughly prepare you for the exams.
Con: The training thereafter in becoming a trader is incomparable. What apparently used to be a year and a half long process has been condensed into two months. They have a system of call overflow that results in inexperienced traders engaging with clients coded as private client group looking to do multi-leg options trades that their traders are not at all prepared for.

Summary: "Anonymous is a great private company that has excellent benefits with a fantastic retirement plan."
Pro: The people are great to work with and have a good team atmosphere.  The facilities are great in Westlake and it is a good location.
Con: The internal politics are frustrating and it is difficult to make major changes due to the complexity of being a large company.

Pro: Good work culture. liberty with work timings and pay
Con: nothing as such and all is well!!

Pro: Excellent benefits, good values.  The campus in Westlake is awesome, although you have to walk a long way from the parking lot to the building.
Con: Promotions are hard to come by, their salary and bonuses are much lower than they used to be.  This is an entry level company.

Pro: challenge but rewarding, fast pace working environment.  Great benefit.  Great opportunity within the firm.
Con: no work life balance. Demanding boss and not a lot of guidance as to how to proceed with the projects you are assigned.  I would prefer more guidance in the initial stage of projects to eliminate the possibility of redoing a great deal of projects

Summary: "Let Anonymous pay for your Series Licensing!"
Pro: Anonymous paid for my licensing
Con: If you have legitimate health issues and must use FMLA, you may as well start your job search now. Don't affect your manager's bottom line or he'll find a way to fire you.

Summary: "They do not value industry exp. or knowledge. A private company that is run more like a public one."
Pro: Some locations offer free parking. Casual dress and jeans on Friday. Not much more to say than that.
Con: They don't provide formal reviews or offer development. You need to start there right out of school in order to succeed. Value isn't what you know about the industry but how to figure workarounds for their convoluted systems. Not a lot of opportunity for those coming from the outside.

Summary: "A very valuable experience that was impacted significantly by the tremendous employees that work at Anonymous Investments"
Pro: Very strong training program for interns that allows them to be exposed to various different business units. Anonymous treats their interns tremendously well in order to motivate them to want to return to the company following college.
Con: Very little to complain about the company, but some days would feel a little sit slow as some of the full time employees would be traveling during the summer for vacation.

Pro:
Very positive and transparent culture

Great pay and benefits

Great work environment and amenities
Con:
Experience can be very different between different departments or business units

Due to groups being geographically dispersed, it can be difficult to remain "in the loop"

Pro: A lot of jobs available.
Con:
Managers pick and choose what they want monitored based on what they are compensated or advanced by. 

Poor team meetings. Competitive environment but people are hired strictly on power rank and there is not monitoring for manipulating or cheating because it makes the managers look good also.

Pro: excellent 401K matching - 9%
Con: I was discharged after 3 weeks of employment because, as the Company told me, I had too much consumer debt (an auto loan and student loans).  This had nothing to do with my performance and was none of their concern but you have to sign a release to work there.  Creepy employer!

Summary: "String Company with Good work but less money"
Pro: Good work, salary is ok but not comparable with competitors
Con: Too much politics; slow moving company

The software delivery process is costly and very poorly run.

The people who do the work are rarely rewarded.
Promotions are given almost exclusively to people in management positions.
