Pro: Great energy at the firm; sincere commitment to serve clients well; will commit the resources to make the required investments. Benefits and pay are competitive.
Con: Work life balance could be better.

Pro: Great atmosphere and corporate culture.  Benefits and profit sharing are 2nd to none.  Best support in the industry for passing the series 7.
Con: The pay is just decent.  It is not as high as competitors.  Flow through to new positions can be quick at first but you quickly can hit a road block and movement will be limited.

Pro: workplace stability is assured fully
Con: people avoid conflicts creating challenges to result / goal oriented people

Pro: I enjoyed it pretty much
Con: i didn't like certain things

Pro: Private ownership, long-term view, trusted brand
Con: Many levels slow decision-making, regulatory environment in FinServ

Pro: Benefits, quick opportunity for advancement into other starting roles
Con: Call center. Hard to see real advancement past entry roles. Micomanaged to the minute of your day. Mandatory overtime during tax season.

Pro:
Good work-life balance if they aren't understaffed and requiring OT

Paid training

Easy to move up in certain sites
Con:
Poor management - There are far to many managers, doing far too little work. When call volume goes up the managers have less to do and can be seen watching youtube or congregating around a desk talking about their children. Their success depends on their teams metrics but the metrics are a crap shoot for the most part. Being promoted is all politics - its about who you know and how hard you can suck up. That may just be how the world works and I am just naive, but this is certainly not a meritocracy.



Metrics - It is understandable that a call center would have metrics, but even the best employees will miss them. They are arbitrary numbers that management places too much weight on.



Faceless Corporation - There is no room for personality, uniqueness, or creativity. Maybe a symptom of a highly regulated industry but feels more like the policies of a faceless corporation.



Monotonous - This is a call center. You take calls. All day. If you are seen taking a break out of schedule you will be told that what ever you are doing can wait till your scheduled break.



Pay - TIAA CREF offers the same position for better pay, more relaxed environment, and more reasonable metrics. They are snatching people from our offices left and right.

Summary: "Great company, daily tasks can be repetitive"
Pro: Benefits, good work life balance, licensing paid for
Con: repetitive work,  daily tasks can be mundane

Summary: "A great place to start your career so that you can move on and take your experience elsewhere."
Pro: Over my career at Anonymous I worked with some amazing people, had a lot of development opportunities and great benefits.  I left voluntarily with a strong professional network and tremendous experience, for which I am grateful.
Con: The culture of the company has really deteriorated - there have been many management changes and shifts in direction.  The benefits are still great, but I don't think the compensation is as competitive as it used to be.  This is a big company and you must learn to deal with a lot of bureaucracy in order to accomplish things - a person who succeeds at Anonymous is flexible, patient, smart, politically aware, knows when to give up, and can shift direction with little to no lead time.

Pro: retirement benefits are amazing, including retirement health
Con: They don't really challenge the employees, other than some minor competitions

Pro: Lots of opportunities for advancement, perks
Con: I would recommend higher salaries

Summary: "Absolutely BEST Employer I have EVER worked for!!"
Pro: Superb management who are engaging and truly care about the future and current success of the employee. Very competitive compensation package including salary, bonus, profit sharing, retirement health funds, 401(k) match, education contribution match, fitness reimbursement, computer reimbursement, and MANY MANY more! Anonymous's health, dental, and life insurance offerings are PHENOMENAL!! Family type environment run by a family from the top down. Excellent opportunities to move globally and into other job types and businesses. Anonymous is a highly diversified corporation with abundant options. Depending upon the position, many teams offer flex-schedules, including working from home. Training is available in areas both inside and outside of the employee's current role enabling them to grow in areas they are interested in.
Con: Interviewing can be challenging depending upon the role you are applying for. Also, if you do not have work experience or financial industry experience, it may be difficult to get your foot in the door.

Pro: Awesome benefits and pay for new associates
Con:
Political company

Very large corporation

Many business units

Pro: Great benefits (one of the best really!) the company trains you very well to get you licensed. This is a great place to start (but don't stay long)
Con: Anonymous is one of the lowest paying company in the financial industry. They start you at $38K. I have been offered $20K - $30K more doing the same for other companies. The quarterly bonus is a joke. If you are a decent rep you can max you bonus really fast. The company does not care if you have post graduate degrees--you will not advance for being better educated and prepared then the next guy. Also, the company has this weird mentality to promote women. If you are a woman and want to advance fast, apply here. Management will hire less qualified women over qualified men just because of their gender. I have seen friends who had 3 years experience or more apply for a job, and management will hire a girl who is still going through full trader training. If you are looking to get paid three times as much, get trained here and apply at Moran Stanley or eTrade. Anonymous does not seem to understand I cannot pay my mortgage with a class A medical insurance.

Pro: Culture, opportunities, many different departments.
Con: Many subpar people, low pay

standard compensation

Attrition of a lot of senior employees recently

Pro: Great company, people, and benefits
Con: Long hours taking phone calls dealing with frustrated customers.

Pro: Work life balance, good supportive colleagues.
Con: ok benefits cant say much

Pro: Company is very Organized and easily promotes
Con: Company can be Cut throat and very competitive

Pro: Great atmosphere, no back-stabbing, everyone is very helpful.  Low-pressure environment because you are paid based on customer satisfaction rather than commission.  Good training program and lots of potential to move up in the company.
Con: Relatively low pay for this position, company tends to be a bit overly conservative, company is hemorrhaging 401k customers so overall, the customer base is shrinking.  Hold times can be atrocious.

Pro: Excellent benefits, 401k match and profit sharing, employee health credits.
Con: Call center environment, limited off-phone work.

Summary: "Great Experience with Lots of career advancement"
Pro: They provide an enormous amount of training and resources in order to advance career. Mentors and managers are very willing to help young associates.
Con: Starting salaries a bit lower than median salaries for the locations where you'll work. Can be hard to manage quality if life.

Pro: Good work/life balance, friendly colleagues, wonderful benefits
Con: Poor raises that don't keep up with inflation

Pro:
I joined this company reading the same reviews like most of them do in here but probably the biggest mistake of my career to have done except a few. And those few are the pros:



- Gurukool sessions

- Good quality work

- Good transport facilities

- Great marketing of own brand

- Good leave policy
Con:
After I quit the company, I realized how come there are so many good reviews about this company. Then I realised probably they're the ones who never had any work in the company during work-hrs



- no work-life balance, Managers will tell u upfront to work till 16 hrs a day and shout at you in front of everyone ( ask u to do development during day time and Prod support at night)

- improper performance review, biased and politically influenced

- Ethics helpline is just a gimmick, there is blatant favoritism etc

- HR is a puppet who are mere slaves of managers/directors

- BAD BAD COMPENSATION: Bonus is HEAVILY included in the CTC and they'll eat away all you own money

- They'll give a huge chunk like 50K as transportation which U wont get upto even a penny if u dont opt for (good for far flung commuters)

- NO TAX saving options in salary and U get MEAGRE take-home (the company earns keeping all ur money in their own FDs)

- Medical Benefits/Hospitalization is only upto 1 lac/a where in a part of premium is deducted from ur salary too (My current org gives upto 3 lacs covering even in laws paying complete premium)

Summary: "A relationship company that cares about employee development."
Pro: There are very clear pathways to advancement.  Anonymous really seems to take care of its employees.  I heard when I first joined, and it seems to be true, that you can do your basic 9-5 and be fine.  No one bats an eye.  But if you go above and beyond, then you'll be rewarded with promotions & salary.  Pays well with sizeable end-of-year and 401k bonuses.  Benefits are good, 401k match is fantastic, as you would expect of a company that specializes in retirement plans.  The only people I've seen be let go by the company really deserved it.
Con: "Relationship company" means politics are everywhere, especially in middle management.  Every decision is made by committee, which while great for consensus forming means that every decision takes 10x as long as it needs to be.    Constant reorganizations.

Pro: Motherly company and well kept canteen areas
Con: Poorly Managed Organization; Loads of non-workers.

Pro: Anonymous Labs provides the start-up atmosphere within a larger corporation. They are truly on the cusp of cutting-edge tech innovation and are utilizing design thinking methodology to create user-friendly experiences with their products.
Con: The corporate hierarchy still does exist and Anonymous Labs is still trying to secure an identity with which to move forward and gain recognition outside of the company.

Pro: Great culture, benefits (401k, health, profit sharing)
Con: Big corporation feel, mundane, somewhat demanding

Pro: Awesome Team, Technology stack was Great

Pro: Okay if you really need a job. Some departments can be very good. It all depends on the management. Decent benefits. good money management for employees.

Depending on the department and manager it can sway to very, very micro management environment. Favoritism, politics. Managers and Directors with zero people and management skills. When people die at their desk and leave or take time off for stress, that's a big problem they need to address.

Summary: "Good pay but you worry about your job everyday"

Con: Long hours. Incompetent management at all levels. Half your time is spent playing politics just so you don't have a target on your back. It is not a meritocracy. You are promoted if you know how to play the political game.

Pro: The biggest benefit of this company is that they have a great overall benefit package from healthcare and retirement.  They treat their employees well from a benefit stand point.

Pro: Very Good Company to work for.
Con: I did not find any cons.

Summary: "Anonymous might be a good place for you to work, depending on what's important to you..."
Pro: The total compensation is very generous. I worked there for 10 years, from 2001-2011 and every year we received 20% profit sharing bonus, even though the economy was terrible 2008-2010. Which means they were always profitable.  They are focused on on growing their asset share, and if you are good at sales, you will excel and be promoted often.
Con: The employees aren't the most friendly and helpful people, it is a culture of help yourself and you will do well. They are always focused on the bottom line of reaching their outrageous asset goals, at any cost, even lying to their clients. They change CEO's every four of five years which means you have to adapt to a new "vision" to drive sales.

Summary: "My experience at Anonymous Investments has opened my knowledge to the financial industry."

Con: I take inbound calls from customers all day.  Customers sometimes treat me very poorly.  I am paid on an hourly basis.

Summary: "A good place to spend some prime years in your career; comp can plateau out in some cases, but generally a rewarding pla"
Pro: Many high quality professionals at lower and mi levels within the company,particularly on the technology side of the company.  Within the business leaders, the typical political class emerges and operates as such.  Internal communications is a priority for most of these executives.
Con: Overt focus on personal brand management and career advancement by the middle class.  As these executives are often paid well, they can be defensive and self serving due to the low likelihood comp can be replaced somewhere else.

Pro: I worked at Anonymous for 6 years as a Client Service Manager in IWS. Overall, the job is challenging and rewarding but offers little flexibility in terms of how you structure your day. You have 30 minutes for lunch and be prepared for blackout periods for vacation during seasonally high volume periods (i.e. December and April). Regardless of the experience, credentials and skills you bring to the role, you will still be managed like a $10/hour customer service rep. In my experience, don't look to your manager to provide career and professional development, that is up to you. Lastly, depending on the level you are hired at (i.e. 25, 27, 29) you will not be eligible for the full, advertised bonus. This is the great unspoken fallacy of this position. Your time, effort and sacrifice will be rewarded by giving up a portion of your yearly bonus to subsidize the more tenured client managers on the team.
Con: Lack of flexibility, bonus "bell curve", adherence to high customer service levels at the expense of human capital, increasing micro management

Pro: Cool Atmosphere. Nice Views. Bad Customers
Con: Lots of potential for growth.

Pro: For experience starting out, the pay and benefits can't be beat.   The training provided is good, especially if you're on the phones and need licenses to perform your job.
Con: The company demands a lot from you, in terms of time and commitment.   It is also a very political environment, so if you don't march in step, your advancement opportunities can be limited.

Con: Management don't care about advancing your career once you've hit a certain salary grade, if too long in a position you are basically pigeon-holed, HR practices are there to defend the Firm not employees, politics get in the way of work and on-the-job happiness, despite a good line-up and impetus diversity & inclusion are not (really) a priority.

Pro: Great benefits, 401k, match, profit sharing.  Private company, run well, they have the fundamentals solved which most companies do not.  Fundamentals being defined as connectivity between work and cost, established quality control, right sized spans and layers, simple interfaces with the customer, etc
Con: A bit regressive in terms of future state.  Middle and upper management are complacent and lack current knowledge of corporate culture (want to manage like the good old days, more political in orientation versus meritocratic and performance based).  Need to focus more on problem solving than fire fighting.  Lack of proactive thinking and execution.  Over reliance on historical success and failure to recognize competition.

Summary: "Big corporate company with big corporate mindsets."

Con: Large corporations adapt at glacial speeds, and this one is no different.  As a technology professional its imperative to stay up to date with the latest innovations, and in a company where your job is primarily spent maintaining 20+ year old systems, that's hard to do.

Pro: Boss was a great guy

Pro: Good hours, great pay, no working weekends.
Con: I was recruited strictly for my customer service skills.  I was concerned about metrics such as call times, call quota, and surveys and asked clear questions about these issues.  In the face to face interview, I was very mislead.  I was told the main focus was on customer satisfaction, and this was not true once I was on the floor.  Our training about the subject matter was excellent, but we received almost no training on the complex and multiple computer programs.  There was no hands on training of the system.  This lack of training on an absolutely vital part of the job is why I had to leave the company.  Also, many times we asked a manager or mentor a question, we were told something that was later disputed.  There was no consistency regarding information.

Summary: "No opportunity to influence change in the Equity Trading systems group."
Pro: location, bonus, shares, benefits, some intelligent peers
Con: In the tech group, there is very little (if any) opportunity to influence change. Decisions are made by architects and there is very little opportunity to have your voice heard.

Summary: "Overall positive experience and great place to start working fresh out of college."
Pro: Great entry level company with solid training. Almost impossible to fail series 7 / 63 exams with all the help they provide.
Con: Inbound call center. The pay is low. Company knows what you are doing 24/7 with little to no freedom.

Pro: Benefits are great - 401K match is 7%, and heath/dental insurance are top notch.  Great cafeterias in the offices.  Some of the nicest coworkers you could hope for.
Con:
Getting promoted from this department is next to impossible.  This used to be a 'desirable' destination, with the potential to advance one's career.  No more.  They care less about the front-line folks helping clients, and more about 'stats.'  Your breaks are timed/measured, the length of your calls is measured (long calls = baaaaaad,) and getting promoted outside of the department takes an act of congress.

Management, in general, is a bunch of glad-handing guys and gals.  You seldom see managers let go/demoted, even if they are consistently poor performers/coaches.  This leads to a lot of stagnation, and little room for advancement (unless my manager would take the initiative to seek a different role or retire, which hasn't happened in the 5+ years I have been there.)

Pro: Fantastic company and a great place to learn, they have a generous benefit program paying for things like CFP , gym etc. This is dynamic place to work with a great culture
Con: Far too much politicking necessary to get promoted. The introverts that work hard rarely get a mention , Stingy in there raises. Inflation is 3% yet consistent dont give that

Summary: "Great company to work for.  Great benefits."
Pro: benefits, profit sharing, privately owned family company, people don't generally leave there
Con: time off policies, overly conservative company

Summary: "The sky is the limit, excellent opportunities to grow your career."
Pro: Anonymous likes to hire the best of the best and it shows as you work on exciting and challenging projects.   The opportunities to collaborate and learn from really smart people is phenomenal.
Con: I don't really have any cons.  I have enjoyed my experience immensely at Anonymous,

Summary: "Good company with great benefits. Limited upward mobility."
Pro: Good benefits -- 401K Match, Profit Sharing ect.
Con: Limited upward mobility. Can become locked into particular group/role.

Pro: Anonymous is truly committed to helping you develop your career. The office culture is one where professionalism and mutual respect are fostered. They truly practice what they preach and provide the tools for career and retirement savings success. It's up to you to use them.
Con: They still have some issues with breaking down silos, but they are actively seeking ways to break down the barriers between groups.

Pro: Good Company.Proper standards and good salary
Con: So many dependencies. Work culture is not good

Pro: Anonymous has a great benefits package and year end bonus based incentives.
Con: salary, slow employee development and growth.

Pro: Smart people across the company, lots of very good career options, the benefits are great, and Anonymous has a stellar reputation.
Con: There can be high stress in certain parts of the company due to long work hours and there is also high turnover.

Pro: Compensation is generous. Time can be flexible. Benefits are outstanding. Negative culture is limited to my current group - however, it's a Con that the bad behavior is an open secret in the firm.
Con: Leadership is lacking. Fear is the current culture. Employees in my group are not valued. There is no credibility in reporting - negative messages are not accepted. Mobility is not encouraged or tolerated. Group leadership uses position and the necessity of partnering relationships with other groups to intimidate and manipulate outcomes.

Pro: Benefits (pension, bonus) are really excellent.  Training opportunities are good, advice would be to join the company, skill up on as much as you can (and you will have time to do it) then leave after a year.
Con: Where to start?  Ridiculous amount of people working on small projects that in any normal software house would take 3 weeks but take 3 months in fmr.  The Ireland offices are pretty much treated as an off-shore group, work is allocated from the US, but Ireland is not seen as an equal partner. You are expected to fill the time with coming up with "innovation" ideas, which basically means trying to convince the US partners to let you have more people ... exacerbating the first issue which is there's too many people and not enough work.  Also they have no clue what the function of a QA group in a SDLC is, and as far as career growth they expect testers to transition into "real" careers, i.e. management or automation developers.

Pro: Values drive, Respect Work Life Balance, Overall enjoyable experience and you get to learn too
Con: Things move at a bit slow pace, but ok

Summary: "Micromanagement reigns as employees are left to wither away"
Pro: They will hire you right out of college and pay you a decent salary with good benefits. The facilities are nice and some of your coworkers can be friendly. Training and L&D structure is quite good.
Con: Incompetent management who are only around to spy on employees every waking moment of the day. They drill you with metrics and are quick to point out the negative aspects of your performance while glossing over any positive aspects. For example, you could be leading your team in trade accuracy yet they will berate you for the fact you take a few extra seconds in between calls to wrap things up. Your metrics suffer if you have to use the restroom when you aren't on a break (often times you go a 3 or 3.5-hour stretch without one). Your schedule is outside of your control and offers no room for any leeway (I would always have break and lunch at different times every single day of the week). If you work on a schedule where you have to work on weekends there is almost zero chance of you ever getting a Saturday or Sunday off. Many of your coworkers and managers are rude, narcissistic egoists who will do anything to get ahead. There is almost no room for upward mobility if you start in the call center - something made very clear early on. It's just an endless line of phone jobs, finding a spot where you aren't working on the phone is exceedingly rare. Despite the fact that it does pay well, reps are still underpaid for the amount of work they must do. Full traders are almost always sitting in a position where there are 20+ calls holding all day for the entire 10 hour shift. Soul-crushing monotony with zero work/life balance, this job will inevitably make you wish you would get in a fatal car accident on the way in to work.

Pro: New facility, friendly people, amazing compensation and benefits
Con: there are no cons that i can think of

Summary: "Anonymous Investments is not an environment for women who have families and involved in their children's lives."
Pro: Good benefits (employee accounts, healthcare, vacation policy)
Con: Not much upward mobility for women and not very understanding when it comes to pregnant women in the workplace regardless of years of experience and capability/expertise. HR personnel does not work in favor of the employee. Very bureacratic environment.

Pro: They have great benefits, paid time off, and great training to get licensed for the financial exams. Thy also have some 4 10-hour shifts you can work instead of 5 8-hour shifts.
Con: Moving up in the company is completely up to whether or not your manager likes you. Until you move up you're forced to work in service, at the bottom of the pole. You are also typically required to work weekend and nights starting out. Low pay compared to other financial companies. Only work here if you're ok with sitting at a desk answering phone calls all day.

Incredibly high amount of mid-level management

Summary: "Ok place to work, but not all its cracked up to be."
Pro: They recruit you with the promise of quick promotion and fast track to a 6 figure income. Its as they promise - atleast in my previous roles. Fantastic 401k matching and PSP. Great benefits, great training. Overall pleasant company to start with if you're new in the industry or ready to retire
Con: Its a machine and you get treated like a replaceable cog. Heavy micromanagement to control output of product (ie what you say to clients) They're like the mcdonalds of financial services - you know what you get, whether good or bad. Working there you're forced to adopt their processes and procedures with exact scripts, very robotic - often times reminds me they want you to be a parrot (ie repeat what they say with greater enthusiasm, then they feed you a cracker like Iago from Aladdin). Management recruits you by promising you a book of business and that its like you running your own business but with fidelity's resources and support. Further from the truth. Once you're in, you always have to continue to generate revenue for the firm. This doesn't lend a good hand towards servicing your existing customers. Good pay, but its a hamster wheel. The moment you stop running, you get slapped.

Pro: Wonderful, friendly people to work with.
Con: Everyone is on an abbreviated salary schedule - hispanics and african-americans alike.  This is "old money." There is compulsory volunteering activities and people are kept in check by your typical caucasian female managers.  While I was there multiple members of minority groups left for higher paying jobs.   They will milk you for all your worth.

Con: Projects move at a snail's pace.  A lot of politics three and four ticks down from the CEO.  If you like fast paced and challenging, this is not the place for you.  If you want to be more than just a small cog in a huge machine, this is not the place for you. The most consistent complaint to HR is that the same people get the rewards and opportunities.  The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result.  If any of above "rings true" then get whatever you can and leave.

Pro: Major Pros: Free Cab and free food. Thats it!  Might be lenient towards female employees. Used to be a good firm 5 years back
Con:
Hi Folks,



This is an honest review from someone who is been working for 4 Years in this company Anonymous Gurgaon Unitech cyber park office.

Total experience is of 8 Years now.

I have seen this company on all its sections functioning in gurgaon. So i will comment on each dept individually. Myself been part of I.T Technology department, i have worked in development/maintenace and support roles in this company so knows in and out. This review is completely transparent and genuine.





I.T Technology Dept Review: 



1) Only if you join above "Tech spec/Project Lead" level i.e 10 plus years this company might be for you otherwise please go to any service based firm even if you are paid little less. The life below the 10 Years guy is a hazardous journey. The people at higher level are sitting for more than a decade,  they do not have any kind of skills ..be it technical/managerial. Pure office politics and not giving credits and demotivation from senior management. Knowledge sharing is not a concept here, only self learning and politics is the mantra.



2) The Support profiles in company L1/L2/L3 ,People in these roles are highly frustrated, There is no learning there are no knowledge sharing sessions between development and support team.The heads of two departments are often on rivalry which leads to suffering of employees only. They do not have work life balance, the shift allowance and oncall support allowance are worst than any other firm. Working in night shift entitles you to a mere 200 rs a day and being oncall for 24 hrs even on weekend from home entitles you to only 350 rs a day. 

The project once developed is made live and the support team is not made aware till the release day what they are going to support in production :):).



2) Zero onsite opportunity, and by chance if there is any(1 week/1 month) they make you travel on sunday night ..reach UK on monday morning directly to join office then dey make you fly back on friday evening after office...as they dont believe on spending even for 1 xtra day to employee....and per diem they give is 28 pounds. Which is lowest.



3) High disparity in salaries within peers. A mid level employee salary difference could be in 1-8 lacs, so you can imagine the disparity level as you go up.



4) Their promotion cycle is July? But the clever HR has declared minimum difference for next role change is 18 months. So that automatically comes to 2 years. And mgmt will obviously take 2 cycles as a concept to promote you so minimum 4 years of waiting for a promotion after "senior analyst programmer" which is for 5 plus years itself and ranges to 10 years.



5) Bonus potential. It is part of pkg only and based on rating it is reduced as well . So how they can call it bonus. Next is you have to wait for year end to get it, if you leave between, it is completely surrendered.



6) No HR in the company. There is high shortage of HR. There is no concept of HR meeting of whatsoever. The HR is not available in the company for anything you dont have any HR to discuss any grieviance you have. There is just payroll department. All the HR are contractual ppl passed from colleges..they are kids just for recruitng people, even talking to them feels ashamed of urself.



7) Company itself finding difficult to cut off the extremely highly paid people working in the company since beginning. These people are stuck to company like termites they have packages equivalent to what their team is getting and are not a value to company. So company is slowly trying to get rid of them and past 5 years there has been sacking of people at higher levels quietly.





Operations-Back Office Department Overview:



1) It is worst for Operations / back-office department people.  Long hours.Strict breaks of 60 mins, which are being checked via software which checks the login hours of employee on computer.If the time out is more than 1 hr then he is to be scolded.



2) Worst paid, over worked. Highly uneducated an unprofessional culture in Operations team. So 1 rating for that. Just for sake of getting a job and so called brand name ..you can join Anonymous in operations. It is worst then call centers.

Pro: Working at Anonymous was great! The internship program was very structured and I received a lot of training and supervision from my manager. It was a great opportunity to learn, have a large share of responsibility, and understand the workings of a large company.
Con: The company is big so it can be difficult to make connections with people. However, I was able to meet many other interns and work closely with senior management.

Pro:
This is a company that cares and provides opportunity to show it.

1. Benefits

2. The pay is very good especially considering the work/life balance: I declined a job that paid 10k more, but fidelity pays overtime, where as the other job was gonna work me 55-65hours per week. NOT worth it. Anonymous provides a very good pay with the ability for those who want to work over-time to make more money.

3.Great opportunities for growth. They pay you to get your licenses, they have great tuition reimbursement benefits. If you are ambitious and want to grow, Anonymous is your place. I am already planning to get my licenses, an MBA, a masters in law, and move up in the next 6-7 years. 

4. A great culture with efficiency to its core.

5. Healthy lifestyle emphasis. They have the FIT food which means salads and healthy food is super cheap. How affordable? $2 for a salad vs $10 for hamburger. Yes, they want their employees to be healthy and thank goodness. They also have a recreation center and a health center.

6. Ability to get involved with community and company. They have great affinity groups for LGBT, AfricanAmerican/Hispanic, Women, and Veterans. They also have AnonymousCares so it is great for people who enjoy social groups.
Con:
This is financial services and it is highly regulated, what does it mean, there are rules. LOTS OF RULES. But that is only a bad thing if you are one of those people that can't follow rules or can't follow order.



The rules are very simple: Don't be late. EVER. Not a minute. Why? Because it affects the entire company. This company handles big clients with big expectations. It handles other peoples retirements, which means their futures. Yes, there is a high level of commitment, but there is also a high level of opportunity.

Con: Nothing to share -- you have some good managers but the old ones are stuck on their ways.  No Vison at all

Don't believe the reviews that you see below. They do not accurately reflect the life of a Anonymous employee or the "small guys" at the end of the totem pole ( 80% of the company). Mid to senior level management is a different story. They live a drastically different life than the average employee who works tirelessly and is underpaid. Wine and dine events for mid to senior level management  are constantly ongoing in our cafeterias. Such events are disrespectful when you are requiring your employees below you to work weekends during tax season.

Summary: "Great place to coast by or finish your career ... otherwise avoid it!"
Pro:
- Good benefits plan and bonus packages, amazing 401k contributions/matches



- Large enough company to move around in and chart a career path



- Pockets of great situations (good leadership, interesting work, challenging opportunities)
Con:
- Those pockets of great situations are growing fewer and further between each day, the amount of influence one's boss can have on their career at Anonymous is astounding ... in 3 different jobs, I was rewarded (1) on par/average, (2) over-the-top with $$$ and shares and promotions, and (3) not at all .... my approach to the work didn't change in any of those jobs, so it shows that people of equal talent and skills could expect significantly different experiences at this company



 - Jobs are moving out of Boston, so local opportunities are few and far between ... those that pop up are usually pre-reserved for a hiring manager's friend (i.e. probably not the most qualified candidate), so the talent base is watering down, causing animosity, and those that want to advance their career in the Boston-area have to look elsewhere



- There is a layer of lifers at the Director / VP level that have settled into a comfort zone, earning high salaries from the days of raises/big bonuses (long gone), they are staying off the radar, and don't want to rock the boat ... so they are stifling innovation, they are roadblocks to progress, and they are blocking career opportunities for younger, talented, innovative staff members.



- Didn't get a raise in 3 years despite the company pulling in $2.2-2.4B in profit each year, was told it'd be made up to me in the form of a "higher bonus", but the bonuses were the same each year. The company manages the bonus %s, the share rewards #s, and the raise $$ in a way to keep people looking forward to something, but the overall pool of compensation rewards is shrinking every year.

Pro: Good name to have listed on a resume, good benefits if you're able to use them, good food on site.

They tell you overtime isn't mandatory but you need to have a valid reason to opt out and then if you do opt out, you receive emails asking you to reconsider. High expectations and low direction from many managers. Stuck in one role for 1 year before the possibility of ever moving around within the company.

Pro:
1) 10% year end profit sharing (added to 401K account) and 7% 401k match

2) Stability of company

3) "Always learning" mentality, constant weekly coaching meeting to ensure we are on top of the market

4) Good pay if you can perform well (only speaking for branch positions ie VP Financial Consultant / Financial Consultant)

5) If you are new to the field the Anonymous call centers is the perfect place to start. Anonymous will license you, train you, and help you find the right department/branch to work in. Anonymous is big in promoting internal candidates.
Con:
1) Increased stress. Due to Anonymous's business model to constantly bring in new business we are focused on bringing in new business all the time. I never take full lunch breaks and leaving at 5 PM makes me feel guilty. 

2) Hampster wheel. There is no means to the end.  Managing a $1B book ensures you may get $50 - $60k a year in "residuals/trails" at Anonymous while at a wirehouse a $1B book may generate $1MM + in residuals/trails

3) Long hours. If you are looking for an 8-5 job, working at the branch sales level isn't for you. Work/life balance is tough.

Summary: "This job will suck the life and drive out of you."
Pro: It is easy because your job becomes repetitive. They have nice benefits that convince you to stick around.
Con: There is no end to the work load. From the second you pick up the phone, you will take call after call for 8-10 hours, day after day, year after year. I have been here a few years and have talked to 1 or 2 people who actually enjoy working here. Trust me or not, but if you make the move I want you to think about the moment you read this and doubted what you're reading.

Summary: "Great Company-Not much room to move up"

Con: Management plays favorites, very hard to advance especially if you don't kiss up. Even if you out perform co-workers, and go the extra mile with the customer, you still may get passed up for promotions for those who are "buddies" with the boss.

Quarterly bonuses were based on annuity production and accounts transferred to Anonymous's professional investment management services.  Professional Investment Management was limited to model portfolios comprised of  mutual funds and some ETFs.  As in any large corporation the goals continuously changed and became increasing more stressful.

Con: Management has way to may priorities throwing you in a number of different directions. The fire drill method of management makes it hard to no what to focus on. The middle management is hit or miss, you either have someone to help you move up, or someone who is afraid you'll take their job.

Con: This is where your dreams go to die. You answer phone calls all day long 24/7. You feel like a robot with going over the same questions over and over again. Even at the prestigious higher roles you are still only offering two cookie cutter solutions PAS (Portfolio Advisory Service) and Life Cycle Funds both of which have mediocre performance. As a Financial Solutions Rep we aren't even allowed to sell the product on performance. Why else would you hire someone to manage your money other than performance? The people that sell it don't even know what the performance is and its so hard to find you eventually give up. If you want to be paid a lot to be a robot selling mediocre products this a great place for you.

Summary: "A lot of travel, low pay, but great experience."
Pro: You learn a ton about the clearing and custody business. You are one arm of the full implementation spectrum, but it allows you client facing opportunities as well as exposure to all levels of management and different departments. The experience, knowledge and exposure are the biggest advantages to this job
Con:
Travelling can be extensive. Each implementation is at least 1 - 2 weeks (including the weekends) and it's not uncommon to go from one to another. Some implementations are scheduled and promised by upper management to the client, for 10 - 12 weeks. There were many instances where employees would travel from a 2 week conversion to a 4 week conversion to another 4-6 week conversion back to back. 



I don't know if the pay grades were appropriate for this sort of commitment to the employees.

Pro:
Competitive Pay

Some coworkers are great

Great benefits package offered

Great 401k match



Great potential for advancement
Con:
Anonymous - who is a recordkeeper for who knows how many companies 401k plans, has a 5 year cliff vesting schedule, and you're not even 20% vested in company contributions until 2 years.



The systems provided need a MAJOR overhaul.  There are procedural specific systems and client specific systems to use when handling calls.  These systems are not updated, so 1/2 the time you are under a constant worry if you are handling something incorrectly.  When cross trained on multiple products, you are not trained completely, so customers can ask questions you are supposed to be able to answer, but you can't because you don't know.  The answer is supposed to be searchable while you put the customer on hold to get the answer.  But holds can only be for 3 minutes, and it can take a lot longer than 3 minutes to find the answer because 1/2 the time when you search something the system comes back with no results. 



If a customer escalates, they don't go to your immediate manager, you're to call your "solutions desk and escalate the call" and that rep is supposed to handle the call from that point.  However the solutions desk reps are extremely lazy and will do anything and everything to push the call back on the tier 1 rep because they don't want to handle the call, thus causing the customers to become completely frustrated, yelling and screaming at us over why we are not transferring them to a supervisor, and then give us a bad customer survey.



If you need to enter a work item, they are shipped off shore to some reps in India to handle who have no idea what they are doing.  So they resolve the work item incorrectly, and we need to enter multiple work items for the same exact thing over and over.  We promise customers a 5 day work around timeframe and something so simple can take over 1 mo to resolve because the India reps just don't care.   The customers become very upset over how long it takes to resolve a simple error. 



While the company offers great potential for advancement, it is all in who you know, not what you know.  I had an interview for an internal transfer once, and while I was nervous as I didn't have a lot of interview experience at the time, my interviewer was constantly yawning and looking at his phone even before the interview started.  I don't think I was that boring, but that was extremely unprofessional and I can't believe he got the job he did because while I didn't get it, once trained I'm sure I would've been way more suited for the position. 



When you do need your manager and not a "solutions desk rep" they are nowhere to be found because they are always "in a meeting".  



This job creates a lot of extremely stressful situations, but when you become frustrated and voice your opinion, you're in the wrong and put under review or fired.  You can offer suggestions on how you think things should be and how to correct it, and management will pat you on the back for it, but then nothing is ever done to fix anything.

Pro: Good starting out pay good training program. There is a lot of different hours to choose from good work environment and lot of opportunity to move up
Con: The customer service role is a calle center role which they do not tell you until the end of training. You just sit there all day taking calls

Con: Focuses too much on younger talent instead of looking at those with experience. work/life balance is good but can be detrimental if you want to move up. People without families are able to participate in after work socializing and are able to mingle with senior managers whose kids are grown up. As a result, those of us with families tend be left behind those who are single and can go out and drink with the V.P.s and get moved ahead.

Summary: "Good people hamstrung by micro-managing senior management who won't make tough decisons"
Pro: Solid pay, decent work-life balance, excellent benefits. The people at Anonymous are smart, friendly and uniformly desire to do the right thing.
Con: Terrible disconnect between senior management and the people below them. Poltiical maneuvering among senior leaders is widespread, a result of C-level unwillingness to set direction clearly or resolve conflicts decisively. Company culture is consensus-driven - often from the bottom up in that individuals, groups and teams are left to work things out themselves - and when issues among teams arise that cannot be resolved below the SVP level, they remain unaddressed and left to fester until things get bad enough that someone senior HAS to step in, usually with more fallout than would have been necessary if the problem had been addressed earlier. There is a serious blind spot when it comes to recognizing the limits of consensus-building and the fact that leadership by directive is sometimes necessary.  Micro-managing is common, and far, far too much time is spent on producing presentations and reports.

Pro: interview process for senior is also that as of 1 -2 year frsher

Summary: "Great company with pockets of terrible management."
Pro:
Great benefits for employees. Salary+Bonus+Annual Profit Share+7% dollar-to-dollar 401k match.

Contractors treated well in most groups. (I have been contracting the last few years)

Durham NC location is pretty casual. Business casual dress with jeans on Friday. Relationships with management have always been casual side.

Some groups work with offshore resources and get to travel to other countries.

Some groups are in flexible work arrangement situations. Some people work from home much of the time. Even in other groups, you generally can work from home if needed for personal reasons from time to time.
Con:
Base salaries can be very low, especially when you get promoted to the next level.

Some groups work in crowded arrangements because leadership will not support any official work from home arrangements.

Lack of oversight on Directors and Vice Presidents with direct reports. A bad apple can really tear a department apart. 

Review process is not individual. People are stack ranked and there are quotas on high ratings. Even if you have 2 star performers, only 1 can receive the most excellent rating. The process is truly not individualized.

People provide reviews for employees they have had very little interaction with. Can get very personal.

You will have to change departments to earn more money as annual merit increases are often nominal.

Your career is in your hands here. You can not depend on any management or HR group to help guide you in advancing your career.

Summary: "Anonymous is a great place to advance your career."
Pro: The firm genuinely wants to do the right thing for customers.  It is widely diversified, which means you can get great, broad experience.
Con: Defered compensation schemes mean that many in senior management end up just trying to hold onto their job.

Pro: Worked within many roles, good exposure to management, worked on projects that mattered
Con: Wasn't the laidback, technical company I was looking for, but this isn't any fault of theirs

Pro: Anonymous has a great 401k match and profit sharing potential.  The associates are great and training is good.
Con: There is a lot of uncertainty on the retail side of the company currently due to changes in the way the call routing works and sometimes there is a lack of communication from local management.

Summary: "Solid, steady, conservative company with great benefits."
Pro: Great job stability as long as you do what you're suppose to. A lot of opportunities depending on what you want to do.
Con: As with any job, a lot of job satisfaction and upward mobility will depend on your current manager. The phone site managers can be a bit over zealous.

Pro: The only thing I could think of is their Health Benefits
Con: It's a Call Center! There are over 4,000 employees in Merrimack location and you are just a number to them. People are very cold and unwelcoming.

Pro: Smart colleagues, good compensation, nice offices, interesting work, great opportunities for advancement.
Con: Churn and burn organization full of type A personalities. There's a bit of a "what have you done for me lately culture." People feel expected to work a lot of hours and are overly busy, which means that the common niceties are sacrificed to get the job done. Seems like a good place to build a career if you are starting out, but only if you are very driven. A lot of meetings and not as much time to get work done.

Pro: Benefits are satisfactory, pay could be more inline with the industry, vacation policy is ok but has not been updated for over 20 years.
Con: Massive attempt to eliminate older employees in the branch system, will not promote (especially if you are a woman) unless you are young and are a member of the so called "boys club".  If you are a young male you will be supported and promoted by management.  Managers will lie to HR to support this movement.  Anonymous is on the wrong track, this has not always been true, however, seems to be the direction they are taking in 2015. It boggles ones mind that a company the size of Anonymous would not find the best talent in the industry, instead of promoting mediocre sales people to manage branches, most of whom do not know the first thing about how to treat employees. I was one of those employees that worked harder than anyone else and was still treated badly, and after all the years I devoted to this company you still pushed me out. Shame on you Anonymous.

Pro: Benefits are amazing, match is also great on 401k. Profit sharing is great for building long-term wealth.
Con: Can be a lot of moving parts and hard to be up front in the action.

Pro: Great co workers, great benefits, awesome salary starting out with raises and promotion potential
Con: Branches can create a lack of mobility unless you are willing to relocate

Pro: Health/Dental/Life insurance. Unlimited growth potential. Tuition/Computer/Gym/Insurance reimbursements. Management is (somewhat) supportive of coaching/growth of reps. Sick days. 3 weeks Vaca. Paid holidays. Overtime is paid at almost 3X. Profit sharing is huge. Employer match is huge. Ability to work as much as you'd like.
Con: Culture is shifting within the firm to focus more on the bottom line rather than clients. Increasing micromanagement. Call center environment. There is a disconnect between decisions made from upper management and actual impact on associates/clients. 5 year graduated vesting for company match. MINIMUM 10% overtime during tax season to accommodate for inefficient/poor hiring schedule and practices.

Pro: Great company, fantastic benefits, amazing work culture, values driven
Con: Rigorous training. Long hours. Hire and fire policy.

Pro: everything is always going to be awesome
Con: absolutely nothing in bad about working here

Pro: People are professional and they care.  Leadership is excellent and C level executives are very in tune with what is happening in the business.  Open environment where ideas are encouraged.  Fairly conservative and cautious company which means quality triumphs over speed.  This means you actually have time to think and do things right with less pressure to simply deliver.
Con: Not a performance based company.   While they claim to be,  monetary reward system tends to be socialistic with little distinction for a person's productivity. Much of compensation is tied to 401K as opposed to cash in pocket.  Will know more on this once I've gone through the bonus round.  Once you get hired in you are fairly well set since they tend to steer away from terminations, rather they look first to place people in another position.   This makes it challenging for managers who are dealing with performance issues.  But even with this, the vast majority of people are top notch.

Pro: Started career at Anonymous as an intern and was offered a full time position upon graduation. Management is open and helpful- I was given lots of responsibility even as an Intern. Colleagues are always willing to collaborate and assist each other. Flexible hours and able to work from home is a large bonus!
Con: Can take some time to implement change, but to be expected in a large organization.

Pro: Great benefits, you can learn a lot. Have great potentioal
Con: The environment is all work and no play. Everyone eats at desk, it is kind of depressing.

Pro: Great 401k program with 7% match and 10% profit sharing. Quick upward mobility

Pro: Best work culture, friendly environment, adhering new technology. Best place for lady employee as well.

Pro: I honestly love my job.  I'm so grateful for the opportunity to work for a company that truly cares about their clients!  Providing excellent customer service is absolutely necessary and we take it very seriously. Anonymous strives to hire like minded individuals that create a positive work environment.  They review their salaries to make sure they are staying competitive and there's plenty of overtime opportunity. The benefits are great. Tuition reimbursement, 10% profit sharing, 7% 401k match, health reimbursement (gym memberships), etc.  They are very lax compared to other companies when it comes to using sick time, last minute vacation, and changing your shift to accomplish a better work/life balance. Anonymous is very open about upcoming changes within the company with all levels of employees.
Con: Not so much Anonymous as it is the industry we work in but tax season (leading up to the tax deadline of April 15th) and distribution season (retirees requesting their minimum required distributions before the end of the year) can be incredibly draining.  Last year we were slammed and it made for a very long couple of months.

Pro: Large company with good benefits.  It has the feel of a public company given focus on results and the next big project.  Still, lots of smart people working  there.
Con: Revolving door for supervisors/executives.  Can be very hard driving and they definitely are focused on performance.

Pro: Good work-life balance, interesting work, nice people, large annual re-invest in the business is great for technology and business process management.  401K is great benefits are good.
Con: Heavy at the top with many Vice Presidents which causes layers of middle management that can be blockers for up and coming talent.  Politically correct is rewarded more than results - this stifles innovation and speed to market.

Summary: "Good company; pay scale changes too often."
Pro: Solid company, a lot of opportunities to grow and get promoted (especially if you're willing to move).
Con: The branch network is like a different company with high management turnover and a new bonus system basically every year. It's focused heavily on activity around new clients which makes it difficult to do a good job maintaining long term clients. That's how Anonymous tries to keep you from building a book of clients that might follow you to a private RIA

Summary: "Do yourself a favor, Run Away from Anonymous"
Pro: Benefits were good, they match 7% after 1 year of service, but, not fully vested until 5 years. Most people do not stay 5 years.
Con: Call center is a "sweat shop" in my opinion. Make you eat lunch, 30 minutes, at your desk-they call it a "Working Lunch". The calls are non-stop and you are limited in a career due to this being a call center. Very political place, no room for advancement. You are coached and everything you do is recorded both on computer and phone. Adherence to your schedule is a big thing, also, if a customer give you a bad survey, and its not your fault, you still get in trouble. Blah!!!

Pro: Flexible work hours, work from home policy, good transport coverage for all employees including contractors, some excellent technical leadership teams within the organization, good learning curve if interest is within financial services.
Con: Over a period of time leadership teams have been swamped with service delivery mindset, lack of  technical leadership, growth opportunities are only given based on employee manager relationship rather than talent, onsite opportunities are scarce,  managers run the whole performance cycle show with 0 contribution from HR teams.. HR teams are non-existant in this organization. Not a good place to be in if you are in for technical career path. More emphasis on production support organization & operations than on IT development or getting new exciting projects to retain IT employees

Pro: Friendly, Challenging, Innovative, Supportive, Adaptive, Flexible
Con: Depends on the team that you get into

Pro: Worked at the call center in Westlake Texas. Fantastic facilities, decent pay, good people.
Con: It was a call center job, so dealing with ignorant people was part of the job description. Additionally, sometimes it's tough to get promoted out of the call center.

Pro: .great place to work yes
Con: .too far to drive each day

Pro: Its Great place for contractor Enjoy Cab facility , Work from home means life is balanced.
Con: Difficult to find out good person surrounding.. lot of politics to save or protect own person.

Pro: Very nice facilities, excellent licensing program for new brokers, great health and 401k benefits
Con: Where do I start? The unnecessary micromanaging? The months of brainwashing? (They force you to watch countless hours of internally-produced videos during new hire class on why Anonymous is the best company you'll ever work for...). The secrecy of everything, including the breakdown of the bonus structure that is supposed to make your miserable job worth it. They make you feel bad for hating your job while at the same time putting under unmanageable working conditions. I had to work 10 hour shifts with a 30 MINUTE lunch, and if I took 1 minute longer than that, I got a threatening email from my manger. SERIOUSLY? I could go on, but there's so much that I could say about this company. Do not work for Anonymous unless you are desperate and have nowhere else to go. I've worked in call centers before, and this, by far, was the worst experience I've ever had.

Pro: Great environment, friendly coworkers, helpful managers

Pro: Open door policy (even PMs have their doors open); everyone is willing to grab coffee and answer questions. Great environment to learn.
Con: Some communication isn't streamlined across teams. Some divisions have more developed and elaborate intern programs, and some less.

Pro: Base pay not so competitive, but generous bonus plans more than made up for that.  Good place for recent college grads to start their careers and get a solid foundation of experience.  Beautiful facilities, great design, and lots of art.  Lots of opportunities to participate in classes, seminars, information sessions, etc...both in person and online.
Con: Everything is communicated via 50+ page Powerpoint documents that no one reads beyond the 3rd slide during meetings. Annual increases are tiny or nonexistent, although the HR documentation indicates ranges for double-digit increases (dream on).  Some execs are reassigned to lead departments in which they have no experience and are clueless about strategies and issues.  Overall, they are very slow to take action on toxic performers, which causes turnover of  the solid performers who can get jobs elsewhere and not have to deal with the grief caused by the toxic colleagues.  Sr. leaders ask for feedback and suggestions, but rarely act on honest input - it's easier for them to manage the status quo.  Although the ongoing mantra is about ethical decisions and behaviors, I personally encountered an environment where confidentiality was breached and bullying was evident...the sr. exec chose to look the other way.

Pro: Anonymous has a lot of respect towards their employees. Great scope to improve skills. Work from home option. Good perks. Good hike. Reward for your work.
Con: Have heard lot of rumours about internal politics going on, but it would be there in every company. Dint affect me though

Pro: Good Compensation+ you often get raises and quarterly bonuses
Con: They Micro Manage you and tend to promote those they like over stats.

Pro: Great place to work for. You get opportunities to learn and contribute.

Pro: Nice Benefits and good health care.

Pro:
This job is technically a "call center", but don't let that dissuade you, Anonymous an amazing place to work. The benefits, training, and exposure to the financial markets are invaluable. For those wanting to enter the industry that do not have degrees from overpriced private colleges, Anonymous is the place to be. You will work alongside some of the best and the brightest, ambitious individuals who come from a wide array of backgrounds, all sharing a common desire to help the uneducated investor find success.



I can only speak for the Jacksonville, FL location, but the training is phenomenal. The series 7 instructors, alongside the rest of the learning and development team will make sure you are successful. You will have to be self motivated though, every day during the initial training you will be coming home to take 1-3 hour tests, but if you ever need assistance with a concept the mentors are there for you - and are actually encouraged to help you by being paid overtime.



Whether you want to move up in Anonymous or leave and go to another firm, this is a great place to get your foot in the door in a normally very competitive industry.



Benefits are amazing. Make sure you take advantage of everything.



With the brand new systems in place, schedules are more flexible!
Con:
If you want to go to a role involving financial analysis, or anything unrelated to the direct relationship with the clients, it is almost impossible to do starting from the phone roles, you will easily get a job at another firm with the training and certifications you gain, so you may have to jump around from firm to firm.



The advisory/guidance roles in Anonymous are less "sales" related in comparison to say Merrill Lynch, but they are still sales related. At the end of the month if you did not speak with a single customer that needed an annuity, you should not see any form of negative impact for not putting someone in one. Anonymous should be leading the industry in the charge towards a more "fiduciary" standard.



The compensation was recently increased to 42k for the entry level, which is okay, but honestly everyone across the board should receive about an extra ~10k. Anonymous can afford to do it, and the retention rates would drastically increase. Most of the employees are recent college graduates, so amazing healthcare and benefits are not as important as cash money to invest.

Pro: Learn how to sell over the phone. Learn a lot about mgt
Con: Tons of phone work. Really all phone work

Pro: great training and support, ability to grow within the company, benefits.
Con: salary in lacking unless you work in the upper ranks of the company, work/life balance can be difficult at times

Competitive Pay, Good environment, Friendly colleagues, Great Perks!



I would recommend this company to pretty much anyone.
Con: Tons of red tape...You have to wait to get anything productive done here. On boarding can take a while...You might be learning your new job and the proper way to do things at Anonymous for more than 6-8 months before you are self sufficient.

Summary: "Phone job with little to no apportunity off the phone"
Pro: Covered parking, great employees (and to some degree managers) , nice looking campus, does not publicly traded, thus, does not need to answer shareholders, fantastic class setting to help you get licensed (series 7/63)
Con: Been here for 3 years. "promoted" 3 times. Anonymous Micro-manages its employees like McDonald's. 100% phone job. Want to go to the bathroom? Need to leave a note in regards to a customer issue? Need to talk to your manager for a moment? (you get the pattern) Too bad, it will eat into your phone statistics since they measure how many seconds of every minute you're actually on the phone and report it to you every morning. FORCED over time for 10 months out of the year (i.e kiss your weekends goodbye) even though on the interview they claim it's just for 1-2 months. All career development (which they don't stop talking about due to fear of the very high turn-over they have) is being concentrated around your ability to stay on the phone for the rest of your career (unless you want to be a manager of a phone team). I honestly don't know one employee that is not actively looking for a different job.

Pro: They will teach you everything you need to know about the stock market, the training is exceptional. Pay and benefits are average but they are very generous with bonuses. In the middle of a growth spurt so lots of new opportunities and career progressions. They are also hugely profitable and a Juggernaut in the industry, you will have no fear in the company going under.
Con: They are growing their client base faster then they can hire new representatives. As a result the work load is severe, inflexible hours and mandatory overtime. You have to book your vacations about 6 months in advance in order not to have corporate operations deny your time off requests. The job is also very repetitive once you know what you are doing and as such it is very easy to burn out.

Pro: The benefits package at the time was very good. The pension plan, in particular, was one of the best around, especially once you had built up some service time. The working atmosphere was, for the most part, friendly and relaxed.
Con: In a lot of cases, progression up the hierarchy seemed to be the result of time served or by stroking the right ego. If you are the sort of person who thinks differently and enjoys a dynamic environment, this is probably not the place for you. Being told what to do by Boston, as in other US multinationals, can make for an easy, but un-challenging routine. The organisation in Ireland is also completely at the whim of management in Boston and things can turn from positive to negative (and back again, to be fair) with consequent insecurity at times.

Summary: "Pay is great and benefits are awesome"

Pro: Anonymous invests in their co-op students. They had between 20-40 co-op students each semester (most in Toronto Office). Every week HR organized walkthroughs of different departments and seminars to help co-op students better understand their business. Co-op students get many benefits including presentations from Portfolio Managers and guides on interviewing and recruiting to professional etiquette. Of all of my co-op terms I was treated best at fidelity and that was a common experience. Anonymous is also a very highly respected employer to have on your CV.
Con: A con to Anonymous is that there are a limited number of investment roles. Their investment team might hire one top student a year. There are roles available in Sales, Finance, Products and Accounting but no investment roles. As far as I could tell you would have a better chance getting a job with McKinsey than investing money for Anonymous. This isn't really a con to co-op students as much as it is to grads who want to actually do investing.

Pro: I was offered a great salary and benefits.  The hours seems reasonable and not ever having to work weekends seemed great
Con: I went through the entire hiring process and was made an offer, went for drug testing , fingerprinting and to have a badge made . On a Monday before class started I mentioned I was pregnant . On that Tuesday I recieved a call from hr asking question regarding my pregnancy , on Thursday I recieved a very rude call stating they were withdrawing my offer due to "unspecified concerns that came up during background check" even though the background portion had already been completed and passed long before... There's no doubt in my mind that they changed their mind due to my pregnancy , which Im pretty sure is illegal. I'm very disappointed , I was looking forward to this job and wasn't even expecting a maternity leave from them, I was back at my current job when my youngest was only 6 days old. There's nothing in my background that should've kept me from getting hired , per their rules that I looked over carefully. Whatever their reasons, I know that my merit and experience more than qualified me for this position , and my character has never been questioned, especially by an employer or associate. Their loss I guess.

Summary: "Good training, good atmosphere, development opportunities, job growth opportunities."
Pro: Good training, good atmosphere, development opportunities, job growth opportunities, forward looking and innovative culture. A great place to build a career.
Con: Vertical corporate structure lends to career growth opportunities, but lack of tenure with the firm seems to be  bureaucratic red tape.

Pro: Anonymous has an incredibly in-depth four month long training program that will not only bring pre-licensed financial representatives up to speed to pass their Series 7 and 63's (even for those completely new to the industry), but will also familiarize you with all of the software that would be used on a day-to-day basis. Generally speaking, upon completion of the program, financial representatives are capable of adequately performing the job duties in what is objectively a complicated job function without any sort of assistance. Also, barring a layoff climate or doing anything illegal, job security is very, very high; never hitting your numbers will still get you your weekly paycheck. If you play the game, opportunity is most certainly there to advance (and your manager will be first in line to assist you in achieving your goals), but you can only go so far in the call center, both in terms of job duties and salary.
Con: Unfortunately, the training program is where my positive experience ended. Employees are reminded every day from the first time they peruse the careers website, to the job interview, to on-boarding, to training, to team meetings, that Anonymous isn't like Merrill Lynch, Schwab, JP Morgan, or any other player in the game; Anonymous is a family-owned company and doesn't have to play to it's shareholders, and thus they are one of the few in the business "for the customer". That sure sounds nice, but beyond being family-owned, it's just not true. This job is in a 24/7 call center, and just like every call center in the world, metrics are king. You'll never move up anywhere in the company for retaining a multi-million dollar account or preventing perilous actions through education of financial instruments or any other morally outstanding action... you'll move up for finishing your calls on an average of less than eight minutes. This "time = money" focus exacerbates an already-beaurocratic business structure by incentivizing representatives to transfer their calls or to be curt to the point of being entirely unhelpful. That's fine, and almost expected from most call center representatives with other companies, but in financial services, it's unacceptable; you're dealing with people's retirement accounts and livelihoods. On the sales side, recommendations are limited to proprietary target-date funds and bloated, high-fee "managed" accounts. Going above and beyond to solve problems that are repeatedly surfacing and are consistently unaddressed is a habit discouraged by management: "that's not your job". Other than their own propaganda, nothing differentiates this company from the other financial services firms--do not take a potential paycut to choose Anonymous over them with the idea that you'll be working for some sort of Red Cross organization, even though they will spin it that way. At the end of the day, this is a 24/7 call center (where your job is to verify customers, reset passwords, give website support, send checks, and enter trades at their direction...financial professional is thrown around very loosely around Anonymous, but I would not consider the FR to be one) that is ALWAYS hiring. If you weren't able to deduce, there is an unhealthy amount of turnover at Anonymous due to employees leaving for increased responsibilities and salaries (most Jax representatives went to Merrill, which was literally across the street!). On the other hand, if you have some sort of relevant degree or experience and are out of work, there is a ton of job security and experience to be gained here. It's a stepping stone at best.

Once you get licensed and "get on the floor" that is when the trouble begins.



The job is extremely boring. Dealing with people calling every second of the day from about 9-4pm is horrible. Most of the time you are resetting passwords, not actually doing anything finance related. And when you do get the chance to do finance related things, all you do is enter trade tickets and hit send.



In training, they sold to us that we are "financial professionals," however, I would beg to differ. The only difference between "service associates" and a regular CSR rep is that at Anonymous, you are licensed.



The job sucks. It sucks your soul. It is not a fun environment. IF you enjoy  answering calls all day for $16-20 dollars a hour, have at it.



**Also, it should be noted that promotion to the sales side is extremely hard. There are 200 apps a year for 25-50 sales jobs. You have to kiss major butt and kill your metrics to get ahead. It is just too many people applying for those jobs. Managers will say that there are so many positions you can work in, but in reality they are all the same job, with a x<5000 in pay differential in the service side.



AS OTHER REVIEWS HAVE SAID, ONCE YOU ARE HIRED IN A PHONE SITE, THE CHANCE OF LEAVING TO A BRANCH OR TO ANOTHER DIVISION OF FIDELITY (fund management, analysis, etc). IS EXTREMELY SLIM. PLEASE KNOW THIS.

Pro: The benefits (401, medical, etc) are above standard for most employers. They're also the most likely firm to get you to pass a series 7 if you have no finance experience or degree to fall back on. If you can handle call center work there is some job mobility in that function, just don't expect to get into the back office or anything beyond a phone unless you're a lucky duck destined for management.
Con: Where to begin...The mantra being preached to new hires is that your contribution matters and you're helping our customers just by answering the call. In reality, training is now so utterly warped and schizophrenic that you likely will need a promotion above the entry level position to assist with anything more complicated than cutting a check or trading a mutual fund. Consequently, it is absolutely crushing that you can't help half the customers that wait hours in line to get to you and that's even worse when you first start to where you transfer 95% of your calls. Management is unhelpful and most of the call center managers you honestly scratch your head at what they actually do other than go to meetings and give you self-directed coaching assignments. As with any call center, metrics are King. I got promoted entirely because I got through calls fast and didn't ask questions only for the next role to be even worse. Certain departments (core/hnw services mainly) have forced overtime right now that is held against you if you don't meet the supposed goal or have other activities that prevent you from doing so. The new systems internally have also taken hold times and raised them exponentially because of the new/barely trained reps having to transfer everything and attrition causes old reps to leave for jobs outside of fidelity or internal promotions with the stress the new system has lumped on them from new hires being functionally useless. Volumes aren't even as bad as they were last year but it's still a high stress job that keeps you tied to a cubicle having to apologize to clients for management failing to see the problem in changing the entire service model at the busy time of year when clients are already in a hurry and coming in in droves. The money isn't enough to make this worthwhile.
