Pro: Lots of great resources, training is definitely better than average for the industry, lots and lots of great employer provided benefits, facilities are very up to date and modern, tons of resources at your disposal, and a great place to learn more without necessarily having to be in a pure sales or commission environment.
Con: Pay and bonus structure is significantly subpar - every time this is brought up you're reminded "how great" Anonymous's non-salary benefits are, which is somewhat true, however the fact that I have access to all kinds of benefits that don't apply to me ,or don't really have any personal benefit to me, personally, irrelevant.  I can't pay rent, buy food, or pay all the other bills I have will my "great benefits."  Money is the only thing that helps with that - and the salaries Anonymous pays, compared to the broader industry, are ridiculously low.  Moreover, there have been numerous changes that have occurred in the last 12 months that are ostensibly to "make things better" for the customer, as well as the associate, but the net effect has been the opposite ... for both.  They've basically significantly increased the scope of the role, while narrowing the performance metrics ... all while creating an increasing environment where it essentially makes it impossible for you to provide the positive experience the customer is expecting, and meet your goals.  How this has played out out to associate is ... you can kiss making more than the bare minimum for your quarterly bonuses (which also ... in not very much at all) goodbye.  Also, over the last 12 months or so, there seems to have been a dramatic concern with turnover, primarily among the associates who have been with the company less than 12 months.  The company has become ridiculously preoccupied with finding ways to keep this demographic with the company that they're basically throwing everything but the kitchen sink at them in the misguided hope it will keep them from leaving.  Basically ... they're focusing all their measures on increasing salary, compensation, and quality at work to the employees who have been there the least, and contribute the least to the company's overall functionality.  I've been with the company, and in this function for years, and even though I've been given yearly bonuses and increases I sit next to people who have been licensed less than 6 months, and are making the same amount in salary as me, or more.  It's really insulting, not to mention makes all the experienced, and seasoned employees feel extremely unappreciated.  Then there's also the issue that performance and ability really have no bearing whatsoever towards promotions or recognition for achievement - the current situation at the location where I work reminds me more of my senior year of high school, and everything boils down to a popularity contest.  The end result is you have people who weren't even competent to begin with and routinely failed to meet even the most basic of their performance metrics, being given increased levels of responsibility and management if they're "popular."  Granted this exists to some degree or another no matter where you work, however the level I've witnessed over the years is on the order of 20 times worse than anything I've experienced in nearly 15+ years in the workforce.

Job Title: Workplace Planning and Guidance Consultant I
Summary: "Depends on where you are in the company"
Pro: Amazing benefits. 7% 401k match, 10% profit sharing into your 401k every year, 5 year period for full vesting. That can get lucrative after a while. You also can have the Portfolio Advisory Service manage your 401k free of charge as an employee, and you have access to beautiful grounds (the complex is thousands of acres large with a pond and hiking trails and two cafeterias and a couple gyms, tennis and basketball courts and softball field and volleyball court). The health insurance is a little pricey but the plan itself is the best I've ever seen in terms of what it will cover. And last but not least, if you do your years i the dumpster up front, there is excellent income potential within the company.
Con: My experience is all within Workplace Participant Services business unit., working with workplace retirement plans such as 401ks and 403bs, and the company that pay us to service those plans. In WPS, we are underpaid for what we do (median in New England for our job type would be closer to $70k), the expectations are always changing, applied inconsistently, and you are prodded and driven to do overtime because they choose to understaff for the busy seasons to save money. In the call center positions, you're on a clock, you get the legal minimum required breaktime, and there is a general lack of respect for work/life balance. Everywhere else in Anonymous, I hear the experiences are great, so I would say this is a reflecting on being within Workplace Participant Services, not Anonymous as a whole.

Certain employer events would also cause flows of assets beyond my control. They attempted to capture this in the goal setting, but that was done so far in advance that it was certainly not an exact science. The travel time made it very difficult to have much of a personal or social life as well. This was my first job out of college as a software developer. They have a training program where they send you to North Carolina for five months to learn about various technologies and to work on a "real life" project.

About halfway through the program you get notified of the actual team that you'll be on when you return to your job site. You have some input with this, but the decision is ultimately made by management.

The program itself isn't too bad. I learned about a lot of technologies that I hadn't heard of and it gave me a little bit of real world experience.
Con:
Work non-existent/not challenging
Office is located in the middle of nowhere (Texas)
Old fashioned attitudes
Not a lot of young people unless you work in the call center
Old technology
Too much bureaucracy

The downside to the training program is that the team that you get placed on is very hit or miss and very much or if your control. Some people were placed on awesome teams working with cool products and technologies while others were stuck working on software that was 20 years old. 

Also during the training there are a lot of B.S. corporate events/talks, which were super cheesy and unnecessary. Some of the topics during training were a waste of time too, like learning how to write an e-mail (yes, I'm serious).

The team I was placed on seemed to have no plan in place for me when I got there despite the fact that a manager has to request an associate from the aforementioned training program so it's not like I was placed on their team by surprise or without their knowledge.

The whole time I was there I wrote probably a total of 20 lines of code because the product was in maintenance and there was very little new development. There wasn't really any work for me to do, so I essentially got paid to read reddit all day.

There are tons of meetings to attend and most of them are just people from various teams/business units arguing over minute details about random aspects of a project. The amount of red tape that you have to go through to get things done is pretty high.

Pro: - Good experience working with smart people
Con: - Senior Management needs to be more supportive of younger generation

Con: Be prepared to work long hours as needed,

Pro: Great training (actual curriculum and off sight classes), great benefits (7% match on 401k, profit sharing), great tools and resources (internal and external tools). Leads generated for you, and pretty good experience with all phone site reps and "spokes."
Con:
Great place to work for a very specific demographic. Everything is sales based, regardless of the "relationship model" that you hear about. Your success can depend on your geographical location, too. Some branches are extremely "flow heavy," while you really have to grind at others. 

There's a lot of talk about being wealth planners, but you may spin your wheels if you attempt it; there's simply no time to focus on anything that isn't closing a sale. 

Need to be employed for a whole year before match or profit sharing start. Vesting doesn't begin until you've been employed 2 full years.

Pro:
- if you like to be treated like your 12 this call center is for you

- if you like to work in a cheap office surrounded by homeless people this is the place for you 

- if you like to have to time out when you go to the bathroom this is the place for you

Every second of your day is supervised. You will more than likely have a 10 hour shift where you will spend 9 hours and 15 minutes of it on the phone and if you don't you will get in trouble and receive "verbal warnings" that turn into "written warnings" .

You receive two 15 minute and one 10 minute break (to go potty) 

You have to time out during your one hour non paid timed lunch break.

Now factor in every person calling in extremely mad because there is an issue with the website and they had to literally wait 45 minutes to get to you so they take their anger out on you.

It is not even sure if it's the Walmart of the financial industry. 

If you never want to make 6 figures in your life this is the place for you - well you might make LOW figures if you spend literally your entire life there sucking up to some of the strangest people you will ever encounter which in return will suck the life out of you.
Con:
This is 100% call center.

Nothing in the financial industry to do with this job - You do get your series 7 and 63 so that you can do the most exciting thing with your job and take orders from customers. Don't screw up or you'll get a boo boo aka trade error. #verbal warning

Its filled with people either making a mid life career change and they are so excited about a 401k and insurance (because they were going nowhere in their life) or you come straight out of college and if the person is halfway normal they are gone in less than two years.

The managers are some of the biggest jokes I have ever experienced in my life.

If you think women don't have an equal opportunity please go to Anonymous Salt Lake City. Women are promoted and have higher jobs for the sole fact they are women.

My manager would call me homeslice, homeboy, homies, holmes, homes, gangsta, etc 

She was so out of touch with the team it was truly remarkable. Unfortunately though that seemed to be the common theme.

Con: A highly political company with unknown employee measurement and hidden scores. As a senior person in my position you get to know the skill set that is important for your job. When you do outstanding work you soon realize that advancement Is not based on merit but who you are aligned with. A company that is interested more in protecting management with an emphasis on the org chart and less about the work itself. Constant internal battles and intentional reorganizations. An internal employee goal program that ignores how you want to grow as an individual instead focusing on how a manager wants you positioned. If you get a good manager that focuses on the work it can be a wonderful place but soon there will be a reorg and and you will find yourself having to pay more attention to the political back channels and less on your passions and skill set. Politics is extended externally as well with profits spent on preventing governmental "regulation" but internally a love of regulating the employee. Highly protectionist from the top on down. This protectionism even extends to internal technology where systems in place are more about what management wants rather than what the employee needs.

Pro: Training is pleasant. They hire right out of college. Work-sponsored outings are a delight. Great facilities, beautiful campus, on-site Starbucks is the greatest perk of all. Friendly coworkers. Pretty packaging for what proves to be quite an awful deal.
Con:
Customer service representative work and culture is truly toxic, mentally taxing, entirely sedentary, and unsettlingly monitored by management. You are physically chained to your desk by a phone set for nine hours a day, and provided with two 15-minute breaks and one 30-minute break, all of which are timed by the tracking system. 



There's a big sentiment of favoritism that guides promotions, bonuses, and on the flip side - verbal / written warnings. You don't need to be able to think in order to excel in this role, you just need to be able to follow chain of command and avoid questioning anything. Voicing your opinion will always work against you.



For anyone who studied finance / econ / business, be warned: this is NOT a finance job in any capacity. You will not learn anything about the financial service industry by being here - unless you move into a licensed role, in which you'll really only be able to learn about the industry to pitch the same handful of Anonymous products that benefit the company, so it's really just a glorified sales role. I work with many people who previously worked in grocery stores, coffee shops, or retail shops, who never went to college. It doesn't matter what you know - if anything, it'll benefit you to avoid all forms of thinking whatsoever, as Anonymous does not value ideas, only obedience. 



Your schedule is monitored by a system that quantifies every second you spend on / off the phone into performance metrics that determine your fate at the company. Do not drink too much water at your desk. If you take bathroom breaks, it'll harm your metrics and your manager will have to talk to you and possibly issue a warning. Management speaks like they "want to help you", but they really want to help themselves climb the Anonymous ladder, and couldn't care less about their expendable employee base. Pay is very low for a financial services industry job...customer service reps are barely making $38k. And this was after a much-raved about "pay increase" that we should've been so humbled and honored to receive, for the grueling work we struggle through. 



Coaching sessions are torturous. You'll be placed in a room with your manager and possibly two to three other colleagues, to listen to each others calls, and tear them apart to bits. You are expected to adhere to a call structure and parrot the same lines, check off a certain number of transfers to certain departments, pitch a certain number of "contribution increases" to bring more money to Anonymous at the customer's expense. Managers never tell you what you did well on calls, only what you did poorly. It's not that we don't want feedback and to improve - but sometimes, we did some really nice things on the calls and want to be recognized for our positives too.



Minor technicalities are a guaranteed pull down the rabbit hole of warnings. If you have a technical error, the quality team screens more of your calls, notifies your manager, and you get a "verbal warning". They'll screen exponentially more of your calls than they do for anyone else, so that they catch more mistakes you made that everyone else makes too - regardless of how minimal they may be, the repercussions escalate very quickly. Management gets excited to prosecute their employees and never looks at the full situation when quality provides feedback. Half the time, they don't even read their emails or listen to the call, just issue a warning because you "messed up," and they don't care about your side of the story. Sometimes if you try to explain, they'll ask you to stop talking.



If you start in a phone center, you will end in a phone center. Before you begin working, management will pitch to you that the "sky's the limit" with career growth in the company, but they don't tell you about the red tape that stands between you and the sky. Anonymous sucks people in for years and years, until they don't have any speakable skills to pitch anywhere outside the company because they've been on the phones for so long, and they're stuck there. It's a culture run by unfair management who talks down to you like you're an incompetent toddler. You will be overworked, underpaid, and undervalued for all the efforts at self-betterment in this job, as it all goes to waste. If they like you, they like you. If they don't, nothing will change that. Either way, get out of there sooner rather than later. The brand name that Anonymous provides isn't worth the mental and emotional suffering of their customer service work.

Pro: great 401k match 100% match up to 7% and usually an annual 10% profit sharing match.  The Health and dental were excellent.
Con: You can be paid more elsewhere but I never felt I needed to compromise on my integrity.  Although Anonymous claims to be a meritocracy, I found that knowing the right people was more important than sales and customer service performance to one's promotability.

Pro: Easy promotion. Manager's focus on developing you to ensure more success. The benefits are amazing
Con: Heavy emphasis on meaningless stats. Some of them will only matter if you get basis points (commission) from them

Pro: Excellent benefits. 401k had 7% match and 10% profit sharing. Occasionally there is free breakfast and lunches. Room to grow in the company if you are willing to move
Con: On the surface the Financial Consultant position seems great. They give you a book of clients, there's no cold calling since they provide leads and you can make over 6 figures with average effort. But in reality it's a pure sales role with very little concern about what's right for the client. Definitely not a fiduciary advisor and the turnover is extremely high.  It's all about selling product and filling the buckets. Anonymous FCs are managed by the ever present spreadsheet. Everyone is stacked ranked and if you are below average on any category your branch manager or RPC ( who are usually inexperienced coaches that stink at sales) will come talk to you to see how to improve. The problem is there are like over 20 categories of things they measure you on. So you will always be below average in something! Another annoying thing is every click on the computer, every phone call, every email is tracked like big brother ! They also continually roll out some new method or spreadsheet and say this is the way things are going to be so get used to it. 4 months later you never hear about that spread sheet again. There is no adjustment if you are new, if you are in different markets or have a smaller or a more established book. There is a certain level of gamesmanship with the numbers too. Click here it counts, click here it doesn't even if you did the work. Talk to a client for like 30 seconds and tag their deposit and you get credit. Drop this client from your book without the client knowing and you won't get hit with an outflow.   The people who do well in the role game the system the best. All the managers are ok with this and all they care about is selling managed money, annuities and bringing in new assets. Who cares what's right for the clients. That's really the sad part the clients think you are helping but in reality you are just selling what pays you the most basis points and hope they never call you after the sale. My advice is if you get this position plan to work it for 2 years then find something else in Anonymous not in the branch network.

Pro: Anonymous has great benefits and pay very competitively. When I was there, they tried to hire and pay at the 75th percentile, so I had a lot of great coworkers. There were lots of opportunities inside the company, so it was pretty easy to stay engaged and content.
Con: It's financial services... not rocket science. Even though it's a fantastic company, I eventually got bored. I was in a smaller regional office, and there weren't a lot of opportunities to move around without moving. And I disagreed with the "culture" the local business head was creating - definitely not a Anonymous norm.

Pro: Longer term outlook for business decisions because the company is privately owned, and not run based on quarter-to-quarter results. I work with smart people, who for the most part are motivated by more than just money.
Con: There's a lot of change all the time - sometimes it's hard to operate in the environment of uncertainty, and it takes its toll on morale too.

Pro: Great benefits including help paying down student loan debt and great 401(k) match program. Friendly environment.
Con: Promotions are much more about who you know than your effort. I feel like at times I am not told the whole truth from upper management. Everyone puts on a smile, but not always genuine.

Pro: Good Benefits, flexible work schedule
Con: Promotes total benefit structure to the point it feels like they are using it in lieu of compensation increases. Easy to get lost in the corporate ladder

Recommends

Positive Outlook

I have been working at Anonymous Investments full-time (More than 10 years)

Pros

Large, privately held firm with values that are reinforced at all levels of leadership. Career opportunities are ongoing and the vast majority of people at the firm will help you progress if you're willing to do the work.

Anonymous provides exceptional benefits with options based on personal needs and various family situations. While pay and bonus structures are sometimes criticized, being patient will pay off for …
Con:
Anonymous retail is open 24 hours, causing scheduling conflicts for some candidates

Career tracks within the firm can be limited due to licensing requirements, or lack of licensing flexibility in the groups

Pro: Good environment, Work life balance, good code of ethics and values
Con: No proper/ frequent change in the pay scale as compared to the other companies. Growth within the organisation is limited.

Pro: Profit sharing, 401k match very good
Con: Management has too much power

Pro:
Great Company, respects its employees

Wonderful Company Culture
Con: Lack of growth opportunities and limited scope of work

Pro: I worked for Anonymous in a number of HR roles. I had tremendous opportunities to work with a number of different group and professionals overall. The work was stimulating and fun! I felt that I could add value in so many ways. It was one of the best places to work as an HR professional.
Con: If you don't like to be promoted and valued, then this is not the place to work.

Pro: The pay and benefits are great for the Albuquerque area, they also offer some amazing perks to inspire you to make choices.
Con:
Anonymous does not practice what it preaches.. You are told when you are hired and during training that customer service and advocating for the customer is the main goal.  That you should "own the call". However as soon as you are on the phones, you are told that once the customer is handed off to what ever dept ,  you should not be involved anymore, that you should not make too many outbound calls to the customers because we are an inbound call center , I do not consider this owning anything.  The procedures and resources are time consuming and cumbersome.  Your computer is prone to freezing when you are in the middle of a call because of all of the resources you have to have up,  and yet you can not say anything about your computer not working properly. 

  Anonymous has compassion as part of it's mission statement , yet most of the procedures could not possibly show less compassion for the customer if they tried.  In short I feel like I was lied to about the position I was hired for.   

   Management shows favoritism as well as cliquishness, and though everyone appears to be friendly it is surface only.  You never know what management expects or what they are in charge of  because it changes constantly.

Pro: This is a great place to work!  Lovely culture and office location.
Con: Nothng! This place is fantastic. Great, talented people

Pro: Process oriented, few BU's are really good in terms of compensation, work life balance. Transport facility is good.
Con: HR looks to have no rights, your concern will not be listen very high. Too much intervention of management for small small decision making. Indian management are not enough empowered. Cafeteria is horrible.

Pro: Family owned company. Great benefits, profit sharing and 401k match
Con: Low base salary when you take whole compensation package into account

Pro: Company works hard to create a pleasant environment and provide great retirement benefits, standard bonus brackets, and private stock options for excellence in performance.
Con: There is a culture at Anonymous that you have to learn.  Your main success comes from ensuring you don't walk in the door from the outside and try and lead and influence people who have been in the company 20 years without their permission first.  A bit of political advice that can go a long way  People never leave there cause their 401K keeps growing and that creates some havoc for opportunities.

Pro: Salary, benefits, growth opportunities, dedication of staff
Con: Stated values are not always supported by behavior of senior management in all divisions.  Certain divisions are in a cost cutting cycle at the expense of employees' work life balance.

Pro: Excellent place to work; great benefits
Con: None that I can think of at this time.

HSA

100% up to 7% of 401k match

Managers use fear tactics to drive numbers.

Call center environment

Outbound calls are requested by the participating companies but to the customer, it is just cold calling.

Due to the industry fears, target date funds are pushed on everyone without access to the management service so there's no actual financial advising or RIA work.

Summary: "A Really Good Company to Work For!"
Pro: Privately-held firm with tremendous values and a mission to inspire better futures for their clients, their employees and, of course, the firm itself.
Con: The con is also a pro.  Anonymous is a very conservative firm and, because of that, sometimes slow to embrace change particularly if there is risk involved.  Being risk-averse isn't necessarily a bad thing....but it can keep you from being a first mover.

Pro: Takes care of employees over and above
Con: Political agendas. Set mindset. Lack of autonomy

Pro: Very respectful employer with equality at it's core. Focused on improving associate experience with excellent opportunity to progress
Con: Due to type of industry, regulation and focus on reputation the work can be boring and little opportunity to work with new latest technologies

Pro: Good colleagues and work enviroment
Con: Bad pay and hard to progress

Pro: everything is good, people, culture etc
Con: working hours should be flexible, work from home should be allowed

Pro: Anonymous Investments is one of the top company's in the financial industry.  The firm's focus on workplace atmosphere, collaboration, career growth, benefits, and work-life balance make one of the most rewarding and enjoyable employer's.  Anonymous also regularly hires third party company's to conduct employee surveys, and that feedback is taken very seriously.  I say this because I've seen senior management respond to areas of improvement with meaningful and relevant changes that enhance the working lives of Anonymous's associates.
Con: The usual large company drawback's apply.  If you're looking to work on the most cutting edge technology or explore ways to disrupt industries, maybe it isn't the best place to work.  Although Anonymous focuses on innovation strategies and new markets, it's size means that change does not come quickly, for the most part, as there are many processes and controls wrapped around existing models. There are also significant regulations to which all players in the financial services industry must adhere, which is fine, but learning and adhering to those regulations limits flexibility.

Pro: Great company with amazing benefits
Con: Too many re-orgs and constant change

Pro: Good work/life balance, opportunities exist, the 7% match and 10% profit sharing 401k bonus are very nice, too. It is a company that is slowly but surely seeking to improve the work experience. My managers have been awesome, too.
Con: Most of the opportune moves are lateral, Anonymous takes it's sweet time on paying bonuses and raises, it is a call center job and if you don't enjoy this type of engagement, opportunities are severely limited. Not many jobs here that allow you to critically think, but rather answer questions. Most co-workers treat this as a job, rather than something they enjoy (though this is not true for all)

Pro: The company has a great amount of benefits that allow you to be successful in life. Great campus to work at and the systems are state of the art.
Con: Salary is not as competitive like other Financial firms but you can offset that with the benefits that are being offered. Company culture is great but it does depend on what department your role lands into.

Pro: Anonymous has a great culture. I have never worked at a better company. Great perks, decent pay, bonuses, amazing cafeteria, overtime and VTO always offered. Manager Apprentice program, PTO, 4 months maternity leave, loan and tuition reimbursement . I love the Employee Resource Groups. Great way to start career out of college.
Con: The job. We are answering calls from employees and retirees from well known companies. Health insurance is very difficult and the calls we get are a bit much. A huge disconnect from Anonymous and the clients. It's great to help people however we get rude callers who want something now and do not understand how insurance works, no matter how we explain it. Very stressful job and I hate to look elsewhere but the stress is not worth it all.  If you love customer service and can take calls from angry people all day then this is for you. NOT a bad company, just the Health insurance side is not a great department or position.

Pro: Great Work environment, shift options, excellent technology and trading platform.  Great Benefits.
Con: There is no vision insurance.

Pro: Great benefits, and wonderful people to work with
Con: Very competitive to get a position at an Investor Center within the area

Summary: "Great place to start, but move on"
Pro: Fantastic benefits, above average compensation, great co-workers, and lots of professional training.  Great place to start a career, but not a place to work for ever.
Con: Anonymous does believe in its employees.  I experienced it multiple times, they only believe in their name.  On the surface Anonymous appears to value its employees, but in reality they have no loyalty to its workers.  That will only become apparent after 5+ years of working for them.  The pay offset the negative aspects of the company.  You would think that there is room for advancement in such a large company.  However, that is not case.  The Pros do out way the cons for a period of time, 5-7 years.  After that, take your experience and move on.

Pro: Anonymous Investments is a great place to start your career. I started right out of college 2 years ago and the starting salaries are competitive. Plus, you get amazing benefits such as dollar for dollar match on 401K up to 7%. In addition they give you 10% of your salary for profit sharing at the end of the year. I have worked with a lot of very intelligent people that challenge me everyday to make me better. I enjoy the challenge because if we aren't helping each other improve and to learn new things a job can get stale very quickly.
Con: While the salaries are competitive at the beginning the raises are almost none existent. And, to get a promotion is even more difficult. If your looking for somewhere to grow quickly then Anonymous isn't the place for you unless your lucky. Also, there is a lot of politics involved in this company. You will see coworkers move past you that are terrible at their jobs (borderline clueless as to what is going on), but network very well and talk to the right people. This can be very discouraging to those who actually try and work hard. Because, at the end of the day your picking up their slack and they're reaping the benefits.

Summary: "Very tough and political, but you will learn a lot and be very marketable"
Pro:
- Tremendous brand name that helps your work have a big industry impact

-  Privately held company - doesn't worry about quarterlyy earnings

- Great resources to accomplish whatever you need to do

- Opportunity to grow for younger workers

- Excellent salaries and benefits
Con:
- Very tough and political organization. To be successful, you will have to be a strong corporate politician

- Not a very friendly place for older workers. The benefits and HR strategy focus on making Millenials happy while managing out older employees.  Anonymous is a great place to start your career.

- Privately held company - Since management isn't exposed to Wall Street pressure, they are slow to change.  For example, Anonymous has been a slow follower in developing online trading, launching an ETF business, creating passive investment products, and developing a robo-advisor.  The company is not innovative. It seeks to copy initiatives from other successful companies.

- Senior management is not willing to take risks. They are so well compensated that they have nos insensitive to put their lifestyles in jeopardy. 

- The company is very large.  Projects and product development have become very bureaucratic.

- Dogmatic commitment to active management.

- Products are too expensive and have seen erosion in their competitive position from companies like Vanguard

Pro: Privately owned company with huge market-share.  Anonymous still keeps the customer-first approach and believes heavily in creating a great job-experience for it's employees.  The benefits are good and they seem to be continuously looking for ways to improve upon the existing benefits package.

Pro: I love my coworkers, they are truly nice people to work with. Anonymous has excellent benefits - medical, dental, 401k with 7% percent match (though you have to be there a year to get match and work 5 years to be vested), quarterly bonuses on performance and profit sharing. I truly love Anonymous and what they stand for. I just hate the role I'm in.
Con: The role just sucks, especially if you work nights because they never hire enough people to work late nights so people can wait up to 10 minutes just for a password reset! It's a call center so it's constantly taking call after call and people can be too needy or hostile because they can't treat their retirement account like an ATM. You have to be in the role for at least a year to even be considered for other roles though it will just be another job on the phone all day. Also your calls are graded all the time and depending on your manager... it's a miracle if you do anything right on a call. Some people call in to get a balance and just because you didn't get the persons life story doesn't mean the call was "inconsistent". Metrics are so whack.

Too many layers and bureaucracy makes everything slow. Project management is stuck in the 90s.

Summary: "Good Company if You're in the Right Team"
Pro: Decent Salaries, great bonuses, great benefits, insane 401k matching, and generally fun coworkers. Anonymous tries to figure out what makes their employees happy - for example they recently started helping with student loans which was incredible. Certain teams have great dynamics and click really well with each other. There's a ton of diversity, so you get interesting perspectives from everyone.
Con: They tend to promote people based on who has the loudest mouth.  They also have a streak of hiring incompetent people and then moving them around instead of firing them. There are politics abound in most of the upper management and they try to obfuscate everything from lower employees. It is difficult to move around in Anonymous. I tried several moves, but kept getting blocked so I ended up leaving.

Pro: Great work/life balance, benefits are generous, and management really cares about their employees.
Con: Depending on location there may be caps on advancement

Pro: If you are lucky to land on a great team there will be unlimited opportunities for your personal advancement and flexibility with your work schedule. High performers stand out and are quickly recognized. Very generous profit sharing and 401K plan matching.
Con: Conversely, the wrong team manager will make your life miserable by micro managing and being completely inflexible. There are many of these new managers that do not recognize the need to manage people as individuals - instead everyone is painted with the same broad brush and treated as an inexperienced new hire.

Pro: Once off of contract the company is great! They really care for their full-time employees.
Con: May be on contract for 2+ years before being hired permanently. Little to no benefit for contractors.

Pro: Nice collaborative environment to work with. People are very friendly. New ideas and innovations  are welcomed

Pro: Great people, good benefits , great technology.

Pro: Good company culture, people care of quality of their work, a lot of collaboration, improved employee experience in the past couple of years.

Summary: "Easily the BEST run financial firm I've worked for."
Pro:
I've worked for Scottrade, T. Rowe, and a couple others and this is by far the best run company I've worked for. You meet and work with the sharpest people and business partners. The exposure to products, investment strategies and financial planning subjects provides a Graduate level education in finance. 



Who your manager is makes a difference as far as culture and our is AWESOME. And for such a massive company, they are extremely aggressive with innovation and rapidly implementing changes to drive success. Top management really knows what's going on in the field and is nimble in providing solutions. Anonymous's value proposition and products often sell themselves so driving business is very easy. A FC role is highly coveted so if you can land it then it will fast track your career at Fido as its a gateway role to many other career paths.
Con: Multi asset class managed account performance.

Summary: "i was associated with one of the worst team within Anonymous Investments Westlake TX"
Pro:
None as i know.

4 guys leaving team because of manager's cheap tricks, dirty politics and rude behavior
Con:
- Discrimination based on region, race and color

- Mood swinging decisions of service and product s need to be punished

- Sick treatment to contractors

Pro: Anonymous is serious about helping customers be ready for retirement and for their children's education expenses. The people are highly ethical, hard working and smart.

Pro: Despite its many layers and different internal organizations, Anonymous provided an overall great experience. Solid training, cutting edge technology and likely the top benefits package in the industry. Brand recognition and commitment to marketing are also great advantages.
Con: Anonymous tends to continually change the compensation plan for their reps and management teams. Very corporate culture which was always a bit heavy on conference calls and offsite meetings. Identity crisis at times in terms of promoting a sales versus customer satisfaction culture. All depends on whose in charge at the time.

Summary: "Great place to work, but its not a technology company like they believe...Software Engineer - Leap Hire"
Pro:
-Great retirement benefits

-laid back environment ( my business unit no longer has a dress code )

-great set up ( 2x 24" monitors for everyone )

-other benefits are really great (maternity/paternity leave was increased, tuition reimbursement, college loan help)
Con:
-pay, team quality, manager quality, and the projects you work on differ enormously between business units and groups within those units

-too many managers with little to no technical experience making technical decisions (my boss still thinks git and github are the same thing)

-managers seem to make decisions that please everyone vs making the right decision

-hiring process was terrible, my technical interview consisted of the following questions:

        1) is javascript a subset of java?

        2) how would you write an SQL query.

        3) what is a class?

        * this sounds awesome until you realize how dumb you could be and still get hired if this is all the knowledge you need

Those roles are primarily outside Covington - New York, Boston, Rhode Island

Summary: "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly"
Pro:
1 ~ Many would tell you the best thing about Anonymous is the people you work with and I agree. I have made several life-long friends and look forward to seeing them every day. Asking around you will find many people also found their significant others at work as well.



2 ~ Upward mobility and job opportunities. I may be biased from working at the Westlake campus where there are over 6000 jobs but it is also relatively easy to move to other locations within the company. There was a time years ago when it might have felt like you had to go to Boston to move up in the company but those days are gone and there are many great leadership positions throughout the country.



3 ~ Brand recognition you can be proud of and sleep well at night. Anonymous is a discount broker so not ripping people off with high loads or fees. They did not get caught up in the mischief so many other firms did with the mutual fund scandals or financial crisis.
Con:
The best things about Anonymous are also the worst things about Anonymous. 



1 ~ If you end up in the wrong department with the wrong boss your life can be a living hell. Anonymous is very liberal in its HR policies which can be good but also means they let things fester for a long time before taking action. There is a percentage of people that will take advantage of this and especially if you are on a small team you may end up constantly covering for a weak link.



2 ~ It is an American dream to start in the mail room and work your way up to VP someday and that is totally possible at Anonymous. In fact, it may be a bit too easy. It is completely common to attend leadership meetings and hear from senior executives "I started on the phones just like you!"  Well, that is fine once in a while but at some point you do want people leading you to actually have some training and experience. Anonymous is full of hundreds maybe thousands of Directors, VP's and SVP's that started on the phone "just like you" and it shows.



3 ~ Anonymous has managed to stay out of the news but there are plenty of unsavory things they do behind the scenes. They are currently very worried about the Department of Labor proposed Fiduciary Rule. Their current employer benefits business model is already unethical but if the rule is enacted will be illegal as well. It has long been a major IRA rollover sales lead source to take advantage of relationships with employers to gain access to employees. Anonymous is the world's largest 401k record-keeper and should this lead source be taken away it will be a huge hit to their personal investing sales model in which two thirds of the new assets are from internal rollovers. The Anonymous brokerage business would be nowhere near what it is today without having taken advantage of these workplace business relationships.

Con:
No loyalty 

In the 12 years i worked here i was NEVER once asked whether or not my manager was doing a good job.  There is really no tangible process for promotion, pay increases, bonuses.  If your manager likes you and you have a decent relationship then you get raises & bonuses.   I have never seen so many mgmt people afraid of conflict, afraid to tell employees they were not performing, etc.  The culture is one of fear to tell the truth, when people are asked they do not tell the truth because they fear retaliation.   I personally sat in a senior mgmt meeting and heard a Sr. VP, tell another manager to tell her minions to stop sending feedback to Sr. Mgmt, they may ask for it but dont really want to hear it.  When they downsized a few yrs back they laidoff some of the best most knowledgeable talent, i suspect bcuz they made the most money, but many left were clueless which meant that those remaining had to do twice as much and cover the clueless.   When employees are having heart attacks in their cubicles something is very wrong

Pro: 401k plan is awesome! Company has great benefits. Schedule was flexible.  I learned a ton while working there.   I would recommend working there to anyone interested in financial services
Con: Sometimes there's to many layers of management.  Updates to procedures can take a long time one an improvement has been agreed upon.

Pro: As mentioned, great benefits. 7% match and 10% profit sharing. If you do 7% your going to be putting away 24% of your total pay into retirement which is great.
Con:
Their Portfolio Advisory Service (PAS) is the key product along with annuities that you are pressed to sell. They train you really well on how to overcome the objections of Clients. You get paid 0.07% or 7 basis points for every dollar you put into these products - JUST ONE TIME - there is a tiny bonus based on Retention. The worst part is that every one in the Financial Consultant role knows the product is terrible and underperforms consistently by 1.5%-2.2% on a yearly basis. If you work here, prepare to exchange your conscious for your paycheck. 



Management will talk trash about you after you leave, there is no loyalty. You will work with 400 Clients, the best Financial Consultants don't develop deep relationships with Clients because you don't have the capacity to do that because you must sell about $36 million a year at a minimum in their garbage products.

Pro: Strong culture, beautiful campus, great leadership team.  Lot's of talented people to work with.
Con: Lack of upward mobility, and other cons typically associated with larger firms.  Nothing specific, although the industry has been challenging lately.

Pro:
'LEAP' - Their technologist graduate program is exceptional. 6 months of training, 4 of which are classroom based. Professional external trainers teaching everything form agile to public speaking to Spring MVC. They invest heavily in their young talent, and it pays. 



Salary was competitive as a grad (in my location at least), as are annual salary increases (I averaged 8-10% per year entering as a grad - in several smaller bumps - enough even to stay on par with peers who job-hopped!) though I don't know how that scales for higher-ups. The performance/review process is formalized and well run. 



The work environment is very good - flexible work hours, good work/life balance, very little tolerance for toxic behaviour, good people, I usually work 40 hours and leave the office at 5 most days.
Con:
As a technologist, the office is still very male-dominated - though this is a problem everywhere for software engineers. 



A lot of the salary/bonus structure is very clearly tied up in the overall company performance. During a recession  or market downturn, the salary/bonus experience may be very different. 



There seems to be a lot of politicking in the upper-management. My team felt this through frequent group re-orgs, initiative changes, sudden U-turns on key priorities etc.

Pro: Benefits are great. PTO is decent
Con: A lot of management turnover

Summary: "Depends where you are in your life"
Pro: Good benefits. Co-workers are nice. Work is super easy and doesn't take much time if you are smart. Great for coasting into retirement.
Con:
Not a good place for people who are implied leaders. It's a very top-down culture. You have no budget even as a VP, no freedom to push outside the "Anonymous way". Most people have been here for the last 20 years and it shows how out of touch these leaders are with how workforce of today looks at leadership and work in general. Long tenured middle managers and individual contributors also show a strange indentured servitude behavior. Many don't have the spine to say the truth, stand up for their beliefs and do the right thing. The culture is to sugar coat bad news and push all decision making as far up as possible. 



This might be fine if you come from a top-down, command and control culture. If you have worked in a culture of empowerment, this will be a stifling place. 



The company is headed towards uncharted territory but people up top lack the will to get rid of the "leadership" crud that only knows status-quo and actively tries to stonewall new ideas. A vast majority started their careers in phone sales - so they are not equipped for todays and tomorrows world. It will be an extremely hard task to correct the current heading of this ship. Drastic measures are needed to clean house but I doubt it will happen. I am waiting to see what happens in the next year.



Again, if you are a young, go-getter this might not be a place for you.  If you want to build a career that enables you to work in another company later, don't count on developing yourself as a leader here. If you want to be told what to do and just want to spend a few more years until retirement, this place is great and has excellent benefits.

Pro: Very good company and benefits. Cares about its employees
Con: Large company structure forcing groups to have cookie cutter procedures

Summary: "Benefits are great, but NOT worth it."

Summary: "This USE to be the Best Place to Work.  Now, not so much"
Pro: You are surrounded by smart people and will learn a lot.  You will most certainly get experience that will translate to any other financial services firm in the world.
Con: They have everyone at each others necks now for survival.  What use to be an environment of constant improvement and making things better for investors is now an every man for himself environment with everyone worried about saving their own skin.  It is tragic what has happened to the once premiere investment firm to work for in New England.

Pro: Great compensation, very good benefits.  The company is privately owned, so you are not constantly worried about the vicissitudes of the shareholders and whether it's an up or down quarter.  Don't get me wrong, they very much care about making money, but it's not the same grind as a public company.  Their eyes are focused on the customer as the one to please, not the shareholders.
Con: There are really great organizations within Anonymous, but there are also some organizations that are horrible.  Where I worked before I left they had no management skills.  EVPs would have a tantrum at meetings - yelling at the attendees.  They nitpicked everything, and never showed any appreciation when you completed a project.  Other cons include the fact that you have to have all your investments at Anonymous or jump through hoops for compliance.  You also cannot mention that you work for Anonymous on social media.  You have to have all your political contributions and volunteering activities preapproved.  I guess that's standard for financial services, but it's still a con as far as working environment.  It's hard to know where they are going with the Merrimack site.  They keep moving the technology jobs to North Carolina.

Pro: good benefits and work balance.

Pro: Vacation, 401k match, insurance, Licensing
Con:
Anonymous caters to new hires. They are like comcast: Throw the world at you if you are a new employee, but the people that have worked here and put their time in, and actually contribute to the company are rewarded with the opportunity to do more work.

 Every benefit is designed to get people in the door.  New hires got a  12% bump in pay, plus a signing bonus of $2500.   I have worked here for almost 10 years and I get to do my job, the help desks job, and the new hires job, and don't get so much as a thank you. Too much middle management that has no idea what goes on on the phones.   Work is not challenging.  Roles are not defined. Who does what... No one knows.  

Meet your sales number? Here's a Snickers bar.

Pay is low.  

I'm sure that there are some people that enjoy their work, but in the Active Trader  group, the morale is low, attitudes are awful, and suggestions are ignored.

Work site is in a horrible location- every time you go outside, you are accosted by homeless people for money.  Building is not owned by company.

Pro:

Con:

Pro:
- Generous compensation: overtime is available (and expected during tax season), company match is great if you stay with the company for more than one year, quarterly bonuses that can be up to 200% of goal provided you hit your metrics.

- Licensing training is next to none and you will be very prepared for your daily work. Great way to build knowledge of finance.

- Lots of chances at upper mobility as long as you are willing to work for it.
Con:
- Working on the phones can get a little dry after a while. Management seems to be aware of this though and they are attempting to improve employee experience.

- What you are able to do for customers is limited as a function of your position in the company. Thus, until you reach a higher position, you don't necessarily get to do a lot of the fun things. This can also lead to customers feeling like they are getting the run-around.

Summary: "Ok career for someone just out of college"
Pro: Good benefits. If you can survive your first year and move on to other departments it gets better.
Con: Company is very big and slow to change. My director was out of touch of the business and results were overlooked. She was never around and only concerned about her career.

Summary: "Great expereience but not so great pay"
Pro: The people I worked with were very kind and open to my questions
Con: The pay is a bit below industry standards but management is attempting to balance that with benefits

Summary: "Look Elsewhere if you want to Enjoy Your Job"
Pro: Perks at Anonymous is 10% profit sharing, 7% match, lots of positions and places to go within the company so you think you would be able to find something that you like, best thing was learning about investments for my own personal use moving forward though...
Con:
Anonymous chips away at your soul. By far the worst culture in any place I've worked, and sadly its improved from it was when I started.   Know multiple people that currently work and have worked there that don't like there job, but sometimes stay because handcuffed by the money they make, me being part of that group for awhile. 



-Expected to work lots of OT in sales jobs.

-Lower Pay than comparable jobs.

-Very tedious and repetitive for most phone sales positions.

-Manager half the time doesn't even know your role so that can't help or teach you other than to tell you to work harder, more OT, or give suggestions that have no tangible merit behind them. Part of that is because of the change that happens so often and never gives groups stability within the company.

-Worked there for six years and only ever knew the people directly around me.  Its ironic as you talk to people all day yet you don't get to know anyone at the job unless your in a higher up positions where you have more leeway to be off the phone for a few minutes.

-Entry job is into service group is awful, super strict on when you can go to lunch, break.  Basically no flexibility.

-Each move up the ladder did get slightly better but its not a good thing when you have to get 4 or 5 promotions before you say to yourself this job is alright.

Pro: Excellent benefits, decent salary and bonus
Con: Long hours, unrealistic workload is expected.  "Do more with less" is the new motto.  Previously focused on quality, but due to competitive pressures, efficiency is top priority.

Summary: "Large company that provides all of the resources needed"
Pro: Anonymous is a very large company that provides lots of opportunities for career development and advancement. They have a history of filling openings with internal candidates. Benefits are great and they have a culture that encourages strong collaboration. Technology is the best that I have seen and they are constantly looking to plan 5 years ahead in order to constantly improve business.
Con: Opportunities to transfer can be limited if you restrict your search to one location. Company has a history of layoffs which can impact job security if an employee is not performing a critical role. On the plus side, they provide a generous severance package. Don't regret working there as the experience was great.

Pro: Fantastic benefits w/ 401k match and profit sharing, generous PTO, HMO and high deductible insurance options, tuition reimbursement and student loan payoff assistance.
Con: Though it is a meritocracy, politics tend to be important in upward mobility. They have become a little more friendly to parents in the workplace with some departments offering reduced hours, but its typically in lower-level positions so once you've advanced to well-paying positions, you have to take a significant pay cut to keep working.

Pro: Benefits. 10% profit share and 7% 401k match. Flexibility. Open door policies with most of upper management and willing to help you progress career.
Con: Sales team underpaid relative to peers. Located in middle of nowhere in Smithfield, RI. Not a sales role, only care about how many clients you talk to.

Pro: Great company with lots of opportunity for advancement and career changes with god benefits, and good pay. I worked at the company for over 10 years and learned a lot about retail and B2B investments. Have a few FINRA licenses (24,65, 63, 7, 31, and Insurance) and was working towards my CFP that was supported and sponsored. There are also lots of internal and OTJ trainings. Plenty of great people and some pretty awesome financial industry leaders. It's a privately owned company so if they want to pursue something they don't have to get the stock holder's buy in and they allow the employees to provide input on a lot of the process and employee engagement improvements that are currently in place. Overall it's a very dynamic culture constantly changing.
Con: Super lager company so you could feel like just another worker and that your voice doesn't count. At times the hiring process when moving between roles can be a bit monotonous (in that it's a hurry up to wait months situation). Overall it's a very dynamic culture and constantly changing so if change is not what you like this probably isn't for you.

Pro: free coffee, good co-workers in the office.

Pro: Good profit sharing and retirement benefits
Con: None I can think of

Pro: very structured compoany, great benefits, work schedule, flexibility, learning opportunities, they pay for graduate school or other degrees or courses plus they have internal certifications
Con: horizontal hierarchy,  not much room to grow at the site i worked it was a site director, a lot of managers who reported to her and then everybody else. but still a good place to start your career and Anonymous always looks good on your resume

Pro: Great benefits, good pay, loved the team that I worked with, plenty of opportunities to do over-time, etc.
Con: There wasn't much growth potential for me, unless I wanted to leave my department and pursue an actual desk job [which I didn't]. There, otherwise, weren't many cons to this job.

Pro: Overall a very good company with great benefits and potential career growth if you are willing to move across the country, depending on your business unit.   Also, this is a great company in which to start your career.
Con: Very large organization with business units in all facets of financial services to the point that, in some cases, they compete within Anonymous for the same business.  In the branch network, the employee needs to be very careful about the manager of the branch.  There are some managers that are not equipped to deal with people.  The one I worked with tended to treat everyone like they are small, errant children regardless of age and/or experience.  I had worked in a different business unit for a number of years that had very qualified managers who knew how to manage and motivate adults .

Summary: "Good company of you're in the right organization"

Con: Cliquey culture in some parts of the organization prioritizes who you're friendly with over your contributions.

Pro:
Great paid training program to pass 7 & 63 licencing exams. They pay you to study and train you well with an extremely high pass rate for the exams. 



Continued training and development is very good. 



A lot of good benefit programs like loan repayment, computer reimbursement, bonuses, 6 weeks of paternity leave, a lot of other random benefits that are great.
Con:
Very restrictive on personal trading. If you like to trade in your own account they restrict the number of trades you can do per quarter to about 60. This might not matter to some people but for others it is restricting. 

They limit you to long only positions in your personal account unless using it as a hedge. You can short index ETFs. Again this might not matter to some people but could be restrictive if you like to trade.



Overall it is a very mundane job. Some people love it and it is a great fit but you are tied to a desk and a phone which did not work for me.

Pro: Experience varies widely based on groups. On the tech side PI is one of the most modern whereas FI is stuck in the early 1990s. My group is excellent and for Anonymous we are on the cutting edge. Work life balance is great - in general the management is very flexible. There are politics but a good manager will shield the developer from this. If you can prove your valuable by innovating Anonymous will take notice - if you do nothing new then you will stagnate. Base compensation is on the lower end of what a developer could make elsewhere but the wide array of benefits, especially the contributions to 401k (7% match and generally 10% profit sharing) are unheard of. Senior management seems to have a clear vision of what they want but the execution on it by middle management is variable.
Con: So much of Anonymous's tech is old and maintaining, enhancing the existing systems and building new capabilities requires lots of investment which up until the year the company had been pouring money into. In my opinion some of this money was wasted on buying expensive vendor products from the likes of IBM and Oracle that could have been done without paying for a license. Another issue is Anonymous still hires too many useless contractors and unnecessary project managers.

Pro: Good training program, private company with good job security
Con: This is a call center and you will be on the phone ALL DAY LONG.  There are no jobs in this co.that don't require you to be on the phone all day long regardless of the job title.  Benefits are great if you can stay for the 5 year vesting schedule which 90% of the people don't bc of burn out.  That's why the benefits are great bc no one ever vests so they never get paid out.  You get 1-2 hours off the phone per WEEk....not per day.  Eventually you can't take being on the phone anylonger and you either leave or get burnt out which effects your performance.   Pay is lower than industry average and the main goal of all 1000 employees is to get one of the 50 or so jobs that don't require one to be on the phone all day.  These non phone jobs rarely come up and competitive is fierce.   Decent job for first time out of college person looking to gain experience and then leave.  Also, everything is based on phone metrics so keep your headset on and don't drink much water bc that will require you to go to the bathroom and hurt your phone metrics.

Summary: "If you're looking at the Financial Rep Role, read this."
Pro: Decent benefits(which they've recently begun to cut back on). It's a mellow work culture, your co-workers are quite friendly and helpful in general, it's not a cutthroat environment at all. You will learn a lot at this job, and they do foster development within the constraints they provide. They're incredibly flexible with scheduling and accommodating for sick days etc, which is a huge plus for me.
Con:
This pertains specifically to the Denver site, but is also relevant to the role as a whole;





1) In the FR role you're essentially forced to burnout. The efficiency metrics are high, and when you good at the role you will take 70-100 calls a day. If you haven't done this before, you have no idea how exhausting it can be, people are pissy, impatient and dump their problems in your lap every day. Despite having a Series 7, you will quickly learn you're not really a stock broker, you're a frontline customer serviced rep in a call center. I rarely trade, most of my day is spent playing clean up with banking,tech support or paperwork issues while playing damage control with inconvenienced clients. You will quickly learn how insane people can be, you WILL have a client cussing and irrationally berating you because you can't make their check clear on a Sunday. 



2) The career opportunities are narrow, particularly for the Denver site. During training they will tell you that everyone is promoted within 4-5 months, and some promoted out of the training class. This is misleading at best. I'm a top performer in the site and now over a year in role, there are serious issues with favoritism in hiring, I've seen stellar candidates passed over countless times. Even with a promotion, it doesn't change the fact that 90% of jobs are on the phone. It's not easy to be leashed to a phone for 8 hours at a time, there are no projects, or tangible accomplishments, your tasks are often monotonous and dry.



3) There's a massive morale problem in the role, more than half the people I talk to are actively seeking other employment or are despondent and burnt out. If you don't drink the company Kool - Aide 100% (which you never should at any job) you will quickly see a lot of the problems with the business decisions, common practices and client t treatment are frustrating. With this being said, there are people who enjoy the job, and stay in it for years, just be very self aware when you consider the job. 



4) For the licenses, you're underpaid compared to the industry. They justify this by giving you a "culture" that is superior. To a degree it's accurate, compared to other phone sites and financial firms, it's pretty decent. 



5) Your central metric, upon which bonuses and promotions are centrally focused, are customer surveys, which are graded irrationally and unfairly. You can correlate higher, but it is largely random, and it can be infuriating.

Pro: The ability to personally contribute to a leading financial services firm and the undisputed number one online broker, structured call model that allows for personalized customization, tons of exceptional products/services to offer clients, great deal of PTO each year, enormous opportunity for voluntary overtime, tasty cafeteria food at reasonable prices, beautiful campus, tremendous opportunity to work in different business units at the phone sites.
Con: Call center drudgery, uninspiring site leadership, inadequate work reference material, broken service satisfaction grading model, zero authentic corporate culture, working for a firm as risk-averse as Anonymous is cumbersome.

Pro: Outstanding benefits package. Very positive corporate culture.
Con:
Ever ask yourself  "How can I waste my finance degree AND make myself less marketable at the same time?" Well, have I got a job for you! Sarcasm aside, let's just be brutally honest here. COLLEGE STUDENTS/GRADS PAY ATTENTION!!! Unless you plan to become an advisor (cough...salesman), most of the jobs you will find in the world of personal investments/brokerage services are going to be a CALL CENTER JOB! This is just the nature of the beast, yet something that your career counselor at college probably wont tell you. Call center experience is only a marketable skill to more customer service jobs.  I have worked at Anonymous for several years and can honestly say that I feel I have wasted years of my life doing something I have grown to absolutely despise. Dealing with customers on the phone is a life-draining experience. So let's bring it back to Anonymous, shall we? Would you like a real-life sample of what your job will consist of as a "Financial Representative" or "Customer Advocate" at Anonymous? Well, say no more!:



8:00 a.m. - Distribution check request.

8:10 a.m. - Hour long password reset with 90 year old client. (College degree hard at work!)

9:10 a.m. - Distribution check request.

10:10 a.m. - Help client find tax form online. 

10:15 a.m. - Why wont my debit card work?

10:25 a.m. - Why wont my credit card work?

10:35 a.m. - Complex multi-leg option trade.

10:45 a.m. - 30 minute password reset with 80 year old client. ( I went to college for this?)



Now rinse and repeat this for 30 calls a day, day in and day out. Not exactly what you pictured yourself doing with that shiny, expensive college education, is it?

Look...I could go on and on about other details of the job (particularly the wacked-out survey questionnaire Anonymous bases a large portion of your bonus on) but I'll leave that for some other disenchanted soul. Here is the bottom line...if you want to do sales, that is great for you and you will find many career opportunities at any brokerage firm, including Anonymous, and you will make a great living doing so. However, if sales is not your thing then I highly suggest you look elsewhere.

Pro:
*Good benefits



*18 days of PTO right off the bat (sick and personal days are combined).



*Friendly, helpful, and intelligent co-workers



*Loose attitude towards using cell phone at work, as long as you're doing your job



*Quarterly bonuses are based off of customer service, not sales



*Training is paid and very, very thorough



*$2500 bonus for passing licencing exams



*If you're moving more than 50 miles for accepting the position, they will give you a relocation package. But, you have to ask BEFORE you sign the acceptance agreement. You will not be eligible for the package if you have already signed.



*Work stays at work, no home-work



*Voluntary and unpaid days off for when call volumes are low, typically come up during the summer
Con: This is a CALL CENTER, you will spend 7.5 hours a day taking INBOUND CALLS for at least half of the year with no breaks in between. They will tell you when you get hired that you can be promoted within a few weeks, that only applies to 1% of employees, and they usually have years experience in the industry. And if you do get promoted, all they do is change your title, give you a very small pay increase, and stick you back on the inbound phone line. Usually takes about 3-5 years to get off the inbound phone line, as most of the non call center positions are filled with external hires. They will give you a list of regular ol' business day schedules before you sign, then change your schedule to something vastly different when you get licenced.The sign in bonus is great, until you find out that you have to stay at Anonymous for more than a year to avoid repayment. It seems like they are using it as a tool to artificially increase retention. This job is VERY monotonous, and you will be burnt out after 4-5 months after completing training. Most people in the office are either trying to get into a position where they aren't on the phones, then applying elsewhere when they find out there are none. Service reps are the front line, so when other groups have meetings and off phone work between calls, you will not. Constantly changing rules about what you can/can't do on the phone, and very little communication about changes. The worst part is watching upper management coming in 30 min late and leaving 30 min early, while you are tied to your phone, taking inbound phone calls from slightly rude people for over 7 hours a day.

Pro: They contribute 17% of your income to your 401k, on top of your contribution. Great health insurance.
Con: Very resistant to change. An attitude of "We've made it, so there's nothing to improve." They send out surveys to customers but disregard any input that doesn't praise them.

Pro: Benefits.  Great 401k match and profit sharing
Con: No on campus gym in SLC

Summary: "By the name company standard is good but It's stressful work culture."
Pro:
1.Good infrastructure, company standard is high. 
2. Decent hike and facilities. 
3. Open culture and no bosses rule. 
4. U will get opportunity to understand different technologies. 
5. Good Internal Job postings.
Con:
1. Pathetic canteen, U don't get anything apart from lunch time. 
2. Growth is slow due to tons of HR policies(ex : join as associate wait for 18 months to complete in the team as per the policy,  in order to go different team after that get 6 months grace period to apply for different team if u didn't get different team, then u have to accept promotion as software again u blocked for 18 months,  so from associate to software and staying in software engineer u will end up 4 years in the company, forget about senior it will take 4+2 to become senior and 6+4 to lead) now u guys understood slow growth means. 
3. Work load is high, no appreciation for the work you do. 
4. If you join this company as an senior software engineer then salary is good, mid level it's as same as other company standards. 
5. Approval for each and every idea, first of all manager don't appreciate your ideas they just listen and implement themselves and take there name.

Summary: "Call Center Representative: Great Coworkers, Somewhat Unpleasant Work"
Pro:
Wonderful, kind coworkers. 

Wonderful people in upper and lower management.

Some of the customers are the sweetest people you will ever speak with.

Really understanding and accommodating for disabilities (mental and otherwise!).

Great CEO.

Room for Growth.
Con:
The same problems as most call center work: 

The call center should have a more regular office-like environment and employees should be able to take their time with customer cases-- including necessary off-the-phone time (such as faxing, e-mailing, and account maintenance) without having to jump through hoops to do so.

The customers can be difficult to deal with and really unkind. Most people will be reasonable, but each day there are bound to be at least a few calls in which people are truly frustrated and you just have to have a thick skin about it or find another job.

Like with any job, there is always one manager who is very difficult to deal with. In the case of where I worked, this team manager ended up making the majority of her team quit because of her attitude. I'm lucky that I was placed with one of the other, excellent managers instead of her.

Pro: Flexible hours - just get the work done. Surround yourself with smart hard working people, even if outside your group, and you will do well
Con: A lot of middle management and wondering what people actually do to provide value

Pro: As a ~20 year employee holding a variety of positions, the quality of people has always been outstanding. I've worked for (and with) some tremendous talent, and I've had the opportunity to lead some great people. I've also developed relationships that will last. Anonymous offers great benefits and the work environment and amenities are 2nd to none
Con: The work culture and expectations have become increasingly demanding and it's not uncommon to see e-mails (and sometimes phone calls) at all hours and through the weekend. Senior Teams are under a great deal of pressure to perform, and as a result, Anonymous feels more like a machine and less like the community it was 5 or 10 years ago.

Con: Behind the curve in terms of the amount of time it takes to implement a solution or roll out a new product.

There is reasonable work-life balance compared to many other managerial jobs.
Con:
- Below-market pay at mid-level and senior manager positions

- Bureaucratic and byzantine structure - lots of layers and siloed groups

- Can be political - more about who you know and how you're perceived than the actual quality of your work / ideas

If you have the right manager, you can last there for a few years and you will want to because of all the great benefits. But when you start to feel like you don't even want to say "Hi" to the Publix cashier, thats your sign to either move into a more challenging role or time to get out.

Pro: Great benefits, ample opportunity for growth
Con: Anonymous has a reputation for chewing people up and spitting them out.  There's a high turnover rate and you're typically either there for a very short time or for years if you can cut it.  During my lengthy multi-year tenure, Anonymous's focus went from a very high level of efficient customer satisfaction fading into higher and higher efficiency to the point of rushing people off the phone if they had no outside assets to consolidate.  Higher level management tends to be aloof as to the customer and employee concerns/issues that reps are having to face daily on the front lines, oftentimes blindly making decisions with no idea or regard as to the unintended consequences that negatively affect employees and customers.  Advancement is based on merit to a degree, but company politics and who you know is much more important despite management's efforts to thwart this.

Con: Due to the nature of the financial industry and a large financial firm that has been around for over 70 years, it can be difficult to innovate and move quickly on new projects due to a lot of legacy software. Summary: "Challenging work, but 0 support from management when needed."
Pro: The work was challenging and you learned something new on a daily basis.  There was plenty of room for growth and development within the role.  There was such a sense of satisfaction doing the analytical work and keeping the client satisfied with Anonymous's record keeping of their HW benefits.
Con: No work/life balance.  No support from management.  You are set up for failure if you are passionate about your work.  If you're good at your job then you are loaded down with the work of other employees that don't do well in their roles.  You are then given an impossible amount of tasks to complete in a deadline that will not be met, and you're given little to no support.  If you don't mine working 65 to 75 hours a week in order to keep up with the workload then this will be the place for you.  However, if you do not enjoy working weekends, holidays, cancelling vacations, etc. for work on a constant basis then look elsewhere, because management will really look down on you for not sacrificing everything to meet their impossible expectations.
