Summary: "A Job to nowhere with a very low compensation at all levels"
Pro:
Mostly good honest people to work with. Diverse.

A good company for entry levels positions (but that's it).

Very nice and large campuses nationwide.

Can jump between departments if you want to make a change (but mostly horizontal movement that can last for years with no pay change)
Con:
The fund a accounting group methodology of work is one big mess of excel spreadsheet macros with errors written by very few people at Anonymous and hold the knowledge and responsibility of why/what this job is about. The rest just push buttons and fake it. 

If you took 1-2 finance classes in college you will probably learn nothing new to help you in the industry. The monitoring and problem solving skills learned are 100% based on troubleshooting of departmental chaotic/confused processes of using excel and/or internal softwares. 

Managers don't (mostly) have any managerial skills or passion to manage and do so in order to climb the latter. In reality, they are analysts who stayed at Anonymous the longest (or when everybody else left after 2-3 years). 

Those who leave (which is almost all employees except managers) do so after realizing they will never be able to support an adult life/family with the low pay (including all "unique benefits"). 



In conclusion, 

To demonstrate the shortsightedness and focus on internal computer troubleshooting I will use this fact: Most managers and directors can tell you a lot about how to find a variance due to miscalculation of an Excel's spreadsheet formula but no very little to nothing about the stock market, bond market, and most importantly the nature of mutual fund investing. 



After a while it becomes a very sad, and discouraging, work environment. 

Not a long-term company for go getters

Summary: "Overall Great Company, Truly Hampered By Floor Managers"
Pro: The total compensation including benefits and 401k contributions is good. As a phone representative the number one benefit is the colleagues that share the role and the customers we get to hear from. Really enjoy the interactions with the diverse active and retiree populations!
Con:
Huge downside at the Durham NC location. Many of the floor managers are unprofessional and constantly an impediment to helping the customer and helping employees develop. This is the first and only organization that I have worked for that will actually discourage you from applying to an open position within the firm. Has happened on a few occasions now and so appears to be the norm where to apply you need to go through current manager and they never follow up to discuss or confirm if an intent letter was forwarded.



Most of the managers I have interacted with were never able to answer serious inquiries on customer accounts and push back greatly when a customer requests to speak to them. Very sad to think I could be treated that way when calling in as a customer.



These same individuals are commonly loud in the call center environment where it is common to not be able to hear the customer on the line. Just recently I had to put a customer on hold while doing a death notification because I did not feel it appropriate for the caller to hear the loud laughing from a manager and team leads. This is a very common occurrence at this location. Finally, quite a few give me the impression that they do not do much at all during the day besides going to the gym (1+ hr), out to lunch (1 hr), listening to calls, and meetings. Back to the serious customer issues, have only had one manager that ever seemed to care about the issue and helped to get it resolved.



At this time it does appear this situation as a whole is why I will leave Anonymous and transfer all funds immediately thereafter.

Pro: great people, benefits, and culture

Pro:
Great benefits.

Job security - second to none. Working in Finance and providing guidance or customer service is a job that only gets more secure as the economy gets worse.
Con:
Completely undervalued - we were told for over 1 year that we would get raises and we did not. All the other groups in my business function received pay raises, and 3 or 4 other functions in the company did the same job as my group, and they got paid 20-50% more. The only time I felt like anyone cared that I was working my tail off was when I announced that I was quitting.

Overworked - you are tethered to your phone, and you are required to take inbound calls constantly. It is a call center.

"Sales" - you are consistently told that you are in a sales function, you have a quota to hit, and you are held to metrics. However, you have no control over what phone calls you take or what customers you talk to, and the environment and pay are not reflective of a sales function.

Pay - the pay was pathetic compared to the rest of the industry/rest of the company.

Budget cuts - we were not allowed to work overtime, but our sales goals were raised.

Inconsistency - calls were transferred to my function by other sales roles. Those sales roles had very little idea what customers needed or wanted, and we were restricted from giving any type of pushback. We were required to take all calls that came to us, regardless of whether the customer's questions were in our job description.

Promoting based on politics - I saw multiple instances of people getting promoted that did not deserve the job. There was an explicit instance that I witnessed where someone was hired into a position because they were a woman, even though they were less qualified than another candidate (who happened to be male) - management made an explicit comment that they wanted to hire a woman to the position.

Summary: "Good introduction to retail finance. But this a call center through and through. Do not be deceived"
Pro:
-extensive training program
-licensing help
-good introduction to finance
-genuinely nice coworkers 
-good computer systems 
-get to be a customer as well
Con:
-extreme micromanagement 
-does not care for ability or knowledge, only that you meet your call metrics. There is a person on my team that has to call for help over 10 times a day, but no worries  because they take 50 calls. 
-job goes from remedial customer service work to having to explain complex investing and tax strategies.. no consistency in service. 
-management is all about the flavor of the day: for a couple of months it was having great conversations with clients, then it was all about having a good workplace to be in.. now it's about taking as many calls as humanely possible with no rest. 
-management likes to hype up the small things.. like wireless headsets, or taking a break when you want to... but they will pass a long all bad news to the lower level managers and will not face the front line reps at all. They refuse to hear any criticism on policy updates. Some are so far removed from helping any client that it's comical what they expect.
- lately they have been devaluing the high net worth service reps. They used to allow for casework and follow up on issues, but they've tossed that in favor of handling as many clients as possible. So now the client with 2 mill as equal standing as client with 2k. 
-management treats all reps the same, no matter fresh out the dorm room or seasoned worker. Can be frustrating..
-this is not a role to stay in for long. Go the sales route. Stay away from customer service. 
-refuse to be competitive in pay
- bonuses are a joke.. almost insulting 
- if all else fails, other firms in town have better pay.

Summary: "Worst environment I've ever seen for UX designers"
Pro: Oh, none. I'm sure other departments are better — it's a big company. Also, the Starbucks and front desk people are very nice.
Con: Horrible, horrible environment. I've been in enterprise UX design for years, and I've never seen something so bad. First, most of the "design" team doesn't come from a software design background (think "first job after local graphic design agency") — they have very strange, inefficient, and ingrained processes. Members of management are emotionally volatile, manipulative, and aggressive to the point of creating a truly unhealthy environment (something I wouldn't say lightly). There is an incomprehensible Mean Girls culture where no one talks to each other openly and everyone throws their other team members under the bus to get ahead. I walked out of this job (something I never thought I would do) and I can't recommend it to anyone.

Pro: There is some great talent and fun people to work with at Anonymous. The company has good benefits and fairly good pay. I got some great experience starting my career here. I grew thick skin dealing with the daily client abuse. Training is good, they will hold your hand and spoon feed you through anything to get you certified.
Con: Welcome to Corporate America. Promotions can be a nightmare with hurry up and wait mentality. sometimes there will be 6 months between job opportunities. In Denver there is a very limited amount of opportunities, managers will tell you to move to the east coast if you don't like the jobs available. Trade support will witch hunt you if you get a trade error, even if its for 1 cent. Trade errors are used to punish employees and lowers your chances of getting promoted. Managers will use fear tactics to push the bottom line which has more to do with customer surveys than anything else if you are in service. I wish I could write some of the profanity the customers will say to you over the phone, truly horrific dealing with the general public. Training in large classes of 20+ young professionals feels a lot like high school and its not ideal for education. Classes tend to get "clicky" and like managers, the facilitators always have their favorites. Unless you are a great "suck up" don't expect to get promoted based on your merits here.

Con:
I originally found this job posting when searching for Hospitality related jobs. Hospitality professionals, BEWARE. They are going to tell you that you don't need a finance background and that they can teach you everything you need to know. This is not all together true. They are going to train you the absolute minimum that they can, and then they throw you onto the phones. 



This is not a customer service position. It's sales. Most of the calls are awful, and people pretty much yell at you all day for things that are completely out of your control.  Need help? Call your help desk that's most likely to belittle you and make you feel like an idiot. It's bad enough that customer's are rude, but any other department you call for guidance is rude too. 



Have a bad day? Well, everyone is going to know about it. They send out a stack rank email every day with your calls handled, hold time, after call work time and survey score to your entire time. Oh, the survey score scale rating goes like this: Highest score = 100%, and not the highest score = 0%. Seems fair right? Even better, they ask three questions, one of them being satisfaction with rep, and it doesn't even count. The only one you get scored on is the one that asks about their overall experience. 



I understand that this job is just not for some people, as I found out pretty quickly. I was told that advancement could happen quickly, however the path to an off-phone role can take years. This is why so many people seem jaded when I was in training, but I didn't see the red flags quick enough. 



Also, you get a 30 minute break and a 30 minute lunch for an eight hour shift. You have to use your break time to go to the bathroom so it doesn't eat up your after call work and effect your metrics. You pretty much feel like a kindergarten that's being monitored consistently.

Summary: "Anonymous is a good company to work for"
Pro: Trustworthy company, professional atmosphere, good benefits (401K match, profit sharing, bonuses and more), good people.  In Covington KY location - on site medical office, full cafeteria (breakfast, grill, deli, salad bar, entrees and Starbucks coffee), on site gym, no dress code, beautiful campus
Con: Can be hard to get hired, temp if you have to, but don't give up if it's what you want.   Best way to get in the door without temping is to be willing to work a phone shift.  If you can get in the door, you can have a fulfilling career here.

Communication with management can be very poor. When I took my job I was told it would support my Series 7 license however 6 months later I was told it would no longer be supported and I would lose it.

Summary: "Supportive growth, red tape being cut, and innovation focused"

The campuses are beautiful and well kept, the people give hours and hours of volunteer work because Anonymous cares and allows it, and everyone I've met has very little reason to want to go somewhere else.
Con: You're in an office. If you don't like sitting at a desk and knocking out work within a cubicle then this isn't the most modern work space. Changes are in place to move everyone to a more creative space but it's not quite happening yet. However, you can get out and move around and take walks around the campus (if you are not in Boston) to refresh.

Pro: Well run company.   They will help you achieve success, however you define it.

Pro: They pay you while you study for your exams.  Only positive
Con:
The firm constantly states how conservative and honest they are, but that is only in regards to their clients, not employees.  Upper management constantly lies about anything and everything.  False promises across the board.  Stated that simply working a full calendar year qualifies you for their 10% profit sharing payout.  After a year of work, told we wouldn't be receiving the payment because we missed the "deadline" that was never mentioned.  When speaking to managers/directors about why this was never mentioned to us, simply told that "you should have received it."



Promotions are just lateral moves.  Want you to assist their customers on the phone, but if they talk to much it ruins your metrics and you get yelled at for it.  Nothing is done to problem customers.  You will spend an hour on the phone calling the Risk group about a blocked account for someone who a negative balance with the company.  Of course you can't hang up on them either.  Don't let them lie to you about how you're a "financial professional."  Very little finance, everything about appeasing their horrible client base.



"Promotions" are almost constantly handed to the most unqualified applicants.  It isn't what you know or how well you perform within your role, its all about how big of a shill you can be for the company.  



When applying for a new position, every female candidate will be promoted regardless.  This trend can be seen throughout the whole company.  Women make up maybe 10% of Personal Investing but when it comes to manager roles its around 70/30 Female to Male.  



If you're looking to get sponsored for your 7/63, work here for the 2 months it takes to get them and then leave like everyone else.  Turnover rate is rampant.  Pay is garbage and no one is looking out for you.  Wait for the near future for more layoffs.  Vanguard is taking all of Anonymous's clients and no one is safe from the chopping block.

Con: Salary is the worst especially given the number of competitors in close proximity. No raises this year and many positions being cut. A fellow employee was literally let go due to persistently low customer surveys which you have to get a perfect score. Anything else counts as an F. If you get a good score you're still screwed. This employee had his CFP and masters paid for by the company. What an asinine  policy to spend all that money on someone and then walk them out.

Pro:

Free, AC transport which will cut down lot of travel time and risk to your life

Freedom to change our teams internally, manager won't be having any power to stop by it. This makes manager to be in top of his game. 
Very humble President in India. 
Matured captive unit in India, which gets lot of ownership in india
Employees have the freedom to use their leave quota provided it is planned. 
Good learning environment, company invests a lot in learning materials. They want to keep employees very relevant in the market.
Con:
Common judgement process for employees is a pain. You need to be Rockstar to climb the ladder. 
Culture of meeting too often, no proper focus while working on complex code 
Mid level management is bit incompetent and arrogant 
Sometimes goals are written in blood. They aren't flexible. Innovation is must no matter complexity of your project. 
People are insecure because of this. They try to take credit for others work. It's about survival among fittest.

Pro: Open 24/7 so that gives you a lot of flexibility.  Great benefits! 6 weeks fully paid parental leave for males and 16 week I believe for women who had a baby.  Tons of overtime opportunities in tax season.  Low stress, pay is great for entry level.  401k match and profit sharing totals to 17% a year (profit sharing 10% and 401k match 7%) managers want you to do well, flexible breaks and lunches, flexible with school schedules and family schedules, Anonymous all in all is a great place to work!
Con: It's a call center, at least you get paid well.  Sometimes you feel like a operator transferring calls. Bonus is effected by how your team does as a whole.  They make a lot of changes throughout the year and you need to be on your toes to keep up with all of it.  Colleagues can drag you down by being negative about their job.  Customer experience surveys are a very big factor in eligibility for larger bonuses and annual raises.  You can take thousands of calls but 30 surveys can make or break your eligibility for a raise. Some other small things, but this position is a call center position it's not always easy but definitely a good starting job to get you comfortable with the lingo and customer facing position.

Pro: Amazing opportunities for incompetent people.
Con: Only incompetent people get promoted. Managers and upper management are extremely insecure and have no idea what they are doing. Constant lies are feed to the employees on a daily basis. The good performers are stuck in their roles and do not get promoted so that the manager can benefit from their stats. Terrible employees always get promoted so that the manager does not have to deal with them anymore. If you are a woman here you will immediately get promoted and preferential treatment. Lots of stress here and terrible work environment. Management and upper management in this company are the most conniving narcissistic people you will ever meet.

Pro:
Best reasons to stay in Anonymous .

1.Lot of good opportunity to ppl who are well skilled.

2.Lot of extra benefits to user like few are Work from home option,food coupons,free cabs.

3.Few other reason to choose Anonymous as ur job is due it's Branding .One of most successful history of this company has to say all.And importantly u have lot of senior forks working here who can help u understand lot of stuff related to this company.

Pro: Unmatchable benefits. Good training ground for career following Anonymous.
Con: Financial Consultant Turnover in Atlanta is staggering from 2015 until current. Management seems to just not get it, and is not willing to listen to employees that voice concerns (which has been done continuously over this time period). Expect micromanagement and inept leadership.

Pro: Not a lot of pros here but the hours weren't bad I guess...
Con: This is a call center environment.  Pay is minimal and management has poor communication over all.  Actually that's not true, they have NO communication over all.  You are always being monitored.  What I mean by this is that all the calls are listened to and graded, if you stop calls to go to the bathroom, it counts against you.  If you don't take your break/lunch EXACTLY at the specified time, it counts against you.  If you're stuck on a long call and you go past your break time, you're SOL.  And it counts against you.   The computers are so old and constantly freeze and crash on you, which gets increasingly frustrating everyday.  You would think for a multi-million dollar company they could provide their minions with some semi-functional equipment in order to do their jobs efficiently.  But I guess not.  Anonymous also boasts about all the opportunities they have for their employees to branch out to, and frankly the opportunities are few and far between.  They sell you the dream.  And even if you are lucky enough to get a different position, you'll still be on the phone all day taking ~60+ calls per day.  The job descriptions are very vague as to what you'll be doing.  And the little information that is conveyed is very deceitful.   No where was it ever made clear that this is a call center.  Had I known this, I wouldn't even have applied.  I did not go to college to work in a call center.  PLEASE do not apply here!!  Run far and fast!  If you really want to work at a call center, find a different one.  Do your future self a favor and DO NOT WORK HERE!  You WILL regret it.  You'll be thinking about this review while you are sitting at your desk and be thinking "why, why didn't I listen to this person!"  This job was such a joke and a stain on my resume.

Summary: "Used to be a great place to work...."
Pro: Anonymous's benefits package is amazing, I don't know of a company that has better benefits.  Every group I have worked in has an array of diverse, intelligent and super friendly people.  I have made life long friends throughout my years at Anonymous. For a newly graduated college student, Anonymous is a great place to get your feet wet, to learn (their training programs are topnotch) and for an entry level position, the pay is very competitive.
Con: I have been with Anonymous almost 12 years and made my way through a few different departments along the way.  For the first few years, there really seemed to be a Anonymous culture, we were all proud to be working at such a great company with such integrity. But as the years wore on and I sat in a role where I felt doomed to stay because moving up beyond my current position at the time was not an easy feat, I did finally land that "destination role" position, the one I thought I would be with until I retired. Fast forward to today, currently two year in the "salaried" position and miserable. I am doing the work of three people because they won't back fill our department, we work some times 80 or more hours a week just to stay on top of what is put in front of us. The promised "big" raises, we were told was nixed from above. The morale is horrible. I have been sick more than I care to mention from the stress. I entered this role knowing very little about the position and there wasn't any training, I was handed 130 clients to start with and told, you'll figure it out. My laptop has never worked properly, mail doesn't go out or come in all the time, to name one of the many issues, no one knows how to fix it, nor will they replace it.  I never thought I would say this about Anonymous, but I do feel like a number. I have talked to many of my co-workers in other groups who are feeling the same way, so it's not just the group I am in. Right now, until I can find (or have time to find) another job, it's just a paycheck, not a career.

The longer you work here, the less you'll like it.  They micromanage you on everything, literally.  How many meetings, referrals, toa's, managed money, annuities, flows, mutual fund sales, how you say hello and goodbye to a customer. Non-stop meetings with "coaches", who are either people who never really did sales or did it for a few years here and ran for the hills to get out of the branches.  Some branch managers require a debrief with their consultants after every meeting.

The elephant in the room is that they have good products but we are constantly forced to push PAS which is their worst product.  

It's cookie cutter, they want every client to have a managed account and an annuity.  You definitely can't think for yourself, or help clients in unique ways- everything is run through a computer template. 

There is way too much garbage meetings to do any real planning for people.

Pro:
The benefits are still excellent, despite having been cut back over the years. 



 Anonymous has tremendous resources and a strong presence in the financial services space, which will give anyone working at the company phenomenal exposure to the industry and an excellent opportunity to learn about virtually any aspect of the business from capital markets to 401ks, from mutual funds to institutionally manged funds, from insurance to retail advice.
Con:
Long ago, Anonymous became less of an innovator and more of a follower.  It has been late-to-the market in a number of areas such as online trading, ETFs, passively managed funds, separately managed accounts and a slew of other financial innovations over the past several years.  



The financial services industry is in a state of change.  Passively managed money has eclipsed active management.  Automation is taking the place of highly-paid financial advisors and portfolio managers.  And fees for all aspects of the delivery of financial services are declining.  As a high-margin, slow-to-innovate company, Anonymous is at risk.

Pro: Overall, I was extremely happy with my experience with Anonymous. I chose to move firms due to issues I had with my site and my role, not with Anonymous as a whole. The people are friendly (for the most part) and I had a great relationship with my manager.
Con:
The HNW role could be extremely frustrating at times, to say the least. We were fully licensed brokers, but the majority of my time was spent doing password resets and distributions - I'm not sure why the firm would pay our licensing fees only to have us perform repetitive tasks any (unlicensed) customer service rep can do. Dealing with the general public is trying - people will call in and scream/curse at you over something you had no control over. To be fair, most conversations weren't negative but the really bad calls could ruin your entire day.

Pro: The benefits are definitely pros. 401k matching up to 7%, tuition reimbursement and medical are all noteworthy benefits.
Con: Your pay will be low unless your are in sales. Service used to get paid well if you worked your way to the top, however, Anonymous recently restructured variable compensation and top performing reps are taking up to a $10,000 pay cut. While they cut your pay they are asking you to do twice the work by consolidating roles and drastically increasing calls per hour expectations. Expect to  handle complex problem resolution on matters like alternative investments, international wires, or incorrect cost basis research all while taking 7 calls per hour.  You will get paid around $50,000  for practically handling every aspect of service for all clients and financial consultants who very likely know less than you but get paid over twice as much. In summary the pay is low, the goals are practically (now) unattainable, job security is not the best.

Summary: "A big company with big company pluses and minuses"
Pro: I worked for Anonymous in two stints lasting a total of 12+ years on the IT operations side.  On the whole I was treated very well, but it was about what I put into it.  I felt that I worked hard and was rewarded (promotion and $ wise) appropriately.   As with any big company, your success is very dependent on your supervisor and how they choose to treat their staff.  But I always felt that if you worked hard and performed well, you got what you deserved.  Benefits are very good and I felt I more than compensated fairly for my work.
Con: Anonymous by nature is risk averse because of its reputation and that is also it's biggest issue when it comes to innovation.  Anonymous, for all it's lip service as a leading edge company, is behind the curve on technology and is working to make strides in cloud services and robo investing services to keep up with more innovative companies attempting to steal the millennial generation market.  In addition, there is no real accountability within technology operations (including the need to really measure performance against budget) so there is a lot of stagnation among long-time employees and in  management.  Anonymous moves very slowly on re-orgs and layoffs after telegraphing changes are coming, leaving employees in limbo for long periods and impacting productivity.

FPCMS in WLK has gone through several leaders. The decisions made at times seem to contradict the firms values. The current leaders have their select few chosen ones, who can do no wrong. However, it is apparent that they have their own form of nepotism. They will force out people who may block their people from getting promo'ed. This has happened time and time again. Pro: The 401k in the USA is pretty good. You should get a return above 6% of thereabouts. No reason you won't have over $100k in your 401k account after 5 years. This is the only pro to working at this company.
Con:
If you're looking for a technology position, I would go to a technology company. Anonymous is a financial services company first, and as a result they have some questionable practices. They have their own version of agile which just doesn't work. Be prepared for hour long stand ups in the morning, project managers that are not technical and fail to keep track of meeting minutes.



From a salary perspective Anonymous is way behind technology companies. I left a senior position in Anonymous, and joined a junior position in a technology company. My salary went from $74,800 to $120,000. 



Once you get to senior in Anonymous, the path to principal, manager, director and above is almost non-existant these days. Your promotion path is not based on job performance, it is based on putting the time in with the group you're with. This much was admitted to me in my review meetings. If you join as a senior or get promoted to senior and want to be promoted to principal be prepared to put in more than 5 years before even being considered for it, and chances are the company will use a down turn in the economy as a reason for not giving you the promotion you deserve.



If you're near retirement you'll be fired so the company can save money by not giving you a full retirement package. I know a lot of people that this happened to in 2008, and again recently. 



The company keeps changing direction. When I joined in 2007 teams were organized by function - developers, testers, etc. Recently they re-organized by product. You can be sure in another 6 - 8 years they'll go back to being organized by function after an independent consultant comes in and makes the case for it.



Every 8 years the company sheds around 10 - 25% of their staff - most of them are the people it pays the most.

Pro: They generally provide great benefits and a good work life balance.
Con: Must be willing to work in Smithfield RI.

Pro: Great benefits and office locations and designs.
Con: Not really in touch with input.  They have programs designed to get outside the box thinking for ideas, but quickly then tell you the guidelines/parameters on how you are allowed to think outside the box.  Sort of dismisses the whole point.

Pro: Anonymous invests lots of training, resources and time for new employees. Not everyone makes it in the first 8-10 weeks of training and they either quit because they find out that the job is not for them or they fail the Series 7/63 tests. It's a great feeling of accomplishment after you get through the initial training program and pass the financial licensing exams and you feel like you belong to a strong reputable company. From there you can move on to other departments like sales, stock and options trading, 401K investment guidance, pensions, operations, management, training and education, support desk help, compliance, etc depending on your interests. Everyone that I worked with in management was very supportive of my goals in wanting to move up in the company or try different areas of the business. As long as you have a plan and show interest in another position, they help you secure the position by working with the managers of the group or department that you are interested in. The 401K/health/reimbursement benefits are the added incentives to staying with Anonymous long term and the 401K matching/profit sharing is the best in the financial services industry, maybe even most of corporate America.
Con: The downsides to Anonymous is that you are working in a call center and sometimes day to day activity can become boring, mundane and very repetitive. Some managers are known to micromanage when you can take breaks including how often and they monitor operational metrics very closely (number of calls taken, average handle time and how much time after every phone call). They are very persistent about coaching on what is the best language to approach each customer, sometimes to a point of emphasizing perfection. If you are there for 5 yrs or more, base salary becomes stagnant and it becomes more challenging to apply for positions and roles that offer more compensation potential because the people in those positions have been there for 10 years or more.

Pro: Great benefits. Smart people doing great things.
Con: HR pigeon holes people. Hard to advance. Bias toward younger employees.

Pro: Great benefits, flexibility with schedule when you have senority.
Con: It used to be a great place but has been downhill with upper management constantly finding ways to pay you less and expect you to do more. Morale is low so they implement small fixes that they always renig on and avoid the bigger issues. This year they increased metrics dramatically while cutting bonuses avoiding mid year raises and asking us to take over other departments work. The longer you work there the less you will make.

Monotonous phone call after phone call. This is a CALL CENTER but you'll never hear it referred to that way. No opportunities for growth within the company and whatever job there is, it will be taking inbound phone calls for customer service as well. Shift assignment is "random" and you could be like me and get stuck working 

2-11pm for the first 6 months when you were told it would be a 9-6 during the interview process. Even now I'm still not on a day shift. Very little time not taking phone calls and it can be 8 hours of back to back customer service calls during busy season.

Con: Director level and up are extremely disconnected, and give only lip service to the associate experience. Innovation and going above and beyond are not rewarded in bonuses.

Summary: "Conformity Culture.  Innovators and Fast Movers Stay Away."
Pro: The firm's client service delivery is second to none.  Abby and her team have recognized that the culture is slow and have attempted to make changes over the years.
Con:
Legacy leaders point to minor wins as progress.  Small thinking and high school culture wins, and friends are rewarded.   Medium bets are avoided for less risky career steadying choices.  



The Voluntary Buyout program targeted legacy leaders over 55, while giving opportunities to legacy leaders...over 50?  A clear message was sent.  What sense is there waiting for higher positions at Anonymous if you are in the first half of your career.



The same leaders drive the same mediocre results, and continually keep positions in the firm.  Repeated service model and strategy changes cannot change the mediocre managers leading each team. 



Leaders in the business with finance backgrounds do not bridge the gap to "innovation" in products, they can measure but are not creators.  Always concerned that if the market tanked, I wouldn't be able to sell products at Anonymous's prices with the cost structure so heavy.

Summary: "Historically strong company, high pay, but in a downward spiral"
Pro: Anonymous has always paid (overpaid?) its employees, and has been evolving its benefits package to stay competitive. It is a good place for an inexperienced to cut their teeth and learn some tangible skills in a large corporate environment.
Con:
For the last 18 months the entire retail business has been in turmoil with one new "operating model" after another. What this actually amounts to is an impossible tapestry of control and as a result there is no meaningful work getting done as everyone thinks someone else is in charge of making decisions, or worse yet - groups go off to build something in a silo. 



Interestingly, there has been several waves of layoffs during this time, so it is hard to know if this organizational dysfunction is just incompetence by top management, or if it serves a larger objective to pare down the staff. Anonymous is under unbelievable pricing pressure and with flows leaving managed products and share of wallet favoring competitors like Vanguard, the Anonymous workforce will need to be drastically smaller in the coming years.

Summary: "How is it to work at Anonymous, Gurgaon location !"
Pro:
So, to start with, Anonymous has a great working culture.  There is a lot of inter team and intra team interaction within the organization. I was working in the operations department and it was fun to work there. 



Firstly, you become eligible for a promotion / IJP after spending 18 months in the current role. Good thing is a lot of IJPs (Internal Job Process) keep coming out. So you can plan to switch your role.

Secondly, there are a lot of fun activities, events and stuff that keep taking place

Thirdly, cab facility and complementary dinner and lunch facility available.
Con:
There are a few disadvantages as well.



1) At times, the promotion process is really slow and delayed. This may result in decreased motivation and frustration.

2) You can't expect a great appraisal. It is mostly 10-12%

Summary: "Financial Representative - an exciting career talking to angry customers on the phone."
Pro: The pay is decent, the benefits are good, after 6 months you are eligible to begin having your student loans reimbursed. Anonymous puts a substantial amount of effort into training you to pass the series 7 and series 63 tests.
Con:
Beyond training you to pass the series 7 and series 63, Anonymous doesn’t really train you for the job you will be performing. 

Most, if not all jobs, are customer facing phone center jobs. Half your time will be spent dealing with angry customers. Most of the time they were told the wrong way to transfer money, or otherwise service their account, by a poorly trained rep. Other times, a form will be rejected and instead of Anonymous sending an email or making a call, a poorly worded letter will be sent advising the customer to call the general service line instead of the back office group that can actually help with the problem. 

Prepare to be micromanaged. In an eight hour shift, you will get one paid 30 minute break and one unpaid 30 minute lunch. Other than that, you are expected to be on the phone. You will receive “coaching” from your manager if you spend too much time writing notes on an account, if you don’t enroll enough people in the voice recognition system, if you call the help desk too much because you don’t know how to help the customer, if your calls are longer than ten minutes, if you don’t take at least 6.5 calls in an hour, or if you don’t get enough new business leads. Also, your job performance will be judged based on what customers think of you. Customer surveys must be “top box” for them to count toward your bonus.  If you help a customer who was given bad information by a previous rep, even if you resolve the issue, if they’re still unhappy with the overall service Anonymous gave them (which they usually are), you get a poor evaluation. That poor evaluation is then used to assess how much of a bonus you get.

After passing the series 7 and 63 you get a retention bonus. Meaning, if you work at Anonymous for less than a year after receiving the bonus, you have to pay it back. This was put into place because of the huge amount of turnover that takes place once reps are done with the training and start the actual job.

Additionally, you will be taught how to avoid giving anything that resembles investment advice by directing customers back to the website for almost everything.

Summary: "Leaving Anonymous was the dumbest thing I ever did"
Pro: Anonymous Investments’s is one class act. Great culture. An undying commitment to doing what is best for their clients, their associates and the community where they do business. I spent nearly eleven years at Anonymous and those years were the highlight of my professional life. I feel proud to say I’m an alumni and still consider the company as ‘my company’. I left on June 30 as part of an ‘early retirement’ offer that was to good to pass up. Four months later, I’m seriously regretting ever leaving.
Con: Very few. Maybe the only thing that I could complain about is the company has an irritating habit of ‘reinventing the wheel’ every five minutes. Blink twice and something has changed.

Con:
DO NOT EVER APPLY HERE. They could not care less about you as a person. They revoked my offer Today, a Friday and I was supposed to start on Monday. This is right before the Holidays and they knew about my current situation that a family member has CANCER. Not just a sickness, CANCER that I am paying OUT OF POCKET FOR. When they ran a credit report they found something that I didn't even know about, total around $4000. DID NOT KNOW IT WAS THERE. This happened on Wednesday. So I call the collections agency at their request, settle it, give them the information that things have been taken care of and they tell me today that my offer was still revoked. THEY DON'T CARE ABOUT YOU. They will screw you over, spit on you, and laugh about it. SERIOUSLY. The Recruiter did not care one cent. Now I'm completely screwed, no job, cancer, and bills. Oh, yeah! Happy Holidays! 

P.S. I have several friends who use them for their accounts and they will be closing them because of what they've done in this situation. And I will make sure this is all over my social media. This is REAL LIFE. I was COMPLETELY SCREWED OVER.

Summary: "Better than most but could still use improvement"
Pro:
- the ability to work from home occasionally (I believe this relates only to specialized groups.  Those starting out would likely not have this option.)

- excellent health benefits and 401k (on site gym, walking stations, on site doctor, reimbursement on health insurance if you follow a fit program, etc)

- decent bonuses

- some flexibility.  I say some because I have noticed that parents can be given a hard time if they ask to work from home too often or have issues come up.  This would also depend on how "favored" you are with your manager.  See "cons" for explanation.

- awesome coworkers

- longevity of the employees.  This is both a good and bad thing.  It is good because it gives a strong sense of loyalty to the company and knowledge stays within the firm.  It is bad because people assume they are "entitled" to pay raises or promotions simply because they did a job for a period of time.  (Not necessarily that they did it well.)  They are very disillusioned to how the real world works in regards to higher pay or promotions and that can become frustrating.

- the culture.  I do enjoy the culture as a whole at Anonymous.
Con:
- no mobility especially if you are already in a specialized area.  They talk about moving people up or across all the time, but in reality, it doesn't happen.  

- favoritism.  (Yes, it exists everywhere and that includes Anonymous.)  What's hard to stomach is knowing the person getting preferential treatment is a horrible worker while those who do a great job can be given a hard time.

- abuse of overtime.  It's hard to believe that management wouldn't be aware but it seems to be a common issue that is not addressed.  Those working needless hours would get a higher payout on bonuses as well based on hours worked per year.  Essentially they are being rewarded twice for "stealing" from the company.

- the bonus payout really stems from management's opinion of you.  Even being a high performer on the team does not guarantee a fair rate.  In all truth, it's impossible to understand how they derive at their numbers.

- my managers have either been disengaged or came from departments where they had little to no working knowledge for our group.  It's very hard working for someone that lacks basic knowledge of what your work entails.

- they advertise a lot about woman empowerment, but I haven't witnessed it in my group.  I would venture to say it might be the exact opposite.  If you are talented, you are more likely to be seen as a threat and this will be reflected in how you are treated and the type of compensation you receive.

- the "fit" meal program is kind of a joke.  When I started with the company, I thought it was a fantastic idea, but "fit", as far as my coworkers and I can tell, is based solely on sodium intake.  If you buy anything non-fit, be prepared to spend a small fortune for a little portion and average/below average taste.  Items like curry can be unfit.  I don't get that at all...

Summary: "Not for strong performers looking for a long-term stay"
Pro:
There are two details worth noting before beginning my review.  First, every organization within Anonymous is siloed from the rest and even within an organization different departments can be run in a very different manner.  As such the experience can be wildly different depending on where you land.  Glassdoor will not let me post the name of my particular organization so all I can say is that we focused on workplace investing and I was a QA in the tech department.  My review is based on my placement.  Second, different levels within tech are ranked based on letter designations.  A TA is an entry-level engineer, TB is an engineer, and TC is a senior engineer.  TD is either a principal/lead engineer or a manager and every letter higher is a leadership position. 



1) Benefits and Initial Compensation

For those hired outside the company, the initial salary will typically fall around the market average plus any position at a TB level or above qualifies for a bonus.  The benefits are also very competitive.  The retirement package is practically unbeatable with a 7% match and 10% profit sharing contribution each year.  Health insurance rates were constantly creeping higher but were still reasonable and coverage was strong.  PTO was very generous for salaried employees.  There literally aren't enough desks for the employees so most people are allowed to work from home at least a few days a week.  There are also a handful of minor perks that you can enjoy like a small reimbursement for the purchase of fitness equipment or extra payments made towards existing student loans, up to $2000 a year for five years.



2) Campus

The main Durham campus has been extensively renovated over the years and for the most part is very nice.  Every floor follows the open-office concept which makes for a loud and exposed experience at a desk and the conference rooms have glass walls so privacy for meetings is sorely lacking.  Also, the stairways and back hallways have not been renovated and tend to smell like mouse traps thanks to a constant rodent problem.  However, the main spaces are well-lit and nicely decorated, desks are generally well-equipped, the front entrance makes a good first impression, parking is plentiful, the outdoor walking paths allow a chance for some fresh air, and there are certain on-site amenities that employees can use like a health clinic, tech support bar, cafeteria, and small gym.  Bear in mind that the latter two are not particularly cheap or well-equipped and are more for convenience than a cost-saving measure for employees.



3) The Employees

In the years that I worked here I met some wonderful people at the TA-TC level and a few at the TD level.  Even though I have left the company I still make an effort to stay in touch with these individuals and am glad to call them friends.
Con:
1) Long-Term Compensation

While the initial package can be competitive the generosity will deplete very rapidly over time.  Even in a good year strong performers were lucky to get a yearly raise over 2-2.5%.  Raises for promotions, at least from TB to a principal/lead level, were an embarrassing 5% plus the potential for an extra 5% to the bonus.  HR and leadership would constantly try to use bonuses as an excuse for low salaries by claiming that it could help hard workers make up for the difference in their declining salaries but due to fine print the bonuses rarely met the advertised amounts.  For example, a TB qualifies for "up to" a 15% bonus.  However, bonuses are paid from a special budget that typically gets funded 80-90% in a good year.  Bonuses are also based on performance and even a strong performer would typically get 80-90% approved while an average performer could get 50% or less.  This math means that even during a particularly strong year for the company  a top performer is likely to see their 15% bonus come in at around 8-10%.  In spite of all the articles Anonymous posts about how to convince one's boss to increase one's wages there is zero room for compromise here.  The typical excuse from management is that if they adjusted someone's salary it would only make that person happy for a few years before that person would fall behind the market and complain again so management is better off leaving people where they're at.  Meanwhile salaries are regularly adjusted for Leap hires leading to TAs and TBs making more than many TCs and TDs.  To put the compensation gap into further perspective, many top performers were making more than 20% under market value after 2-4 years at Anonymous.



2) Low Technical Innovation

Technology here tends to lag behind true tech companies by 5-10 years and most of the higher level staff don't keep up with the times which means that even when new tech is pushed it is usually done without proper planning or understanding.  QA has yet to adopt an effective strategy for automation, they are still primarily using expensive licensed products instead of moving towards open-source, and the majority of the QA staff has little to no practical experience with automation or development.  Dev only cares about pushing out as much new stuff as possible with no regard for design or long-term quality as shown by the complete lack of unit tests or acceptance criteria.  Focus areas that would seem to be up-to-date fall short.  The mobile apps for example have consistently scored ratings that are average at best and are prone to performance issues, bad design choices, and bugs.  Most of the projects claim to be agile but every single agile project that I worked on was just a waterfall project with agile terminology mixed in.  It was common to see 6-12+ month projects that claimed to be agile even though every proposed feature was committed to by management on day one with no input from the team.  Even with hot technologies like blockchain and cryptocurrencies Anonymous pretends to be paying close attention while remaining willfully blind behind the scenes.  This lack of innovation and understanding can have an impact on engineers besides making the projects boring or frustrating.  If you aren't making a personal effort on your own time to keep your skills sharp and instead rely on your job to provide this exposure then you will quickly find yourself falling far behind the market.



3) Leap

Leap is a program used to recruit college graduates.  Every single year hundreds of new, largely inexperienced TAs from across the nation are hired and put through one of the various tracks, software development for example, for six months in the Leap program before being placed in an organization.  The first two months are classroom training and the latter four are spent on a project.  Unfortunately Leap's training does nothing to prepare these associates for their career.  The classes are too generic and broad and instead of using in-house staff to help provide mentoring the Leap management hires external contractors with no experience in the company and sometimes little experience in the field.  Even in the rare cases that internal management or company representatives did lead a particular class session their talk was focused more on random Anonymous information like the makeup of the executive team or pictures of the various campuses instead of useful material for the particular track.  The projects meanwhile are throwaways that rarely serve any purpose beyond keeping the Leap participants busy.  The problems don't end with Leap graduation either.  Hundreds of TAs are being brought in yearly but the company will rarely need hundreds of new TBs or TCs each year and TD roles are incredibly rare so the result is that many engineers find little room to grow once they are placed in their organization.  The company refuses to release official numbers but the general consensus is that turnover among Leap grads within their first two years of placement is abysmal.



4) Politics

The only way you could find a more political workplace is if you went to work for Congress.  A strong performer would generally still get raises and could potentially work their way up to a TC level but for the most part recognition and job security were more about cozying up to leadership than going above and beyond in your job.  Talented engineers were constantly leaving because they were being passed over for promotions or opportunities in favor of poor talent that played into the politics.  The best example of politics would be the yearly review process.  Like most companies Anonymous forces employees to fill out a self-evaluation each year then go through an end-of-year review with their manager.  However, unlike most companies Anonymous uses a process called common judgement.  Months before employees can even fill out the evaluations all of the leadership, managers and above, go off for a few days to collectively decide the rankings and rewards for everyone.  As you can imagine this turns into more of a popularity contest.  If employee A did great work while employee B was average at best but B kissed the feet of more people in the room then B was likely to get a better review than A.  Ratings are also based on ridiculous factors like the time you've spent in your current position or whether the final results resembled a bell curve distribution.  Someone may be a strong performer but if the bell curve is skewing left or they haven't been in the role as long as others, even lower performers, they'll likely get an average rating.  It also means that the entire process of filling out self-evaluations is a farce.



5) Career Growth

Many of the employees at a TD level or above are lifers regardless of any value they may or may not add in their role.  Between this, politics, and the massive influx of TAs from Leap there is a bottleneck around the TC level.  Most associate engineers can get promoted to a TB level eventually but to get to a TC level is a mix of a waiting game and politics and to move above that is a matter of even more politics plus being lucky enough to be in the right place at the right time.  Discussions with one'smanager on how to move up are met with excuses on top of excuses.  The most common claim is that an associate has to be performing at a given level for a certain undisclosed amount of time before being moved to said level which equates to strong employees doing work well above their pay grade without any reward for their efforts apart from an empty promise that if they keep it up eventually they may get promoted.  



6) Morale

While Anonymous likes to keep their inner workings private the fact is that they've been systematically laying off thousands of employees over the past two years.  One event back in the summer of last year in which hundreds of people were let go just a month after thousands of other employees voluntarily left managed to leak out to the media and made the news.  In another recent round 100% of leadership in a personal investments organization was forced to reapply for their jobs, 75% were kicked out, and the remaining 25% that got through didn't even receive a pay bump for being rehired.  The expectations for each department are not decreasing, if anything they're increasing, so those who survive a layoff are left with significantly more work to do.  Meanwhile, in spite of record profits continuing to pad the pockets of the millionaires and billionaires running the company the yearly raises and promotions for regular engineers have remained static.  Work/life balance has become a pipe dream.  If you keep your head down, only do the work assigned to you without signing up for anything else, and only perform at an average level you may manage a reasonable work/life balance but strong performers are increasingly expected to pick up any slack in their departments and do more without any reward in return.  It was common to see 1-2 engineers doing well over 75% of the work for their team while putting in nights, weekends, and holidays or vacation days.  Many strong engineers considered it a light week if they only had to do 60 hours.  Allocation was irrelevant.  You could be assigned 100% to one project but you would still expect you to take up additional project work under the table, usually under some false pretenses of being a volunteer activity in which you were forced to participate.  This was made even worse by the overload of meetings that many teams engaged in.  It was common for project members to spend 40-60% of their week in meetings, the vast majority of which added no value, but management would not consider the meetings when planning the project timeline so engineers would still have a full load of tasks to perform on top of the meetings.  Some managers engaged in morally questionable activities like cheating hourly employees out of overtime or trying to cheat former employees out of earned PTO days.  Also, a quick search online will review numerous lawsuits that have been filed against the company in recent years by current or former employees.  If you complain to HR they will either tell you that they aren't concerned with your thoughts or they'll leak information back to your manager and you'll be punished for "unrelated reasons".  Needless to say, when combined with the other issues already listed above it's no surprise that morale here was sorely lacking. 



7) Leadership

Every single issue listed here and more all point to one major problem - leadership.  To say that leadership in my organization operated like a "good old boys club" would be an understatement and their ignorance was matched only by their arrogance.  QA leadership was the worst but dev wasn't far behind.  Across the board there is a lack of even basic knowledge regarding quality assurance, software development, or general industry trends and zero attempts are made to improve.  You could count on one hand the number of TDs and above in QA who could write "Hello World" or even a decent manual test case and still have unused fingers.  Many so-called leaders would even argue that it wasn't their job to know or understand such things.  Since leadership has no idea what they are doing with regards to technology much of the work that principal/lead engineers and managers should perform, including testing strategies or resource needs, is being pushed off to junior engineers who are better equipped for the task.  However, while leadership does nothing to support these lower-level engineers leadership would still take credit for successful deliveries or, if a release went poorly,  throw the junior staff under the bus.  This brings up the issue with leadership having no idea how to handle modern engineers or how to run a modern tech department.  The general mindset is reminiscent of an 80s approach.  For example, at a departmental all-hands meeting last fall, the only such meeting all year, senior leadership in the department acknowledged the drastic turnover among TA-TC engineers but then proceeded to rant about those "darn millennials" expecting gifts just for doing their work and how these young people should be "grateful they have a job".  Never mind that these TA-TC engineers are keeping the department afloat while being ripped off in every feasible way and openly insulted.  The general attitude from TDs on up was that they were above the common rabble.  They'll steal a lower level engineer's ideas because they have none of their own but still insist that because they outrank that engineer on paper they are somehow more intelligent.  In an effort to pad the budgets and feign importance it was common to see an overabundance of leaders in project teams.  There were assignments with one lead or manager for every 1-2 engineers even as the engineers did the work the leads and managers should have been doing.  Budget for employee expenses has been reduced to practically nothing.  Those below a TD level rarely get to travel, the laptops and other hardware are painfully dated, even small recognition awards like $20 gift cards have been cut, and there are frequent cases of managers forcing their employees to attend team lunches while making each team member foot their own bill.  Meanwhile management can afford catering for their "leadership building" events, it is common to see senior leadership traveling 1-2 times a month just to check in on their teams, and many senior leaders have brand new equipment even though they are least in need of such devices.  Leadership will ask for feedback but if you do anything other than sing their praises they will complain to your that you aren't a team player or, chew you out in your next 1:1, or give you a bad performance rating.  Attempts by previous leadership from years past to at least pretend that they cared about the opinions of those beneath them, an anonymous online suggestion box or anonymous yearly surveys for example, have been shut down under the reign of the current leadership team because according to them it wasn't conductive to their goals.  The executive team makes no effort whatsoever to reach out to the TA-TC engineers and turns a blind eye to everything going on beneath them so long as the leadership teams reporting to them bows down and claims everything is fine.  The executive team also makes poor decisions without doing proper research or math on the consequences.  For example, right before the layoffs last summer many of the older staff members in the company were "offered" a buyout.  The executive team grossly underestimated the number of individuals that would take the buyout, by almost 50% according to most sources, which means that a lot of teams lost a lot of experience and talent which in turn reduced the productivity of those teams greatly.  Perhaps the best recent example of leadership here is to point to a particular team that was once a gem for technology in the company.  Under the expert guidance of an externally-hired leader the team was able to blaze the initial trail for modern day testing in the company.  A few years ago though the executive team decided to force the leader overseeing the team to a new department and bring in a longtime company veteran as a replacement.  Under the awful reign of this new individual within 18 months over 2/3 of the staff on the team had left the company, multiple HR complaints had been filed against the new leader, and the team had become a shell of it's former self.  Thanks to the "good old boys" mentality though this leader hasn't even received a slap on the wrist and they along with their other leadership buddies will openly criticize every person that left the team claiming that those who left couldn't see the big picture, didn't understand how things work at Anonymous, or were overrated and couldn't actually do their jobs.  This is in spite of the facts that the team has gone from superstar status to an unproductive, floundering mess and the department hasn't seen a major technological breakthrough in years.

Summary: "Call Center Job. Avoid if you have the choice."
Pro:
-They hire good people.  It is nice to assocaite with other representatives when there is time (which is almost never).  Almost every one of my peers had a friendly personality which went a long ways on the bad days (which was most of them).  

-Management was reasonable and let me leave the phone position to an internal operations position before I had been working there one year.
Con:
-First of all, it is a call center job.  The title makes it sound fancier and in the interview they might make you think you are going to be doing a lot more things related to investments than you actually will.  Probably 80% of calls are password resets and simple financial transactions.

-Benefits are good as a percentage, but my base salary was so much lower than what I made after I left that 7%  401k match AND 10% profit sharing was less than 4.5% 401k match at my current company.  There are a lot of benefits that most people don't use that they use to justify how great the benefits are.  Like adoption assistance, tuition reimbursement, college loan assistance.  Just do the math with what you will use and how much you'll get with your salary.  Remember that your base salary grows exponentially with raises and your benefits grow based on that.  Lower base salary now = even lower base salary in 10 years.

-They say they pay for the CFA; they don't.  They specifically told me in the interview that they pay for CFA prep classes.  It also says that in the tuition reimbursement documentation.  There is one stipulation though.  It only qualifies if you take the class from an accredited university.  I don't know of any official universities that offer specific CFA review classes (you take the review classes to prepare for the test, not to get college credit).  I had a friend who took Kaplan review classes and then fought with them for months for the reimbursement and ended up just giving up.  I took and passed two CFA tests while there without a penny going towards the classes.  I don't know if they are intentially tricking people or if nobody knows enought about the CFA to know that the stipulation the put on it makes it null.

-The job itself is miserable.  So many metrics that you have to hit, fielding literally thousands or random questions and complaints.  Constant coaching (telling you what you do wrong).  One time I got "feedback" for saying "no problem" because "problem" is a negative word.  There were days when I would get up, take a shower, get dressed and then call in and go back to sleep because I just couldn't bring myself to go back there again. Some people were ok with it though.  Most, like me, were not.

-Schedules can be bad.  I worked every Saturday after I finished training until I left.  Other people got it much better and others got it much worse.

Summary: "Great company to start in the financial services industry, and have a long term career as well."
Pro: Training, their L&D department is awesome. The trainers teach you what you need to know to start. Anonymous supports your continued growth if you want to though. Benefits are amazing! Low deductibles on Health plans and on High Deductible plans they give you money each year for your HSA. They have 10% profit sharing on your gross if you are hourly, 7% 401k match (yes 17% total, you read that right). Their fringe benefits are amazing, too many to list. Sales bonuses are based on how happy the clients are in my role and then you get extra on meeting or exceeding department goals. My boss is supportive as well as the team and if you need help with sales  language or tactics there are specialists that help you. Basically you can succeed if you want to.
Con: If you are not top of the pack you may find it hard to advance to the next role, but thats how sales works. To get to Branch offices from the phone sites is sometimes difficult, but if you are willing to relocate it can make it easier to make the transition. When you first start out you don't have as much vacation, about three weeks, but by year five you finally get to about 6 weeks.

Summary: "Truly best company to work for in financial services"
Pro: You might hear "call center"and cringe but the Anonymous regional center are absolutely amazing. I've been with the company over five years now and couldn't imagine working anywhere else. Casual dress, awesome cafeteria very low cost healthy options, the Westlake location is on a nature preserve so there are awesome walking trails to use during lunch or breaks. Lots of windows and natural light. The best benefits like 28 days PTO once you're fully vested. I'm making a great salary that in a career I feel I can stick with forever.
Con: Be ready for change with technology (which I also see as a plus). The new system you're learning will probably change again in 3-5 years. If a review for Anonymous is negative honestly they're probably in the wrong role. It can take a while to navigate to a dream position within the company (five years for me), but work hard, dress for the job you want, and you'll get there! Not a ton of work from home opportunities.

Pro: Good Training, Great co workers, good benefits, good entry to financial knowledge

Managers aren't that helpful. They will spend time trying to coach you on things that might not even matter, or might not even work. They will tell you they will look for opportunities for you, but you are on your own.



Required to stay at your role for 1 year.



Long term for vest/match to go through



Company values high metrics, regardless of how you handle your job. Good Metrics = good benefits, even if you don't do your job correctly



Lots of departments to work with. Very messy and your metrics are dependant on other people doing their job properly.



Lots of favoritism on the office.



Don't leave the position until after 1 year if you don't want to pay the bonus back.

Summary: "Like every company, there are pros and cons"
Pro: Good company to work for with great benefits.  Beautiful buildings and properties to enjoy with amenities (if you have time to use them).  People who work at Anonymous are often there for many,  many years - which speaks for itself.
Con:
Too many useless meetings that easily could be an email.  



The regularly lay off people - often without reason 



Too many "fire drills".  Sometimes it seems as if the folks liked running around like chickens with their heads cut off regarding some uber-pressing deliverable (I can imagine it makes some people feel very important) but, it often just made everyone look as if they don't have their acts together and were unorganized.  When firedrill moments are coming several times a week  then its no longer a fire drill, its a way of doing business. Which is silly.  Especially because it would glorify the concept of rushing output.  Which, in actuality, was just a breeding ground for errors, and there often were.

Summary: "Good, But Not What It Once Was"
Pro: Benefits - numerous benefits outside of the standard package. Take advantage and it will pay off later for you personally.
Con: The mantra at Anonymous is "Do more, With Less". Every year you are asked to do exactly this. The work is 24/7. When you are out of the office there are no backups and you are expected to check in on vacations. You can be very succesful here and have a great career; just know that your work is priority number 1, 2, 3. Everything else is a distant runner-up.

Pro: Free hand in your work
Con: Lot of unfit management people

Summary: "Once a great place to work, but things are changing......"
Pro: Fair pay (not exactly up to industry standards, but OK) and AMAZING benefits!  Health insurance, life insurance, many discount benefits through a number of vendors (Verizon, etc.), great short and long term disability insurance and of course a decent retirement plan.
Con: When it comes to advancement at Anonymous the mantra is, "It's not WHAT you know, but WHO".  Your skills and experience mean very little when it comes to advancement.  To get ahead you just need to be friends with the right people.  It matter more who you play golf or poker with than what your experience or expertise is.  And it's starting to show in the quality of the firm.  As is the compartmentalization of duties and leaving major decisions to each units management team with very little oversight.  This has created a few sandbox bullies who have been allowed to run roughshod over their particular departments without any ramifications.  So weigh your options carefully if you're looking at applying at Anonymous.

Summary: "All in all, a good place to be."
Pro: Anonymous puts a ton of resources into training and is absolutely all about doing the right thing for the customer.  They do a good job of attracting professional people who are willing to help.  There are plentiful development opportunities and networking opportunities in the form of employee resource groups.
Con: Politics.  They vary by business unit but they can range anywhere from a nuisance to absolutely noxious.  Yes, I understand this exists in pretty much every place, but there’s a long-standing impression that people tend to get ahead based on who, rather than what, they know.  The higher-ups also tend to play favorites and it becomes fairly obvious who those are and are not.

Pro: Used to be a value based company who cared about their employees
Con: Culture over the past several years has become toxic for IT employees. New management who don't have a clue and spend more time fighting with each other than together

Summary: "I have had a long tenure at the company and have had many opportunities as the firm has grown and changed."
Pro: My managers in the past have been flexible and reasonable. The 401k match and profit sharing are great benefits. Younger employees are taking advantage of the new College loan benefit program.
Con: Our management and employees in many departments don’t reflect our customer base. I believe this will erode our ability to connect with our customers over time. We will build solutions that will miss the mark.

Pro: Great benefits, meritocracy 95% of the time, quality working environment, willing to promote from within (I started on the phone and ended up in development).  Allowed me to be adventurous and try three careers in 11 years.  Smart and talented people.  Good support for women and many women in management. Beautiful campuses.
Con: Can get stuck in a position if your salary is too high for lateral move.  Bad managers can ruin the experience.  Mission not deeply satisfying.  Low diversity.

Pro: Anonymous has some great benefits: student loan reimbursement, good health insurance, they pay for your licenses etc.
Con:
You are on the phone ALL DAY LONG, dealing with mainly irritated old people.



Anonymous tries to make it seem like their is "a ton of career growth", but really it is just customer service phone job after customer service phone job.



They move you around to different departments to make it seem like you are being "promoted", but really it is the same old crap.



I worked in the Stock Plan Service group in SLC, and was excited to find a career path I was interested in.... Only to find out that Anonymous's generous $10k per year tuition reimbursement policy doesn't apply to you getting THE ONE CERTIFICATION THAT IS 100% applicable to your job. 



You wanna know why? Because everyone who gets it leaves for way higher paying jobs elsewhere. Of course, Anonymous will never tell you that's the real reason.



As soon as I found that out, I started shooting my resume out to competitors in the industry. I easily received multiple offers, off the phone, for way more money. I suggest you do the same!



Oh, and Anonymous does this really cool thing called "loans". Basically they promote you to a higher position, give you more work and responsibility but don't pay you any more money. How generous of them, right?

As an employee, the work feels very futile.

Summary: "Depends who you are/who you know- things change daily at Anonymous.  Depends on which manager will implement it."
Pro: Starting pay and yearly merit reviews based on performance Lots of OT.  The company match is 7%. You also get profit sharing.  Health and college reimbursements. Company discounts to many companies - just say where you work and most of the time you get a discount.
Con:
Heavy volume call center - can’t sip water between calls. Didn’t hire enough people to fill in after many took the voluntary buy out package 6/2017. 
You’re expected to know everything that has changed and is changing and not all teams are unison in the messages that is announced.  Branding - it’s huge - it’s bologna when you don’t even get a chance to get to know that person- and they don’t forget it no matter how many years have passed, what hardships you have been thru, and where you are now in work life.  Anonymous allowed for managers and interim manager to bully associates.  Managers have their clicks.  You will get wrote up for using PTO when your truly sick.... depends who your manager is!  You will get accused for something you didn’t do- bc your acting manager says you did- won’t pull the call up but purposely stops the audio to say call avoidance calls for immediate termination and I was escorted out.  I transferred the caller to another associate and I never disconnected!

Pro: good package and company diversification
Con: fast paste environment for those who are kindly laid-back attitudes

Summary: "Great place to begin your career in financial planning"
Pro: Good culture that rewards you for taking great care of clients. Anonymous contributes 17% of your salary into your 401k each year (7% match plus 10% profit sharing contribution). Health care plan is affordable and has amazing coverage (90 / 10). Great coaching and mentoring staff - you have all the other consultants in the office to learn from (many of them CFP practitioners), your branch manager who used to be a consultant, another dedicated coach to help you be a better planner, and various product experts (annuities, life insurance, LTC, managed money products, etc.). Anonymous also paid for 100% of my CFP coursework, classes, and exam.
Con: Compliance documentation can take some getting used to. Advancement has been limited to backfilling turnover right now (headcount neutral) as opposed to adding jobs. No ETA on if/when job growth will pick back up.

Summary: "They care about bottom line and appearance far more than the employees."

Con: Always laying off/firing to cut costs.  Do not value loyalty at all. The value employee health but only for the tax deduction.    I don’t feel like they care about employees.

Pro: Benefits are competitive (401K, health insurance etc.). However, salaries are below industry average.

Many team managers lack the technical skills and professional certifications that many in their teams are required to possess. This leads to a very confined way of working and thinking about processes, problems, and solutions in the department as a whole. Plus the metrics used to assess employee / team performance are outdated.... based on production type of work environments (like sales call centers, manufacturing etc), and not suitable for a company operating in the financial services industry.

Pro: Some good benefits, good people to work with.
